The author did not disappoint and I've come to relish her way of giving us touching yet often difficult reads. These are not sugar-coated tales. These are as real as they come and well worth every bit of angst.Highly recommended and a huge 5 stars!

Powerful is the word that comes to mind after reading Lead Me Not. The author takes a truly difficult subject matter in drug abuse and gives it a story. One that is not only heartbreaking but is full of hope as well.This compelling and almost tragic love story between Aubrey and Maxx held me captive. As much as I struggled through Maxx's bouts with being high and the horrific aftermath, I couldn't help but want more. Watching as Aubrey tries her hardest to get through to the talented, yet tortured Maxx was at times brutal. I wanted so much for them to make it. The deep love each has for each other proves once again that sometimes forces not welcome can overcome even the purest of emotions. Maxx's need for his little white pills gave him a freedom he couldn't get elsewhere. Yet Aubrey didn't want to give up on him. She battled her own demons and guilty memories trying to save Maxx from the dark path he traveled.I applaud the author for again tackling something as horrible as drug abuse with the dignity and compassion others often toss aside. Those who suffer deserve a second chance in my opinion, even those who continue to hurt others, like Maxx. I felt so deeply for his character and wanted Aubrey to be his light. But we are left wondering if the damage has been done and if it is too late for these two. As I venture into Follow Me Back, I'm hopeful I get a satisfying conclusion.A wonderfully written book that I highly recommend. It's not all hearts and flowers but you will find yourself compelled to devour every word. Like I said: powerful.

This is a delightful book!! Elle Riley, a successful woman, torn between two men, one from her past and one she currently works with. Both men love her. Both men want her. But does Elle know what she wants?Our heroine has worked hard to be where she is today: the creator of a wildly popular TV series based on her books. The story-line of her books is a loose translation of her turbulent love affair with one Troy Saladino. After a heartbreaking separation 10 years prior, Elle unexpectedly sees him again. Some of the old feelings are still there but that trepidation in being able to commit fully to this man, her college best friend, still haunt her.And to complicate matters of her heart even more, Elle has recently started seeing Luke Kingston, a new actor on her show. With Luke, she isn't caught up in old memories or hurt egos. It's a fresh start for her and he simply makes her feel wonderful. He sees Elle for who she is and allows her to just be herself.With two men vying for her affection, it's all Elle can do to be able to do her job! With the addition of a great bestie in Whitney and other members of the TV show, this is one complicated ride. And although I understood why she ultimately chose who she chose, I wasn't 100 percent sure that was the right choice for my tastes. Both Troy and Luke were swoonworthy in their own ways and Elle couldn't have gone wrong either way in my opinion. Each man cared for her enough that I don't think she would have made a wrong decision with either of them. However, the back and forth between them left me a bit frustrated at times, and yet I realize that perhaps it had to be that way to get the story across in the way the author intended.Overall, though, it was a joyful read that I enjoyed.4 solid stars.

Just when I thought I had Lauren Blakely and her books figured out, she goes and ups her writing to yet another level. With Sweet Sinful Nights, yes we get the naughty hero. Yes we get the out-of-control, off-the-charts, hot sex. And yes we get the touching reunion of two lovers who find themselves face-to-face after 10 years, and the heartbreaking journey to find their way back to one another. But what I didn't expect was the mystery story-line beneath the love story. And that is what made this book so flipping exquisite.Brent and Shannon. Oh my, what a couple. The way they see each other for the first time after so much time apart was perfectly written. From the look on Brent’s face to the satisfaction on Shannon’s, I was as mesmerized as they were. Their love had never really died for either of them and now that they will find themselves working together, it’s anyone’s guess whether those not-quite extinguished sparks can fan that flame once again.The pure electricity, the fiery need that both Brent and Shannon emit, literally had my e-reader smoking. Again. But this is Lauren Blakely we’re talking about. She takes no prisoners and almost has me blushing at least once while reading her books. She doesn’t hold back and the sex never disappoints. Brent and Shannon have some of THE most panty-melting scenes ever written and yet it leaves me wanting more. That my friends is the gift of a truly talented writer.But what I always enjoy most and I’ve used it as my tag-line for these books I adore, is that Lauren Blakely writes sex with heart. That although I know that these two will get down and dirty and often, underneath it all is the pure love and affection her characters feel for one another. Brent has always wanted to protect his girl and now that she is a grown-up woman, he continues to want to not only be by her side, but is willing to risk it all to stay hers. Permanently.A long ago crime that is still as mysterious as it was when it occurred manages to stay in the picture just as our couple is finding their way back to each other. With past hurts now out in the open, both Brent and Shannon fight hard to move forward even with this horrific event still hanging over Shannon’s head.Watching Brent offer not only his love but his full-fledged support no matter what the end result had me swooning yet again over a Nichols man. Oh and a guest-appearance by brother Clay had my ovaries obliterated once more. Having both side by side is one heady combination!What I leave you all is with this: if you want a sexy, passionate yet extremely touching read, then Sweet Sinful Nights is for you. I can’t recommend this book highly enough. The author’s books are like crack for me: addicting yet completely heartwarming at the same time. This is a standalone but the next book in the series will continue an aspect of Shannon’s story with her brother Ryan taking the lead this time.A huge 5+ stars!!

Finally got to reading this book, known as a complete and utter mindf**k by everyone I know! And it was and so much more.I'm honestly sitting here wondering if I should like this book or simply hate it. It evokes such strong emotion to the point where I felt completely dirty upon completion. Throughout actually. Yet the writing is so good, you can't help but want to continue.This very intriguing look into the relationship between captor and captive was executed brilliantly. Both Caleb and Lizzie are well-written characters. I didn't want to embrace Caleb but right along with Lizzie, I started to fall for the man behind the criminal. Their relationship is not one to covet yet I couldn't help but enjoy how Caleb did in fact care for Lizzie when he shouldn't. And actually felt happy when they connected.The brutality depicted in this book is not for the faint of heart. Not only the conditions Lizzie is forced to live with but the acts of violence and torture of a particular biker gang was not pleasant to experience.I will definitely continue on with book 2 and the epilogue since this story has gotten under my skin much in the same way Lizzie got beneath Caleb's.I'm glad I finally took the plunge. Well worth my time and yours. Just hold on tight...it is quite the ride!A solid 4 stars.

I was very intrigued by the premise of this book but sadly it did not meet my expectations.I completely understand the need to experiment in one's marriage. I have no issue with that. What bothered me was that Gabe and Mirella have a very happy and satisfying marriage, yet jumped into this 'arrangement' with Weston and Bridget way too quickly. Clearly there should have been more angst about what they were embarking upon. We don't get Gabe's side of the story, his times with Bridget and I think that was needed. To have each relationship juxtaposed against one another would have been enlightening.There was blatant disregard for Mirella's family for the most part and I felt that some parts were rushed. Times at home for Gabe and Mirella were few and far between and I thought this book would be more about them as a couple exploring new things, not one woman falling for her secret lover.I guess I wanted more explanation as to how each of the main characters were all feeling about this arrangement. It is truly Mirella's story in the end and I'm not sure how much more can be written with 2 more books in the pipeline. I mean she either stays with her husband or she doesn't. They all continue or they don't.I can't say I hated this book but I surely didn't love it either. It truly was just ok for me.

Piqued is one great steamy read. But even better is that this well-written novella also features two main characters that have heart.When Claire has the opportunity to redesign a room in a private club, little did she know what kind of club she would be encountering. Even more surprising is that Hall, the man who has yet to pay her for redoing his office space, is a member!Through some not-so-coincidental meetings, Hall convinces Claire to not only join him at The Club so she can see first-hand what needs to be done, but to be his special guest.Oh wow. I have to say that watching as Claire transform from the quiet designer into a woman who wants to be controlled was amazing. The author lets her heroine break free of what she thinks she should be and transforms her into the woman who now firmly knows who she can be.With Hall by her side, this sexual awakening is off the charts hot! The chemistry between the two is explosive and wildly erotic. In addition, there is a real sense of budding commitment between the two and both Claire and Hall truly care about one another.This is a wonderful read that I thoroughly enjoyed and would recommend highly!A very solid and sexy 4.5 stars!

Michelle Valentine certainly has a flair for writing extremely sexy rockers who have heart. And I am happy to report that Wicked White is no exception.This simple yet really lovely story about Ace White and Iris Easton warmed my heart. Ace is on the run, leaving behind a rock and roll life now out of control. When he finds a sleepy town in Ohio and a beautiful trailer park owner in Iris, sparks ignite and any plans to lay low and stay a loner are now obliterated. One look at the feisty Iris and Ace is hooked.Their romance is not any easy one and the author effortlessly provides just the right amount of heat combined with angst to make Ace and Iris's time together worth reading.Both characters are extremely likable and Ace is truly as swoonworthy as they come. His sexy as hell pillow talk in the form of Shakespeare quotes had me melting right along with Iris. They each have past issues that could have kept them apart but in fact it might just be what brought them together.There are some secondary characters that add that perfect touch and the overall music theme is one that I wholeheartedly enjoy.Overall this is a joyful read that I liked immensely. I look forward to more in this series.A solid 4 stars.

After reading dozens of apocalyptic stories over the past few years, I’ve come to see that the end of the world is the perfect landscape to really and truly see our humanity. When all that we typically identify with is gone and stripped away, who are we and what does that make us? It is powerful and the best stories take those questions and pose them right up front, I believe.That’s what many of the stories in the new anthology “Tails of the Apocalypse,” do and do well. We get a glimpse at a future that is often dire and dystopian, but the collected authors add a twist -- animals. Often pets, but not always, these animals show humanity in a different light as the end of the world takes its shape.Each of the stories has a genuine love and care for the animal featured -- from dogs to cats and even birds. I found myself on more than one occasion rooting for the four-legged and winged friends even above some of the humans who inhabited the pages of the book.The collection stemmed from the success of Chris Pourteau’s Walking Dead-meets-Lassie story “Unconditional” earlier this year. I’d read that story loved it then and found it to be a perfect ending to this collection. I feel I can’t complete this review without saying I’m not a dog person. I do have a dog -- a high-maintenance rat terrier named Louie -- but my heart will always be with my cats, most notably our black cat Ellie who died a few months ago. So when I read “The Poetry of Santiago,” I was truly moved by Jennifer Ellis’ touching story of a man and the cat who loved him.I truly found each story engaging and captivating, but I loved the angles the different authors took from the desert-apocalypse of “The Water Finder’s Shadow” by David Bruns to the wolf pup who tracks down the only person to ever be nice in “Protector” by Stefan Bolz and a return to his Old Man saga in Nick Cole’s “Tomorrow Found.”I look forward to re-reading this collection down the road and to rediscovering the amazing stories Pourteau and crew included in these pages. I received an advanced reader copy, but was under no compulsion to give the book a favorable review. If you enjoy stories of the apocalypse and have a soft spot for the creatures we share this planet with, this anthology is for you.

Just watch -- Ernie Luis will be a name to remember. After reading a short story of his from The Time Travel Chronicles, curated by Samuel Peralta -- The Time Travel Chronicles (The Future Chronicles) -- I was eager to delve into more scifi from Mr. Luis. Lucky for me, he just published the omnibus edition of his time travel stories, Alternate. The collection blew me away with its attention to detail and its action-packed premise. Luis has a story on his hands that will entertain any reader who is fortunate enough to pick up the book.In the beginning, we meet Grey, who is a top notch time traveling assassin working for The Watchtower. He has regrets, including the premature death of his daughter who's been gone for 10 years, and those regrets push him each day as an agent. Within the first part of the story we find out that Grey's world is not so cut and dry. There are cracks in the Watchtower's armor and Grey finds that he is part of a vast conspiracy that spans time itself. The heart of the story -- Grey and his daughter -- are balanced against the taut action scenes. I found myself on the edge of my seat as I read. In fact, once I started, I had a hard time putting the book down. Ernie Luis' writing is crisp, compelling, and forward-thinking.Well done -- I look forward to seeing what Mr. Luis has up his sleeve for the future (or the past?). I received an ARC in exchange for a review, but I thoroughly enjoyed the book and no favorable review was expected.

Regrets.We all have them. Ultimately we have to find a way to deal with our regrets and we all have our own particular methods to accept or reject what we could have done differently in our lives. To this day, I still look back on moments in my life and ask, “what if I hadn’t done that?” or “what if I had done the other thing?”When I read time travel stories, I can’t help but think that many of them also have a firm basis in the pool of regrets. The idea that we can somehow go back and alter our past, to change the part of ourselves that we find the most offensive -- the most unlike ourselves.When I read the latest of Samuel Peralta’s Future Chronicles series -- The Time Travel Chronicles -- I found myself reliving parts of my own past. In a way, this book acted as a vehicle to my own regrets and made me reevaluate my own life.Each of the stories was engaging and intriguing, but a few in particular made me really appreciate this collection.First off, the anthology starts off with a bang with the excellent Extent by Anthony Vicino. In Vicino’s creation, the past can be altered -- as long as you don’t go back any farther than 32 seconds. Those who can use time as a tool have different and varied abilities to travel through and use time. Vicino uses those various abilities to enrich his characters and make a strong story through alternating time viewpoints where we can piece together the truth by the time the climax comes.I have been a fan of Stefan Bolz for a long time, so it would be easy for me to rave about his story, but to be honest, I really appreciated his story The Traveler. When we get time travel stories, we don’t often see the work that goes into the journey through time. Our heroine has to work for her payoff and we as the audience see the pain and growth through her eyes by the time she completes (or even begins) her journey.Daniel Arthur Smith’s Diatomic Quantum Flop is a trippy dippy tumble through time. It’s a take on time travel that puts us in the shoes of someone, no one, and everyone all at the same time. In Doctor Who, time is referred to as a big ball of wibbly-wobbly...timey-wimey... stuff. Take that and a healthy dose of psychotropic drugs and you have Smith’s story. Great stuff...I think.But I would say that probably the story that really stuck with me was Eric Wecks’ Eighty-Three. Wow. The idea that time travel exists but that you inhabit your future or past self for a limited amount of time is genius. What he does with that idea is even better. Our hero, Noah, isn’t always a great guy, but by the end of the story, I was rooting for him and cheered at times. Cheered. Out loud. I was truly happy for the great things that happened and for the route the story took. I couldn’t help loving this story and the way he took the simple bits of unknown life and made them known, but unpredictable at the same time.Once again, Peralta has put together a killer collection. I love each and every Future Chronicles anthology and eagerly await the release of the new books each month or so. I was given an advanced reader copy for an honest review, but as you can tell, the review was well-earned. I found all the stories to be well-worth the early purchase price, and definitely will stand the test of time as well.

With the second installment of Daniel Arthur Smith's Tales From the Canyons of the Damned, we meet a few city workers below the surface. Those we take for granted in our everyday lives, but who we depend on for light, sewer, water, and the like. What happens in an apocalypse happens to everyone, include those we rarely consider and that's the theme of Sandhogs. We view the horror from the eyes of Jed, who can't believe the carnage transpiring in front of him.This one is a short read and that's my complaint. We would benefit more from more time in Jed's head, more detail of their situation, more story altogether. In the end, I imagine it'll fit in with all the other TFTCOTD stories as a small vignette of the horror taking place in and around New York but for me, the size is just a tad small.

The story is simple, but the telling is spot-on with Hank Garner's short story "Writer's Block." We meet Stu Remington, the author of a number of best-selling books. Stu is mired in the middle of a problem many writers can relate to: Writer's Block -- that moment when you want to write, but for some reason or another, can't get past something in your own mind. As a writer, oftentimes, finding something outside my typical writing process helps.For Stu, that help comes in the form of an antique typewriter. He uses it and then watches the next day as the story he tells with it comes true. It must be his imagination right? That's where the fun comes in when Stu tries it a second and a third time. But just like with Aladdin and his magic lamp, the supernatural effects of the typewriter can't last forever. But with that power, what does Stu do with the gift he's been given?Garner weaves a story many writers and creatives can relate to and still manages to surprise us in the end. Well done.

Oh man. Daniel Smith hooked me with his first short story in his Tales from the Canyons of the Damned series. I think there's a long way to go with the series and from what we get in part 1, I imagine Smith isn't saving the best for the last. Some great action, but a lot of questions as well.Nate is a former Army Ranger in his first corporate job at the new One World Trade Center when NYC is crippled by an EMP and a mysterious fog that seems to have enveloped the entire building. After taking stock of their situation, Nate seems to emerge as the de facto leader of his small group.But it's only when Nate and a few of his friends leave their 85th floor security that the story really starts leaping off the page. Blood, tentacles, screams, a stairwell that leads to random floors each time you take it...Smith has let his imagination go wild on this supernatural tale and I think teh adventures for Nate and his crew are just beginning.I loved it and can't wait for the second installment.

I'm a big fan of E.E. Giorgi's work. From Akaela to Immunity and all her short stories in between, I've quickly been drawn into her unique brand of fiction, showcasing her expertise in science as well as her ability to bring along strong storytelling elements for the ride.When I saw she had a new story in her Mayake universe -- The Gaijin Girl -- I was immediately on for the ride. This one is a slow burn, with an emotional gut punch you think you see coming, but it still blindsides you in the end anyway. The story starts out with a brilliant hook:"Sometimes I dream of flying. No wings, no engine. Just me in my white uniform, arms spread wide..." It ropes you in and then shows you a different side to her Mayake world that I imagine we'll be seeing a lot more of with the imminent release of her next novel.I'm buying what Giogi is selling and am glad I had the chance to read this story.

Eamon Ambrose tackles one of the more difficult narrative devices in his first foray into publishing -- Second Person perspective. I might say that the last time I read a story from second person, it was a Choose Your Own Adventure -- which was a staple in my library choices each week when I was in school.The appeal hasn't disappeared as we are given a story set in a post-apocalyptic world where you are learning the circumstances right along with your literary counterpart. What is going on? We'll see. It unfolds and unravels naturally and yet unpredictably all at the same time. I appreciated the pace of the story and the twists Eamon had for the reader as the story found its eventual conclusion. Well done -- I'm looking forward to cracking into Zero Hour 2.

I read the first part of the Silverleaf Chronicles earlier in the year as part of The Dragon Chronicles (The Dragon Chronicles (The Future Chronicles) and found it to be one of the best selections in the anthology. It was interesting and got me invested in the world Vincent Trigili had created.Then, when he started putting out the next part of the story as a serial, I was in. And what a wonderful story. I appreciated Trigili's telling of the story, seeing Silverleaf's journey as the reluctant hero of our narrative. From what I've seen so far, there is so much to draw from as Trigili hopefully continues to tell tales from his Dragon Masters universe, and that is the one drawback to this story. It's a minor complaint, but I easily could have seen this story retold with hundreds of extra pages of additional story in epic fantasy fashion. But this sure to please other fans as Vincent Trigili has pared down his dragon fantasy to the necessary components. But that complaint is, like I said, minor as Trigili still delivers with his protagonists, Silverleaf and Kaylissa. What their quest is and what is eventually turns into is a great journey that leaves the reader firmly behind Silverleaf on every step of his journey.I was given each part of the serial as an advance reader copy, but no favorable review was expected. Well done -- I look forward to more from Silverleaf and his other Dragon Masters.

This is NOT the book by Andy Weir. In spite of the email from Amazon marketing the book, this is a clear attempt to game the Amazon system. If you would like to read Weir's fantastic book, please do so, but find it on Andy's Amazon page -- HERE --> Andy Weir

I loved Nick Webb's military space thriller Constitution. As I read it, I couldn't help but wonder how Webb was going to pull it off -- I kept seeing bad things on the horizon for our protagonists yet the grit and tenacity of the crew of Constitution was able to pull it off. I could not put this book down. I had things to do, and I ended up reading this until I just could not any longer. I can't wait for the second book in the series. Well done, Mr. Webb.

Over the past year, Samuel Peralta has diligently and deliberately put together a powerhouse science fiction anthology series. He's been able to attract big name authors such as Hugh Howey, Ken Liu, Seanan McGuire, Robert J. Sawyer, Jennifer Foehner Wells, and Matthew Mather among many others. But, what makes the Future Chronicles volumes great is the platform for new and emerging talent from the trenches of indie authors. While the established authors have been the cornerstone for these collections, the indie talent Sam chooses for each book is exciting and raw.Full Disclosure: I've been privileged to be in three FC anthologies so far (Alien, Z & Immortality) and have spots reserved in at least two more scheduled to run in the next six to eight months. Other than reading and loving The Future Chronicles Special Edition anthology, I have no involvement in the collection.So if the different anthologies released in the past year were all-star teams, then The Future Chronicles is a best of the best. Some of my favorite stories from collections like The Robot Chronicles, The Telepath Chronicles, The Alien Chronicles and The A.I. Chronicles appear, inviting you to rediscover them, to read them again for the first time in the context of this new collection, outside of the confines of their genre-specific collection. For some, it seems to imbue them with new meaning. When reading A.K. Meek's The Invariable Man (later expanded to a longer book) with a brand new story on one end and stories about telepaths just pages later, it almost can be read with a new and different point of view.In The Future Chronicles, we get eleven stories previously released in those first four of the Future Chronicles collections. Each of these stories is excellent and represents those anthologies wonderfully. What is an extra treat are five brand new stories from Sam Best, Susan Kaye Quinn, Deirdre Gould, Angela Cavanaugh, and Moira Katson, as well as a Foreword penned by Hugh Howey. Each is a breath of fresh air. With the general theme, you don't quite know what to expect...will these stories be about robots, telepathy, aliens, or something else entirely. I'm thrilled to say each of these could very well serve as a foundational block for an anthology of their own.While I don't want to ruin any discovery a reader will make on their own, Sam Best really rocks the beginning of the entire collection, Quinn again provides her own brand of singularity fiction with her story, Gould presents a mind-bending tale that will leave you shaking your head, Cavanaugh could give you nightmares (or are they...) for her story The Assistant and Katson threatens to leave you with tears after reading her heartbreaking story of defiance in the face of death.What's really amazing is how each of these stories works not only in the confines of their own specific genre, but also all alone and then back in the comfort of other Future Chronicles stories that may or may not be in the same vein. Peralta has crafted a juggernaut and readers are reaping the benefits. If you get the chance, read The Future Chronicles and then explore the other titles available in the Kindle Store.

In Nomad, Matthew Mather tears things apart. Families, countries, economies, planets, galaxies…all get ripped apart between the covers of his latest novel. I read his earlier book from this year — Darknet — and found it frightening in a way that was almost difficult to describe. In Darknet, the threat is real, but invisible. In fact, the antagonist can strike and be gone again without you even knowing it, the only traces are digital breadcrumbs left in its wake.In Nomad, Mather does it again, creating an invisible villain — the titular astronomical anomaly — but the effects this go-around are more immediate, more violent, more physical. Instead of bank accounts and identities being torn asunder, it is the literal earth that undergoes an upheaval in Nomad.The story is fast-paced and energetic from the get-go, placing all of our characters in Rome. Some are there for pleasure, some for work, and others are trying to hide from the authorities. The latter is our young protagonist Jessica. We first meet her while she is on a tour of an Italian castle with her mother, but her story goes much deeper and gives her a rich and detailed backstory. In fact, as the story kept unfolding, we kept seeing new aspects of Jessica’s character that led to numerous “aha” moments. Mather wonderfully wove her story in the fabric of Nomad and gives us a great character we can live through in this book as well as others to come.What was great about Mather’s previous books was the scientific reality he’d grounded things in from the technological terror of Darknet to the scenarios he plays out in CyberStorm. The same is true for Nomad, with actual astronomical possibilities. In fact, the very anomaly he showcases in the book popped up in the news as a discovery in just the last few months. The terror of space really isn’t what we can see — it is what we can’t see, and Mather proves it with this book.Mather takes the reader on a wild ride, and all of it feels genuine and authentic. Our characters are real and we want them to be real and to make it in the face of overwhelming adversity. With all that can possibly go wrong, can humanity go on? What will an event like this bring out? The best, or the worst in us?As for the next books in the planned trilogy, Mather certainly has a plan for the second book with the path for our characters, but planted enough seeds along the way to make sure the reader knows the path will be rocky and difficult. I massively enjoyed this book and am very much looking forward to Sanctuary.

First off…I hate Nick Cole. I hate that he can write like he can. I hate that he makes me care about his deeply flawed characters. I hate him so much I can’t help but love him just a bit.I will admit when I first opened the book, I struggled with the first few pages. Found footage in book form. Ugh. It seemed like an unnecessary plot device, but after a few pages, it settles down. Yes, there is the aspect of these recordings and journals being found and pieced together, but the stories are quite broad and involved.  As a reader I found the two main stories quite distinct and after a while I forgot they were “found footage.”In that case, it does draw comparisons to the modern-day standard in zombie fiction — World War Z. Max Brooks’ classic is well known for being a series of vignettes that are only tied together by the slimmest of threads (NOT the movie, which features Brad Pitt as a very capable thread). In this case, there is a sense of that as well, but instead of it showcasing the tales of survival (or death) at the hands (and teeth) of the zombies, Cole shows us the humanity left behind in its wake. He shows the emotions, the torment, the shame, the bitterness, the economics, the brutality, the…life that is left when the plague wipes out most of the nation. What he does better than Brooks from a narrative point of view is he uses the protagonists of Alex and Jasonn (mostly Jason) to find all of those aspects of humanity in the aftermath. Jason’s journey is one made by countless characters throughout literature, starting with Odysseus. He needs to find the love of his life, but with Alex he only has the vaguest idea of where to look. Along the way we see his faults, his fears, his failures on his trek from New York to Los Angeles.There really is so much to take in along the way, Cole could have easily tripled the size of the book with the rich details he added with developed secondary characters. Shoot, Cole could write a whole other story with just the character of Chris, or The Lady, or…any number of them.But we get Jason and Alex. Star-crossed lovers, separated by thousands of miles of land and millions of infected zombies between them. Who are they? What choices do they make? How does that affect everyone else? What does that do to their very souls?I loved Nick Cole’s book. Described as “The Walking Dead” meets “The Notebook,” I can honestly say as someone who hasn’t watched either (I know, I know!) that this book delivers. If you like a healthy dose of philosophy and romance with your zombie literature, this book is for you. I really could go on and on about what I felt as I flipped each page of this book, but suffice it to say I felt all the things. I felt joy, sadness, anger, shame, courage, and fear. Cole places you at the center of the apocalypse and makes sure that you know that each character has their own apocalypse. Each person gets their own ending and even with similar circumstances, each ending is unique. I did receive an advance copy, but that in no way affected my enjoyment of the book. Read this book. You won’t regret it.

When I read Hank Garner's Seventh Son of a Seventh Son, I kept loving it, seeing Garner's growth as an author with a fantastically creative novel. The first thing I read of Garner's was Mulligan, and while it was good, there were a few pacing issues that sometimes could keep the reader distant from the action. In Seventh Son, Garner has amped up the action and keeps his characters moving with a clear motive and momentum throughout the book. Even the characters are not always who we think they are and their actions go against the grain at times, adding to the intrigue.I remember first hearing about Garner's book when it was tied to the Apocalypse Weird series, but somewhere along the way, Garner separated it from that universe. It is clear Garner's book can stand on its own, with a full realized backstory going back thousands of years to set up the action that takes place simultaneously in 1865 as well as the present day.Our main protagonist, Oliver, is the title character who is tasked with being the secret keeper for his family's legacy. The main problem is that the life he was destined for arrives when he least expects it and the secrets he protects are even a secret to him. As he tries to figure out what he is meant for, and who is actually is, the reader is taken on a great ride of ancient sacrifices, futuristic travelers, and secret organizations.I loved Seventh Son of a Seventh Son and look forward to the next book from Mr. Garner.

A return to form for Vincent Trigili in Drac'nor. I have really enjoyed the series thus far, but I mentioned in my last review for Part 4 that I felt the series was treading water a bit. Not so in this installment. Trigili takes his characters of Silverleaf and Kaylissa and advances their storylines considerably with their entrance to Drac'nor. We move forward and also learn some of the mysterious backstory for our two protagonists along the way. Now that we are this far along, I'm actually not sure how the story will wrap up in just one more story. Well done...looking forward to Book 6.

After reading Desmond Doane's "The Dark Man," I wasn't sure what to expect from "The White Night." I guess at the end of the day, I thought this book would be simply setting the stage for Book 3. I knew there will be an epic showdown between the team of Mike and Ford and Chelsea's demon. It would have been easy for Doane to put the pieces into place for that showdown and mail in the second book of the trilogy.This book was no mail-in effort. Doane outdid himself with a thrilling book that had me wishing I could put a plot together half as well as him.Just like in "The Dark Man," we are thrust into the life of Ford Atticus Ford, the lead investigator from a defunct TV ghost-hunting show. Ford is still questioning things after the events in the first book and is trying to put everything together while stationed in the beach in Oregon. Meanwhile, we see a dual story of Mike at home on the beach in the East Coast. The two former partners are about as far apart as they can be geographically, but their lives are as intertwined as ever as forces from beyond the grave are conspiring to put them together again.I nestled in, secure that Desmond Doane (aka USA Today bestseller Ernie Lindsey) would provide a smooth, comfortable, spooky story. Little did I know he would scare the pants off me, causing me to swear at the author midway through the book. Just when you think you have the plot figured out, you better check behind you and make sure no mirrors are shattering down the hall or have any doors swinging shut.As much as I loved "The Dark Man," I have to be honest: "The White Night" is a better book. The alternating perspectives from the two leads perfectly sets up whatever Doane has planned for the next book, but he did so with a punch. In my review for the first book, I noted the similarities to Dean Koontz. The comparisons are well deserved and Doane inched even closer to cementing that legacy.

Once again, I looked forward to reading the next installment in Vincent Trigili's Silverleaf series. I've loved every story thus far and this one was no exception. Silverleaf and Kaylissa are quite the team and they show it once again in this outing.If I have a complaint about this one, it does feel about like just moving the pieces from one place to the next as a connection between the first few episodes and whatever Trigili is setting up to close out his story. It was good, but a little plodding at times. I look forward to the next episode to see the pace pick up a bit and what is new for Silverleaf and friends.

For the past year and a half, I’ve fallen back in love with short stories. It was seeing the anthology From The Indie Side, edited by David Gatewood, that brought it all back. It reminded me of the collections of science fiction short stories and novellas I devoured as a teenager. I didn’t always love all the stories, but each one resonated in some way the more I read them, and I slowly learned that huge ideas can be vacuum-packed into a smaller word count.So I eagerly leapt at a chance to read the latest anthology edited by David Gatewood, Dark Beyond The Stars. Again, I can’t say I fell in love with every story, but the collection featured story after story that reached something deep inside and pulled me along until the page count finally ran out. Dark Beyond The Stars takes readers on an epic journey through space, rewarding them with tales guaranteed to entertain as well as elicit tears.I also don’t think I can address the quality of the book without mentioning a unique fact about the anthology -- each and every writer is a woman. I hope to someday live in a world where this note is unnecessary, but that day is not today. There are some out there who will refuse to read a collection that features only women writers. There are some who may cling to the out-dated belief that science fiction is a men’s game. There are those who wouldn’t even give a each of the writers a chance based on their misogynistic thinking.Those people would be wrong. These women prove that science fiction is a poorer field without them in it. Dark Beyond The Stars is a rich and full universe of stories that, I believe, benefit from a woman’s perspective and voice.Now, as I analyze the volume, I’m not going to go into detail on each and every story -- other reviews have taken care of this and readers can find those details in those reviews -- but I’ll highlight a few of the pinnacles of the book for me.First off, the choice of Susan Kaye Quinn to start the anthology with her story “Containment” is a sure-fire winner. While Quinn sets the story firmly within the universe she’s established in her latest novel “The Legacy Human,” the story stands securely on its own. As with many of the stories in the collection, the point doesn’t become what happens, but really what does it all mean? In this case, we meet an artificial intelligence who works as the manager of mining on Thebe. As the story slowly develops, we peel back layers of the onion to discover our A.I. is more than what he is allowed to be. The themes of A.I., wealth inequality, and slavery are prevalent throughout the story and make it one to remember.Another story I loved was Ann Christy’s “Lulu Ad Infinitum” and consequences of a horrific accident on a colony ship headed into space. One of the passengers, Lulu, is left alive, and is confronted with the fact that the only way to continue is with help, and the only way to get help is by cloning. As the mind wanders over decades and generations, what does the ship look like and who is Lulu after all this time?In the same themes of a colony ship, Theresa Kay’s “Protocol A235,” takes the view of disaster happening in space to the extreme. In contrast to Christy’s Lulu, however, Theresa Kay pulls a slow burn as the first-person protagonist slowly finds out what’s happened, and the life that she has in front of her. The horror of the situation seems a little more apparent to the reader, but watching it play out makes her story one of the gems of this collection.And the heartbreaker of the bunch had to be Jennifer Foehner Wells “Carindi.” Those familiar with Wells’ “Fluency” know the intricacies of the alien ships, operated by octopi-like beings, but commanded by a different species entirely. Ei’Pio is one of the former, resigned to a fate where she cannot move after a plague wiped out the population of her ship. She discovers a lifeform in the aftermath, one confined to a stasis suit who will be her companion for years. The story plays out until a decision must be made and they must leave their area of space or die. Just as I loved “Fluency,” “Carindi” adds a greater depth and history to Wells’ universe.Ultimately, David Gatewood succeeds in editing another premier anthology, but he is merely the pilot ship for an armada of warships made up of supremely talented writers. I loved Dark Beyond the Stars and hope that there is more to come from this group.

As I’ve read Hugh Howey’s Beacon 23 series, I’ve enjoyed the small vignettes on our protagonist's life. Small snippets here and there. It wasn’t until the last part that Howey expertly draws all of the threads together. That the pieces he scattered throughout Parts One through Four are coming to a head with epic and emotional consequences.Someone could do a fair amount of psychoanalysis on Hugh Howey and his stories. For instance, with his biggest stories the past few years, the characters are stuck somewhere with death seemingly all around them -- Jules with the earth and poison sky in WOOL; Vic and her family in a dystopian world covered in Sand; Ness and Maya surrounded by the ocean in the Shell COllector. Finally we get a nameless protagonist (only referred to briefly by a nickname - Digger) surrounded by the deadliest environment yet: Deep Space. But those surroundings wouldn’t be worth anything without a top notch narrative to go along with them and Howey’s got that in spades with Beacon 23.In Beacon 23, we get shades of Ender’s Game, and perhaps more notably the sequels where Ender deals with the actions he undertook in the first novel. For Digger, his actions as a Marine are coming full circle in Beacon 23: Part 5 when he and the love of his life, Claire, receive visitors. These visitors offer a solution. A way to end the war that’s been raging across the galaxy for decades, but it will take drastic action on Digger’s part.I don’t want to spoil the ending, but the actions are bold and radical. For our hero, and the author as well, the emotions that play into it are real. In fact, at the beginning of this final segment, Digger reflects back to a time with his father on Earth. This is perhaps the most poignant aspect of the entire series in those pages, and Howey nails it. The misunderstanding of tears and emotion at a young age and the realization of what missed opportunities there were. I was moved by the story and for a moment forgot our protagonist was even in space.What does it mean to be a hero? How does one define it? Throughout our history we’ve had different definitions depending on where you are from, even getting different aspects of heroism from Norse, Greek and Roman mythologies, let alone stories and values from Eastern cultures. In Beacon 23, we ask the question again with the fate of the Universe hanging in the balance. In the end, I felt Howey did the story proud and can say he has another legitimate hit on his hands.

Logan Thomas Snyder has a potential break-out hit in his Violet series, but it wasn't until I read Being Violet that I realized the possibilities. In Becoming Violet, we meet Tom and Violet and the secrets she hides in a fairly well self-contained story. In the sequel, we see Violet's past come back to haunt her and Tom in a life or death scenario. I loved this story and couldn't wait to read the next.

With Skynoise, Ernie Lindsey shows why he is one of the most compelling and dynamic indie writers out there. Earlier this year, I found "Super," which turned the superhero genre on its ear, and in "Skynoise," Lindsey takes the sci-fi trope of time travel and twists a good yarn through years of mysteries and bread crumbs.One of the greatest mysteries of history is the disappearance of the settlers at the Roanoke Colony, off the coast of modern day North Carolina, back in the 1500's. Historians to this day are uncertain as to the fate of the early colonists -- did they die off? Did they leave with a Native American tribe? Even some even farther-out conspiracy nuts have argued for extra-terrestrials. Lindsey takes the Roanoke mystery and uses it as the central historical narrative to tie the present-day to our time traveling protagonists in a timey-wimey sort of way. As a high school history teacher, I am fascinated by stories like those of Roanoke, and was thrilled when "Skynoise" started and ended with the Roanoke mystery in full swing.We quickly meet Helen, a non-fiction author whose latest book tackles the mystery at Roanoke. On her book tour, she repeatedly deals with Chip, who comes across as a conspiracy nut at first. Soon we find out there is a lot more to Chip than we initially see, which is definitely intentional on Mr. Lindsey's part -- this is definitely a story that will make you think in circles. Parts that happen at the beginning or even before the start of our tale are revealed later on; this is a book that would work well in repeated readings.The best I could compare "Skynoise" to is "Timecop" plus "Conspiracy Theory" plus maybe a little "The Italian Job." Lindsey keeps the pace up well, pausing at times to take a breath and to get our characters some important information. In the end, Skynoise is a wonderfully-told, and fun book that showcases Lindsey's storytelling skills.

Another Hugh Howey book. Another vision of the future.This time out, however, the future isn’t so bleak and isn’t a terrifying place to be. In fact, in The Shell Collector, the world he’s created has been decimated by rising sea levels, but the story is bright and hopeful, a stark contrast to the previous trips to the future we’ve taken with him.I really enjoyed The Shell Collector as a speculative fiction romance, featuring Maya Walsh as the intrepid reporter, trying to unearth the truth about Ness Wilde, the CEO of Ocean Oil. Wilde and his family are pariahs because of the earth’s condition; sea levels rose in no small part to the ways the Wildes have abused the earth’s resources over the years. But, as she gets to know Ness, she discovers that the story she is planning does not accurately paint him or his family. That there is far more behind the man.Throughout it all is a search for elusive shells, which have become collector’s items and currency in this futuristic society when shells have all become rare due to the ocean conditions.This book is vastly different than anything I’ve seen from Howey before, but there are themes that he has certainly tapped into again. A prominent one is going beneath the surface of the earth. In WOOL, the deeper the characters went, the more the sparks of rebellion grew. In Sand, the deeper the divers went, the more death and despair crept in. In both, claustrophobia was present, but the way out was usually through death.In The Shell Collector, Howey again takes our characters deep—this time to the ocean’s floor to see the creation of new life in the volcanic hearth in the depths of the Atlantic Ocean. Claustrophobia is present, but this time, our characters experience hope and healing. The shells that each of them are for different reasons, are given new life in a submarine at the bottom of the world, and they discover each other in the process. Unlike in WOOL or Sand, where the depths of the earth usually lead to death, Howey utilizes the intense pressure to create love and affection between our protagonists.Science fiction plays a role in this book, to be sure, but it is a light one. Howey has created a romance novel and a good one at that. The plot was consistently pushed along by twists and turns, but wasn’t bogged down by unnecessary points where Howey could have devolved the story to erotica levels. Howey once again shows he knows how to write, no matter the genre or convention. Well done!

With the first part of the Apocalypse Weird Saga, Nick Cole uses his story to affect and confuse the audience -- and probably on purpose.From the title heading, it's clear that Cole's entry is just the first of many into this strange apocalyptic future. Most of the book focuses on a few people who are the survivors of an apparent zombie virus. The audience is lulled into thinking this is all this is going to be -- a simple zombie tale, but then Cole changes the game right before switching narratives. Will we get back to our zombie survivors? Will the next book pick up where this one left off? Will we find answers to what the next apocalyptic event is? Who is Mr. Steele??There are many unanswered questions, but that is exactly what Mr. Cole intended, I imagine. With a bevy of other talented authors on deck, Cole is simply setting the stage for the craziness to come. I enjoyed the book and will gladly read whatever else the Apocalypse Weird crew has up their sleeves.

Once again, I find myself falling deeper and deeper into the worlds created by each of the authors in a science fiction anthology. As an editor, David Gatewood is putting together world-class collections and the quality of the book is through the roof.I won't go through each and every story, but each one deserves their place in this anthology. In contrast to previous collections, I was actually unfamiliar with most of the authors in the book. With each story, however, I felt drawn and compelled to seek out their previous work.The argument could be made that the best stories served as bookends to this fantastic book -- Peter Cawdron's "#Don'tTell" and MeiLin Miranda's "Word-Bound." Both had a tale that drew the reader in, captured and held them until an emotional and surprising conclusion.The other stories that caught my attention on the first read-through were Therin Knite's action-packed "Venus in Red," Vincent Trigili's thriller "The Null," and Autumn Kalquist's "Decode." Of course, Sam Peralta's "Trauma Room," while short, provided a great mid-point to the collection and Susan Kaye Quinn has spent enough time in her Mindjack series that writing a telepathy story is probably second-nature at this point.I really enjoyed the book and look forward to more from each of these authors.

In Revolution, Cawdron paints a picture of a world similar to our own, but with technology advanced a bit. Alexander Hopkins is getting home on a red-eye flight from Russia when that world slams into him with all the force Homeland Security can muster.The breadth of the story is short, so I’ll keep my review brief as well, but you want to catch each word in this tale as Cawdron once again showcases why he is one of the best indie writers around. The pace of the story is at first lazy and perhaps a bit deliberate – much like the landing of a 747 after a 10-hour trip. Once Alexander is on the ground, however, the action picks up and you find yourself whipped around from one place to the next in a desperate attempt to survive and figure out what is happening.While the beginning of the story starts with lethargy, the ending is sudden and abrupt, stopping too soon for my taste. I wanted more, but isn’t that the mark of a great story?

Samuel Peralta is a poet, and as such, is able to create a visual picture with few words. In Trauma Room, we see this perfectly. Just about 1,000 words long, the tale moves quickly and yet leaves the reader wanting more. In such a short span, questions are answered, but so many are left unexplored, unanswered.Well done, Mr. Peralta -- I enjoyed reading the story and look forward to more.

Who are we and what exactly makes us human? Is it our bodies, made of flesh and blood? Or is it something more? Is a soul something created by the love of two people nine months prior to birth, or is it created by the love of a parent regardless of when that love is given?Samuel Peralta asks some difficult questions in his tale Humanity and comes away with a fantastic story that leaves you wanting more.

With a title like that, it was a little difficult for me to want to read this book. Peter Cawdron has made a title that is very provocative, but if the reader can just get past it -- get to the heart of the story -- they will realize that Satan has very little to do with this tale at all.I love Peter Cawdron's work. I just adore it. I have been a huge fan of his previous books and was instantly drawn into the narrative he created in MSS. While I admit the title took me aback, it turns out the title, and the message from the stray moon of Saturn, are both a little deceiving. Deception is a key concept of this book, starting with our protagonist, Jasmine, or Jazz for short.Jazz wakes up out of stasis, but is missing 20+ years of her life. Now an astronaut headed for Saturn, all she remembers is being 19 and living outside of Atlanta. Her crewmates may or may not have secrets of their own, but the biggest secret seemingly is what is Bestla, the moon orbiting Saturn.In the process of a re-self-discovery, we are seeing the world through Jazz's eyes, crisp and clear at times, but vague and confused at others. She is smart, but the years of college and learning to be an astronaut are gaps in her memory. She doesn't know what to do all the time and turns to the only one she believes she can trust -- the ship's AI, Jason.I'll say this about Jason -- he may be the best character I've seen in a long time. I loved what Cawdron did in creating a character that feels totally real, but is not only fictional, but also doesn't have a body to call his own. The evolution of Jason was fantastic and I would love to see more of him in a future book if Mr. Cawdron ever decides to revisit his MSS Universe.Once again, the story is well told, well paced, and one I would recommend highly.

With Doorway to Arkomo, Jacqueline Dooley creates an interesting and wonderful world that instantly draws reminders to Narnia or Middle Earth. Like Narnia, there is a hidden doorway to this world from ours and in the case of Arkomo, the doorway is into a hospital where Grace is being treated for cancer.As a new parent to a chronically ill child, I have already been in the hospital more than I or my son would like. I can relate to Dooley's hospital scenes and know most of the children in hospitals like the character of Grace would trade about anything to have a world like Arkomo.I really found myself interested in the story and look forward to finishing the tale in Dooley's second book in the Arkomo series.

What a great concept and story from Logan Thomas Snyder. I picked up Becoming Violet a few weeks ago, but just got around to reading it yesterday. Boy am I sorry I waited.At first, I thought it was a typical "Bicentennial Man," Isaac Asimov robot story with a man dissatisfied with his robot. Snyder, however, took the story in a new direction, giving the reader an introspective, yet action-filled tale of love in the face of trials. What does it mean to love? Does it have to be between two humans or can it be more than that?I thought BV was a great short story and look forward to what Mr. Snyder has next for his readers.

What a fantastic start to Pennsylvania fiction outside of Michael Bunker's brain. Chris Pourteau paints a vivid picture of the ongoing war between TRACE and Transport, showing the lives of a squad of soldiers about to go to battle in Gettysburg in New Pennsylvania.Throughout my life raised in the North, I was trained to root against the Confederacy. In Pourteau's story, he clearly posits TRACE as analogous to the Confederates, but shows the humanity behind the soldiers. History paints in broad strokes, but from the story here, it struck me that the individual lives of the men (and women) fighting in the wars are not black and white.There was one scene in particular (when you read it, you'll know what I'm talking about) that had me in tears as I was trying to digest the action of the book. Well done.I loved Gettysburg and look forward to the sequel(s?) that Pourteau has up his sleeve for the QB and her group of soldiers.

Stefan Bolz has his own brand of positive fiction. You see it seeping through every pore of The Three Feathers. In his book The Fourth Sage, the characters work together to achieve a goal they never could have even dreamed about.In Dark World, I was afraid I wasn't going to get a Bolz-style of story, but the opposite is true. There is a darkness and violence to it, but in the end it just reaffirms the good Stefan Bolz believes in.What happens when the border between the worlds of angels and humans is crossed? What becomes of an angel when her only tether to herself has just been destroyed? That's the basis for Bolz's story here and he pulls it off well. Your heart breaks for Amber as she struggles in the world of men to grapple with the being she has become and her journey to salvation.The path isn't always neat and clean, but Stefan Bolz once again brings us a work worth reading.

Beautiful and haunting at the same time, Samuel Peralta paints an emotional story of love and loss within the context of a time-traveler. On first glance, you may think you've heard this story before, but Peralta does his own spin on it, giving the reader snippets of time, fragments of a life lived.They say love forged during war -- during crisis -- is the truest love of all and that's what happens with our protagonist, Cpl. Caitlyn McAdams when she meets and falls in love with an injured man during the throes of war. McAdams is fated (doomed?) to meet this man over and over throughout her life for brief periods of time. Throughout it all, the reader feels the affection...and frustration...of our two lovers who cannot have a life lived in the same timeline.I applaud Peralta's work and look forward to seeing additional stories written by him.

Once my eyes dry out, I may be able to actually read what I'm writing here, but I'll sum it up with this: in Nina Tozzi's debut, she definitely understands the heart and the emotion of the story.Janey X39 is an android, kept in a dark, dingy basement. She is allowed to come upstairs only to clean and take care of Barbara and her family. Her clothes are rags and her food is "android paste" -- a bland and colorless food that provides the nutrients she needs to survive. Throughout this story, Tozzi beautifully and tragically paints a picture where Janey begins to understand what -- or perhaps who -- she really is.I can't say I was surprised by the ending, but Tozzi does such a fantastic job of portraying heartbreak and loss that I didn't even mind not being shocked at the reveal. The point is -- Janey is shocked. In spite of everything that had happened to her and her existence as an "android," Janey shows a lot of humanity in the pages of this story.Ms. Tozzi is a welcome addition to the world of self-publishing and I hope we see more of her work in the future.

With a name like "Soda Pop Soldier," I half-expected a light-hearted romp through modern video games. What I got was something completely different. Something telling about how many of us live our lives online and the anonymity that we expect. Something visceral and violent, yet clean and sanitized at the same time. Something that fully engaged my head and heart alike.Nick Cole's Wasteland Saga led by The Old Man and the Wasteland was Cole's bleak dystopian debut. He impressed me with the deliberate and purposeful pace of that novel, but in SPS, he treats the reader to something completely different. Is the future portrayed in Cole's new novel a dystopia? I would say it is, but it resembles more of a Ready Player One-type future rather than the post-apocalyptic tone of his previous work.Unlike RPO, however, Cole infuses his world with a much darker tone. RPO always had a certain Reagan-era optimism. That everything would be OK even if Parzifal didn’t succeed. Here though, there is a certain amount of fear behind the scenes. If PerfectQuestion doesn’t get everything just right his existence is definitely in question.The gamer PerfectQuestion is a key piece in ColaCorp's ongoing war for advertising space. The winner in the online arena gets billboard space in Times Square and other key spots around the world. PerfectQuestion is good at what he does, but his squad finds itself outmatched in their latest round of battles, leading to his pay getting cut.In order to make ends meet, he takes to the back alleys and signs up for an illegal game called the Black, where twisted fantasies play out for those who want to indulge in that sort of thing. This game, however, turns into something more for PerfectQuestion and an additional quest to finish alongside his professional life in WarWorld.Throughout it all, we see the real world, but in many ways Cole presents this as almost more fantastic and ridiculous than the online worlds that PerfectQuestion plays in. There are scientific advancements that take humans to other planets and planes that seemingly traverse around the world without stopping, but most of that is unavailable to the average person. The more the book explores those areas – the areas inhabited by the rich and powerful – the more the reader finds themselves in foreign territory.In many ways PerfectQuestion is more at home in the war and fantasy of his online games than in the real world.Hence why we never really get a clear picture of who our protagonist really is. What’s his name? PerfectQuestion is the name of his online avatar, but we are lead to believe that the names he gives others in real life are false ones. His name – his true name – is PerfectQuestion. He is more at home online.I don’t know if he was intending it, but I think Nick Cole is certainly saying something in this book about our online behavior and the idea of anonymity. Are we truly anonymous online? In an age when the NSA could be spying on our every behavior, what protections do we truly have? When PerfectQuestion meets others in real life, they seemingly all know him by online personas. He doesn’t have an identity outside of the computer until the final pages of the book and we as the reader are left to decide if that is a good or a bad thing.PerfectQuestion plays the part of a samurai in the Black game he launches into to supplement his income and that aspect of his life transcends and bleeds through every facet of his life. He is a noble person who truly wants to do what is right. There is an honor code he follows, even when the easy option is staring him in the face.I loved Soda Pop Soldier. It definitely wasn’t light-hearted, showing off a fast-paced action with only brief pauses to catch your breath. Cole upped his game for this novel and I look forward to what he has up his sleeve next.

With Book Two in his Tunnel Trilogy, S. Elliot Brandis pushes the envelope even further with the torture he puts his characters through. It is cringeworthy at times, but in the end, he makes the case that the struggle is worth it.In the first book, Irradiated, older sister Jade is forced to rescue her irradiated sister, Pearl, from the evil Queen in the Tunnels below the earth, sacrificing everything to do so. In this book, Pearl is five years older and definitely a bit jaded by her experiences with the new colony of irradiated people who have gathered around her and her kind. There is a war looming -- one that Pearl wants no part of, but war finds her anyway.We also get a parallel story of Flynn in the Tunnels. Flynn is irradiated as well and his abilities give him an opportunity to help or hurt those closest to him.Once again, Brandis seems to take glee in punishing his characters, pushing the boundaries of what most authors would do to further their characters' suffering. By the end, however, the pain, both physical and emotional ties our characters together and leads the narrative towards a (hopefully) epic third act. Well done.

With Irradiated, readers get a new dystopian fiction with a lot to take in. S. Elliot Brandis isn't afraid to kill off characters and to put his protagonists in complex and difficult situations.Jade is the older sister in charge of making sure Pearl is guided through life. Pearl is what is called "Irradiated" and suffers from/is blessed with mutations as a result. There are others who are irradiated and somehow they are drawn to Pearl and her abilities, but there are those who wish to see the Irradiated wiped out for good, ensuring a struggle between the fascist and fanatical forces under the earth and the liberal and free people who live on the planet's surface.I enjoyed the story and really looked forward to reading the second book.

Thomas Robins did something amazing with Part 4 of his first original science fiction novel -- he turned the story on its head and gave the readers a thoughtful, intelligent, and tense final ride in Ineeka's shoes.Through three previous installments, we learned what Ineeka was trying so desperate to escape. We learned about her path from the inner city of Chicago to outer space and beyond. Ineeka is a great character and with Robins' style of storytelling in the D2E series, he does a phenomenal job of ending the story he took nearly a year telling.I loved how Robins told the story and am looking forward to re-reading this story with it in one collection when Robins puts out the complete D2E story. Well done.

We are creators.Regardless of our professions, each of us is inherently a creator. We start early, creating unconquerable cities with building blocks and spinning entire lives centered around dolls and teddy bears. Creation is at the heart of humanity. Even when we think of our meals, we are mentally creating appetizing combinations of cuisines.The art of creating has advanced by leaps and bounds as technology has advanced us as a species. Part of the problem with humanity creating is the fear that we might be too good at it. That we might create something we can’t control. That our creation takes on a life of its own.We’ve seen this in literature for hundreds of years with Frankenstein as the long-lasting example. More recently we can point to 2001, Terminator, Blade Runner, The Matrix and dozens of other books and movies that have shown us what humanity has dared to create has ultimately come back to bite us in the end.And so, we get the latest David Gatewood anthology of short stories, The Robot Chronicles. Gatewood has again assembled a ridiculous amount of literary talent for 13 outstanding stories all involving robots in one form or another. Headlining the collection is Hugh Howey (WOOL) and Matthew Mather (Cyber Storm) and neither one disappoint. Howey’s story, Glitch, was published not long ago on its own and reminded me a lot of the movie Real Steel with fighting robots. What one person perceives as a glitch may be more than that, especially to the robot.I’m not going to go through each of the stories, but each was fantastic and memorable in their own unique ways. I was a huge fan of Isaac Asimov as an adolescent and found each of his Robot stories to be their own moral tales in many ways. These stories are no different, offering viewpoints on what life actually means and how we treat it. Just because we are the creators, does that mean it lessens the life we hold in our hands?A perfect story to go along with this idea is W.J. Davies’ Empathy for Andrew, where we see a situation similar to what Asimov’s Dr. Susan Calvin might have been involved in. Testing new and breakthrough robotics techniques, scientists push the limits of where the line between robots and humans lie. Andrew is the titular robot who is put through a battery of tests to test his empathy chip and Davies does a remarkable job in telling this story.Another story I remember from Asimov’s Robot collection was that of Satisfaction Guaranteed, another Susan Calvin story where she was noticeably absent until the end of the tale. In this story, a woman has a human-like robot live with her and eventually she comes to think of him as more than a robot. You see this theme played out in two separate stories – Ann Christy’s PePr, Inc. and Patrice Fitzgerald’s I Dream of PIA. Both handle this theme in remarkable different (and in Fitzgerald’s case, bawdy and funny) ways.There are also hints at Asimov’s child/buddy stories like A Boy’s Best Friend or Robbie where a child has a robot for a companion and friend. Edward W. Robertson takes the story further. His protagonist, Alex, received Bill as a companion when he is young, but over the years they become more than that – business partners and musicians. Just like a number of famous musicians, things happen and the band doesn’t always survive, but in Baby Your Body’s My Bass, Robertson ends the story on a positive note, in a very Golden-age way.But the stories that really resonate and stick with me tend to be those that have a larger scope in mind – like A.K. Meek’s The Invariable Man where the fate of the world may be at stake or Deirdre Gould’s post-apocalyptic story System Failure.One of the best things about this collection of stories is that it got me to get out my collection of Asimov robot stories and re-read and re-discover them in the light of this remarkable modern anthology. Each of the stories in TRC is fantastic, even if I didn’t specifically name the story and author. I’ll carry these stories with me for a long time.I really enjoyed The Robot Chronicles, just like I did with Synchronic and The Indie Side. David Gatewood is becoming someone to know in the science fiction short story game and his anthologies are now “can’t miss” books for me.

My wife loves to wash the carpets several times a year.  We have a Bissell Big Green Machine, which we are very pleased with because it works great.RugDoctor platinum Pure with Oxy has a much more delicate scent than our normal cleaning shampoo, Bissell Deepclean Pro.  This RugDoctor scent, sparkeling breeze, is great for those who do not like strong perfumed scents.  I used to always buy RugDoctor in the red jugs at the grocery store, which were not concentrated.  I would say the new formula works just as good, but because there were a few stains that took more work I am not as trilled as I could be.  Overall, it works very good.RugDoctor platinum doesn’t make suds like our usual Bissell Deepclean Pro.  The proper amount was used and it didn’t seem to pick up stains as well as Bissell.  It took a lot more work to go over the stain spots to get them to lift.  It hardly looked like dirt was coming up at all, but the water was very dirty.  RugDoctor doesn’t foam up, which is probably why it is claming there is “no sticky residue” like the others.  This claim is true, but overall, my wife still prefers the Bissell DeepClean Pro because it lefts stains a bit better.

At the time I first bought this switch plate, this style in the pewter color was easy to find.  I see they now have copper and bronze options, but the pewter version seems to be on the way out and the price is going up a lot.  Buy them while you can!

We decided to upgrade the kitchen light with this chandelier.  We only have two of the links in use so it isn't too long.  My wife actually installed this one herself (first time she ever installed a light) before I got home.  She helped me and watched me install several other lights, so I am gladly she felt good enough to challenge herself and take on the project.  So have confidence, someone who only watched how other lights are done can do this job.60 watt bulbs were much too bright so I bought some 40 watt bulbs and they are just right.  A light with five bulbs really makes a room light up.  I think the chandelier has a mixture of classic and modern.  The center is fairly plain and the edges of the glass pieces give it a modern look, in my opinion.We spent a lot of time looking for a light fixture that had at least four bulbs, would bring the look of the room up a notch,  and wasn't too long so I wouldn't bump my head.  It really is a challenge because we wanted to both really like it too.  This was the shortest hanging light we could find that was a little more fancy.  I really wish they made lights that were more elegant and met the rest of our needs.

Ubervita has a nice line of health/fitness supplements that are all reasonably priced.  In my opinion, this is a company that cares about the quality of their products.  The Ubercran comes in a big plastic bottle, but it IS a full bottle (not one that is 90% empty like other supplements).  Ubercran isn’t just cranberry as it also has vitamins C and E to help absorption and another seven herbal ingredients that promote urinary tract health.  You cannot go wrong with Ubercran as the company that makes it offers a full refund for any customer who isn’t completely satisfied with any of their products.

The size of the candies is similar to the “bite size” you might see in the candy dish at the office, but these candies aren’t your typical Hershey’s chocolate.  The tin comes with both milk chocolate and dark chocolates caramel candies.  The chocolate coating is a nice size, but the majority of the candy is pure caramel.  The chocolate itself doesn’t taste like typical Hershey chocolate, but reminds me more of the type that would coat a bonbon.  The caramel is very chewy, so be careful if you have any loose dental fillings.  Just one or two pieces are very satisfying and filling, for me at least.  The tin the candies is very nice looking and the presentation as a whole makes it more gift worthy.  This tin has a bit of luxury candy in it so who wouldn’t want one as a gift?

I really like the look of the Schlage Accent levers.  I have installed thirty of the various types in this style for my own home and others in my family.  I think they look great and really give a tough of class to a home.
I have a 2013 VW Jetta TDI and this cabin filter worked perfect.  It took like a minute to change and really is something you can do yourself to save some money.

I have a lot of TCP LED bulbs in my house.  I bought these because the 60-watt equivalent was too bright for my new kitchen light.  The new kitchen light takes five bulbs and the 60-watt bulbs were so glaringly bright that it was uncomfortable.  So having these 40-watt equivalent bulbs was just right.I like the daylight color bulbs better than the yellow light too.  I am glad the price has gone down to the level the curly-q bulbs were when I first got into them (about $6 a bulb).

I like how these diapers have a very elastic band so they will fit nice and snug regardless of the size of your child – they always fit just right.  They are quick and easy to take on or off so it saves parents some aggravation too.  They are very cute diapers and work great for daytime use.  For nighttime, I really recommend the Huggies Overnights, which in my opinion hold more than any other nighttime diaper.

Of all the stuff I take as part of my supplement routine, magnesium was sadly missing.  I should have been taking this regularly ten years ago.  Magnesium is great for keeping bones strong but for me more importantly it helps with blood pressure.  It is suggested to take two tablets twice a day to get the full 100% daily value.  As these tablets are large, it will take some motivation for some people to take that many in addition to whatever they currently take.  This bottle is a 60-day supply.I have found calcium taken with magnesium has a great muscle relaxation response and can really help one sleep.  Although I wouldn’t recommend taking this combination for extended periods due to potential calcium build up in arteries.
There isn't anything easier to change in a car than an air filter. It is a simple 5-10 minute project that can save you money doing yourself.  It fit perfectly in my VW 2013 Jetta TDI.

The capsules are small and easy to take. Each capsule has 1,250% of the daily value, so they will probably be more than enough for your needs.  If you are not able to get vitamin D from the sun, you can take these.The image of the bottle is funny because it looks like the bottle is full to the very top.  In reality, 80% of the bottle is empty.

Astragalus is known to improve a whole lot of various issues so one could even say it would be good for "general health."  I know the disclaimers say it doesn't do anything, but if you look into it like me, I think you will be impressed.  I think there is at least three things I found to be something I would like improved.
Theses are great looking jeans.  They are well made and very durable.  The best part is the adjustable waist on the inseam so kids on the smaller size can fit in them with a little adjustment.

My older son first got a few Schleich horses when he was three years old.  He saw them o the shelf in the store and had to have one.  He loved to visit the horse stables near us that are open to the public to visit and so horses quickly became one of his favorite things.  This horse wash area seems to be a bit feminine because it has a couple of pink items, but other than that, this is a really cool set.  The pieces are a rubbery plastic or a hard plastic, depending on which piece it is.  It has lots of small parts so it isn’t for small kids.  It has all the intricate detail Schleich toys are known for and will be a lot of fun for kids that love horses.

My wife thinks the scent of this shower oil reminders her of the type of perfume older women wear, but I think it smells like moose or hair products.  The scent is barely noticeable after using it and is light and pleasant.  The shower oil has a nice gold sparkling look (which looks just like one of the shampoos I used once).
