The shower oil doesn't go a long way so you will probably have to apply more to the sponge before you finish showering.  It leaves skin nice and soft, so I would say it does what it is supposed to do.

I was a little concerned that this may not be bright enough, especially as it was replacing a very strong bulb.  It gives off a lot more light than I expected.  The yellow light really doesn't attract bugs, so it is great for a light outside the entrance way.
Replacing the windshield wiper could not get any easier than this.  It took less than a minute and I didn't look at the instructions.  It worked perfectly for my VW.

Axe has products that really have a strong scent.  Just using the shampoo, the bathroom smells like Axe for about five minutes.  What does Apollo smell like?  Well, the shampoo is blue and it smells just like a blue shampoo would made from Axe.  I know that may not be telling enough, but it is accurate.  My wife thinks it smells nice, so I guess one could say it is a smell women like.
These are about the size of typical fish oil capsules.  I would say there is a slight pumpkin scent to them but not too strong.  I think it is easy to add these to one's supplement routine.

The Pastor Theologian: Resurrecting an Ancient Vision is a new book by Gerald Hiestand and Todd Wilson that examines church history and our current environment to show the need for a return of pastors as Ecclesial Theologians and then provides guidance for pastors to step into this "ancient" role. As Timothy George states in his Foreword, "the social bifurcation between church and academy that has marked Western culture since the Enlightenment does not excuse local church pastors from one of their own major responsibilities. "Pastors are the theological chief executive officers of the church."  It is this role that Hiestand and Wilson are calling men to embrace.Heistand and Wilson do a wonderful job setting the stage by taking the reader through a quick trip of history (with the addition of a large detailed Appendix) to show the developments within the church and how the rise of the academy as the intellectual hub also led to the loss of Pastor Theologians. In ancient days men could be great theologians of the church as well as faithful pastors serving their local congregation. With the rise of the academy though, these roles became divided and men who felt called to write theology for theologians and pastors left for the academy. This short walk through history is quite beneficial for the reader to see the development over the course of roughly 2000 years.Hiestand and Wilson are straightforward in their diagnosis of our current setting. They state, "Pastor theologians aren't extinct, but sightings are rare. This is because pastors no longer traffic in ideas. They cast vision, manage programs, offer counsel, and give messages.....None of this in inherently wrong. Indeed, all of these are important pastoral tasks. But we no longer view the pastorate as an intellectual calling....Intellectually speaking, we expect pastors to function, at best, as intellectual middle management, passive conveyors of insights from theologians to laity. A little quote from Augustine here, a brief allusion to Bonhoeffer there. That's all." This idea of middle management is a very helpful picture. Are pastors only to transfer ideas from the theologian to the pew, or are they also able to write for the theologian and as the theologian?  Hiestand and Wilson are also clear that the Pastor Theologian does first have a heart for the church. "We do envision and want to advocate for a return of the pastor theologian who has a shepherd's heart and a pastor's primary vocational identity, yet who functions as an intellectual peer of the academic theologian and, as such, produces theological scholarship for the broader ecclesial community. that helps shape and inform academic, cultural, and ecclesial discussions with a view to deepening the faith of the people of God."The authors provide eight helpful characteristics of a pastor as ecclesial theologian. They are: 1) Inhabits the Ecclesial Social location, 2) Foregrounds Ecclesial Questions 3) Aims for clarity over subtlety 4) theologizes with a preaching voice 5)is a student of the church 6) works across the guilds 7) works in partnership with the academic theologian and 8) traffics in introspection. They also lay out 10 strategies on becoming an ecclesial theologian. They are as follows: 1) Get a PhD 2) Staff to the Vision 3) Get Networked 4) Guard Your Study Time with a blowtorch  5) Read ecclesial theology (and other stuff) 6) Refer to the place where you work as "your study" 7) Build study-and-writing leave into your schedule 8) recruit a pastor-theologian intern 9) Earn buy-in from your church leadership 10) let the necessity of love trump your love of truth.  These two list, making up chapters seven and eight of the book provide a helpful starting point for pastors who feel called to write theological works for other theologians and pastors. This book is definitely a book that should be read by all pastors who have a mind and heart towards theology as well as serving in their local church. Well done!I received a copy of this book from Zondervan in exchange for an honest review.

In the introduction to Preaching for Revitalization, Michael F. Ross states clearly the problem facing so many churches today. He states, "There is a famine in our land for the Word of God, a dying hunger for 'holy manna' (Amos 8:11). And it is the duty of godly preachers to seek to do something about the lack of holy manna, that preaching of the Word that reforms religion, revives the Church and regenerates dead souls." For a church to experience true and lasting revitalization it must return to the Word of God having a central role in all that it does corporately. "True church revitalization can never take place and be maintained unless it is the product of a biblical pulpit." The centrality of the Word of God cannot be bypassed for a church to truly  experience revitalization. Ross defines revitalization as "the process whereby a church is refocused on its mission of both evangelism and nurturing, and renewed in its efforts to minister to others so that numerical, spiritual and organizational growth occur and are sustained."Ross proposes the following outline to accomplish church revitalization which also serves to divide the book into four parts:1) Certain priorities of revitalizing preaching that will positively affect the interest shown by others toward a minister's preaching can be deduced from Reformation and Puritan preaching.2) A certain content to revitalizing preaching that will positively affect the growth experienced from one's preaching can be deduced from Reformation and Puritan preaching.3) Certain characteristics of revitalizing preaching that will positively affect the ethos of one's preaching can be deduced from Reformation and Puritan preaching.4) A certain style of revitalizing preaching that will positively affect the impact of one's preaching can be deduced from Reformation and Puritan preaching.In part one the centrality of the Word of God and preaching is the focus.  If the preaching of the Word of God is not central in a church then that church has shown what it thinks about the sufficiency of Scripture to revitalize a church. As Ross rightly states, "when the Scripture is no longer supreme in authority, the sermon is no longer pre-eminent in liturgy; an soon sacramental priorities replace preaching. These 'sacramental' replacements may not just be penance, the eucharist or liturgies to Mary and the saints, but may also include drama, liturgical dance, overemphasis on music and other innovations in worship revealing a lack of confidence in Scripture and a low view of preaching."In part two Ross helps the reader to see the proper balance in preaching between five types of preaching he discusses: 1) Christological Preaching, 2) Ecclesiastical Preaching, 3) Missiological Preaching, 4) Doctrinal Preaching, and 5) Ethical Preaching. In each chapter Ross explains what each type of preaching is and why it is necessary and shows the focus on these types of preaching in Reformation and Puritan thought.  Part three examines four characteristics of Puritan and Reformed preaching: 1) Spiritual 2) Romantic 3) Controversial and 4) Camaraderie. Part four focuses on expository preaching as the best type of preaching and then examines its historical roots before examining method and process.  As someone who enjoys reflecting on Reformation and Puritan thought I was greatly encouraged by the connections that Ross made to these eras and church revitalization. This book would be a blessing and helpful read for all pastors, not just those trying to revitalize a dying church.I received a copy of this book from Christian Focus in exchange for an honest review.

The Secret Life of a Pastor "represents pastoral letters that [Milton] composed to [his] students across the years, as [he] had the opportunity to teach in seminaries." "The letters vary in length , language, and, at times, in tone. There is no cookie-cutter approach to mentoring, and the variations in the letters reflect this." From the very first page Milton shares his heart's desire to pass on to future and current pastors wisdom that he has accumulated in his years of pastoral experience.  His love for Christ, the church and his students is clearly seen and wonderfully communicated.Milton's letters to his students cover a wide range of topics. Some of these include: Having a proper understanding of time spent in seminary, study of original languages, a Pastors relationship with his wife and kids, the necessity of expository preaching, the Pastors role in equipping the saints, the centrality of Christ and the gospel, rest, and many more. Milton's love and wise words blend together in these brief letters and will surely be an encouragement to aspiring pastors, new pastors and seasoned pastors alike. As Milton states, "The common denominator in all of the published letters is the author’s desire to lead future pastors and other church leaders in surrendering their identities, ambitions, and plans to the supreme Mentor, our Lord Jesus Christ." This desire translates into a book that will definitely be an encouragement to every pastor who reads it. Well done!I received a copy of this book from Christian Focus via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

A great concern for the American Church, and truly the Christian Church throughout history, is that we take the truth that we are made in the image of God and turn it on its head. We make God in the image of man. Not just any man, but ourselves. We place on God characteristics, or accentuate his attributes, in a way that fits Him into our agenda. The most obvious form of this in our culture today is the prosperity gospel. Men and women twist Scripture to come up with a God that wants to give everyone great prosperity if they would only believe and give enough. These false teachers feed on people's desire for riches and use a "myth" to do so. While this is damaging for sure, there are also more subtle ways that we can create a false God/Jesus.  In The Original Jesus: Trading the Myths for the Savior Who Is  Daniel Darling examines 10 myths that we can create that lead us astray from the original Jesus.In the Foreword, Russell Moore, is spot on when he states that "Many Christians could easily just buy a golden Buddha from a flea market, affix a brown beard on it, and call it 'Jesus.' This little idol would have as much resemblance to the living Son of God as the mental constructions we so often piece together and call 'Jesus' in our lives. Darling's remedy is to expose the myths for what they are and then to show how they fall short of the true Jesus. The ten myths that Darling examines are: 1) Guru Jesus. This myth views Jesus as an inspirational figure and good teacher, but not our victorious King. 2) Red-Letter Jesus. This myth sets the Bible against each other. The person who thinks this way chooses to focus on certain words and teachings in the Bible and reject the rest of it. 3) Braveheart Jesus. This myth views Biblical manhood as rugged manhood and any deviation is not true manhood. Characteristics like "not violent but gentle, not quarrelsome," "not arrogant or quick tempered." are minimized in this view. 4) American Jesus. This myth makes Jesus the mascot of every conservative political cause to the point where the concern is more about the political map of the country and less about souls being rescued from darkness. 5) Left-Wing Jesus. This myth focuses on areas like caring for the poor, often with handouts, and uses Jesus as its mascot. 6) Dr. Phil Jesus. This myth turn Jesus into simply a self help guide, wanting to help you be a better you. 7) Prosperity Jesus. Again, this myth makes Jesus a means to and end and the end is our material prosperity. 8) Post-Church Jesus. This myth is becoming more and more popular. People who hold to this mythical Jesus sever Him (the head) from the Church (His body) and claim to love and follow Jesus while having nothing to do with the church. 9) BFF Jesus. This myth does away with much of Christianity and focuses solely on just loving Jesus. 10) Legalist Jesus. This myth adds our own rules/regulations/preferences to Jesus as a means of acceptance. In each chapter Darling does a wonderful job of exposing these myths and showing why we need so much more from Jesus than what they have to offer. I was really blessed by this book and highly recommend it.I received a copy of this book from Baker Books in exchange for an honest review.

Friendship among believers is a subject that is practically assumed, yet often not thought through or examined in light of the cross. Friendship Redeemed: How the Gospel Changes Friendships to Something Greater by Adam Holland is a new book that examines Paul's friendships and encourages believers to model their friendships after Paul's example. The fellowship that we find in Christian friendship is to be one of unity, modeled after the unity of our triune God is whose image we are created.  As Holland states, "Mankind was created in the image of the triune God. We were created to live in harmony or perfect unity with one another. Our relationships with one another are and were to be a reflection of the relationship that the Godhead has had within itself throughout eternity. The Christian is called to bring these heavenly realities down to earth.  When an unbeliever sees a Christian friendship, he gets to see a small glimpse of what the world looks like when it is ruled by Christ. They get to see a glimpse of what it looks like when the Shalom, or peace of God, has been restored in the world." With this thought in mind friendship should be a topic that we think seriously about so that our friendship is unique to the world and points them to Christ.To have friendships like this we must live with the cross always in view. Holland examines Paul's friendships and brings encouragement for readers to model their friendships after his.  Holland draws from Paul's friendships with Tychicus, Onesimus, John Mark, Epaphras, Luke and Demas.  One thing that really stands out from this survey is the different types of people that Paul had friendships with. He didn't limit his circle of friends to people who were just like him. As Holland rightly says, "Paul  challenges us to take risks on people even when they are not like us. Paul’s friends were made up of a pretty diverse group of individuals—a  former slave, a doctor, both Jews and Gentiles, etc. If you only have friends who are like you, you will never be challenged to be something more or something different."When we model our friendships after Paul we will also have to embrace risk.  Again Holland is helpful when he states, "How can you tell whether one of your friends is going to be a John Mark (a friend that leaves and comes back) or a Demas  (a friend that leaves you and never returns)? You can’t! So, should we shut the door on any friendship in fear that they may abandon us or hurt us? No! Paul models for us how living on the other side of the cross calls for believers to take risks with others. Sometimes you are going to get hurt." With Hurt also comes the opportunity for forgiveness and restoration. Again drawing from the example of Paul, Holland states, "Paul models how to love others when they have wronged you. People in general are quick to turn their backs on those who have wronged them. Paul displays a forgiveness that is only possible through the Holy Spirit. It is a forgiveness that was displayed on the cross when the God of the universe gave up his  life when everyone had wronged him." This is truly how the gospel changes friendship. In light of the cross we are able to love those who are different than us and to forgive those who may hurt us. I was greatly encouraged by this book and highly recommend it to all believers. It is quite easy to hold to a worldly model of friendship, it is far more difficult to hold to a biblical example. Thankfully, Adam Holland has provided the church with a biblical look into friendship. Well Done!I received a copy of this book from Veritas Press in exchange for an honest review.

Pray for the Flock: Ministering God's Grace Through Intercession is a recent release in the Practical Shepherding Series. This series, as clearly stated in it's name, seeks to provide practical help for pastors as they seek to lead their people. This is now the second volume that I have read in this series and I must say that the authors have definitely provided a series that offers quick, readable and highly beneficial books for pastors.In this volume titled, Pray for the Flock, Croft and Fullerton take on a discipline that is without dispute highly necessary for pastors and one that is also probably highly neglected. If most Christians were to examine their prayer life an honest take-away would be that we do not pray enough. And most of us in practice probably do not treat prayer with the serious focus that it deserves. The same holds true for pastors. The demands on a pastor's life can often take their free time, but also can intrude on time that would have been spent in study or prayer. As the authors note, the sermon has to get done so a pastor must set aside time for sermon preparation, but if busyness encroaches it is easy for prayer to get pushed aside. While this may be a common occurrence, it isn't a habit that a pastor should want to remain. As the authors state well, "prayerlessness reveals our lack of taith and highlights our misplaced priorities." Croft and Fullerton aim to encourage and equip pastors to give prayer its proper place and to make it a high priority.In the first chapter titled, A Call to Prayer, Ryan Fullerton lays out six truths to help make prayer a priority. These truths are: 1) Not praying for your people is a sin, 2) Praying for your people glorifies God, 3) We are called to imitate leaders who pray for their people, 4) Praying for your people reflects the priority of the early church, 5) Praying for God's people will lead them to change, and 6) Prayer is how ordinary men do extraordinary things for God.  These truths will challenge pastors to move away from prayerlessness and force them to lean on the Holy Spirit for the strength to change. In the first part of the book the authors walk the reader through the Bible's teaching on prayer. Here the authors show that it is mandatory for a pastor to pray for his people.  As Croft states, "praying with people and pleading on their behalf before the Father are essential aspects of shepherding God's people. Pastors must pray. Elders must plead before God on behalf of their people. Leaders must lift to the throne of grace the needs of the church, both the church's needs as a whole and the needs of individual believers." This first section is a wonderful reminder to pastors of their biblical duty to pray for their people.Part Two of the book tackles the practical application side of prayer. The chapter titled, Pray Deliberately, encourages pastors to prayer through their church membership roll so that all members are being prayed for. This section also gives practical advice on praying during public church gatherings, praying with other pastors, praying for God's global work, praying and fasting, and being equipped and ready to pray at special occasions. Each of these chapters is an encouragement and will surely bless any pastor who reads them. As I stated at the beginning, this is now the second book that I have read in the Practical Shepherding Series and I would highly recommend this book, as well as the series, to all pastors.I received a copy of this book from Zondervan in exchange for an honest review.

Recently I received a digital copy of 30: Three Decades of Songs for the Church by Sovereign Grace Music to review. This album is a collection of 14 of their more well known songs.Below is the track listing:1) Let Your Kingdom Come2) All I Have is Christ3) Jesus, Thank You4) Behold Our God5) O Great God6) The Glories of Calvary7) Oh the Deep, Deep Love8) Now Why This Fear9) The Glory of the Cross10) I Will Glory in My Redeemer11) Greater Than We Can Imagine12) I Have a Shelter13) I Stand in Awe14) Before the Throne of God AboveEach of these songs is God-exalting, Gospel-rooted and Church-edifying. These songs are sung by guest such as: Kristyn Getty, Matt Papa, Matt Boswell, Sojourn, The Village Church, Enfield and more. Each of these artist offers a different take on classic Sovereign Grace songs. After listening to the album multiple times and listening to many of the original releases on previous albums this album has its own unique feel to it and does not just feel like a quickly thrown together selection of old songs just to make a new album. Many of the arrangements are drastically different than the previous versions and the guest artists provide their own unique singing styles to the songs.  I have been thoroughly blessed by this album as it has led to many days driving down the road and worshiping God through song! Well done!!!I received a digital copy of this album from Sovereign Grace Music in exchange for an honest review.

As a parent I would rather not have to talk to my kids about how to protect their bodies. I would rather live in a world where there was no danger of a sexual predator ever being alone around my children. It would, however, be the height of naiveté for me to ignore the darkness of sin and perversion in our world and to do nothing or say nothing to protect my children. Just because a topic of conversation is difficult does not mean that it is not a conversation worth having. Thankfully, Justin & Lindsey Holcomb with their new book God Made All of Me: A Book to Help Children Protect Their Bodies have provided a wonderful resource for parents or caregivers to talk to their children about how to protect their bodies.Parents have been given the duty and responsibility before God to teach and protect their children. As the authors rightly state "education is important in preventing inappropriate sexual behavior or contact. By teaching children about their bodies and discussing appropriate and inappropriate touch you are helping them understand their ability to say 'No' to unwanted touch, which will help them if anyone ever tries to hurt them or trick them." The authors are very helpful in discussing how God made our bodies, how we are in charge of our bodies, how it is ok to say "no thanks" even to appropriate touch like hugs, and the difference between appropriate and inappropriate touch. The discussion of the difference between a secret and a surprise is very helpful as well. The authors explain to kids that there is no need to keep secrets from their parents, because we have nothing to hide from each other. We may surprise each other with gifts, but this is a very different matter. As the mom in the book says "Surprises are fun and make people happy. Secrets are different from surprises. Secrets are not nice, they can make people feel confused or sad."The artwork in God Made All of Me is by Trish Mahoney and is done very well. Every page has a picture that complements the point the authors are making on that page. These pictures will certainly aid in helping children to understand how to protect their bodies. I do want to mention one area that may concern some parents. The authors chose to use proper names, rather than slang terms (or nicknames) many parents may use with their children, when discussing private parts. These names only appear on one page of the book and the authors explain to parents in a summary in the back of the book why they feel it is helpful to use proper names. They state, "it might be uncomfortable at first, but use the proper names of body parts. Children need to know the proper name for genitals. This knowledge gives children correct language for understanding their bodies, for asking questions that need to be asked, and for telling about any behavior that could lead to sexual abuse." While some parents may disagree with the use of proper names (although a disagreement should not drive parents away from this book), the authors intent is clear and commendable. I cannot honestly think of any reason why any parent would not find this book helpful and necessary. Sexual predators present a real danger and we have a God given responsibility to protect our children and should seek out resources to help us in doing that. God Made All of Me is one of those helpful resources and will certainly be a helpful book for any parent who uses it.I received a copy of this book from New Growth Press in exchange for an honest review.

There certainly aren't a shortage of books that are out today discussing the topic of prophecy. From Left Behind, to Blood Moons, books about prophecy, no matter how sound the thinking may be always gathers lots of attention. Thankfully, there are some solid resource out that deal with prophecy in a helpful way.  Understanding Prophecy: A Biblical-Theological Approach by Alan S. Bandy and Benjamin L. Merkle is one of those resources.In the Preface the authors state the purpose of the book very clearly, so instead of trying to reword their thoughts I will just share them.  They state:The goal of this book is not merely to explain various "prophetic" texts but primarily to give the reader a framework of how to interpret any passage in the context of the Bible. The reason for this framework for reading prophecy is simple: We cannot correctly understand the details of the Bible without also having a gras if the bigger picture. Evangelicals often dispute interpretations of various prophetic passages so that a consensus view proves elusive. Differences of opinion do not reflect varying levels of intelligence or diligence so much as different presuppositions, which lead to a different understanding of the whole. Unfortunately, many people are not aware of their presuppositions and consequently do not have a firm grasp of how an individual text fits into the larger picture of salvation history. Thus, we want to provide a biblical-theological perspective for interpreting prophecy.Chapters 1-3 provide the framework for how to approach and interpret prophetic passages from a biblical-theological perspective. Understanding redemptive history and having a Christ-centered view of Scripture are helpful in properly understanding prophecy and the authors are very helpful in this section. From there the authors move on to discussing Old Testament and New Testament prophecy. Even though the authors hold to differing millennial views, Bandy is a historic premillennialist and Merkle an amillennialist they show much agreement on how to interpret prophecy. Two areas of disagreement: What does 'All Israel" in Romans 11:26 mean and the millennium are discussed in two Appendixes. I found this to be helpful, even though I have actually studied these area to some extent, because it provides a short summary of differing views that some readers may have never thought through.Overall I was very encouraged by this volume and I am thankful to have this as a resource that I will surely use for years to come.  I received a copy of this book from Kregel Academic in exchange for an honest review.

A few years ago I was introduced to Geerhardus Vos. I was studying some introductory works on Biblical Theology and kept noticing a title being referenced. That book was Biblical Theology: Old and New Testaments which I subsequently purchased and which still has a prominent place on my bookshelf today. I have found Vos' writing to be both theologically rich and accessible.  Originally published in 1896 Reformed Dogmatics: Volume One: Theology Proper by Geerhardus Vos was a titled that was previously unavailable to English readers. Thankfully Lexham Press and Richard Gaffin Jr. (Translator and Editor) have now made available this systematic work from the gifted Biblical Theologian Vos.Reformed Dogmatics: Volume One: Theology Proper covers the being, attributes and work of God. This volume is divided into seven chapters. They are: 1) The Knowability of God 2) Names, Being, and Attributes of God 3) The Trinity 4) Of God's Decrees in General 5) The Doctrine of Predestination 6) Creation and 7) Providence. The topics covered in each section are addressed through a series of enumerated questions. The answers to each question are given in a concise statement or paragraph. While the questions do divide the text, I never got the feel that the work was disjointed. The questions flow smoothly from one to the next in a way that does not make for tedious reading. The best way to show both the clarity and depth with which Vos writes is to provide a short excerpt of one of his questions and answers. In his discussion on the Trinity he asks, and answers the following question:12. In which theses can you state the doctrine of the Trinity?a) There is only one divine being. Scripture expresses itself decisively against all polytheism (Deut 6:4; Isa 44:6; Jas 2:19)b) In this one God there are three modes of existence, which we refer to by the word "person" and which are, each one, this only true God. In Scripture these three persons are called, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.c) These three persons, although together the one true God, are nevertheless distinguished from each other insofar as they assume objective relations toward each other, address each other, love each other, and can interact with each other.d) Although these three persons possess one and the same divine substance, Scripture nevertheless teaches us that, concerning their personal existence, the Father is the first, the Son the second, and the Holy Spirit the third, that the Son is of the Father, the Spirit of the Father and the Son. Further, their workings outwardly reflect this order of personal existence, since the Father works through the Son, and the Father and Son work through the Spirit. There is, therefore, subordination as to personal manner of existence and manner of working, but no subordination regarding possession of the one divine substance.e) The divine substance is not divided among the three persons as if each possesses one-third. Neither is it a new substance beside the three persons. Finally, neither is it an abstraction of our thinking in a nominalistic sense. But in a manner for which all further analogy is lacking, each of these persons possesses the entire divine substance.I chose this example because the Trinity is possibly the most difficult doctrine in Christianity for our finite minds to comprehend. I think that Vos' comments provide a helpful and clear definition of what is meant when we speak of the Trinity. This is the type of thought and clarity that can be found throughout this work.  The back of the book provides a Question Index, a Subject and Author Index, and a Scripture Index. The Question Index is incredibly helpful. Here each question is listed without the answer, making it an excellent resource to quickly navigate to a desired topic or question.The editing of this book is simply outstanding. The dust jacket is very nicely designed and looks good on a bookshelf. The book itself has a high quality binding on it. The text itself is very crisp and clear. I read a lot and have come to notice that not all paper and ink are alike and the quality of the print in this book makes it very easy on the eyes during extended reading. Overall, I am very pleased with this work and am thankful for the publishers, editors and translation work. This is an excellent resource for the church and I highly recommend it.I received a copy of this book from Lexham Press in exchange for an honest review.

In the Preface to this set the publisher writes: "The Old Testament commentaries of Derek Kidner (1913-2008) have been a standard for a generation. His work has been a model of conciseness, clarity and insight."  It is these three descriptors: conciseness, clarity and insight that I was hoping to find in this two book set. While sold individually (Psalms 1-72 and Psalms 73-150) I have chosen to do the review as a set since the majority of the time I would think they would be purchased together. The perk of being able to buy separately is a lower buy in cost for one book if the reader wants to have a hands on look at the commentary before committing to the set. Either way I want to briefly look at whether this set meets the aforementioned thoughts from the publisher.Volume One from Derek Kidner covers Psalms 1-72 and also provides a 50 page introduction. Sometimes introductions to commentaries can be glossed over but I would highly recommend taking the time to read through this introduction. Here Kidner discusses poetry, the layout of the Psalter trends in the study of the Psalms, the Messianic hope as well as some of the technicalities to Psalm reading.  I found the section on Titles and Technical Terms to be very useful. There are so many different names and terms throughout the Psalter (i.e. David, Solomon, Heman the Ezrahite, Miktam, Maskil) as well as the many according to's (The choirmaster, The Sheminith, The Gittith, to Mahalath, etc.) that it is easy to forget exactly what the term or description means. This section provides a quick reference for a short defining statement to clarify for the reader.From here Volume One also covers Book One and Two of the Psalter with Volume Two covering Books Three, Four and Five. I really appreciated the layout that Kidner uses for his commentary. He begins Each Psalm with a bold heading and name. From there he provides a short paragraph or two summary of what the theme of the Psalm is.  He then begins his commentary notes by taking a few verses at a time. Each of these sections is divided again with bold chapter and verse font with a description. This layout makes it very easy to flip through the commentary and arrive at the section the reader is looking for very quickly. I found Kidner's notes to be clear and helpful in seeing the main theme of each Psalm. His writing style is definitely to the point as there isn't a lot of fluff or over explanation. Overall, I think this would be a valuable commentary set for a Pastor as well as anyone looking for an in depth study into the Psalter.Priced at $18.00 each will certainly make this one of the most affordable commentaries on the book of Psalms. While not as thorough as some of the other larger volumes that are available this set by Kidner is certainly not one to be overlooked and for the price it is a great deal to pick up for anyone preaching through the Psalms or taking up a personal study of the Psalter.I received a copy of this commentary set from IVP Academic in exchange for an honest review.

One of the great perks to writing reviews has been being introduced to many commentaries that I would have otherwise not known.  This is certainly true of Galatians from the EP Study Commentary Series by Peter Barnes.  I am always eager when receiving a new commentary to explore the style in which it is written and its range of use. For example, is this written exclusively for Pastors/Teachers or will other church members looking to enhance their study find it profitable as well. Below, I will try to briefly comment on the layout of the commentary and then the content of the commentary.Barnes begins his commentary on Galatians with an introductory section that covers the background, dating and structure of the epistle.  This section is written in chapter form and is presented in a very readable way. I did find the structure of the epistle section to be different than most commentaries. Here one typically finds some sort of outline of the layout of the book. Barnes instead chose to write a concise two paragraphs discussing the layout. While this isn't as profitable as a reference to come back to it does make the outline something that the reader can read in full. The terms Barnes uses here are the same terms that divide the commentary making it a helpful reference as well.  Perhaps the most helpful section in the introduction is Barnes' examination of the New Perspectives view.  Galatians is a polemic for justification by faith and is very strongly worded towards those who would add to this.  Barnes is quite helpful here in seeing how the New Perspectives brings with it confusion that must be handled seriously. As he states, "the 'New Perspective' is certainly that. It has radical implications for our understanding of salvation. Because Wright misunderstands the nature of faith, he grounds assurance on the wrong basis....The result, in the end, is a kind of Christianized Judaism. If, as Luther maintained, the distinction between law and gospel contains 'the sum of all Christian doctrine', then the effect of the New Perspective is to muddy the waters again." Barnes is dead on in his examination and the implications of this view.Moving into the commentary Barnes presents a layout that almost feels devotional as far as the way the chapter divisions go, but is loaded with content.  Each section is titled and then offers a brief introductory sentence or two.  From there the passage is written in a different font which makes it stand out somewhat. From here Barnes moves into his commentary on the passage. As he works through the passage each word or phrase from the passage is written in bold. This is helpful as the commentary itself is written in a continuous paragraph style (again, making it read more like a book than a commentary) but the bold font allows the reader to quickly find the section of Scripture that they may be looking for. I found Barnes commentary notes to be quite beneficial. It is clear that he has consulted many resources and pull his thoughts together nicely in what is a very readable commentary. Certainly some of the content may be a little heavy for the average reader, but I am sure that anyone who would pick up this commentary to help their study of Galatians would find it beneficial. Many sections also have a short Application section as well.  While not as extensive as some other commentaries that a geared towards contemporary application I found Barnes' short application notes to be helpful as well. For example, the application note for Galatians 6:1 "You who are spiritual should restore him in a spirit of gentleness" begins with an excellent exhortation. Barnes states, "dealing with the sin of a fellow believer is one of the most difficult and spiritual tasks that the Christian believer ever has to carry out. Wisdom, discernment, gentleness, a sense of proportion, a hatred of sin, a love for sinners and a true sense of humility are all required."  This application note certainly helps to orient the readers mind in the proper direction.Overall, I am very pleased with this commentary and look forward to reading more in the EP Study Commentary Series. I received a copy of the book from EP Books in exchange for an honest review.

The Glory of a True Church by Benjamin Keach is the second release in the Baptist Reprints Series from Free Grace Press.  These reprints are making lesser known works from our Baptist forefathers available at a reasonable price.  This most recent release focuses on church discipline.  If I had to chose one subject that is either greatly misunderstood or largely ignored it would probably be church discipline.  Keach's book was originally published so that the masses could have access to a book on church discipline that was small in size. I think that this reprint will serve much in the same capacity.The Glory of a True Church is small in size, 86 pages, and presents a clear and understandable look at church discipline. Keach states his purpose was "to write a small and plain tract concerning the rules of the discipline of a gospel church; that all men may not only know our faith, but see order in this case also." This need was great in his day as it is today. As Keach says, "certainly, ignorance of the rules of discipline causes no small trouble and disorders in our churches." This book serves as an excellent concise look at the nature and purpose of church discipline.I found Keach's questions that he poses and answers throughout the book to be very helpful. Here he addresses common questions or objections that may arise when talking about church discipline. These are helpful as they supplement the straightforward teaching of each chapter nicely. Overall, I found this book to be a great blessing. Even more than this book, the series promises to continue to be an excellent source for provided quality Baptist Reprints at a reasonable cost.I received a copy of this book from Free Grace Press in exchange for an honest review.

It's no secret that sexual sin has become one of the most devastating sins in the church. Families, Lives and sometimes churches get destroyed when men's lives get out of control and sexual sin becomes their god and brings with it hurt, pain and ruin. So, what should the churches response to this problem be? Programs are good. Rehab is helpful. Putting up fences for protection is also necessary. All of these deal with correcting issues on the surface and while offering a level of protection they do nothing to change the heart.  What is needed is gospel power to change men from the inside out. Love for Christ needs to penetrate men's hearts to the level that it drives out the affection for lust, pornography or whatever other sexual sin may grip men. In Hide or Seek: When Men Get Real With God About Sex John Freeman points men to Christ and the power of the gospel to change our affections as the only real hope for lasting change.Freeman divides those who struggle  with sexual sin up into three categories: God-Haters, Idol-Makers, and Game-Players. A God-Hater is someone who constantly gives in to sexual sin and begins to feel that God is not able to or never will "do anything redemptive about it all." This person can begin to reject some of God's attributes like his omniscience, not wanting "to acknowledge that he sees not only what we do, but also what we think and desire in our hearts - things no one else knows." If we are not quick to run to Christ and recognize the power of His forgiveness to change us then we will begin to hate this aspect of God.  The next group Freeman discusses are Idol-Makers. Idol-Makers are those who turn to something other than God whenever the stress and anxiety of life are turned up. Where do we run to for comfort or stress release when things are tough. If it is to some sexual sin then we have an idolatry problem.  The last group Freeman discusses are the Game-Players. This group looks like they have it all together and may be on the surface fruitful in their ministry at church and at home. But, they are actually just playing a game.From here Freeman points each group to Christ. We must know the power of the gospel in our lives, we must know what our status is before God and we must know that He doesn't intend to leaves us in the pit of sexual sin. When we sin so often we begin to look at our "record" before God and feel as if the gap is too large, the distance to great for us to be able to come to Him and enjoy intimate fellowship. We must recognize the truth of our justification at this point or we will just be driven further from God and further into sexual sin. In Christ, we are forgiven, and that means that God looks at us and sees Christ's righteousness. Help is found here and in the context of community at church. Isolation will not help with sexual sin. We must be joined together with other sinners who may sin differently but nonetheless recognize our status in Christ and His ability to change from the inside-out.I found this book to be a very encouraging look at sexual sin for men. Instead of giving them a hefty to do list that will only add one more burden, Freeman points men to Christ early and often as He is the only one capable of producing lasting change and victory over sexual sin. I received a copy of this book from New Growth Press in exchange for an honest review.

The Christ-Centered Exposition Commentary Series is a new commentary series from Holman Reference edited by David Platt, Daniel Akin and Tony Merida.  The editor's goal is "to present an easy reading, practical and friendly commentary" and "to exalt Jesus from every book of the Bible."  In the introduction the editors lay out four distinguishing characteristics for the series.They are:1) This series seeks to display exegetical accuracy. The desire is to handle God's Word faithfully, even while every volume may not be verse-by-verse commentary.2) The series has busy pastors in view by presenting its material in a readable, pastoral style rather than academic.3) A desire to be known for the "inclusion of helpful illustrations and theological driven applications.4) To exalt Christ in every book of the Bible. They carefully state that, "we are not commending wild allegory or fanciful typology.  We must be constrained to the meaning intended by the divine Author Himself, the Holy Spirit of God.  However, we also believe that the Bible has a Messianic focus, and the authors in this series will exalt Christ from all of their texts."Some of the authors that will contribute to this series that is projected to be 48 volumes are: David Platt, Daniel Akin, Tony Merida, Al Mohler, Eric Mason, Mark Dever, Russ Moore, Matt Chandler, Francis Chan, Thabiti Anyabwile, J.D. Greear and Paige Patterson.  This is a very respectable list of pastors and authors to contribute to this series.Exalting Jesus in 1 & 2 Thessalonians by Mark Howell will definitely serve as a useful resource for the pastor/teacher or lay-person.  Each section first presents the "Main Idea" of the text.  This is what the author see as the main point that the biblical author is trying to convey in the text.  Next a brief outline is provided to give the reader a visual of the flow of the passage at hand.  After this is the main section, the exposition.  Here Howell provides a very nice clear, concise exposition of the text.  This isn't a commentary that is going to dig deep into the languages or sentence structure but rather reads much more like a devotional commentary.  Each section ends with questions to help solidify what was just read into the reader's mind.The greatest benefit to these commentaries is their readability and keeping the main idea as the main focal point of the commentary.  An example of this can be seen in 1 Thessalonians 4:13-18. While I disagree with the conclusion Howell comes to regarding Christ second coming and his pretrib, premill view, he makes sure that this is not his focal point.  Howell points the reader to the fact that "Paul teaches them to look back and be grateful for what Jesus has done and to look ahead and be hopeful for what Jesus is going to do."  His commentary on the Thessalonians being uniformed is helpful as well. Howell states that "Paul clearly reveals that their grief and hopelessness was the direct result of their failure to understand death from God's perspective." From here Howell moves into his particular eschatological view, but he makes sure that he addresses it as a secondary issue and is not dogmatic about it.  This makes the commentary beneficial to readers of a different view point as they will be able to still glean overall truths from his commentary.I have now read multiple volumes in this series and each has been a blessing. This is one of the most accessible commentaries that I have come across.  I was blessed by this commentary and found it very helpful and look forward to future volumes in this series.  Overall, excellent work! I received a free copy of this book from B&H Publishing Group (Holman Reference) in exchange for an honest review.

Early on in my Christian life I was introduced to Martyn Lloyd-Jones in his book Studies on the Sermon on the Mount.  I was taken in by the way in which he preached and how it translated into written form. He spoke in a way that was doctrinally deep, engaging and understandable. Over the course of the years my fondness for Lloyd-Jones remains as I find him helpful every time I read his work. For this reason I am thankful to Crossway for publishing Experiencing the New Birth: Studies in John 3, 24 previously unreleased sermons on John 3.Lloyd-Jones is very well known for his exposition.  He may be unmatched in this area throughout the entire history of the Church. John 3 is a vital chapter of the Bible. Being born again should be a topic that does not grow old for us and we must also realize the depths that this truth really has.  It is not a thought to be brushed past lightly but rather one to meditate on deeply.  Lloyd-Jones' exposition will provide the resource to do just that. His exposition is always helpful and coming to a better understanding of God's Word.  Anyone who is looking to study John 3 would do well to purchase this book. Crossway has done the church well by publishing these previously unpublished sermons.I received a digital copy of this book from Crossway in exchange for an honest review.

Preaching With Accuracy by Randy Pelton is a helpful book for pastors to find the main idea of a text and then apply it appropriately.  As Pelton states, " the first skill is the ability to identify the dominant meaning of a preaching portion....the second skill is the ability to follow the language or concepts in a preaching portion to the gospel. Having arrived at the gospel, the preacher is able to show how God-in-Christ-through-the-Spirit makes the preaching portion mean something for the Church."  Both of these skills are vitally important. A pastor/teacher must be able to identify the big idea of a text as well as know how and where it fits into the grand theme of Scripture.Preaching With Accuracy begins with one of the more important questions with regard to preaching: Does Exposition Still Work?  Pelton is clear that is we answer 'no' to this question then there is no need to explore how to preach with greater accuracy.  There is plenty of topical preaching in American Christianity and I am thankful that Pelton stated his view of the supremacy of expositional preaching clearly and upfront. Next, Pelton works with the reader in finding the main idea of a text and how to differentiate between the main idea and other smaller ideas that may be present as well.  This is important because if we miss the main idea of a passage then we miss what God was intending to communicate through the author.  We can "park on" and communicate a small truth but miss the main point of the passage.Pelton continues throughout the book to guide the reader into a better understanding of how to approach the preaching portion.  I found the book to be very helpful and a nice blend of many other books on preaching that I have read.  Pelton provides many examples for the reader to practice as ideas are presented.  This is helpful in that it gives the reader a guideline for the text and then a practical example to try.  There are even blank spaces for the reader to fill in his thoughts, rather than just reading what Pelton found in the text and then moving on. Overall, I found the book to be quite helpful and will definitely use it as a reference in the future.I received a copy of this book from Kregel Academic & Ministry in exchange for an honest review.

Marriage is difficult. Placing two sinners in the same living quarters and having them structure their lives around each other can be problematic.  Thankfully, none of this caught God off guard. He planned marriage to be a reflection of the love that His Son has for the Church. A marriage with Christ as the center is what God intends and in the When Sinners Say I Do Video Series with Dave Harvey takes the viewers through 8 sessions to explore what Scripture says in relation to building a healthy marriage.  Drawing from 20 plus years of pastoral experience and 32 years of marriage Harvey is an excellent source for wisdom in how to relate to one another.Each sessions is around 20 minutes long with some topics covering two sessions.  The session topics are: Sin Part 1, Sin Part 2, Design, Contentment, Mercy Part 1, Mercy Part 2, Sex and Stubborn Grace.  These sessions are Word centered with Harvey working from multiple text throughout the sessions.  The text of Scripture as well as other quotes that Harvey uses are shown on screen with him and show up very nicely on the blue background.  The style of this DVD is simple, but it works well. These sessions have been a blessing to my wife and I so far and I am sure they will continue to be in the future. This would be a great resource for Pastors to use in counseling or small group settings.One note: In one of the sessions when talking about the prodigal son Harvey paraphrases by saying he spent his money on hookers.  I felt that this was unnecessary and it reminded me of so many younger pastors who feel the need to be crude or shocking to make their point. It didn't fit well with the overall lesson and was not the norm for Harvey in these sessions.I received a copy of this DVD from Shepherd Press via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

Sadly, we all have blind spots in our lives.  Areas that we do not see as we ought to, as Christ did.  What is even more sad is often times we see other believers who are gifted different than we are as the enemy.  We seek out the negative instead of the positive and focus on it.  So, instead of being a unified church doing kingdom work we can quickly become divided and hinder our witness to the world.  In Blind Spots: Becoming a Courageous, Compassionate and Commissioned Church, Collin Hansen defines three different types of Christians and examines both the strengths and weaknesses of each group.The classifications that Hansen uses are: Courageous, Compassionate and Commissioned.  In the Foreword Tim Keller provides a helpful overview of these classifications.  He states, "The 'courage' group stands valiantly for the truth; the 'compassion' people stress service, listening, and engagement; while the 'commissioned' folks are all about building up the church and reaching the lost. Once things are broken down like that, it becomes clear that these should be strands in a single cord. Each group goes bad to the degree it distances itself from the others." It is along this line of thinking that Hansen explores these three groups, examining the strengths and weaknesses of each.  If a church can become unified around Christ and the gospel and recognize that each member of the body will be gifted differently by God then it can keep from becoming warped and having blind spots where it neglects one' of these areas.  The chart below breaks down these three groupings with positive characteristics listed in yellow and blind spots in greenHansen says that "we talk a lot about church unity. So where is the evidence that we actually want it?...You lament the divided church, yet you're quick to speak about the problems you see with other believers."  I know this is so true in my life.  It is so much easier to write-off other believers than to actually take the time and effort to get to know them as a brother or sister in Christ.  We can so often treat our Christian family as if they are the enemy. The solution is to compare ourselves to Christ instead of comparing other believers to ourselves. As Hansen states, "When you and I compare ourselves to Christ, we get unity because we see our sin and forgive one another as God forgave us....When you and I compare ourselves to Christ, we're more impressed with the grace he lavished on us than with our own contributions to the kingdom."Ultimately looking at Jesus as our example is the solution to our blind spots. As Hansen says, "Almost everyone loves something about Jesus. Some of us love his courage to endure the scorn and shame of the cross. Others love his compassion to associate with sinners and liberate the oppressed. Still more love his compassion for the disciples to heal the sick and cast out demonic spirits. It's harder, though, to love the real Jesus who does all this and more, then calls us to follow in his steps. We often seize on one aspect of his character and ministry and brandish it as a weapon against other believers." The call of this book is to recognize different believer's giftings as from God and to work together to further the advance of the gospel. To do this we must first, examine our lives and our hearts to see what blind spots we have, repent and love our brothers and sisters in Christ.You can check out a free excerpt of Blind Spots here.I received a copy of this book from Crossway in exchange for an honest review.

The One O'Clock Miracle: A True Story About Trusting the Words of Jesus is a new children's book written by Alison Mitchell and Illustrated by Catalina Echeverri.  This book tells the account of Jesus healing the officials son found in John 4:46-54.  The retelling of the story is done in a way that is sure to grab and keep the attention of young minds.  It is a sad truth that many "Christian" children's books simply cannot be trusted to be faithful to the text. However, The One O'Clock Miracle is biblically faithful and turns young minds to the wonderful story of a man who trusted the words of Christ. That is certainly a truth that we as Christians parents should want to place before our children.The artwork is very well done and compliments the story very well.  The pictures are well done, colorful and full of detail.  They really do add to the story in a way that shows that time and attention to detail was put into the illustration of this book.  In a time when the book market can sometimes seem to be flooded with sub-par books for children, The One O'Clock Miracle will be quite a blessing to families looking for a quality book that will entertain their children and teach them the truths of God's Word.I received a copy of this book from The Good Book Company via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review

The Reformation Commentary on Scripture is a wonderful commentary series that lets the reader see first hand how Scripture was interpreted during the Reformation time period.  This volume provides its reader with a vast array of well known, not so well known, and probably unknown commentators on Luke's Gospel.  The work by the project staff that has gone into pulling all of the information together is truly commendable and a great gift to the modern day church.  In the introduction Timothy George, the General Editor, list four goals of this series.  They are:1) The enrichment of contemporary biblical interpretation through exposure to Reformation-era biblical exegesis.2) The renewal of contemporary preaching through exposure to the biblical insights of the Reformation writers.3) A deeper understanding of the Reformation itself and the breadth of perspectives represented within it.4) The recovery of the robust spiritual theology and devotional treasures of the Reformation's engagement with the Bible.This commentary on Luke accomplishes each of these goals.The commentary is presented in a very easy to follow way.  I was very curious about how it would flow, given the vast amount of contributors in it.  I must say that I was pleasantly surprised both by the content and the ease of knowing who the original author was and the source that it came out of.  Each section begins with a passage of Scripture with a given title (i.e. Luke 11:14-26 Jesus and His Power Over Demons). The Scripture is from the ESV and is double column and italicized across the top of the page.  Each section of Scripture then has an Overview section, which gives a summary of the thoughts that follow.  Each topic in the passage is identified by a bold font making it easy to scan through the sections.  Each commentary section begins with the author (i.e. John Calvin) in all caps and is followed directly by the commentary on the section and ends with the reference (i.e. Commentary on a Harmony of the Gospels).  The order that is provided by this layout is very beneficial to the reader for a variety of reasons:1) It allows the reader to clearly identify who the Reformation author is and from what writing this excerpt came from.2) If the reader is scanning through the commentary with the intent of finding a particular passage the bold font and headings makes it easy to quickly find the passage you are looking for3) It is easy to compare how different writers of the Reformation chose to comment and expound on the Scripture passage.4) The original reference makes it easy to follow up by consulting the original source, if available.I was pleasantly surprised and thrilled to "meet" many new voices from the Reformation period through this commentary.  I was also blessed by the short biographical sketch in the back of the volume that gives the reader a short introduction to those writers he may not be familiar with.  There is also an eleven page timeline of the Reformation in the back of this volume that is an excellent historical resource.I cannot express again how wonderfully smooth this commentary reads while at the same time keeping the original authors voices.  The reader doesn't get what the editor thinks Calvin, Luther etc. said about a text but instead they get the authors own words.  It is truly commendable what the editors have done in bringing together all of these voices.  Instead of having to flip from commentary to commentary, or browse the internet the reader can simply read through the section and have a wonderful flow to their study.  Also, many of the original writings may not be accessible the way some of the more well known writers are.  I am truly blessed by this commentary and feel that it would be a great addition to both pastors and lay-persons libraries.I received a free copy of this commentary from IVP Academic in exchange for an honest review.

We live in a restless world.  People constantly shift jobs, houses, churches....you name it and we move from what we hold sacred now to something completely different in just a short time.  We shouldn't be surprised when this happens in the world, but the problem that Michael Horton addresses in Ordinary is when this restlessness creeps into the church.The world is always after the next big thing. What was popular last month, or sometimes even last week quickly gets sidelined by what is popular now.  The sporting world is a prime example.  The new, young, hot athlete makes headlines and everyone begins to follow his every move and quickly forgets about the guy that was new, and young last week.  The problem with this creeping into Christianity is that it leaves believers chasing after the next big ministry opportunity or church movement instead of faithfully chugging along where God has placed them.  We can quickly come to the wrong conclusion that God only uses Christian "rock stars" and has no need of the Christian plumber in small town America. And so, the Christian plumber is not content serving God where God has placed him and longs for something new and different. The truth is that God has all types of people in all types of places for His glory and for our good.  Horton continually points the reader to this truth to counteract the restlessness that we can all feel at times.Horton expresses this seeking after the next big thing well by stating,  "The regular preaching of Christ from all of the Scriptures, baptism, the Supper, the prayers of confession and praise, and all of the other aspects of ordinary Christian fellowship are seen as too ordinary." Horton is also on point when he describes how so many view church. He says, "We choose a local church the way we chose a neighborhood, a phone company, or a new car. We might become a member, or we might not. There may not even be membership (since that would be too formal and interfere with a person's relationship with Christ). Instead church leaders will bend over backwards to make sure people (at least the right people) are happy, because they know that you can go to the church down the highway, one that has a wider menu of options." Sadly, Horton is dead on with one of the major problems in American Christianity and that is consumerism.Horton is engaging and on point with his arguments and reasoning. I have come to love reading Horton and he is on the top of his game in Ordinary.  I highly recommend this to all believers, especially those who may lead what they feel to be rather ordinary lives.  There are shifts in church culture constantly and we would do well to ground our faith in the One who never changes rather than in what is new and current.  Horton points the reader to the One who brings "sustainable faith in a radical, restless world."I received a copy of this book from Zondervan in exchange for an honest review.

Books on evangelism come in many different shades.  One can quickly find a book that implements a system of questions to present to everyone which can often times result in cold evangelism that lacks a personal side.  On the other end of the spectrum one can find books that tell the reader to just "share their story" or "live the Gospel." This approach confuses ones testimony with the Gospel and can lean so heavily on relationships that we spend more time just being friends with people and forget to get around to the good news.  The first group can often times offend people, but not with the Gospel, but rather their approach. The second group hardly ever offends anyone, one reason is because the good news is watered-down and disguised so it doesn't offend.  What we need is what Rico Tice presents in Honest Evangelism.From the very beginning Tice reminds the reader that we are sent out as "sheep among wolves" and if we accurately and consistently share the Gospel with people we are going to get hurt.  There will be people who don't like us because the message of Christ will offend them.  We can and must expect this and yet still move forward in love to share the Gospel regardless of the cost.  In Chapter Two Tice ask and answers a very important question: Is It Worth It?  The three truths that Tice presents as fuel for evangelism are 1) The glory of Jesus 2) The guarantee of a new creation and 3) The grim reality of death and hell.  These are excellent motivations.  So often we can be motivated by guilt rather than these three points and Tice makes sure that we begin this book on evangelism with the right frame of mind.To combat our fear or the thought that we must save people Tice reminds the reader of three valuable truths: 1) God is Sovereign 2) God is Gracious and 3) God is Powerful.  If these are true (and the are) then God is capable of saving people through the presentation of the Gospel by His grace and power.  This frees us to share the Gospel with others and trust God with the results.  I found Tice's book to be highly encouraging.  It is pointed in the fact that the reader can't escape seeing the need to evangelize and yet it is gracious, not guilt-tripping the reader into evangelizing.  I would highly recommend this book alongside others like Evangelism by Mack Stiles and Tell the Truth by Will Metzger.I received a copy of this book from The Good Book Company via Cross Focused Reviews.

Who Is Jesus? by Greg Gilbert is a new release with a title that poses a question that is worth everyone's consideration.  Was Jesus God, man, a good teacher, a moral example.....?  Anyone who is honest with themselves and is thoughtful should want to search out what Jesus claimed about Himself and if these claims are valid.  Gilbert writes in a way that is engaging for believer and unbeliever alike.  For the believer this short book will both encourage and provide a resource.  For the unbeliever, "give Jesus a chance. It may be that as you learn more about him, you’ll realize that there are actually some very good reasons for believing what he said—about himself, about God, and about you."Gilbert works through some of Jesus' major claims in this book to show that He is indeed God. For instance, "Jesus said things like, “I and the Father [by which he meant God] are one,” and, “If you have seen me, you have seen the Father.” And, maybe most shocking of all, “No one comes to the Father except through me.” You see what I mean? Ordinary people don’t say those sorts of things! God and I are one? No one comes to God except by me? Those aren’t ethical teachings that you can decide to incorporate into your life or not. They are claims. They are Jesus saying what he thinks is the truth."  Gilbert continues: Jesus’s reply to that question rocked them. He said, “Truly, truly, I say to you, before Abraham was, I AM.”There’s that name again, and Jesus’s use of it was deliberate and confrontational. How do we know that? Because otherwise what he said is simply bad grammar. Even if Jesus just wanted to say that he pre-existed Abraham somehow, he would have said, “Before Abraham was, I was.” But by using the present tense—“I AM”—Jesus was clearly taking for himself, again, the unique and exclusive name of God. That’s why they picked up stones in order to stone him. If he wasn’t really God—and they didn’t think he was—then he had committed the worst kind of blasphemy." Claims like these make the case that Jesus was just an ordinary man, moral example, and never claimed to be God a little hard to hold on to.The ultimate purpose of studying to find out who Jesus is is tied into His death and resurrection. It is here that Gilbert is truly excellent.  He shows man's sinfulness, man's need for a Savior, what Christ came to do and what His death and resurrection secure for the believer.  Gilbert clearly says, "Jesus didn’t come only to show us authentic, God-intended humanness. No, Jesus became human because we needed him to do so. We needed someone to represent us before God and be our substitute. That’s ultimately why Jesus came—to be a loving Warrior King who would save his beloved people."  AMEN.  Our desperate need is only met in Christ, a truth that Gilbert clearly delivers to the reader.Gilbert closes his book with a statement that is worth closing this review with: "I hope that in reading this book, you’ve realized that if nothing else, that isn’t a question that can be nicely ignored. Whatever you wind up thinking about Jesus, the fact remains that he makes strong, even invasive claims about you and your relationship to God. Sure, you can ignore those claims—you can ignore anything if you try hard enough—but when somebody says, “You are a rebel against the God who made you, and his sentence against you is death. But I have come to stand in your place, to take that penalty, and to save you,” that’s something you probably should pay attention to."  A claim worth investigating, as eternity is at stake.If you are a believer buy this book so that you will have an excellent resource to engage with unbelieving friends.  If you are an unbeliever buy this book and spend a few hours with it, and see if Jesus is worth the attention that Christians seem to give Him.I received a digital copy of this book from Crossway in exchange for an honest review.

A few months ago I began teaching a Sunday School class through Romans 8.  Over the course of the study we have often times "parked" for a week on a key word or phrase and discussed it in the attempt to better understand what Paul is saying.  I think this has been helpful, but one risk is that we can get so focused on individual words that we miss the big picture.  To guard against this I usually try to remember the big themes from chapter eight as well as the entire book.  This helps me set my vision on Paul's overall picture and how the present text relates to it.Around the same time that this teaching started I also received a copy of Grace Has Come: Songs From the Book of Romans by Sovereign Grace Music.  I love the Book of Romans so I was eager to see how they were able to transfer it to song.  After listening through it roughly 15-20 times I must say that the breadth and depth of lyrics are amazing.  The great themes of Romans show up in every song and for anyone who is relatively familiar with Paul's letter will recognize the flow of the album through the book of Romans.  Songs like Grace and Peace provide memorable verses like:Grace and peace, oh how can this beThe matchless King of allPaid the blood price for meSlaughtered lamb, what atonement You bring!The vilest sinner's heartCan be cleansed, can be freeOh, what an amazing mysteryWhat an amazing mysteryThat Your grace has come to meAfter a few listens through I found myself humming these words, and many others like these to myself. One of the great things about music is its ability to become memorable rather quickly.With so many options available for Christians as it relates to music these days, I think it is a blessing to have Sovereign Grace Music and their desire to promote God-honoring, Bible-saturated lyrics.  As I listen through this album over and over again the great themes of Romans start to rattle around in my mind and that is a very good thing!  Modern music styles and theologically rich lyrics are a rare combination, it seems, but Sovereign Grace Music has delivered just that combination in this album. I highly recommend it.I received a digital copy of this album from Sovereign Grace Music in exchange for an honest review.

One of the great perks to reviewing books is the opportunity to come across books/resources that otherwise I would have been completely unaware of.  Such is the case with Why Christmas? by Barbara Reaoch. This family devotional is intended to be used for the month of December leading up to Christmas Day.The lay out of the devotion is quite simple and effective.  Each day begins with a Scripture passage or two followed by a short section that explains the passage.  I found these "Listen" sections to be written in a clear, concise manner.  The points being made about Scripture are written well for young ears.  The next section "Truth" is a short summary sentence that provides a truth about Christ.  The "Discuss" section allows for interaction between parent/child.  Here parents are provided short questions to engage their children with.  The "Memorize" section works through a passage of Scripture to memorize over the course of the week.  The last section "Sing" allows for a time to sing as a family.  Each week has one Christmas hymn to sing which is provided in the back of the book.  These hymns are: "Hark! the Herald Angels Sing", "Angels, From the Realms of Glory", O Little Town of Bethlehem", and Silent Night, Holy Night."  As a family who enjoys singing I was pleased to see these songs added in.  Each daily devotional also has a picture to accompany it.  The artwork is nice, though feels a little outdated, but this isn't a huge deal to me, just worth noting.Overall, I think this devotional could be very beneficial to my family as my young children get older, as well as any family who is looking for helpful resources in pointing their children to God.I received a copy of this book from Shepherd Press via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

One of the great perks to reviewing books is the opportunity to come across books/resources that otherwise I would have been completely unaware of.  Such is the case with Why Easter? by Barbara Reaoch. This family devotional is intended to be used for four weeks leading up to Easter Sunday.The lay out of the devotion is quite simple and effective.  Each day begins with a Scripture passage or two followed by a short section that explains the passage.  I found these "Listen" sections to be written in a clear, concise manner.  The points being made about Scripture are written well for young ears.  The next section "Truth" is a short summary sentence that provides a truth about Christ.  The "Discuss" section allows for interaction between parent/child.  Here parents are provided short questions to engage their children with.  The "Memorize" section works through a passage of Scripture to memorize over the course of the week.  The last section "Sing" allows for a time to sing as a family.  Each week has one hymn to sing which is provided in the back of the book.  These Hymns are: When I Survey the Wondrous Cross", Man of Sorrows! What a Name", "Up From the Grace he Arose", and "Thine Be The Glory."  As a family who enjoys singing I was pleased to see these songs added in.  Each daily devotional also has a picture to accompany it.  The artwork is nice, though feels a little outdated, but this isn't a huge deal to me, just worth noting.Overall, I think this devotional could be very beneficial to my family as my young children get older, as well as any family who is looking for helpful resources in pointing their children to God.I received a copy of this book from Shepherd Press via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

Four Spiritual Laws, Five Steps, Romans Road.....while well intentioned and packed with truth many times these forms of evangelism can come across as cold and robotic. Often times, though not the intent, the person being witnessed to can feel more like a project and less like a person who we are interested in getting to know. The Unbelievable Gospel: Say Something Worth Believing by Jonathan Dodson is a new book that seeks to give a fresh look at evangelism and some of these methods.Dodson states that "though it is unintentional, 'modern' forms of evangelism have generated gospel witness that is impersonal, preachy, intolerant, and uninformed about the real questions people ask. These encounters can result in not much witness to the gospel at all. such repeated experiences create a distaste for evangelism, not only in the mouths of non-Christians but also among Christians." From personal experience I would certainly say that this rings true.  Often times formal evangelism is received as a sales pitch, where taking the time to interact with people and engage them with the gospel is received better, even if repentance and faith are not the response of the person being witnessed to. We must never change the gospel message, but we must be aware of how we are presenting the gospel. As Dodson says, "the pressure we feel to share the gospel doesn't translate into the loving concern we may genuinely have for them. Instead, our compulsion bleeds through, coming across as a pressure sale, and people feel like a means to an end, a project. Even when what we ay is true and we have good intentions, the way we say it can make people wish we weren't talking."
