Again, DO NOT CHANGE THE MESSAGE, but are we presenting the gospel as the good news that it is or as a sales pitch or something we feel guilty about not doing, so we etch out some formal time once a week/month to do it in.Dodson spends the first two parts of the book dealing with these types of reasons that make evangelism burdensome for us and the unbeliever and then re-centers our eyes on the gospel. Dodson's understanding of the shortfalls of these methods is to be commended. It is here, though, that I must address my issues with the book.  In seeking to correct these "methods" Dodson seems to over-correct and lean almost solely on friendship evangelism.  I think I know what he is trying to say, the landscape of our world has shifted and we as Christians need to recognize this and seek out ways to engage people, I just think he does a poor job of saying it.  I also, did not like the terms Gospel Metaphors as ways to share the gospel.  Those "metaphors" being: acceptance, hope, intimacy, tolerance and approval.  A Metaphor is "a word or phrase for one thing that is used to refer to another thing in order to show or suggest that they are similar." (http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/metaphor) The problem is that Dodson speaks of metaphors like acceptance (justification) but these are not metaphors for the gospel they are outcomes of the gospel.  The gospel is what God has done on the Cross through Christ in punishing the sins of His people so that they may be brought back into a right relationship with Him.  The outcome of the gospel story is that we are accepted, have hope, intimacy, tolerance and approval.  These are truths, but they are not the gospel. Failure to communicate the gospel and instead focus on these "metaphors" can very easily turn evangelism into a man centered activity rather than a proclamation of what God has done. The danger can be to seek out what our hearer is missing in their life and then fill the gap with God.  God isn't a gap filler though, He is a Sovereign King. It is here that the books falls short for me.  Dodson recognizes the shift in our culture, and for that he is to be commended, but his approach to the shift left something to be desired.For a better picture of biblical evangelism I would recommend Tell the Truth by Will Metzger or Evangelism by Mack Stiles.I received a copy of this book from Zondervan in exchange for an honest review.

Every year as Easter approaches there are new resources that are released to point to the work that Christ did on the cross to secure the salvation of His people. One of the perks of reviewing books is receiving some of these books that I may have otherwise never read.  Heaven, How I Got Here: The Story of the Thief on the Cross by Colin Smith is one of those books.The interaction between the thief on the cross and Christ is well known in Christianity.  It is a picture of grace and mercy that reaches to even the hardened criminal who puts his faith in Christ.  Colin Smith has written a gripping account of the thief looking back from heaven to his time on the cross.  Smith writes in a way that grabs the readers attention and emotions from the start, and even knowing how the story ends I never wanted to put the book down.  Smith tells the story of the day in the life of the thief, beginning with the start of the day, knowing that he was going to die that day, to the unlikely end, with Christ for the rest of eternity.Truths from Scripture are sprinkled throughout the book, as the thief, now in Heaven knows much more about the revelation of God than he did that day on the cross.  Smith tells the story wonderfully and many times throughout I paused to reflect on the fact that the grace and shed blood that was sufficient for the thief's salvation was also sufficient enough for me, and one day I will share in the glory that he is already enjoying.  Buy this book. Read it and share it.  An interesting point of view from a well known story and one that is sure to fill every reader's heart with amazement at the grace of God.Heaven, How I Got Here is an incredibly powerful story that will be a blessing to all who read it. I highly recommend it.I received a copy of this book from Christian Focus via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

Preaching is a job that carries a world of weight with it.  The pastor is to stand before the people and confidently say "thus says the Lord" which means that he better know that is really what God says.  Sadly, many preachers in western Christianity do not take this charge seriously, which makes it all the more crucial for those who recognize and understand this responsibility to craft their sermons in such a way that reflects God's intention when He authored it.  Enter Unashamed Workmen: How Expositors Prepare to Preach. A new book edited by Rhett Dodson that opens the doors to 10 pastor's study habits as they prepare to be a faithful expositor of the Bible.Timothy is charged by Paul to "Study to shew thyself approved unto God, a workman that needeth not to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth" and as Dodson states, "Paul's injunction to Timothy sets the agenda for every pastor devoted to proclaiming the whole counsel of God. Preaching presupposes study, and diligent study is nothing if not the exertion of deliberate effort to understand the meaning and purpose of every passage of Scripture in its context."  Preparation is vital.  One of God's chief means to edify His church is through the preaching of the Word, so those that preach ought to take the role seriously.Ao one who enjoys study and teaching I cannot begin to describe how much of a blessing this book was for me.  The opportunity to peek into the study habits of 10 seasoned pastors was a great blessing to me and will certainly be for all who read it.  I was encouraged to read how these men thought through their preparation. Even when coming to differing views (i.e. how many commentaries to read in preparation) their reasoning was laid out, which made it easy to see which style of study best fit my own and then glean wisdom from them.  After each pastor walks through their preparation a text to a sermon is provided.  I found this helpful in that I could look for how the study habits were applied to a particular sermon instead of guessing how it all would come together.This is not a text book on sermon preparation, and is not trying to be. Rather, it is a window into the study habits of 10 pastors as they study and craft their sermons. I was truly blessed by this book as it helped me to evaluate my study patterns and to recognize that there is no one right way to study. A high esteem for the Word of God and rightly handling it and presenting it to the people is a must, but Pastors can always reflect on how they reach this end and seek to improve their study methods all for the glory of God and the building up of His church.I received a copy of this book from Christian Focus in exchange for an honest review.

I really appreciate and enjoy the New Studies in Biblical Theology series published by IVP Academic. I find many of the areas of theology covered intriguing, and appreciate the authors attempts to span the scope of Scripture to communicate the biblical teaching on the subject. With that being said, they aren't always the easiest books to read, and therefore are not accessible to the broader church as some more intermediate works may be. For this reason I was pleased to recently receive God Dwells Among Us: Expanding Eden to the Ends of the Earth. "The substance and basic thesis of the book is distilled from G.K. Beale, The Temple and the Church's Mission: A Biblical Theology of the Dwelling Place of God [in the New Studies in Biblical Theology Series]." Beale and Kim have worked together to provide a more accessible version of the aforementioned book and have really succeeded in doing so.Why should learning about God's presence with his people be such a big deal for us? "God's presence brings life and light. Since true life and sustenance are found in the presence of God, we must regularly drink deeply from the river of his delights." Therefore, we ought to desire to know what Scripture teaches about God's work to dwell with man. This is where Beale and Kim trace God's presence from Adam through the patriarchs to Christ and ultimately His eschatological dwelling with his people.I found Beale and Kim's examination of how God met with the patriarchs in small sanctuary settings to be very insightful in the continuing of God's dwelling with Adam and his commission to fill the earth.  They state in summary, "The patriarchs Abraham, Isaac and Jacob receive the Adamic commission in direct connection with the building of small sanctuaries. Just as the Genesis 1:28 commission was initially to be carried out by Adam in the sanctuary of Eden, so this commission is passed down to Israel's patriarchs and begins to be fulfilled in a small sanctuary." Beale and Kim trace this idea through scriptural example of God meeting with man in a way that is quite helpful in seeing the continuity of this idea throughout Scripture.Ultimately, God's presence with his people leads us to the incarnation, crucifixion and resurrection where Christ commissions the church as his temple.  Christ's "death and resurrection launched the temple of the new creation, which Christ expands through bringing believers into that temple. As more believers become part of this temple, the temple expands, and will continue to do so until Christ's final coming. At that time, the temple will be expanded to cover the entire new and consummated cosmos for eternity." Beale and Kim continue by focusing on worship and the glory of God, "The parallels between the creation of the tabernacle and creation of the heavens and the earth remind us of the ultimate purpose of the tabernacle: to fill the entire heavens and earth with the consummate, end time glory of God. The tabernacle not only teaches us worship and how sinners can come into the presence of a holy God; the tabernacle reminds us of the mission of the tabernacle to expand and filled the entire earth with the eschatological glory of God. The goal of worship is mission, to expand the dwelling place of God until it fills the entire earth that God will create for all eternity." How humbling and exciting to be a part of God's work in bringing his people to himself who will one day fill the entire new creation as we worship him.Beale and Kim really drive home the point of the centrality of Christ by saying, "The locus of God's presence shifts from the Jerusalem temple to the person of Jesus so that he is the continuation of the true temple....The Spirit creates a link with heaven through trusting Christ, and this trust brings them into the sphere of the true temple consisting of Christ and his Spirit. Worship in the true temple would no longer be geographically located in Jerusalem but in Christ....Jesus inaugurates a new creation as a true latter-day Adam, since he is inaugurating and expanding a new eschatological temple, which the first Adam should have done in the beginning of the first creation. Likewise, Jesus does what old Israel failed to do, which included establishing and widening the temple of God's presence to bring in the nations."I was tremendously blessed by this book and highly recommend it. I would especially recommend it to those who may have difficulty seeing the continuity of Scripture because their theological system stresses discontinuity. This book is a blessing in that it communicates a weighty idea into a form that is quite accessible.

God's presence is a crucial aspect of Scripture and critical to the life of the believer. The Presence of God by J. Ryan Lister is a new release that provides the church with a wonderful biblical theology tracing the theme of God's presence throughout Scripture that shows the unity of Scripture and its Christ-centeredness.Lister explains his desire for the book by stating the following: What I hope to help impress upon us all is that the presence of God is not about mere intuitions and platitudes. It is not a mystical feeling or emotional charge. It is first and foremost a theme of Scripture; and even more, it is a theme on which the story of Scripture hinges. To demonstrate this, I want to make one major argument in this book that rests on two very simple but very significant biblical truths. The first truth is this: the presence of God is a central goal in God’s redemptive mission. The second truth follows: the presence of God is the agent by which the Lord accomplishes his redemptive mission. God’s presence, then, is both eschatological (it is the end-of-time aim of the Lord’s mission) and instrumental (it is ultimately what fulfills the Lord’s mission). So to put our argument in its simplest terms, the presence of God is a fundamental objective in our redemption and, simultaneously, the means by which God completes this objective.This short statement provides a perfect summary of what this book unpacks.  Lister is brilliant in his examination of Scripture and the theme of God's presence.  This work by Lister is a true blessing to the church and a work that I will surely reference for years to come.I received a digital copy of this book from Crossway in exchange for an honest review.

The Reformed Expository Commentary is a series that aims to provide a fresh exposition of the Biblical text for today's generation.  In the series introduction the series editors (Phil Ryken & Richard Phillips) lay out the four fundamental commitments in this series.  They are:1) To be biblical - that is to pay careful attention to the text and exposit the Scriptures.  There is less  focus on the original language and structure and more focus on the story that the passage is telling.2) Unashamedly Doctrinal - this series approaches the text from a Reformed perspective, as found in the Bible.3) Redemptive-Historical - this means that they believe in the unity and continuity of the Bible, and interpret it in a Christ centered approach for all of Scripture.4) Practical - by applying the truths found in the Scriptures to contemporary challenges in life.Aesthetically this commentary looks great on the shelf.  While this isn't a huge selling point, and certainly not a reason to chose one commentary over another, I must say that this one looks really nice on the bookshelf, especially when you have more than one in the series.Daniel Doriani provides the commentary on 1 Peter in a recently released contribution to the series.  I found Doriani's writing style to be quite readable, almost reading as a devotional commentary on Scripture.  His engagement with the text and flow into practical application were quite beneficial for me.  I was especially blessed by his treatment of 1 Peter 3:1-7.  Here much is said about wives that does not fit well with our current society.  To that Doriani says, "We can't dismiss Peter's message as a temporary command, a concession, or an adaption to the times that the church would outgrow. The message of Scripture always transcends it's occasion. Furthermore, the text has no hint that it is temporary counsel." Our understanding of Scripture cannot be dictated by the current times.  Neither can it be dictated by abusing and misuses of Scripture.  To this thought Doriani is helpful as well as he states that "Sadly, men have a fueled the critics by abusing their God-given authority and physical strength. If husbands loved their wives as they should, this passage would not be controversial. It is controversial, yet we will not read Peter accurately if we let contemporary gender debates become our lens for interpretation. It is better to acknowledge our preferences and let Scripture test them (1 Thess. 5:21), since God's Word is infallible and we are not. The prevailing mindset of our age does influence us. Therefore, if our Bible reading never challenges us, we probably aren't reading well. A faith that never upsets us is a designer faith, with the self as designer."  These are strong words, but words that we must hear anytime we come to a difficult passage of Scripture.Doriani is also helpful in understanding this passage as it relates to braided hair and gold.  He rightfully concludes, "For both Greeks and Jews, extravagant dress could signify promiscuity or disregard of a husband's authority.... Modesty is the principal. The problem does not lie with braided hair or gold per se. A gold wedding band is a simple symbol of commitment. But elaborate hair took hours to prepare and so became a conspicuous display of wealth and rank. Inner beauty is what counts.....as a test of Peter's principal, we may ask ourselves how much time we spend on our physical looks and how much time we spend on our mental and spiritual strength each day. If we give more attention to hair and clothes than to mind and heart, something might be wrong." Ultimately, "we should long to please God more than to gain applause or admiring glances. We should pursue God's favor more than human favor, since his appraisal is more accurate, generous, and gracious." Instead of getting distracted by externals, Doriani shows that the heart is key and our desire for approval from God should be foremost in our minds.Overall I was blessed by this new addition to the series. The Reformed Expository Commentary series continues to be a favorite of mine and this is another great volume in the series. Doriani writes in a very clear and understandable way and will surely be a blessing to anyone who works their way through this commentary.I received a free copy of this commentary from P&R Publishing in exchange for an honest review.

God's Battle Plan for the Mind: The Puritan Practice of Biblical Meditation by David W. Saxton is a new release that quickly caught my eye for a couple of reasons. 1) I love the Puritans and have been blessed as others authors have compiled Puritan thoughts on a particular topic and I was hoping for the same from this book and 2) There is not much contemporary writing on the subject. Outside of mention in a few spiritual disciplines books Biblical meditation is a topic that simply isn't filling the book store shelves.  After I received the book I was pleased to see that Saxton compiled thoughts from over 50 Puritan resources (if my count is correct).  This means that he has gathered together, for the reader, important thoughts from the Puritans on meditation that could take hundreds of hours to read through all of the original sources.  This is truly a blessing to the church.So, what does it mean to meditate? Saxton states that, "It means to think personally, practically, seriously, and earnestly on how the truth of God's Word should look in life. He continues, "Everyone meditates on something. We either learn to practice and benefit from biblical meditation, or we inevitably allow our minds to wander dangerously through sinful or depressing thoughts....what a person habitually chooses to daily meditate on reveals his true spiritual condition."  The believer's thought life is vitally important. We ought to be training our minds to think thoughts about the truths of God's Word instead of allowing our minds to drift into thoughts of countless other temporal things. To ensure a proper understanding, as our times have twisted the true meaning, "Biblical meditation does not seek to empty one's thoughts. Rather, it seeks to fill one's thoughts with Scripture, fastening them to the objective truth of God's Word. Rather than seeking to arrive at a plane of self-actualization, biblical meditation seeks to think God's thoughts after Him."Saxton helpfully defines what meditation in the OT and NT look like before giving a Puritan definition. Saxtons provides these summaries: "Meditation in the Old Testament is presented as the spiritual activity of heart and mind that characterizes a God-fearing saint. He loves God's Word and prizes it as gold or honey......Meditation is presented in the New Testament as a key aspect for the godly renewing of the mind. It is also used as a primary means to comfort and encourage Christian perseverance." These are important as he moves into defining Puritan thought on this subject. Here he states, "Puritan meditation was the serious use of the mind....Puritan meditation never encouraged a life of actionless contemplation or useless theological speculation....To bring a person to the point of personal application, practice, and resolution, the Puritans taught that the mind must rightly consider the truths of God's Word."From these definitions Saxton explores Puritan thought on differing types of meditation, occasions for meditation, subjects, reasons, benefits and enemies of meditation.  Sometimes when an author attempts to compile thoughts from so many sources the end result is a bunch of jumbled up thoughts that do not flow together.  This is perhaps where Saxton's work proves most valuable.  He flows from thought to thought in such a way that the book reads completely fluid.  I was tremendously blessed by His work and will surely recommend it to others as well as return to it in the future. Excellent book!!!I received a copy of this book from Reformation Heritage Books via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

Biblical leadership is crucial to the local church.  Biblical leadership is a gift from God to build up and equip the saints, and if the leadership is poor, or the model is poor, the result could be damaging to the life of the local church.  As the authors state, "who leads the church, the type of authority they are given, how they relate to one another, to whom they are accountable, and how they are selected are of utmost importance to the life and health of God's people." The contributors to Shepherding God's Flock: Biblical Leadership in the New Testament and Beyond recognize this and have provided the church with a book that traces leadership models through the Bible and various church models (Presbyterian, Anglican, Baptist, Roman Catholic (for its influence, not for its Biblical faithfulness) to arrive at a theology of church leadership and practical implications from this study.  The scope of work is truly outstanding.  The book is about 350 pages, which isn't short, but the information packed into those pages seems like so much more.  Being able to have one book that traces leadership through an overview of the Bible and various traditions will surely be a blessing to the church and its leaders as we seek to model Biblical faithfulness in regards to church leadership.In tracing leadership through the Bible many key points are made.  The authors examine the OT, the gospels, Acts and Paul's epistles to the churches, and the Pastoral letters.  Each of these chapters provides a helpful overview and a look at the key points that should drawn out.  For example, in summarizing the key points to take away from the Book of Acts and Paul's Epistles to the Churches Merkle states, "from the earliest state, the New Testament churches were led, not only by apostles, but also by mature leaders from among the congregations. As was evident in Paul's strategy, he did not seek to permanently lead the churches that he planted but appointed indigenous leaders for each congregation."  This statement provides a couple of key takeaways 1) churches should examine how they are growing leaders from their own congregations and 2) missions should seek to grow indigenous leaders for the work of the ministry, not just be concerned about converts.  Greg Allison is helpful in his look at the Roman Catholic Church recognizing that "we as evangelicals often look in vain for biblical support for such a notion of the papacy...we conceive of church leadership in very different terms. We acknowledge that Jesus Christ is the supreme head of the church, which is his body and which manifests itself on local congregations. These assemblies are cared for by pastors or elders."  While noting these major difference the authors chose to study this part of history because of its great influence and this is understandable.The last two chapters pull all of this information together nicely into a theology for leadership and practical applications in light of the baptistic leadership model that is favored by the authors.  Overall this book is a treasure chest of information and will certainly be helpful to church leaders, Baptist or not.I received a copy of this book from Kregel Academic in exchange for an honest review.

Mission Accomplished is a new two week family devotional by Scott James that is just in time for Easter.  The cross and the resurrection are at the heart of the Christian Gospel and Easter is a perfect time to bring these truths front and center for our families. It is easy to get distracted and forget to focus on the important things and this helps us to refocus our families on the Cross of Christ and His victory over death.Mission Accomplished is divided into two weeks. Week One: Walking With Jesus to the Cross begins with Palm Sunday and walks with Jesus to the Cross, ending with Jesus in the tomb. Week Two: The Risen King focuses on the resurrection, Jesus on the road to Emmaus with the disciples, the Great Commission, our freedom from sin and our hope in His return.The layout of Mission Accomplished is helpful in leading a family devotional.  "Each devotion includes a Bible passage to read together, notes to help you discuss the passage with your child ("Think About It"), questions and answers to guide your discussion ("Talk About It"), and suggestions for a short time of prayer. Each devotional time could take anywhere form ten to twenty minutes,"  The days also alternate between a hymn to be sung together and a family activity to do.  These devotionals are excellent and provide a great outline for parents to interact with their kids and Scripture over a two-week period. Great family resources are what I have come to expect from New Growth Press and Mission Accomplished meets those expectations. I am definitely looking forward to using this with my family this year.I received a copy of this book from New Growth Press in exchange for an honest review.

From reading many solid, contemporary books over the past few years I have been encouraged by one characteristic that I have seen many times.  Some contemporary authors are writing books that while heavily influenced by sound theology, and containing sound theology, are accessible to a broad range of believers.  I, personally love heavy theology books.  I enjoy sitting and slowly wading through a book that makes me pause and think a lot.  But,  I recognize that this is a gift from God and not everyone is like this, so it is important to have books that can communicate big truths in an accessible way. Covenant Theology: A Reformed Baptist Primer by Douglas Van Dorn is just that book to communicate Baptist Covenant Theology in a way that most Christians will be able to read, and understand.This first question that needs to be addressed is what makes Baptist Covenant Theology distinct from Paedobaptist Covenant Theology?  Van Dorn answers this clearly by stating that "we view the Covenant of Grace as being that covenant which comes through the person and work of Jesus Christ. All gracious covenants in the OT had this covenant and mind prospectively, meaning, God looked into the future and, knowing that Christ was absolutely certain to accomplish the work he was given to do, gave grace to OT saints on Christ's behalf through means of grace that typified this coming work. These means of grace were always attached to covenants. But because of this, only when we come to the new covenant will we discuss the Covenant of Grace proper, the covenant Christ made with his church." This distinction is one that must be addressed at the outset as Van Dorn does and then builds from this premise.I found Van Dorn's discussion on the Covenant of Redemption to be very clear and helpful to those who may not fully understand this idea.  Van Dorn addresses its origin by answering the following question: Where does the idea of the Covenant of Redemption come from? By stating that it comes from the "ideas of a lamb slain prior to creation, names written in a book of life prior to creation, and the work of Jesus to obey his Father in all things and to lose none of those given to him by the Father." The next important question to answer is :Why is the idea of the Covenant of Redemption important?  Because "God will save the elect because he has chosen before the foundation of the world to do so in the Covenant of Redemption. Jesus death on the cross procured this "especially" for them. He did so because it both pleased him, and because he knew that none would accept his offer of reconciliation given their prior hatred of him in their sinful, depraved, unregenerate condition. People can't find God for the same reason that a robber can't find the police. This means that there is something effectual in the death of Christ and in the Covenant of Redemption. That effectual thing is Jesus his intention to save all those given to him by the Father."  Van Dorn presents his chapter on the Covenant of Redemption, as well as all subsequent chapters on covenants, with both doctrinal precision and clarity, making this book highly accessible to most of the church.In his chapters on gracious legal covenants Van Dorn gives a helpful look at continuity in Scripture by looking at promises, the seed, typology, law, and grace. It is in the area of continuity where dispensationalism really falls short, everything is set against each other and the unity of Scripture is often deemphasized. On the other hand, there is discontinuity as well and a van Dorn discusses differences in these same areas. It is here that Paedobaptist covenant theology fails as it rarely sees any discontinuityProbably the most helpful distinction (differing from Paedobaptist) and definition in the entire book is that between covenants of grace and the Covenant of Grace. Van Dorn states "Reformed Baptist, while agreeing that there is grace in covenants of promise - grace that is sent prospectively, in anticipation of the Covenant of Grace- nevertheless define "The Covenant of Grace" as the new covenant made with Christ. So we can think of the Covenant of Grace as the gracious plan of salvation that God has given us in Christ. Old covenants are gracious. Old covenant typify Christ. But they are not the Covenant of Grace anymore than Christ is literally a lamb. He is a lamb, but he is not an animal.  So covenants of grace are defined as "gracious aspects of OT covenants which prefigure the Covenant of Grace" while the Covenant of Grace is the new covenant."This understanding is then expounded upon as a Van Dorn works through six gracious legal covenants. It may be in this section that and Van Dorn's work proves most valuable (and suitably titled Primer) as he writes in such a manner that is clear, biblical, and quite readable for a broader audience.There isn't a shortage of very heady theological books, but it is a treasure to find a resource such as this that combines the sound theology with a practical writing style that is accessible to so many. This book is an excellent resource, one that I highly recommend, and will refer to for many years to come.I received a copy of this book from Waters of Creation Publishing in exchange for an honest review.

Real Christian: Bearing the Marks of Authentic Faith by Todd Wilson is a new book that aim right at the heart of what is means to be a true Christian.  Wilson draws from Jonathan Edward's Religious Affections to provide the church with a modern day look at the marks of authentic faith.  Wilson states that it is important for the church to be clear about authentic faith because, "when Christians are confused about what it means to be real, the spiritual decline of the church will follow." While this is a very broad and general statement I think there is much truth in it.  A quick broad look at American Christianity seems to confirm this statement.Since we have in some ways ignored the distinct marks of authentic faith "we must clarify for ourselves, and for a watching world, what it means to live a life of authentic faith." Wilson's state his claim for authentic faith in a short and simple statement: My chief claim, although provocative, is simple. Real is something you can see. There is a visible difference between real and not-real Christians. It's not enough to say you're real; you should be able to see your real. Luther said that Faith that saves alone is never alone.  True saving faith is always accompanied by change, since the one who experiences saving faith has been given a new heart/made a new creature this idea of visible lasting change shouldn't shock us.  We are being made new from the inside, out.Wilson studies six marks of authentic Christianity.  These are: humility, meekness, contrition, wholeness, hunger, and perfected love. "These six marks provide us with the standard and substance of authentic faith. On the one hand, they provide a biblical standard for whether we are real; on the other hand, they unpack the substance of what mature faith looks like." Wilson helpfully shows our need for an external (the Bible) measuring stick for our faith. He states "our depraved heart is a flattery factory, which mass-produces agreeable thoughts about ourselves at a furious pace. We lose sight of who we are and convince ourselves we're someone more attractive or cleverer or kinder than the evidence in our lives supports. Our untrustworthy hearts keep pumping self-aggrandizing complements into our minds leaving us comfortably reassured, yet spectacularly self deceived."Wilson unpacks how faith produces change in regards to each of these "marks."  He is encouraging throughout the book, yet not without urgent warnings. "If the desires of your heart and the direction of your life have not changed, then you have no reason to assume you're born again. And let me hasten to add, this change must be substantive, not superficial. It must be real change, to the core of who you are -your heart- reshaping the direction of your life, your motivations, and your actions." Ultimately our perseverance points to God's keeping power, not our own will power. As Wilson says, "perseverance proves God has given you a new heart, causing you to walk in his ways and keep his statutes."Overall, I found this book to be a helpful look at the marks of authentic Christianity.  This isn't about some moralistic checklist to follow, but rather real, lasting change that the Holy Spirit will produce.I received a copy of this book from Zondervan Academic in exchange for an honest review.

Spurgeon's Sorrows: Realistic Hope for those who Suffer from Depression is a recent release from Zack Eswine that draws from the life and writings of Charles Spurgeon to bring a word of encouragement to those who suffer from depression.  I've never suffered from any long term depression.  If I get down about something I usually move on within a few hours.  I was hoping that this book would give me an inside view from Spurgeon's battles with depression.One of the first issues to address is the fact that the church can and has handled depression wrongly.  Because of that many who suffer from depression find it difficult to talk about. As Eswine states "We sense helplessness, yes, and also shame. Like other issues of mental health, we don't talk about depression. If we do, we either whisper as if the subject is scandalous or rebuke it as if it's a sin. No wonder many of us don't seek help; for when we do, those who try to help only add to the shame of it all." This statement should cause us all to examine how we view those who suffer from depression. "Depression ought to be taken seriously because it can "so vandalize our joy and our sense of God that no promise of His care can comfort us in the moment, no matter how true or kindly spoken. At its worst, "everything in the world looks dark." Even God's mercies frighten us "and rise like a hideous portents of evil" before our minds eye."Often times people can become depressed from their circumstances.  Rather than just trying to snap out of it (or snap others out of it) this can be a good time for us to learn that "Christian faith on earth is neither an escape nor heaven...we do not equate spiritual blessing with circumstantial ease...[and]..we who've not suffered depression from circumstances must learn the pastoral care of those who have.  So often, not only with depression, we can be in such a hurry to escape trouble that we miss what God may be trying to teach us though suffering.One of the more helpful truths that I gleaned from this book is that some believers have a natural tendency towards despair, as Spurgeon states, "we do see every day that amongst the best of God's servants, there are those who are always doubting, always looking to the darkside of every providence, who look at the threatening more than at the promise, who are ready to write bitter things against themselves" It is so easy to judge others without fully knowing their circumstances or to just say snap out of it that we do not show that love and compassion that they deserve.  Eswine reminds us that, "it is important to remember the truth when we or someone we know is suffering from depression. The truth is that "our sense of God's absence does not mean that He is so. Though our bodily gloom allows us no feeling of His tender touch, He holds on to us still. Our feelings of Him do not save us. He does. Our hope therefore, does not reside in our ability to preserve a good mood but in His ability to bear us up. Jesus will never abandon us with our downcast heart."Where do we turn when hope is lost, "we plead not ourselves, but the promises of Jesus; not our strengths but His; our weaknesses yes, but His mercies. Our way of fighting is to hide behind Jesus who fights for us. Our hope is not the absence of our regret, or misery or doubt or lament, but the presence of Jesus." Ultimately we find comfort in suffering from looking to Jesus. "To feel in our being that the God to whom we cry has Himself suffered as we do enables us to feel that we are not alone and that God us not cruel."Zack Eswine has provided the church with a book that will definitely be helpful to those who suffer with depression as well as informative for those who do not.  I received a copy of this book from Christian Focus in exchange for an honest review.

Romans 8-16 for You is the sixth volume released in the God's Word for You series from The Good Book Company.  The aim for each title, as stated by the series editor is to be: Bible centered, Christ glorifying, Relevantly applied, and Easily readable. This series is promoted to be used to read (cover to cover), to feed (as a devotion day by day) or the lead (study in small group or church setting).  Keller does a wonderful job making this book both readable and providing great insight into Romans 8-16. This book is less like a commentary and more like a guide book, and that's ok!  Keller walks the reader through Romans 8-16 in 12 very manageable chapters that are even subdivided into two parts making it a perfect book for private devotions or group discussion. This is a great commentary for lay-people because it is set up more like a book than a traditional commentary. Each chapter contains 'Questions for Reflection'  that also work well for either personal meditation or group discussion.  Many of the questions are personal application questions like 'How does this text apply to your life in ____ area.'I think most commentaries on Romans would probably scare many Christians away because of the depth of theology that the book presents.  Many of the truths that Paul discusses in this book are hard for one to wrap their mind around. This is where this commentary proves very helpful. It tackles the difficult theology, but in brief easy to read sections, with application mixed in along the way. This would be an excellent book for any Christian to read along with as they read through the book of RomansI would highly recommend this easy to read commentary to any believer to supplement their study of Romans 8-16. It's size and style is neither highly technical or overbearing, but rather easy to read and separated into small manageable portions making it a great devotional read.I received a free copy of this book from The Good Book Company via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

A quick trip down the devotional isle at your local Christian book store will reveal an abundance of devotional style books.  These books with short 2-3 page chapters for each day prove to be popular, but sadly, many are not filled with much substance.  Thankfully, there are also devotional books that dig deep and leave the reader with truth to meditate on throughout the day. Discovering Delight by Glenda Mathes is one of those devotionals.Discovering Delight takes the reader through 22 devotions on Psalm 119 as well as meditations on Psalm 1, 19, 37, 40 and 112, Isaiah 58, Jeremiah 15, Romans 7 and Revelation 19.  These devotions are truly rich in content.  Each devotion is about 4-5 pages and ends with questions for reflection.  These questions help the reader to recall what they just read as well as apply the truths learned.  They serve this devotional well, as they can/do spur on thoughts to meditate on throughout the day.  I was impressed by the depth that these devotions have.  Again, so many devotionals just provide a quick read that may be good, but lacks any real depth.  Discovering Delight is the perfect book for anyone looking for a short 10 minute devotional read for their day that will leave thoughts lingering through the rest of the day.I received a copy of this book from Reformation Heritage Books via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

A quick scan of the internet will confirm that contemporary Christianity is dealing with many "hot button" issues today.  While I do not want to downplay any of these issues I think the difficulty the church has in some of these areas is directly related to biblical illiteracy and improper/lack of application.  Banner of Truth and Sinclair Ferguson have teamed up to provide the church with a most useful resource that is desperately needed today.From the Mouth of God seeks to (as the subtitle states) help the reader trust, read and apply the Bible. The order here is key.  One of those "hot button" issues today where we see the mis-use of Scripture is so-called same sex "marriage."  Some in the church will say that we just need to "love" people the way they are and not try to change them because that is what Jesus did and commands us to do.  While it is true that we are supposed to love people, what they mean by love is accept a certain lifestyle as valid before God and man.  The problem with that is if we trust that the Bible is God's word (1st step) and read it in it's proper context (2nd step) we will come away with a very different application (3rd step).  God is clear in His Word that we are to love people and the greatest form of love would be to show them the Bible is truly God's Word and that unless we repent of our sins and trust in Jesus we will perish (no matter what the sin). We must be diligent on our understanding and use of the Bible and From the Mouth of God is an excellent resource to guide us in His Word.First, we cannot approach the Bible as just another book.  As Ferguson states, "The Bible...is God's personal communication to us. It has a life-restoring goal in view: to bring light to our darkened minds and faith to our dead hearts."  The aim of the Bible is so much higher than just some textbook or history book. It seeks to alter lives. But, how is this God's Book if man wrote it?  Sinclair answers this quite succinctly by stating that "there were..two elements involved in the inspiration of the Scriptures. God (i) over-ruled the lives of those who wrote the bible in ways that would prepare them to write it, and in addition he (ii) superintended their lives as they wrote."  So we have a Bible that is God breathed and also reflects the authors hand in it's writing.I have read quite a few books (some quite lengthy) on how we arrived at the Canon and how do we know that we actually have God's Word.  I think Ferguson's treatment of these two topics is exceptional.  His writing throughout this book is probably the most accessible and readable that I've come across.  Perhaps my favorite chapter was the one titled Keys.  Here Ferguson works through 5 keys for understanding Scripture. They are: Context, Jesus, The Unfolding Drama, Biblical Logic and Each Part of Scripture should be read according to its literary character.  This chapter alone would make a great small pamphlet to hand out to train/encourage the church on reading Scripture properly. I was also encouraged by Ferguson's discussion on Poetry/Wisdom writing. I've recently read a couple volumes on how to read the Psalms and I felt that his work here was a great introduction/primer on how to read and better understand these often misunderstood books.Overall, I was greatly blessed and highly encouraged by this book.  Ferguson has provided the church with a very readable volume that comes at a much needed time.I received a copy of this book from Banner of Truth in exchange for an honest review.

Like most people probably are, I am familiar with Matt Papa from his music.  I have been blessed by many of his songs for the rich theological content which they possess, so when I saw this new release from him I was curious to see if that theological framework that is in his music would translate well into his writing.  Look and Live is a book about beholding the Glory of God in such a way that it transforms all aspects of our lives.  From worship to missions to suffering Papa skillfully writes to show the reader how beholding the glory of God is the light that lets us se all of life more clearly and fuels us in obedience.Beholding the glory of God is what changes us.  Papa states, "The glory of God is the reason why every person in the Bible who encounters God nearly falls dead. It changes you. When we see God, we get small. We lose a sense of our self. We must. His is true excellence. His is true glory. All would-be identities vanish like a shadow in the presence of I AM. Pride cannot exist in His presence."  We are in great need of a bigger view of God in today's American Christianity. When we see the glory of God we also stop comparing ourselves with others and recognize how far we fall short.  Again Papa is dead on when he says, "What makes sin so evil, so damnable, is not the ugliness of the act itself but Who the act is against. We have defied God. Some might say, "Sure, I confess I've done some bad things, but I haven't been nearly as bad as some people. I mean, come on, what about Hitler?" My reply? Judging holiness by the standard of other men is useless. Two men standing at the foot of Mt. Everest don't argue about who is taller. They look up and tremble."  AMEN!!!In the chapter Glory and Mission I appreciated the distinction that he made between missions and mission.  He was careful not to discredit staying where we are, but shows the difference between that and missions.  He states that being on missions is "leveraging your time, talents, and resources for the joy of others and the advancement of the gospel, wherever you are." While missions is "crossing a culture to reach a people who have little or no access to the gospel, with the proclamation of truth and the planting of churches as paramount. In other words, sharing the gospel with your neighbor and southern suburban America is being "on mission" but it is not "missions."  It's evangelism...Missions need to be distinct because the need is distinct. If everything were missions, then we would (or I should say, "will") quickly forget about those who are dying without any way to know Jesus. We will just keep saying, "Do missions! Do missions!" while we stay where we are, or do nice things, and people in the 10/40 window (or least-reached places) go to hell. (I am not against staying where we are or doing nice things. I am just fighting for clarity.)  A lot of good things in the church today get passed off as missions, when they simply are not.  What is needed is both, people serving, working, caring for their local community as well as people going to the ends of the earth for the proclamation of the Gospel.  Again, I appreciated his clarity on this point.I was tremendously blessed by this book and highly recommend it.  It is packed full of truths to meditate on in a very readable form.I received a copy of this book from Bethany House in exchange for an honest review.

We live in an entertainment driven society. One of the negative outcomes of that is that there is always something new and exciting for us to grab a hold of, and we have a little time for those things which may cause us to have to think deeply or dwell on seriously. I think sometimes that mindset can trickle into our Bible reading, where we are drawn to text that have clear meaning for our lives today, but shy away from some harder texts that may cause more serious Bible study to properly understand.In Christ and the Desert Tabernacle, J.V. Fesko attempts to take the reader through the various parts of the tabernacle to show how they relate to Christ and their significance for Christians today. Fesko states, "I hope to be able to show readers, young and old alike, that far from being boring or uninteresting, the Old Testament tabernacle, and later the temple in Solomon's day, is a shadowy picture of Christ and the church. True, people are perhaps easily able to draw the connections between Jesus and the sacrificial animals, as Jesus is identified as the one and only true sacrifice who takes away our sins; but beyond these obvious connections, the Old Testament tabernacle is literally an entire world of references, allusions and foreshadows of Christ and the church. When not need to go very far to uncover the connections between Jesus and the Old Testament tabernacle - the New Testament reveals them to us. If you read about the Old Testament tabernacle in the light of the New Testament, you will never think the descriptions of the tabernacle and its furnishings are boring. Instead, you will be filled with hope and assurance, knowing that Jesus Christ, the true tabernacle, has come to redeem his people, living stones, and unite us to him, the one true foundation, so that we would become the eternal temple of the living God."In the short book, Fesko takes the reader through the building materials, the Ark of the covenant, the table and bread, the lampstand and oil, the tabernacle, the altar and courtyard, the priest's garments, the consecration of the priest, the altar of incense, the census tax, the bronze basin, the work of Oholiab and Bezalel, and the Sabbath. All of this is done in short, manageable chapters. Each chapter gives a quick introduction to the part of the tabernacle being studied, showing its purpose and it's immediate context, then Fesko turns to the New Testament to show how these are but types and shadows. The writing is accessible, and brief, making it a wonderful devotional read for practically anyone. One does not have to agree or fully track with every point to Fesko makes to be truly blessed by this book.I received a copy of this book from EP Books in exchange for an honest review.

The Reformed Expository Commentary is a series that aims to provide a fresh exposition of the Biblical text for today's generation.  In the series introduction the series editors (Phil Ryken & Richard Phillips) lay out the four fundamental commitments in this series.  They are:1) To be biblical - that is to pay careful attention to the text and exposit the Scriptures.  There is less  focus on the original language and structure and more focus on the story that the passage is telling.2) Unashamedly Doctrinal - this series approaches the text from a Reformed perspective, as found in the Bible.3) Redemptive-Historical - this means that they believe in the unity and continuity of the Bible, and interpret it in a Christ centered approach for all of Scripture.4) Practical - by applying the truths found in the Scriptures to contemporary challenges in life.Aesthetically this commentary looks great on the shelf.  While this isn't a huge selling point, and certainly not a reason to chose one commentary over another, I must say that this one looks really nice on the bookshelf, especially when you have more than one in the series.Ecclesiastes by Douglas Sean O'Donnell is a new release to the series.  Ecclesiastes isn't exactly the easiest book to understand or preach through, but "all Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness, that the man of God may be competent, equipped for every good work."  So, even the book of Ecclesiastes has gems for the Christian to mine, though they may take more effort to find.  Thankfully O'Donnell has provided a helpful commentary to meet this need.O'Donnell suggest that the most helpful way to read the book of Ecclesiastes is "as (1) God's wisdom literature (2) with a unified message (3) that makes better sense in light of the crucified, risen, and returning Christ. Recognizing and working within the confines of the literary genre is key to understanding the text.  By unified message O'Donnell means that throughout the book "there is a persistent literary intention and a consistent theological argument to Ecclesiastes." While the message is sometimes dark: "in all our endeavors we cannot find much meaning or sustainable joy in this world or present age. It's vanity" the conclusion is to fear God and keep his commandments.As important as understanding the genre and reading the book as a whole are, understanding the book in light of Christ is where we find the books fuller meaning.  "Jesus Christ redeemed us from the vanity that Pastor Solomon so wrestled with and suffered under by subjecting himself to our temporary, meaningless, futile incomprehensible, incongruous, absurd, smoke-curling-up-into-the-air, mere-breath, vain life. He was born under the sun. He dies under the sun. But in his subjection to the curse of death by his own death on the cross, this Son of God "redeemed us from the curse." By his resurrection he restored meaning to our toil. And by his return, he will exact every injustice and elucidate every absurdity as he ushers those who fear the Lord into the glorious presence of our all-wise, never-completely-comprehensible God." Amen to that!The Reformed Expository Commentary series continues to be a favorite of mine and this is another great volume in the series. O'Donnell provides helpful commentary to guide the reader though the book of Ecclesiastes.I received a free copy of this commentary from P&R Publishing in exchange for an honest review.

With the Christmas season just passing many Christians have spent some time dwelling on Emmanuel, God with us, in the form of Christ.  While this is truly astonishing, that the God who created everything would take on flesh and come in the form of a servant to die for His people, it is not the only time in the Bible in which God condescends to interact with creation.  There is no doubt that the incarnation of Christ is what the Old Testament was pointing forward to and what the New Testament reveals to us,In God With Us Glenn Kreider traces out God's interactions with His people throughout the Bible.  The overarching theme of the book is that God chooses to humble Himself and condescends to interact with His people.  We are completely unable to "go up" to Him, He must condescends.  As Kreider states, "Creation is dependent upon God. Only if God condescends to make himself known, only if he takes the initiative to provide redemption, only if he accommodate himself to his fallen and rebellious creation - only then is there any hope for his creatures. And that is exactly what the Scriptures teach that God has done. Because God is revealed to be what he is by what he has done, the Scriptures teach that condescension to his creation is an attribute of deity."  Kreider begins with the Old Testament and traces out God's interactions with His people.Kreider notes that "the behavior of the incarnate Son is consistent with the behavior of the God who is revealed prior to the incarnation. We see continuity between the two Testaments in the character and practice of God. If the incarnation of the Son of God is a demonstration of humility and condescension, and if he did only what he saw his Father do, then reading the Old Testament should provide numerous examples of God's condescension."  This continuity is truly a blessing to see and understand.  Especially with the charge that the God of the Old Testament and the God of the New Testament are vastly different, we see clearly that Jesus interacts with people in ways that He saw the Father do.What are the practical implications of a God who humbles himself and condescends to his people? "If God is humble, then his people ought to be humble. If God submit himself, by giving up the rights and the prerogatives of his transcendence, then his people ought to submit to one another. If God condescends to look out for the interest of his creatures, then his people ought to care for one another. If God is merciful and compassionate, then his people ought to treat one another with mercy and compassion. In short, if God is most clearly revealed in his Son, and if this revelation is humble and sacrificial, and if God wants his followers to be like him, then surely understanding God in this way compels his followers to give up their rights, privileges, and prerogatives for the sake of others." God's condescension to interact with us should motivate us to praise him for pursuing a relationship with us, and drive us to go to others in like manner.  God With Us is a helpful book to moves us to those responses.I received a copy of this book from P&R Publishing in exchange for an honest review.

Gospel Formed by J.A. Medders is a recent release from Kregel Publications that seeks to bring the reader's focus on the gospel, over and over again through 27 devotional-style chapters.  Medders recommends to read one chapter a day and this would seem to be a good fit as each chapter ranges from around 3-6 pages.  So why keep coming back to the gospel over and over again?  Medders answers this question well by saying, "Gospel-centered Christians are God-enjoying, God-centered, Jesus-exalting, Spirit-loving, Bible-devouring Christians. We don't worship the gospel; we worship the God of the gospel. The gospel is God's act of turning scoundrels into saints, turning sin-seekers into people who now find their utmost satisfaction in God." This is wonderfully good news and we should seek to ponder on it regularly. Gospel Formed is a book that will help the reader do just that.The book is divided into five parts: The Gospel Starting Block, What is Gospel Worship?, What is Gospel Identity?, What is Gospel Community?, What is Gospel Mission? Each section contains chapters that focus on various aspects of the gospel's impact on these areas.  All of these sections a Christ-exalting and bring great encouragement to the reader.  I was especially blessed by some of the devotions focusing on community. In one chapter Medders states, "I love the church because Jesus does. How much do you care about the church? Are you connected to the church? Are you faithful to a local church? Jesus shed his blood for the church and never takes her lightly - nor should you. So how involved are you? How connected are you? Fringe? Once-a-monther? C'mon...The early church braved the sword to gather with God's people, and Christians in our day will hardly brave the rain. That's a problem - one that's bigger than church attendance. This is a love-for-Jesus problem. How we treat his bride equals how we treat him." Strong indictment about how many modern day Christians think little of the great privilege that we have been given.Overall, I found this book to be a wonderful encouragement and a great addition to the large number of "gospel" books out there.  I did find the book to be a bit repetitive at times. The whole point of the book is to bring a gospel focus into various aspects of life so the gospel will be repetitive and that is a good thing. However, some of the chapters felt as if they were a stretch to be a stand-alone chapter and would have fit better if combined with another one.  Not a huge knock on the book but worth noting.  Also, there are quite a few attempts at humor throughout the book that didn't really fit my style.  They weren't off-putting, just were a distraction at times from the main point of the chapter. Again, this is a minor issues that speaks more to a personal preference, but since some will probably share it, it was worth a mention.  If you are looking for a devotion that will point you over and over again to the wonderful grace of God in the gospel and how it impacts all of life the pick up this book, you will be blessed.I received a copy of this book from Kregel Publications in exchange for an honest review.

Reformation Heritage Books recently released The Reformation Heritage KJV Study Bible and I was blessed to receive a copy.  I am grateful for the doctrinal quality of books published by Reformation Heritage, which made me eager to dig in to this study bible and explore what it has to offer.  Below, I will attempt to highlight some of the features that stood out to me and make this bible worth the purchase.1) The Notes: Anyone looking for a doctrinally sound, reformed study Bible will definitely be pleased with this offering, and this feature alone makes it worth the purchase.2) Aesthetics: The picture above is of the hard cover edition that I received.  It comes with a dust jacket and both the jacket and cover are identical in look.  This Bible has a nice binding on it that lays flat which is a huge benefit when studying. The Bible text is 9.8 point font which I find to be quite readable. The notes are 8 point and a different font from the Bible text.  This is a benefit as the reader can quickly scan and notice the difference between Scripture and notes.  All Scripture references in the notes are in a bold font which leads to easy searching for the note that corresponds to the text above.  Each chapter has an introductory note as well, which give a succinct 1-3 sentence summary of content of the chapter.3) Thoughts for Personal/Family Worship: Though technically this is in the notes section it deserves a mention of its own.  Each chapter.....yes, EVERY chapter of the Bible...comes with notes/questions to use for personal/family worship.  These thoughts/questions could easily be compiled and sold as an additional resource and yet they come with this Bible.  These are perfect to spur on meditation after daily Bible reading.  If used in a family worship setting they provide a conversation starter and points to reflect upon as a family.  I was blown away by this feature and I can't recall seeing anything like this before in a study bible.  I will definitely be putting these notes to use in the near future.4) Study Helps: These are short one page helps covering a variety of topics like: Coming to Christ, Experiencing Justification and Adoption, Growing in Sanctification, Reading the Scriptures, How and Why We Pray. Spiritual Desertion, Defending Our Faith, etc.  These serve as a great reminder to grounded believers, or new food for thought for young and growing Christians. Either way this is a nice addition.5) Twenty Centuries of Church History: As someone who enjoys church history I really appreciate this section. 20 centuries are covered at a rate of 1 century per page.  Obviously this is a quick fly-over but to someone who doesn't study church history much this could be a great reference for history that they may not otherwise read.6) Creeds and Confessions: These Creeds and Confessions are included as well: Apostles' Creed, Nicene Creed, Athanasian Creed, Belgic Confession, Heidelberg Catechism, Canons of Dort, Westminster Confession, Westminster Shorter Catechism and Westminster Larger Catechism.7) Free Online Access: So you can take your study bible anywhere you have internet access!While not every feature, this covers the majority of what this study Bible has to offer.  If you are looking for a KJV Study Bible I see no reason to purchase any other one than The Reformation Heritage KJV Study Bible.  I personally do not use the KJV for much regular reading, but with all of the tools and features that this Bible has to offer it will most definitely get plenty of use in my home for years to come.  Excellent Study Bible, I highly recommend it!I received a copy of this Bible from Reformation Heritage Books in exchange for a review.

God's Word is inexhaustible.  We simply can't, in our finite minds and sinful flesh, fully comprehend all that He has written, much less obey Him perfectly, even with the help of the Spirit.  So, there will no doubt be commands that God gives that we simply miss the mark on.  There are, on the other hand, some commands that we try to avoid, or at least gloss over quickly and move along.  I Wish Jesus Hadn't Said That by Steve Timmis is a short book that examines 10 of these commands.  These commands vary from deny yourself and take up your cross, and loving your enemies to blessed are the persecuted and don't be angry.Timmis reveals the reason for such a book, and it is a heart problem.  He states, "we are driven by a desire to secure our own happiness. We pursue the things we want in order to have status, to look and feel good. We pursue the relationships we want in order to have a fulfilling and satisfying life. We pursue health, wealth, and general prosperity.....We buy into a way of seeing the world that is basically aligned to the world's ideas of what is necessary, reasonable, and worth having. This overarching view about things is our plausibility structure: we decide what is plausible and what makes sense, and what isn't or doesn't. But each of the sayings of Jesus that we will consider together in this book turns our possibility structure on its head. Each one shakes us up and reveals the ways in which, most of the time, we don't take Jesus seriously."  We can tend to shape reality into what we want it to be, which often times isn't in line with God's reality.Timmis provides helpful insight into these 10 sayings of Jesus, never stretching the texts past its intent, yet challenging the reader to their core.  Many of Jesus's words are hard.  I think of His words to love our neighbor are especially hard.  I would much rather try to reason away this command by asking "who is my neighbor?" but Jesus has already answered that for me.  Timmis states, "Jesus is saying that we cannot eliminate anyone from the category of 'neighbor.' He is challenging every preconception that would assume someone is, or is not, likely to be a bona fide neighbor. Like a master swordsman, he cuts through all cultural and personal defenses, so his rapier goes right to the heart of his listeners' self-righteous pride."  It is easy for me to love those like me and call them my neighbor. It is much harder to love those so different than me or those who offer me nothing in return as my neighbor.  Thankfully Jesus doesn't give us the option, and also equips us with His Spirit to enable us.Despite the title of the book Timmis says that he is "really glad Jesus did say all those things that invade my "private" world, break into my choices, and turned me and my lifestyle upside down. Because it is in that process of dislocation and disturbance that I discover Jesus to be everything I could ever need and my greatest delight in life. The joy of resting in his promises and walking with the Savior is far more significant and precious than any plan, dream, or ambition I would choose to pursue." I found this book to be challenging and encouraging.  It challenges us to examine our blind spots, but it is encouraging because following Jesus, even His hard sayings, is always the best place for us.  I highly recommend this book.I received a copy of this book from Zondervan in exchange for an honest review.

The Christ-Centered Exposition Commentary Series is a new commentary series from Holman Reference edited by David Platt, Daniel Akin and Tony Merida.  The editor's goal is "to present an easy reading, practical and friendly commentary" and "to exalt Jesus from every book of the Bible."  In the introduction the editors lay out four distinguishing characteristics for the series.They are:1) This series seeks to display exegetical accuracy. The desire is to handle God's Word faithfully, even while every volume may not be verse-by-verse commentary.2) The series has busy pastors in view by presenting its material in a readable, pastoral style rather than academic.3) A desire to be known for the "inclusion of helpful illustrations and theological driven applications.4) To exalt Christ in every book of the Bible. They carefully state that, "we are not commending wild allegory or fanciful typology.  We must be constrained to the meaning intended by the divine Author Himself, the Holy Spirit of God.  However, we also believe that the Bible has a Messianic focus, and the authors in this series will exalt Christ from all of their texts."Some of the authors that will contribute to this series that is projected to be 48 volumes are: David Platt, Daniel Akin, Tony Merida, Al Mohler, Eric Mason, Mark Dever, Russ Moore, Matt Chandler, Francis Chan, Thabiti Anyabwile, J.D. Greear and Paige Patterson.  This is a very respectable list of pastors and authors to contribute to this series.Exalting Jesus in Galatians by David Platt and Tony Merida will definitely serve as a useful resource for the pastor/teacher or lay-person.  Each section first presents the "Main Idea" of the text.  This is what the author see as the main point that the biblical author is trying to convey in the text.  Next a brief outline is provided to give the reader a visual of the flow of the passage at hand.  After this is the main section, the exposition.  This isn't a commentary that is going to dig deep into the languages or sentence structure but rather reads much more like a devotional commentary.  Each section ends with questions to help solidify what was just read into the reader's mind.I was extremely blessed by the doctrinally sound commentary found in this edition.  Many times I found the move from exposition to application to be very helpful.  An example of this can be seen in the section on Galatians 1:6-10 and Paul's concern for the Galatians.  Merida states: "The Galatians transfer hurt to Paul because he saw them as his spiritual children...He was in agony, desiring to see them grow into Christlikeness and knowing that their turning was anything but an insignificant event. His passion reminds us that truth should matter to us! When someone is turning away from Christ, it should grieve us. And when someone is walking in the gospel of grace it should thrill us." Merida's comparison of Paul's anguish over the Galatians turning to our own anguish is timely, as many in our day are turning away from Christ to a "prosperity gospel" or some other false gospel.I was also blessed by the points Merida drew out of the text in what turning from the gospel actually means.  They are: 1) When you turn from the gospel, you turn from God Himself. 2) When you turn from the gospel, you turn from the grace of Christ. and 3) When you turn from the gospel, you have nowhere else to go.  Ultimately we should be passionate about the purity of the gospel because "Christ glory is at stake," "people's souls are at stake," and "the health of the church is at stake."  Merida's clear exposition and application made this section a blessing to read.Overall, I continue to be impressed with this series. I have now read multiple volumes in this series and each has been a blessing. This is one of the most accessible commentaries that I have come across.  I was blessed by this commentary and found it very helpful and look forward to future volumes in this series.  Overall, excellent work! I received a free copy of this book from B&H Publishing Group (Holman Reference) in exchange for an honest review.

Ordinary: How to Turn the World Upside Down by Tony Merida is a fresh look at how believers can do "ordinary" things with a Kingdom focus for the glory of God and the good of others. The first thing that I look for in any book on meeting social needs is balance.  So often, in our present day good deeds towards others gets pushed to the forefront and the gospel gets forgotten.  Another negative outcome can be that people trust in their good works towards others as a means of salvation and forget that their righteousness is based on Christ's work and not their own. Even with these negative possibilities the church still needs to be aware of physical needs around them and help where they can.  The purpose of Ordinary is to make the church aware of opportunities to show neighborly love, hospitality, care for the vulnerable and advocacy for the voiceless in the course of our "ordinary" Christian lives.Recognizing the extremes mentioned above Merida states clearly that "the order of good deeds and the good news is a matter of life and death. Good deeds follow the good news, but good deeds cannot merit eternal life." This is foundational to any of our good deeds towards others, but with the proper perspective the good news should fuel good deeds.  Loving others also means that reconciliation with God should always be in our thoughts.  Merida states that "we don't love the world the way Jesus loved the world if we don't call others to repentance. And we should do so in a spirit of brokenness and repentance ourselves. Love doesn't equal tolerance."  Ultimately, love for others recognizes their spiritual poverty and won't stop at just alleviating their physical poverty.Merida clearly charges both extremes by saying, "the places of greatest poverty and social need are often the places with the greatest need for the gospel proclamation also. We don't need to argue over whether we should do word ministry or deed ministry; we simply need to go. When we get there, we should serve them and love and speak to them and love."  He continues, "Sadly, many today want to do mercy and justice ministry without talking about the atonement. But that shouldn't be the case. Mercy ministry is about alleviating suffering. Those who want to alleviate suffering should want to alleviate more than temporary suffering. They should want to alleviate eternal suffering, which can only come through faith in Christ." He doesn't leave the other extreme without a charge, but says to them: "The "anti-social ministry" people need to also remember that some can't hear our proclamation until they've been delivered physically from injustice and other forms of suffering. Until we pick them up from the road, they won't hear the good news. Today, millions are being drugged, sold, and raped multiple times a day in sex-trafficking. Do you think they will hear your proclamation? I don't."We need to love in word and deed.  Ultimately, we need to recognize that only the Word will truly save and we cannot neglect that.  Yet, deed is important because it shows the love of Christ to others and many times will pull them out of the pit to a position to hear the Gospel message. Humility is a necessary characteristic for all of God's people and caring for the 'least of these' will require great humility.  Merida's closing chapter is especially helpful in pointing this out.  He says, "We must kill pride, and replace it with a heart of humility. We do this by working the gospel deeply into our hearts. When you realize that you were poor, bringing nothing to the table when Jesus invited you, then it changes your view of the poor. When you realize that you were crippled, unable to come to God when he brought you in, then it changes the way you think about the week. Pharisees don't understand Grace. They're often mad, self-righteous, and elitist. Grace-driven people are happy, humble, and hospitable to the poor and weak."  Grace goes to people, with the gospel and with physical help.  We should always recognize that gospel proclamation is our main task, as sometimes the gospel and social work can be given equal footing. But this doesn't mean that we neglect social needs when they are clear and present around us.  The gospel proclamation however must be our end goal because temporary comfort isn't a worthwhile exchange for eternal wrath.I found at times that Merida's language of "need," "should," and "must" to come across a bit strong.  Even though he states that guilt isn't a good motivator, when such language is used it can leave the reader with a sense of guilt if they don't run out and start doing all of the things mentioned in this book.  It should also be noted that a Christian simply cannot be involved in every type of ministry.  The burden that God places on one part of the body isn't necessarily the same one that he places on other parts (Praise the Lord for our many members with many functions).  This doesn't mean that we shouldn't ask "What can be done to help people in need?" but it does mean that not everyone will fall into the types of care mentioned in this book.  Balance is always needed and it seemed that although Merida presents balance in the quotes mentioned above, the stress on these social needs can leave the reader feeling less "spiritual" if they aren't involved in these areas.  The Christian who runs the orphanage in Africa isn't more spiritual than the Christian plumber who works for the Glory of God.  They simply have different callings and that's ok.I received a copy of this book from B&H Books via Cross Focused Reviews in exchange for an honest review.

Is There Anybody Out There? by Mez McConnell is a highly encouraging (though tough to read at times) journey of one man's life who truly is a trophy of grace. Full disclosure: I don't really enjoy reading biographies all that much.  I'm not sure if maybe I got a hold of some dry, dull ones at some point and that turned me off to them or what, but I tend to shy away from reading too many biographies. Part of this reason may be that receiving so many books for review purposes I find it hard to review biographies.  I mean, what do you say? Your life story is kind of lame, terrible book?!?  This shying away from biographies is certainly evident in my 2014 reading.  In fact, looking over my reading list from last year this was the only biography that I did read.  So why read this one?About a year or so ago I became aware of a church planting movement in Scotland called 20Schemes.  Mez McConnell is the founder of 20 Schemes and senior pastor of Niddrie Community Church (the church that 20 Schemes is based out of).  After watching his video testimony online I wanted to hear the whole story, and so I received this book a short while later.Once I opened the cover I found it nearly impossible, aside from the need for sleep, to put this book down.  The amount of difficulty, pain and abuse that McConnell endured as a child was difficult to read.
