It's a bit hard to measure meaningfully, but I can probably fit at least 8 quarts worth (probably more like 10 or 12) of the Knorr in the same space as a 1 quart carton.

Classic symptom, easily diagnosed with the help of YouTube.Laundry was piling up already (towels and sheets mainly) so I paid extra for fast shipping. It came USPS priority mail, in a flat rate envelope - with a box inside that - at the "soon" end of the promised delivery window. No complaints there.The guys on YouTube make everything look easy - and it *almost* is. In my case, the provided self-tapping screws for the new thermostat / cut-off wouldn't thread into the holes. After swearing and sweating way too much for such a simple job, I swapped them for ones that secure the back cover, and those worked fine.Will update this review if the unit fails. But so far it's been great. Would be nice if the manufacturer didn't try to save $0.03 in the original build and used parts that would last - but I know that's wishful thinking.
Relatively realistic.

There's a rectangular "thread outline" (in red) on mine, where it looks like the traditional Levi's "patch" was removed. I didn't want the patch anyway. So no worries. Fits good. Could be thicker. But does what I need.
Returned because the size I ordered (it said would fit my normal shoe size) was at least a full size too small. But the quality seemed pretty good.
Apparently will NOT support OS X "gestures." Otherwise seems to be a solid product.

This is a great item - lightweight, sturdy enough, pretty heat resistant. What I don't like is the texture of the plastic when I put it in my mouth. It's too rough. For the fork it's a minor annoyance, but I most definitely do not want to lick anything off this spoon and for something like pudding that's bad. I'll throw this in one of my car's storage compartments to save me eating with my fingers when a fast food or takeout place forgets the utensil(s) in my order.

Not much to say about a clear plastic soap dish. It's life changing! Yeah, right.It's ridiculous how long one must look in several big box stores to find a decent simple soap dish. Even if I could have found one for $0.99 somewhere, the time I spent would have offset the savings. Actually, it's time I wasted anyway because I didn't find anything!
1oz is tiny, even for a shot. These are basically medicine cups without any graduated markings. Perfect for "random acts of liquor" when you don't want people to immediately fall down.

Unlike the "name brand" rolls I've used, the cut ends have a tendency to curl if they're not sealed, which makes sealing them later a bit more difficult.  That minor gripe is easy to solve : seal the cut end as soon as you cut from the roll, which also saves you the effort of doing two seals the next time. Just make sure you flatten the air out beforehand or it will make storage more difficult.

About me : I've been residing in New Orleans for a while, and explored (by car, bike, and foot) quite a lot, so I've gotten to know the streets covered by this map pretty well. Over the past decade plus I've used Streetwise maps in most of the cities I've lived and visited because of their clear, concise, usable format. I like them better than paper maps by far, and they have advantages over electronics in many situations. Anyway...The map is accurate. New Orleans can be very confusing, but every problem area I've checked matches reality. Don't count on street signs at every intersection. Don't even count on all one-way signs being there. I recommend getting to know the "important" streets, and wandering within a set area rather than trying to precisely move from point to point.The map is NOT comprehensive. I'd guess less than half the hotels, restaurants / bars, and attractions in the Quarter (labeled Vieux Carré here) are marked. If they were all there, you wouldn't be able to read anything. The coverage for other areas on the map is even spottier. Some of the omissions are, frankly, dumbfounding. Don't use this as your sole trip planner.Unlike some other laminated maps I have, this one is "short" - so if you shove it in your pocket (or I guess purse) it doesn't stick out an unreasonable amount. Perfect if you don't want to *look* like a tourist.

I haven't tested the RFID-proof-ness of these yet, but I really don't have any contactless cards anyway. I bought these mainly to protect my passport, and store my little-used contactless ATM card. But I have been using one of the credit card sleeves instead of a wallet when I go out at night. It's just enough to carry an ID, one credit card, and maybe a couple of bills.
Has an artificial after taste I'm not a fan of. I'll skip it in the future.

Hopefully will never have the opportunity to use this, but I typically carry one in my car "just in case." I have not opened mine for inspection, but the packaging looks identical to others I've seen. It's marked (with a sticker) as "Sterile" about a year ago, and "Expires" about 7 years from now. No complaints, especially for the price.If you're not already familiar with this type of bandage, I highly recommend going to your favorite user-submitted video site and searching for the item. That way you don't have to open one up to become familiar with the way it works.

It's a cable - what's to write about? Connectors, length, etc. - it'll either work or not. This fits the bill. Actually besides that, this is quite a nice cable. It has a nice "drape" to it, as it should for the price. I like that it's not very stiffl. That's important if, for instance, you're running it along the back of a desk that's up against a wall - cables that are stiff like mangled coat hangers create all sorts of messes.

I try to keep a pack (or more) in the fridge for when I return after a night out.Watch for them as add-on items, the deals are hard to beat then - a good 10% cheaper than local grocery stores' sale prices. Bonus: if you collect "rewards points" this item yields 3 x 12 = 36 points : the best value in points per dollar value I've found.

A note on size: I usually wear a US 10. That's what I ordered, and received. The fit is perfect.My closed toe shoes are for special occasions; cold, rain, safety, etc. Sandals and flip-flips are what I normally wear every day, including a lot of times when I shouldn't. (first wearing: the pit at a local punk/metal bar) I have literally a dozen pairs at any time, their purchase prices ranging from $3 to $150. It's still early for me to say for sure, but I think these are my new favorites.The Therm-a-Rest foot bed takes some getting used to; it's not super cushy, and the "wedges" are very noticeable - particularly on the toes of course. (more nerve endings there) But after a couple hours it feels nice. Seems like it offers a good balance between support and comfort.Unlike cheaply made lightweight flip-flops, which are flexible all over, there's some obvious engineering in these. The heel-end of these is pretty stiff, under the arch is very stiff, and the toe-end is pretty flexible. For me, this is great for walking because (especially on uneven surfaces) they "stick" to my feet better with less effort, and generally behave the way I want them to.

Total honesty here: I wasn't cool enough to kiss girls in middle school. But if I was, this is what I imagine it would have been like. Beats the "wax flavor" of many lip balms. Seems to do the job I need it to.

After seeing the ridiculously large nylon sheath that came with my Cold Steel Bushman, I knew I had to find a replacement. This fits nicely. Blackened with vinegar + steel wool, then a little oil - it looks great. Took about 15 minutes to stitch up. Perfect fit! I'd love the leather to be a little thicker, and for my application the "snap strap" isn't long enough to go around the knife handle. But the Bushman is not really a normal knife. The price is fair for the time I saved cutting my own leather, punching holes, etc. Very happy.

My life doesn't often put me in situations where I'll care about detecting lightning. But I got interested in the technology after seeing a lightning warning horn installed at a park near my house made me remember some close calls with lightning during my youth. This unit is priced reasonably enough for me to experiment with. After ordering, I had to wait a couple months before a real storm came through … and I missed turning it on! It's Summer in the South now, so it's going to get more use. In the past few weeks I've gotten a good initial feel for it including during a handful of storms.The build quality is more than adequate for an electronic device. I do not feel at all worried about, for instance, leaving it clipped to a jacket pocket and chucking said clothing into the back of my car. But don't expect it to survive "everything."Battery life is awesome so far. Two cheapie AAA alkalines have lasted me many many hours - including leaving it on for about 72 hours straight. I think as long as you don't constantly use the backlight it'll last "a good while."Accuracy … that's hard to judge.I know there are "false positives" - it alerts me when the fan and/or compressor of nearby HVAC units turn on. I haven't quite figured out any rhyme or reason to it. At least for me, it's not super frequent.There are plenty of times indoors when it complains that it "can't detect" - and asks to be moved somewhere else. Sometimes this happens 10 seconds after alerting me to legit lightning. It also happens when I start or shut down my car while the detector is inside. Again, no rhyme or reason I can detect.During storms, I have verified it detects a lot of if not all visible lightning - alerting within a second of when I see the flash, with the distance decreasing as storms approach. It *does* work in my car, except as noted above when I'm starting or stopping the engine. I consider this kind of detection neat, but ultimately not very useful : most people can already detect that kind of lightning just fine with their eyes.I've gotten alerts several times for lightning I didn't see, and based on the conditions … I believe the alerts to be accurate in those cases.The ones you don't see are just as deadly! I think in certain situations (hiking in open fields, biking in very flat terrain, canoeing on a lake, etc.) it's easy to justify a little extra protection.
Works great for what I've tested : car tires, and low pressure (cruiser) bike tires.

I'm sure my understanding of words like "sweater" and "fleece" differ from specific garment-industry terms. But I think the name of this garment is pretty misleading.It's actually a high quality sweatshirt type material. The exterior is smooth, soft, cottony material. The interior is soft, fleece-like, and seems pretty warm for being thin.Size X-Large fits me comfortably (with enough room for at least a thick t-shirt underneath) … 5' 10" / 210 pounds.

An XL fit me (5' 10" / 210 pounds) as intended - loose even with some light layering, but not super baggy. I bought it primarily for wearing over casual clothes in the summer in The South, but will also use it over a fleece / sweater and possibly more if / when it gets "cold" down here.The exterior fabric is sort of rubbery feeling - like some brands "weed cloth" almost. It's not unpleasant. The mesh interior is comfortable enough, even on bare skin. Decent pockets. Ventilation seems good. Removable hood is nice.I don't particularly like the elastic cuffs on the interior of the sleeves. I'm sure they're great for keeping storm-blown water out of the sleeves. They're not even *un* comfortable. But I think they'll get annoying to me after extended wear.The first time I tried to undo the zipper (straight out of the bag) I had trouble getting it to disengage fully - but I haven't had any problems since.As of yet, there's been no opportunity to test its weather resistance. Maybe soon. But everything I've seen indicates it'll do just fine.
Seems to clean OK. The smell isn't the greatest. Meh, it's spray cleaner.

Same quality as "dollar store" glow stick necklaces, but (at least on sale, in this quantity) significantly cheaper. If your expectations are low, these will work fine.They glow brightly (as pictured, more or less) for a few minutes. Within about 5 minutes they are noticeably dimmer. Within about half an hour they will be quite dim. After a few hours, they're basically dark. The promised "8 - 12 hours" is possibly correct in some technical sense, but that's a stretch for any practical purpose.Packaging is a 2.5" diameter cardboard tube, which is also convenient for transport and storage. Inside, the necklaces are packed in bubble-wrap. As far as I can tell, there was no damage in shipment.I'm not sure about the kind of bars where these would be considered fun. Maybe the establishments in China are different than what I'm used to. :) Otherwise, these'll do nicely for my intended purposes.

For the money spent, I have no serious complaints. This is not the luxurious microfiber fabric you're probably hoping for. It's very thin and light. After one washing, it's not super soft - but it's not scratchy the way some cotton sheets can be. After a few nights on this set, I think they'll be great in the summer - when I want "just a little more than nothing" covering me. But I definitely won't be ordering a second set.

These sound a lot better than the ones I bought at a discount store for $4. They serve very well for listening to podcasts, which is my primary use. They pretty well suck for listening to music except at very low volumes. There's very little / no bass response, and the highs can get very very harsh.I'd rate them well below the sound quality of the old Apple earbuds. (not the newer ear *pods* - which I haven't listened to) That said, for my use case they're great - I can block out most noise, but not be totally isolated.

The flask does seem to be actual stainless steel - it's non-magnetic, which is more than I can say for a lot of the Chinese made fasteners I've seen at the local hardware store. It looks and smells clean. I washed it with water, and Everclear. Everything seemed fine with the seal. It compares well with others I've used. Should do just fine for what I'm using it for (Halloween costume) and beyond.The book is 4-1/16" x 6-1/16" x 1-1/16" (that's 4x6x1 with an extra 1/16" in each dimension) and consists of a shiny black cover, with an elastic band on the back that can be stretched to keep the book closed. (and thus the flask from falling out) It will not really pass close scrutiny, at least for anyone who knows what real books look like. (I can envision the comment at a church being "that sure looks like a cheap Bible.") The interior consists of separate white pages, glued on one side. ("perfect binding") My first page was crumpled and ripped - big deal, I ripped it out and now my book is 1 page thinner. They are ALL cut - there are no "cover" pages. My pages were not attached to the cover. I'm not sure if I will glue mine in or not.You're actually paying quite a lot for the novelty - but it beats spending the time to cut up a real book.

Unsurprisingly, this costume isn't at all authentic to a nun's actual attire. :)It doesn't even look exactly like any of the pictures, or match the description. That's bad, but overall I think it's an acceptable costume. Here's what I received…1) The dress / gown. It's *one* piece, with a string tie I think is supposed to go in the back but I don't think it really matters. The "plus size" fits me a bit loosely. (I'm male, 5' 10" ~200 pounds … mostly slender, but a bit of a gut)2) The "collar" is actually more of a "hood" - it's clearly supposed to fit over your entire head. A piece extends down to cover the chest. It's pretty tight on me, but the fabric is stretchy. There's a velcro fastener on the back, which I doubt I'll use for comfort reasons.3) The head covering (perhaps considered the second piece of the habit in the description) fits tightly too, but that's probably a good thing to keep it from falling off - and it's stretchy. It consists of a sort of white headband, with an attached black veil.The cloth used for everything is very thin and flimsy, but it should suffice for a costume. It's a little see-through, which may be a pro or con depending upon your situation. I trust the claims of stain resistance. I wouldn't be surprised if the fabric tears or a seam rips.What is *not* included, despite the pictures and description, is … gloves. That suits me just fine. They probably wouldn't have fit, and I probably wouldn't have worn them even if they did.

Can't beat this as an add-on item. Good value!I tend to beat my sunglasses up. Every pair I've had, prescription or non, ends up with a wire tie or paper clip keeping things together. I don't know that this product has every size one might ever encounter in their eyeglasses, but at least now I likely won't need to improvise as much.The case is a little flimsy, but these aren't for repairing heavy equipment. The product comes with individual "wedges" of foam to prevent the tiny screws from escaping their compartments.I didn't count all the screws, but I think the count is significantly short: 9 compartments filled (3 "blanks") exactly as pictured. I counted 21 in 3 of the compartments … 9x21 = 189, not 250. Minor quibble for me, this is (hopefully) more than I'll use in a lifetime.

"Spot" beam is very bright, I'd say roughly the equivalent of my AA Mag w/ LED conversion but a lot more even. The "flood" is roughly equivalent to the spill from the spot. The "red" mode is perfect - through a long press you "lock" the light into that mode, and the white lights won't come on without special effort.

I like thick and heavy shirts, but they can be pretty hot. After reading reviews I took a chance on this product as something that wouldn't be too thick for comfort, but would still be durable enough for long-term wear. (I can and have gotten 10 or 15 years out of good t-shirts in the past - crummy ones last a year or two, if that)Clearance / Outlet pricing, at least for Orange ones, made this a no-brainer.

I bought this to keep in my car because it's a small bottle and claims "no rinsing." (I know from experience that roadside repairs can get messy, and it really sucks when you finally get back into the comfortable car but have to be careful about what you touch) I think it will work great for that.The product itself is a white liquid, with a unique texture - it's sort of "sticky" but that's not exactly right. It's unusual, but not unpleasant. The smell reminds me of sunblock or body lotion. It's mild and pleasant, not overpowering at all.My quick tests on hands dirty from bicycle chain grease were successful. The best way to clean is (unsurprisingly, as per the directions) to apply it directly, rub hands together, and rinse with water. But skipping the rinse is possible if you wipe on paper towels, etc. If you don't have a way to get the dirt off your skin, you can't really do much more than move it around.I've used GoJo and the like for many years, and this compares well with them in cleaning ability. Those products have a nicer "feel" to them, and especially the ones with pumice will clean monumentally dirty hands a lot better. But those won't hold up to high heat so I can't keep them in my car. I don't know this will do any better, but it has promise.

For the record, actual product vitals are:1.8ozslightly less than 3 3/8" longabout 1 1/4" in diameter at the widestThe slightly flexible yellow container is protected by shrink-wrap plastic, which will keep the cap on (hopefully) "no matter what. Unexpected opening would be very messy. So I'm not going to open this until I think I really need it, which will hopefully be… never!

To be clear: rounding up, the cat I received is 11" tall - exactly as described. It's a sparkly gold. Quite nice.The body & head are one piece, made of a terra-cotta type clay. The arm is made from a thin plastic.Packaging was a thin paperboard box (think crackers or cereal) containing a shrink-wrapped cat. It was shipped in the normal A-->Z logo box along with a couple other items, separated by the normal air bags, but with no additional padding or protection. Clearly that is inadequate protection.When I opened the paperboard box, at first things seemed pretty intact. But upon removing the shrink wrap, a large crack was revealed. The "waving" side of the cat was cracked all the way from the shoulder to the bottom and basically fell apart. The arm was broken. The mechanism was "off kilter" and wouldn't wave, but could be forced back into position.My 100% non-expert guess: Amazon sells a bazillion kinds of similar cats, most made of more durable plastic that can survive rough handling. Somewhere in the workflow, as early as the "slow boat from China" and as late as the friendly UPS driver, there's a failure to communicate that this cat is fragile. Given enough returns, they'll learn what's up and figure out a solution.I'm returning mine (extremely painless process) and will wait a while before ordering another. Hopefully I'll have better luck then, or Amazon will have determined how to deliver these things without incident.
Out-of-the-box, this unit only gave my 75% capacity. (~4200 mAh instead of ~5600) But it's held that pretty well for almost a year. For the price, it's hard to beat that.

Like the Victorinox Fibrox handled kitchen knives, this tool feels light - almost flimsy. This "poly" handle is flawed - there is "flash" at the seams, and there are some sharp edges to deal with. The manufacturer put money into what mattered - not a fancy and expensive handle.But the blades are precise, and sharp - so common kitchen tasks are easy. I've run it through the dishwasher several times without it rusting. (unlike some other shears I've been using)If these do *half* as well as the Victorinox knives I've been using, I'll be super happy.

After reading a lot of reviews, I bought one of these from another retailer back in 2010. (it was more expensive, but also included an external antenna) After setting it up to my liking, it's never alerted except when I've wanted it to. In fact, it did alert me to a tornado that luckily ended up damaging a bunch of houses about 5 miles away.I'm semi-permanently relocated, and left the radio where it was for family members to use - but I'm still in an area with frequent storms, so I bought a replacement to supplement my smart phone's alerts. (towers can be down, batteries can run out) I'll also use it to listen to local FM radio occasionally.This is a nice plastic unit - solid, and pleasant to touch. Unlike cheap radios, the button presses always "take." The setup interface isn't particularly great, but with a few minutes I think almost everyone will understand it enough to do what they need to.The screen is bright and easy to read - and it will stay on (not shut off) if running on AC power. The angle of the screen is great if you keep it "low" - mine's on the back of a roll-top desk, so when I walk by the angle prevents me from reading anything unless I get in very close or tilt the unit.For a relatively small unit, it sounds great. It's not audiophile quality or anything, but it sounds a lot better than a typical clock radio of similar size. Voices (news, whatever) sound fantastic.

My old Kill-a-Watt bit the dust, so I bought this as a replacement. It does basically the same thing, plus a little more …The "hi / low" wattage function is cool. That makes it easy to see, for instance, the initial big draw of a laser printer on startup.The screen is very large and readable (it is NOT illuminated, even though some of the pictures make it appear that way) and can display multiple pieces of data simultaneously.It directly displays the power factor, so you don't have to calculate it from W vs. A. (if that's important to you … for me it's just curiosity)

Like the Victorinox kitchen knives I've used, these feel light - almost dainty. The wood handles are nicer than the Fibrox ( which nixes running them through the dishwasher unfortunately) but they still don't have any "heft" to them. Some might think they feel cheap.But form follows function - they cut better than any steak knives I've used anywhere, hands down. The blades are thin, and extremely sharp. They cut through a decent steak like warm butter instead of sawing through like serrated blades, or hacking through like the blades of middling sharpness you tend to find even in fancy restaurants.Possibly because of the wood, these aren't quite the stunning value the Fibrox handled kitchen knives are. But they're very good, and I'd but another set with no regrets.

I LOVE the Big Bang Theory, and Amy Farrah Fowler is my favorite character on the show. Funko has done a great job of capturing her look. I also bought a Sheldon doll, so now I have "Shamy," as Penny likes to call them on the show. I wanted to buy Howard and Bernadette, too, but the Bernadette doll is WAY overpriced.  Anyway, I love the show, and I love these little dolls.

I purchased this iMac from ANZA09, in part because this seller has an excellent record. I'm so glad I did.The computer arrived well packaged in an original Apple box designed specifically for it. The seller did an excellent job of fitting it with pretty much everything you could possibly ask for in an iMac. This is an older model, which means it still has a DVD slot! I'm so glad about that. I hate that Apple did away with a place to insert a DVD so that you have to buy a separate DVD player. The screen is great and HUGE! It's not the retina display you can find on the very latest models, but it's still great. This computer is ridiculously fast, and so far we haven't seen any drawbacks. Or old iMac crashed pretty much every single time. So far, I haven't encountered a single crash, and I waited almost two months to write this review to make sure it would still be good.So far, I love this computer. It's the best I've ever owned at a really good price.

This movie is hilarious and should be popular with adult fans of Doctor Who, particularly those that also enjoy the IT Crowd or Back to the Future.Chris O'Dowd plays an amusement park employee who dreams of being a real-life Time Lord, like Doctor Who. He has two friends who also work at the park: one is a less-than-insipired aspiring science-fiction script writer; the other doesn't like science fiction and thinks that both his friends are ridiculous. The two friends take the main character to a pub to try to console him after he is fired for taking his job way too seriously and scaring the heck out of a bunch of little kids. The main character heads to a room  in the pub to get beer and crisps, and there he encounters a time traveller, played by Anna Faris, who is his biggest future fan. And that's where the convoluted time-travel adventure begins.There's bad language, so it's not for little kids, but the level of violence and other PG stuff is about the same as one of the more violent Doctor Who episodes. It's laugh-out-loud hilarious. I highly recommend it for any adult fans of Doctor Who. If you want something similar but American and very low budget (but with a lot of heart), I recommend Safety Not Guaranteed with Aubrey Plaza.

I took this shaver to review, but after reading all the negative comments about it giving an uncomfortable shave, I was hesitant to let my son use it on his face.Instead, I decided to test it on my legs. I didn't find it uncomfortable. However, I did find that even running it over an area of my legs half a dozen times, it still failed to shave off all the hair. I know that electric shavers aren't as good at the razors I normally use, but this is ridiculous. The first time, nothing. The second time, nothing. The third time, nothing. The fifth time, a bit. The sixth time, a bit more. Seriously, does anyone really have the time to go over the same area at least seven times to get an almost clean shave? It's probably better with short stubble, but it can't handle anything longer than that.I wish I could at least give this shaver a three-star rating. It's cheap. It does seem to hold a charge. It's cordless. And I didn't find it uncomfortable on my legs. That's about all I can say that's good about it. The box claims that it's quiet, but I don't think it is. It claims to have a "flexing foil," and I guess it does to a very limited degree, but there are many other shavers that are better at following the contours of the face.I guess you get what you pay for.

Teen Boat is a graphic novel for kids about a teenage boy named Teen Boat, who can turn into a small yacht. He doesn't know that his best friend--a girl named Joey Steinberg--has a crush on him. T.B. has a crush on another girl in school, and Joey is heart-broken and angry when, instead of asking her to the prom, T.B. tries to get Joey to help him ask the other girl out for him. Joey befriends the new boy in school, a rich kid with robotic parts, nicknamed Teen Bot. A boat race is announced, and Teen Boat discovers that the winner of the race will get to go to the secret city of Boatlantis, where sentient boats live. Who will win the race? Who will end up together? And what's the story behind Boatlantis?The first half of this graphic novel isn't that interesting, feeling something like an Archie comic, if Archie were some kind of Transformer that turned into a small yacht. The story makes little sense and is inconsistent. For example, in beginning of the story, T.B. can't help turning into a boat when he gets wet and can't turn back into a human until he completely dries. Later when he is on a ramp at sea, though, he turns into a boat and back into a human instantly at will. The second half of the graphic novel is much better, but it feels rushed. T.B. is a rather self-absorbed main character, and not very likable, though he does become more likable as the story progresses. There are lots of jokes, although none of them are laugh-out-loud funny.  I don't want to give anything away, but there are some things that happen in the story more because they're common cliches rather than because they make sense for the story. And they don't make sense. Neither does the idea of people being married to and having kids with objects, even if they are sentient.The story is weak and uneven, but it does end well. The drawings, on the other hand, are very good. The artist does a brilliant job of drawing a boy turning into a boat, not an easy task. The artist also manages to draw each character differently, which I like. Some cartoonists will give every character essentially the same face and body, but here each character has a different face shape, features, and stance. I like that. There's one panel with a goof in that Teen Bot's hand is drawn backward, but aside from that small mistake, the drawings are first rate.This isn't a great children's book, but it is fun enough. I imagine that boys between nine and twelve who like graphic novels and boats will love this.

Veronica Mars is like Buffy the Vampire Slayer, except with crime and sleuthing instead of supernatural beings and slaying. It's smart, and funny, and highly addictive. Start watching, and you'll see. You won't want to stop until you get to the very last episode of the third season. Then you'll wish there were more.

Nory lives in a world where everyone has a magical power that can be fit into a neat box: there are Fuzzies, who can control animals; Flickers, who can turn invisible; Flyers, who can levitate and fly; Flares, who can create heat and fire; and Fluxers, who can turn into specific animals. But Nory's magic is a bit different. She's a Fluxer who has a hard time turning into a specific animal and staying that animal. When she wants to be a kitten, she turns into a "bitten," an animal that's part beaver and part kitten, or a "dritten," an animal that's part dragon and part kitten. Nory wants to be like the other Fluxers her age, but her upside-down magic means she can't go to the Fluxer class at the school her father runs. Instead he sends her away to live with her aunt so that Nori can go to a school with a special UDM (Upside-Down Magic) class.  There she meets a group of kids with upside-down magic like hers, but Nori still wants to prove to her father that she can be like other Fluxers, so she can go home.The story is very well written and the voices of the various characters feel very true to this age group. The pace is fast, and I think many young readers will be sucked into the story and want to read it to the very end. There's a lot of exciting and funny stuff. I liked Nori and several of her new friends. And I think the ending was pretty good.I have two issues with the book, however, that prevent me from giving it five stars.First off, the political correctness here is extremely heavy handed. Nori has a habit of classifying everyone according to skin color first. This is, well, odd. I don't think any kid does this. For example, if your aunt flies in through your open kitchen window, I don't think the first thing that will occur to you is here's "a sturdy-looking white woman." Nori is biracial, and describes her own skin as "brown," while she describes her father as darker. Her friend, Elliot, asks her why she's black when her aunt is white, which gives Nori a chance to explain that her father is black and her late mother was white. Seriously, what kid today asks a question like that? I asked my teenage daughter who read the book, and she also found that part strange. Nori's UDM class is so politically correct that it's a bit ridiculous. Out of eight students, there's one Hispanic kid, one biracial kid, one black kid, one Asian kid, one Jewish kid, and one kid with a disability. Nori's aunt is a taxi driver, and the school nurse is a man. The only things that might be less than politically correct are that the school principals are male while the teachers are female, and the one politically incorrect thing I didn't like at all, which was how the school nurse called Nori "doll." That's kind of sexist. If all these clearly heavy-handed attempts at political correctness aren't enough, the principal of the school Nori gets sent to spells it out for you. "I will not tolerate bigotry," he says. "I will not tolerate unkindness about race, gender, orientation, family background, religion, weight, magical abilities, favorite candy, or anything else that distinguishes one person from another." It's a bit much.The other issue I have with the book is minor, but still...The characters are very good, but this book felt more like an introduction to the characters and their world than an actual story. I can definitely see this turning into a series, and I know most readers would like that. So my issue here is that there's no real depth to the magic of this world. If a world has existed for a long time with everyone having magic, magic would have to be a part of everything in that world. Harry Potter is a great example of that. Transportation in Harry's world is magical. Food is magical. Sports are magical. Even the paintings on the walls and the bathroom no one uses are magical. But there's no depth of magic to Nori's world, which is a lost opportunity and very strange.In Nori's world, when kids reach the fifth grade, they're tested to see what kind of magic they have. After that, they're separated into different classes according to the magic they possess. Fluxers are in one class, and Flickers are in another. And yet for most them, whatever talent they have is irrelevant to their adult lives. Most go on to have jobs that have nothing to do with their abilities. (Nory's Aunt Margo is an exception, since she's a rare kind of Flyer who can give other people rides, which makes her a taxi driver.) So what's the point of using their type of magic to inform their entire middle-school and high-school educations if this has virtually nothing to do with their lives once they leave school? Why don't they just separate for their magic classes, like kids do for electives, and then learn math/science/history/English according to their abilities in each of those areas? It makes about as much sense to group classes together by their naturally born magical talents as it does to group them together by, well, one of the characteristics the principal of Nori's school says he won't tolerate bigotry over, which is to say not at all. "Our entire school system separates Flares from Fluxers, but I will not tolerate any Flare treating a Fluxer differently." Really? Hypocritical much? Still, I think it's a shame that magic doesn't inform Nory's entire world, since that would give the writers and the readers so much more to explore. Here, we've just barely been introduced to it, and yet it feels like we've already seen it all. A more interesting world would have given Nory's world room to grow.My teenage daughter, by the way, had different issues with the book. First, she didn't like Nori because she felt what Nori wanted was stupid. She also felt that way about Nori's new best friend, Elliot. She also hated Nori's dad, which I completely understand. He seems to have no redeemable qualities, but he is necessary to give Nori a reason to leave home. I do think it's necessary for Nori to be wrong about her own magic at first so that she can grow and change over the book. The same goes for Elliot, although I do understand my daughter's frustration with how long it takes them to realize their mistakes. She also had a big issue with the principal's decision at the end of the book, and she's right: that should have been Nory and Elliot's decision to make, not the principal's.All in all, though, this book is a fun, exciting, well-written, and funny read.

2:14 Mins While this isn't a perfect action camera by far, this is the perfect action camera for kids. It's easy to use. You can take it pretty much anywhere: in the air, underwater, you name it. It floats, and it's just about indestructible.'My family took it to a hotel with a swimming pool and a water park to test it out. My husband and I used it to make sure we put it through its paces, and it came through no matter what we did to it. The video included here was shot with this camera. As you can see, we took into a swimming pool and into the water. We threw it up in the air. When it landed in the water, it floated, making it easy to retrieve. We took it down a water slide. We even filmed a hot tub--underwater. We also gave it to our daughter, and her footage came out great. (The only reason why we haven't included it is that she recorded kids she met, including one kid who did a great job hamming it up under water, but we didn't want to post photos of any kids without their parents' permission.) Every time my daughter filmed, kids came up to her and asked her what she doing. When she told them she was filming them, they all said, "Cool!" Some kids asked for and were given a go. You know a toy is a good toy when every kid wants to play with it.The video quality, as you can see, is about as low as it gets, but that doesn't really matter. What does matter is that this is a great toy and that it gives little kids a chance to use a cheap action camera without any fear that it might break. Highly recommended.
I love Wallace and Gromit, but these shorts are way too short and not all that fun. It's much better to watch the full episodes or the movie.

Annedroids is terribly cute and the main characters are good role models for kids in science. It's educational in a fun way, although it might be a bit boring for older kids and parents.Nick, the new kid in town, learns from funny Shania that no one ventures into the strange fenced off area that appears to be a junkyard. But Nick does, Shania soon follows, and they make a new and wonderful friend. Anne is the strange girl beyond the fence who loves to build androids! Each episode is a new adventure as Anne works on improving her androids while the three kids have to make sure they keep Anne's secret safe.This is exactly the kind of show I loved when I was little, although now I'd prefer something with more tension, even if it's Cyberchase, the great PBS cartoon series that teaches kids advanced mathematical concepts in a way that makes them easy to absorb. It isn't very well acted or even well written, and the concepts it teaches aren't very deep, but it's still a lot of fun for the right age group while inspiring kids (especially girls) to love science.

Bought this for myself as a Mother's Day gift, and it's okay. There's one cartoon per page, and most of them are a little funny, though not laugh-out-loud funny. Some of them even made me squirm a little. A lot of the cartoons are about moms, dads, kids, or combinations of the three behaving badly. I kind of wish this were more "warm fuzzies" than squirm worms in the tummy, but it's not awful, just okay.

Bought this at Big Lots (for less than half of what Amazon is currently selling it) and was pleasantly surprised when I opened the box to discover it's American made. I also bought three of the "cloth drawers" that go with it (again at half the price of what they go for here). With the three cloth boxes filling the shelves that have no backing, it looks great, like a fancy piece of modern furniture.I bought this to go against a wall in my bedroom so I could tidy up my bedside table and the floor near my bed. It's great for organizing stuff in an attractive way. If you need to organize some things you don't really want other people to see, I'd recommend getting enough of the cloth drawers to fit them. I'm using the shelves without cloth drawers for pretty things, like books and jewelry boxes. I also have some games on top of this storage unit. You can really organize a lot of stuff with this.I'm very glad I bought this, so it's five stars for the product minus one star for the price here.I can't say how hard it was to assemble, only that my teenage daughter put it together for me in about half an hour. It seemed easy enough.

As others have stated here repeatedly, this "pole" is great, but the name is a bit of a misnomer. At a little more than six inches, I'd call it a "stick" or a "grip," not a "pole." And it needs an adapter if you want to use it with a GoPro, so maybe it should be called a "waterproof action-camera grip," instead. That would be more accurate.PROS:* The screw connector at the top works with most cameras. I've used this on a kid's sport camera and on a Nikon stills camera that also shoots video.* It lets you more easily hold the camera steady while you shoot because it lets you control the camera's movement with one hand, rather than two.* This was tested in a swimming pool and sea, and it does indeed float very well.* It's a bright orange, which makes it easy to find.*It has a good grip AND a strap that make it easy to hold and keep hold of.* It's reasonably priced.CONS:* Only the misnomer that I mentioned above. You ned to buy the goPro adapter for a screw head that is not in the standard goPro kit.The Photo shows two GoPros doing a TV interviewing the sea. One has the pole and a firm grip on the camera. The other does not and had a hart time holding the camera.

Who doesn't like shaved ice on a hot summer day? This Margaritaville Frozen Concoction Maker--the most affordable model of shaved ice maker this company sells--gives you exactly that.You'll start with margaritas (using the included recipe and the "No-Brainer" mixer cup to help  you measure out the ingredients), then you'll move over to orange juice (poured over red wine for a little kick), Snapple, cold coffee, or anything else you'd like to turn into a shaved-ice treat. Kids love the things it can make as much as adults, if not more.This thing is huge and takes up a lot of counter space. It has a footprint of 14 by 8 inches at its base (the top is about half an inch wider). It's also about 17.5 inches tall, so take that into account. And it weighs approximately 17 pounds. The power cord is two-feet long, and there's a storage compartment for it in the back.Except for the blades and possibly the base, the appliance's construction is all plastic. The ice reservoir and the lid to it are NOT dishwasher safe, but I see no reason why you should have to wash either of those since the ice reservoir should hold nothing but ice, which means it should never get dirty. Any water or bits of ice that remain in the reservoir after you've made your frozen treat drips as water into a cup in the back so that it can be easily removed. The blender cup, on the other hand, is where everything BUT the ice should go. It's designed for liquids, but I imagine it should be able to handle soft things, like fresh (not frozen) strawberries or chunks of fruit. We haven't yet, but we do plan to try it with chunks of seedless watermelon. Since it's all plastic, I wouldn't try to stick anything hard in the blender cup itself for fear that it might crack.There are instructions for how to take apart and clean the blender cup itself, but be very careful when you do. The blades are very sharp, but there's also the possibility you might do what my husband did, which is somehow manage to get the bottom part of the blender cup stuck sideways on the cup. That makes the cup leak and impossible to stick under the shaved-ice spout, which makes the entire machine useless. You can call the company (it's a subsidiary of Jarden Corporation under Sunbeam) or visit their website to order another blender cup, which when I called sold for a little under $40, so this is a problem that has a solution. It's just better if you're very careful about how you handle the blender cup, so you don't have to go there.The whole thing is very easy to assemble, and if you read all the clear and brief instructions, you should be on your way to making frozen concoctions within minutes. Put the ice in the reservoir at the top. Close it. Put about two and a half cups of some flavored room-temperature or cold liquid in the blender cup. Slide the green shaved-ice dispenser up so you can slip the blender cup into place under it and lock both parts into position. Press the power button on the left so that it lights up. And press the start button in the middle. The machine shaves the ice and sends it into the blender. Once there, the blender mixes it with the liquid into a delicious frozen concoction. It's that easy.To make a thicker drink, hold the "Blend/Shave" toggle switch up so it's in the shave position. And for a thinner drink, hold the Blend/Shave toggle switch down until the desired consistency is achieved.  The No-Brainer mixing cup makes it easy to put together the parts for margaritas, daiquiris, and pina coladas, but you don't have to stick to just these drinks. If you have an idea for a liquid you'd like to try with shaved ice, go for it! I do wish this frozen concoction maker came with more recipes--particularly for non-alcoholic drinks--but you really can get creative and have fun. As long as it's a liquid that tastes good when it's really cold, it should work.While this machine is a bit of a splurge in terms of cost and the amount of space it takes up in the kitchen, I'm planning to use it at a family get together later this summer, where I'm sure it will be a hit, probably even a bigger hit than the burgers and hotdogs. That, I think, is the best use for it. Just like people splurge on expensive outdoor grills that are only used in the summer maybe four or five times a year, I'm sure many of those same people would be willing to splurge on a frozen concoction maker to make those barbecues extra special and a whole lot cooler.

This is a sweet necklace for anyone born in August or who simply likes peridot (the birthstone for August), but peridot is valued by how deep the green is, and this is only the palest green (probably the second cheapest on the scale). It's tiny and dainty, and it sparkles nicely. The chain is rather plain. This necklace would make a nice gift for a young girl or possibly a bridesmaid, nothing fancy.

This game is a lot of fun! Wait, no, not fun. Fun for the OTHER players. Not so much fun for me. Am I going to lose points for saying that it was fun? No? Phew!This game is a lot like an Addams Family version of Fluxx. Like the Addams Family, it's mysterious and spooky and all together ooky (whatever that means) and hilariously full of dark humor. Like Fluxx, it's a card game where the cards change the rules as you go.Each player gets a family (we've already decided the mad scientist's one is our favorite), and you need to kill your Gloom family off one by one while that family member's points are in the negative. Meanwhile, you have to try to cheer up your opponents' Gloom family members to give them positive points so that they can't be killed off (not without adversely affecting the player's score). When one player has killed off his or her family, the points are added up, and the player with the lowest score wins.Okay, now here's the fun… I mean the dreary part.The cards for each family member are funny on their own, and so are the things that happen to them. The card for Professor Helena Slogar, for example, reads "ECCENTRIC INVENTOR: Helena enjoys gardening, long walks in the moonlight, and reanimating the dead." One effect card (with negative 20 points) reads "GREW OLD WITH GRACE: The player to your right may randomly select and discard 2 cards from your hand. Death becomes you. Hurry it up." If you play the two together, you can tell a story like this: "After reanimating her favorite dog, Grace, the professor discovered she had accidentally left her aging ray on. She aged twenty years, though showed no sign of it except a lovely lock of white hair that had suddenly appeared on her head. Grace aged, too, and died twenty seconds later at the ripe old age of fifteen, which is a hundred and twenty in reanimated dog years." (Of course, you deduct twenty points for the professor, but you also lose two cards.)You don't have to play with storytelling, but the storytelling part is at least 70% of the fun. My teenage daughter held onto her death cards and deliberately lost because she didn't want the stories to end.Wait, did I saw fun back there? I meant Gloom.*giggle*Death and despair have never been so entertaining.One more thing, the cards in this game are made from a sturdy clear plastic that hides the points and whether they're negative or positive. This is important because it lets you see the positive and negative points of the cards that have been played before on that family member--or use other points or blanks to cover them up.

My husband bought me this butterfly necklace for our anniversary, and I totally love it! I love butterflies, and my birthstone is peridot, so this is necklace perfect. It's well made and simply beautiful. Love, love, love it.

Andy Cohen is fun and funny and honest about growing up gay and Jewish in middle America, about his experience working for the CBS morning show, and about his time at Bravo, particularly with the so-called "Real Housewives."I don't have cable. I don't watch Bravo. And I've never seen any episode of any Real Housewives show. If you're a fan, I'm pretty sure you're going to love this book.What I love are behind-the-scenes books by people who have been there and know how to write, like Mindy Kaling and Tina Fey. Andy definitely knows how to write, and his behind-the-scenes perspective has been unique and is certainly entertaining. So while this certainly isn't the best book of the year, it is a fun, funny, quick, interesting read.I liked it. You probably will, too.

This is the cheapest magazine rack I've ever found, so I'm judging it accordingly. It's more functional than attractive, but it looks okay. It's very sturdy, stable enough, and holds about a dozen magazines without any problems. It's a good value, and it does what it's supposed to do. Until now the magazines in the office bathroom have been on the floor or on the sink. Now they have a place where I can store them neatly. If that's all you need and you don't have large pets or kids who might knock into it or knock it over, this will do.

This is one big ugly super-powerful stapler.I had tried manual bulk paper staplers before, but could never get enough pressure for the staples to go through all the sheets of paper. This electric stapler has all the power and doesn't hurt your hand. The spring action was louder than I expected the first time I used it, but by the second sheet I was ready for the staple.Insert staples by pushing down on the button at the top, making the little drawer at the front pop out. Insert the staples, and slide the drawer closed. Plug it into a power outlet. It's now ready to use.The stapler staples with a loud bang automatically when you insert paper into it. It really can take a lot of sheets. It comes with two sizes of staples, standard 1/4" for up to 25 sheets and high capacity for 25-45 sheets of paper.Both load into the same draw, and it had suction cups at the bottom to keep it in place. I found the high capacity staples great for closing a years worth of bank or credit card statements in to neat booklet ready for storage.Since it staples when you insert paper into it, it doesn't let you decide exactly where you want the staple to go. (It staples a little less than half an inch in.) I would prefer it to be adjustable. Sometimes I want a staple closer or farther from the edge but that is a standard margin on documents.If you need a stapler that can easily and quickly handle lots of pages at once, this is it, and because its plugged in to power, no one will walk off with it.

A. J. Jacobs documents his year of attempting to live according to his own literal interpretation of the Old Testament first, and then of the New Testament.I read this book in spurts at first and then read the last part straight through, unable to put it down. What makes this a fun and interesting read is that the writer, although a liberal nonreligious Jew, approaches the subject matter with an open mind and an open heart. He surrounds himself with all kinds of experts on the Bible, and he doesn't judge them. He finds humor in Amish country, comfort in an ultra-orthodox Jewish man's rituals, and acceptance where he least expects it. There are surprises and lessons to be learned everywhere. He also writes about the affect of his experiment in his own life with his son, his wife, and his neighbors. These are some of the most touching parts, particularly in the end, which made me cry. Many other parts of the book made me laugh, and quite a few made me think.He comes away changed for the better, not necessarily religious but with a deeper appreciation for what religion has to offer.  And it does.

Joss Whedon takes the slayer saga into a dystopian future and gives us Fray: a thief and a slayer without a mentor who doesn't know her own purpose and power. Fray is cool, and the world she's in is dark and amazing.My main problems with this graphic novel is that Fray isn't given strong supporting characters, the way Buffy is, and the book feels more like an introduction to a series, rather than the series itself. I certainly hope that's what it is, because I would very much like to see more of Fray and her world. It's a very promising start, and I can't wait to see that promise delivered on.

I got this for my daughter, and she loves it. It helps keep her warm when she's waiting for the bus at college, and people are always complimenting her on it. Who doesn't want to look like a ninja? She prefers to wear it without the cowl, and it's still very warm and comfortable.

This is definitely Spike, in all his glory. He says mean things out of love, and he swears he'll kill you when what he really means is he'll give everything to save you. If you love that about Spike, you'll love this graphic novel. It's funny without being a joke. It's heartfelt without being sappy. Yes, it's violent. Of course, it's violent. You wouldn't except anything less from Spike. And it's very dark, so dark that the humor and the affection shine brighter still. All in all, an excellent graphic novel.

My family loves jigsaw puzzles, particularly my autistic son.These puzzles with the special shapes are our favorites, because every time you put down one of the special pieces, well, it's like solving a puzzle within a puzzle! With only 300 pieces, this puzzle took us just a few hours to complete, but it was a great way to spend some quiet time with the entire family. The image itself of the wolf howling at the full moon is beautiful.If you prefer puzzles that are more challenging, the same company has puzzles with 500 pieces. We've gone through about five or six of their puzzles, and we've enjoyed them all, so much so that we kind of miss the special pieces when we put together puzzles from other companies. The pieces are well constructed, but be aware that many of the special ones by necessity don't lock into the pieces around them. They all fit perfectly, though.Another fun puzzle to put together alone or with the family.

My family loves jigsaw puzzles, particularly my autistic son.These puzzles with the special shapes are our favorites, because every time you put down one of the special pieces, well, it's like solving a puzzle within a puzzle! We started with the plane, the Statue of Liberty, the boats, the skyline, and the sea. The sky is the hardest part, so we left that for my son, the puzzle expert. It took us a couple of days, which is the perfect amount of time.If you prefer puzzles that are less challenging, the same company has ones that have more variety in the image, less "sky." We've gone through about five or six of their puzzles, and we've enjoyed them all. The pieces are well constructed, but be aware that many of the special pieces by necessity don't lock into the pieces around them. They all fit perfectly, though.Another great puzzle to add to your collection.

The Turtle Beach Ear Force Elite 800X is excellent in every way. Noise canceling? Check! Surround sound? Check! Full rich sound with a good range? Check! Cordless? Check! Easy to pair, decent battery life, elegantly packaged, easy to charge, and pretty much the perfect headset for the XBox one in every way? Check, check, check, check, and check!You can also pair it with your Bluetooth devices and walk around listening to music, away from your phone or whatever device you're using. That means you can charge your phone and still walk around listening to music. And the noise-canceling, oh, my gosh, the noise canceling is amazing! Not only does it shut out external noises but you can set it so that you can hear just conversation. How freaking amazing is that?Look, I wanted to find one thing wrong with this headset, because I didn't want this review to come off sounding like an advertisement. Maybe it could be a bit lighter, but then maybe this is the right weight for what is clearly excellent construction. The worst thing I can say is that it is now my teenage daughter's favorite of the many headsets we have and she keeps "borrowing" it.Seriously awesome headset. If you have an XBox One, this is the headset for you.

I love gemstone jewelry, and I've long wanted to have something with my own birthstone: peridot. I also love sterling silver. It's something I've been wearing since I was a teenager. I don't have that much sterling silver nowadays (I've been buying mostly costume jewelry lately), but I do have a few pieces I probably wear more than anything else in my collection. I also love butterflies and butterfly jewelry. This bracelet is almost a perfect combination of all three.Anyone with experience with sterling silver jewelry knows it's meant to be light-weight. The butterflies to the sides of the center peridot seem to have a pave-style imprint and isn't real pave, which I suppose is to be expected. The band is smooth and comfortable and seems unlikely to pinch. The clasp locks in two different ways, so it should remain secure. I've lost watches so many times when they fell off, so it's good to know that won't happen with this bracelet.The highlight, of course, is the peridot butterfly. The gems are a very pale green, so they aren't the fanciest (the deeper the green, the more valuable a peridot is) but they are very shiny and sparkly. It's beautiful, and a wonderful way to to wear my birthstone.The bracelet is made in China. My one issue with it is that it's not weighted at the clasp, which means the bracelet has the tendency to turn around so that the heavier butterfly ends up under my wrist instead of on top.All in all, this a lovely bracelet for any girl born in August who would like a piece of jewelry with her birthstone and who likes sterling silver and bracelets.
After about 5 hours standing in the snow my feet started to feel the cold on a below freezing day, even wearing two pairs of socks. Good water resistance as the rubber is all one piece over the toes.

I thought I would be able to connect and control my iPhone 5 with the USB port. But the USB seems to only charge the iPhone at a week amp rate. The only way I can hear music was by connecting the 1/4" audio jack. I have to have the phone and car stereo on full volume to be able to hear audio books.I have a Toyota sienna 2004 .

I love Jasper Fforde's Thursday Next series, particularly when the story takes place inside the Book World. My favorites so far have been One of Our Thursdays Is Missing (Thursday Next #6) and The Well of Lost Plots. This particular book, though, doesn't take place in the Book World and hardly references it at all. Thursday here isn't a Jurisfiction agent, or even a Literary Detective. Bowden and Spike are mentioned, but they have no scenes. But there is still a focus on books, and there's a lot of great Jasper Fforde humor. It's a fun novel, just not on the same level as the rest of the Thursday Next series.Okay, so what exactly is this book about? Thursday was badly injured at the end of One of Our Thursdays Is Missing. In this book, she's attempting to recover and has developed an addiction to pain-relief patches. These make her muddled, unable to focus enough to book jump, and slow to react in dangerous situations. SpecOps is rebuilding all the divisions it closed down, and Thursday has been assigned the position of Swindon's head librarian, a position that involves lots of money, military-style security, and regular assassination attempts. Jack Schitt is back, and worse than ever. Someone is making synthetic Thursdays with the ability to download and upload information to and from Thursday. Aornis has gone missing. And Friday has received a Letter of Destiny telling him he's going to murder another teenager who was meant to become a member of the now erased Chrono Guard. Meanwhile, Tuesday is trying to figure out the formula for her Anti-Smite Shield in time for the anticipated smiting in Swindon on Friday. Of course, in usual Jasper Fforde form, these different elements end up tying neatly together for a mostly happy resolution in the end.My favorite part of the book is the Aornis storyline, which reminds me a lot of the Silence storyline in Doctor Who. (This probably isn't just a coincidence, since Doctor Who does get mentioned in the book.) It's very funny seeing the characters encountering Aornis and then immediately forgetting what happened. Thursday even has a tattoo on her hand to remind her of the mindworm, a lot light the marks the Doctor Who characters are meant to make on themselves every time they encounter one of the Silence. I suspect Fforde might want to write an episode of Doctor Who, and if he does, I very much look forward to seeing it. I also like the time twists in Friday's story, which again remind me of Doctor Who. (Actually, even the synthetic Thursdays have a bit of Doctor Who in them, if you consider the episode with the Doctor Who look alike.) And I think anyone who loves libraries might enjoy how kick-ass the librarians in this story are. Oh, and two of the major baddies in the series meet their ends, so that's great, too.This is my least favorite Thursday Next novel, but I do love the series, so it's still great fun. I look forward to reading the next book in the series--Dark Reading Matter--when it finally comes out. I hope I won't have to wait too long.

These solar fairy string lights are adorable and can be easily used to decorate a porch, a tree, or a garden fence. They're not very bright, but they're certainly bright enough to shine pretty colors at night. We put them along the fence of our little garden on the flashing setting. The tricky part was finding a place in our overgrown garden that gets enough sunlight for the solar panel. The lights go on at sundown or when it gets very cloudy, and they stay on for several hours or until the sun peeks out from behind the clouds.I don't know how long they'll last, but I bought these from Amazon for a little under $13, so I won't mind if they only last a year or two. It's totally worth it at that price. They're just so darn cute!

While it sounds like a great idea to harness the power of the sun to charge your smartphone when you're camping or far from civilization for whatever reason, the NOCO XGrid portable solar panel has major two issues that can't be overlooked: first, it takes two days in bright sunlight to charge it enough to fully charge a smartphone once; and second, the instructions are confusing.Plugging it into a wall will let you charge it enough to power a cell phone twice, so that should help you at the start of your camping trip. This portable solar panel can deliver on the promise of five volts, but its charging power is not as strong as regular house or car power. Still, when you know you will be in the middle of nature without electricity for recharging phones or cameras, this kit will be able to help, a little. A power hungry device, like an iPhone 5, can use up two days of solar power in as little as eight hours.I have always wanted to harness the sun heating up my car, to charge batteries when it's parked. So I placed the solar panel on my car dashboard. This way it was in direct sunlight and no one could walk off with it while I was working.There are three parts to the kit: the foldable solar panel, USB cables, and a waterproof rechargeable battery pack with a built-in LED flash light. (The flashlight has several settings: high, low, and flashing, the last of which could be helpful to call for help.) The only instructions are on the packaging, and they aren't clear.  Plugging the three parts together will not start the charging automatically. The battery pack/flashlight needs to be turned on by pressing the power button at the front of it.The battery when fully charged from house power was good for about two recharges of an iPhone 5, which is pretty good. But the dream of using solar energy to power my phone wasn't quite fulfilled. Two days is a long time to have to wait to get a full charge. I'm not sure, but I think the kit might be discharging the battery at night. It's possible there's a way to stop this, but because of the unclear instructions, I wasn't able to figure out how. The company does sell extra panels that velcro together for charging a car battery, so maybe using several panels at once can help charge the batter faster.On the plus side, the solar panel is lightweight, strong and rugged and could sit on top of a backpack. I can definitely see this as being useful during a long hiking trip or even in an emergency when you might have no power for days.For a lower price, this solar-power kit might have a higher rating, but a price this high means higher expectations that this kit doesn't as yet live up to. The company needs to work on both increasing the speed of the solar charge and on creating clear and easy to follow instructions.

I bought this game after a Facebook friend recommended it, but the anti-semitic undertones--intentional or not--creep me out too much. There's an angelic hero who's Catholic and speaks of "heavenly visions and a divine mission" while "taking up the sword to launch her holy crusade to purge the world of evil." What evil? How about Dawn Cohen, a villain, who is the ONLY charter with a Jewish last name? Yes, let's go on a holy crusade to purge the world of Cohen!Do you see the problem here?The game isn't designed for storytelling like most good role-playing games. The characters come fully formed, and it's not like you can turn a villain into a good guy or vice versa. You just play the mostly white good guys to defeat the bad guys, including the only character with a Jewish last name.I seriously wish I hadn't spent so much money on a game I find offensive and am embarrassed to have in my collection.ADDED LATER: Some people in the comments below accused me of "trolling." The above is a serious review, and everything I wrote is 100% accurate. The quotes are taken directly from the game. I didn't say the anti-semitism was intentional; I said I can't play this game because I'm Jewish and I find the whole idea of playing a Christian character on a "holy crusade" that involves battling a Jewish bad guy--who is the only Jewish character in the game--offensive. I wonder if people would accuse me of trolling if I were African American who was offended because the only African-American character in the game was a bad guy. (He isn't.) I doubt it, because I think we all know that would be racist. So I have to wonder why some people think it's okay for one minority to be offended and not another. I'm not a troll. Trolls delight in trolling, and I take no joy in discovering a rather expensive game I bought has content I find offensive. I've only posted this review to warn others who might feel the same way. That is not trolling. That's doing exactly what a good review is meant to do.

Having read the series all the way up to and including One of Our Thursdays is Missing, I must say this one is my favorite!Yes, Thursday is missing, and it's up to the Book World's version of her to find out what happened. The story starts out a little slow, with lots of backstory and explanations. You wonder why it's being told from the literary Thursday's point of view, and not the "Real World" Thursday. But once the Book World Thursday meets a strange stranger on a train who informs her that "one of our Thursdays is missing,"  the story takes off.This is a whole new Book World, one where Fiction is a series of islands that must be traveled by bus or Trans Genre Taxi, and that is why I love this particular book so. Gaiman Junction, Picoult Boulevard, the NaNoWriMo sea: it's like Fforde wrote this book just for writing and reading nerds like me!I love, love, love One of Our Thursdays Is Missing! Thanks, Jasper Fforde, for writing it.

I decided I absolutely needed a silicone muffin pan when my old metal one started falling apart, leaving pieces of shiny metal attached to my muffins. Yuck. The muffins went in the trash, quickly followed by the baking pan.This silicone one is great. Muffins just slide right out, with no crumb left behind. It's does buckle--it has absolutely no stiffness--so it can be a little awkward getting it in and out of the oven. The solution I've fond is to place it on a flat baking tray and to slide it from the tray into and out of the oven, with oven mitts on your hands.So glad I switched to silicone for baking muffins.

This is a delightful movie about a highly respected chef who bottoms out, loses his job, regains his love of cooking, and bonds with his young son over good food and a culinary journey that takes him in a food truck from Florida to California by way of New Orleans and Texas.The film contains some men behaving badly, underaged drinking, and colorful language, but at it's heart, it's a movie about family and food. I'd recommend it to anyone, but particularly to foodies, long-married couples, and families with children over 13.t's funny and touching, and it really makes you want to make and eat the perfect grilled cheese sandwich.

We have an autistic son who sometimes leaves the house without us knowing. We put one of these alarms on the front door, so now if he opens it, everyone in the house knows. It's very comforting to know when anyone is going out or coming in. In fact,  when he hears the alarm chime he doesn't leave. I guess it somehow reminds him that this is something he's not supposed to be doing.I'm very glad we bought these.

We’ve owned quite a few Black and Decker toaster ovens over the years. They’re cheap, and they seem to be designed with planned obsolescence in mind. From experience, I never expect them to last more than five years, seven tops. But we still stick with Black and Decker because they’re cheap, reliable for at least those five years, and they get the job done.Over the years, we've found a few features we've liked a few we didn’t. For example, we prefer the ones that are designed to fit under a kitchen cabinet, and this one isn’t. We also prefer the ones that have a crumb tray that can be easily removed from the outside, and this one has that. Yay! We've also been looking for a toaster oven that browns evenly, and it looks like we’ll have to keep looking. Hmm . . . But this toaster oven is also bigger and it’s a convection toaster oven, which makes it a step up from the ones we've owned before.  It’s not perfect, but for the price, it’s pretty good.PROS• Price is reasonable for a convection toaster oven of this size.• Actual interior size is big enough for a 12” pizza, six slices of bread, or a baking pan up to 11-inches square. It’s also taller than the average toaster oven. It looks big enough for a small or even medium size whole chicken.• It can toast, bake, and broil.• It does indeed seem to cook faster than the other Black and Decker we own, but that’s mostly because the other one doesn't work as well as it should. For example, fries that say on the package that they need to be baked for 15 minutes need 25 minutes in that other toaster. With this one, though, 15 minutes does it.• The handle is far enough away from the toaster for it to remain cool to the touch, a big plus if you've ever burned yourself trying to open a toaster oven.• The instructions on the dials are clearly written out in English and couldn't be easier to understand.• You can remove the crumb tray from the outside, which is a bigger deal than it sounds. Previously we've had crumb trays that drop down or have to be removed from the inside, and cleaning both is difficult and messy. Being able to just pull the crumb tray out from the front is so much easier.• There are three sets of slots for the rack, so you can choose how close or how far from the heat element at the top or the two heat elements at the bottom you’d like it.CONS• The sides and back of the toaster do get rather hot, which means it takes up even more space on the counter than just its already large footprint. If you’re not careful, you’ll very likely melt that plastic drying rack or whatever plastic item you mistakenly place too close to it. You also have to be careful you don’t touch the sides while the toaster is hot.• This toaster doesn't bake evenly. The back corners get more heat and food there is likely to burn before whatever is in the center is done. I found this particularly true with the back left corner.• The hum and clicking of the timer as it counts down the seconds are louder than I’d like.And there you have it. It’s not ideal, but for the price, it’s pretty good.

I needed to upgrade an old (how the heck is three years OLD?!) Acer Aspire laptop with a paltry 250 GB hard drive. This was the perfect replacement hard drive.Writing, illustrating, and indie publishing gobbled up my old hard drive's space until there was barely any room at all left. My research showed that the largest my laptop could take was a 1.5 TB drive, but I'd have to compromise on speed for that. This Western Digital 1 TB drive offers the best speed, which made it the best choice. I had a local computer dealer clone my old hard drive and install the new one. It works great! It's like my laptop has been given a second life, and I look forward to a lot more writing, illustrating, and publishing with it.Oh, and the old hard drive didn't go to waste. My husband installed it on his even older Compaq laptop, upgrading it from an even paltrier 80 GB to 250, so it worked out great for him, too.

I make pendants and hang a charm from each one that has to do with the subject of the pendant....make sense?  Well, it does to me.  This selection of charms is wonderful, I can come up with a charm to fit just about every theme.  There are hearts and birds, teacups and wings, shells and pinecones and teddy bears....and many many more.  They are nicely made with some heft too, not cheap ones where you can see the joinings.  I highly recommend them if you need a wide assortment, and I'll definitely be buying more from them.  Hint for the seller:  would love to see some gold colored ones too.

I have end stage cancer.  I know, I don't like it either. Because I do weekly chemo, my activities have gone from working ten hour days to sitting at my kitchen table staring out my window while buying things from Amazon.  Oh, I'm not sad, I'm doing quite well, thank you.  Just tired.  Early this summer, my son's girlfriend put a flower on the outside windowsill which attracted a hummingbird.  I became fascinated watching that little bird drink from the flower.  Life gets smaller when you are sick, but no less interesting. The flower died, and I realized I missed the birds, so I bought this window feeder and stuck it to where the flower had been.  It took about a week, maybe even two, before the hummingbird realized what it was for but now I have at least two (species?) of hummingbirds that sip from this feeder several times a day.  I enjoy having it right on my window so I can get up close and personal with the birds. The birds, however, are not so sure.  They cock their heads and look inside, and unless I'm very still, they fly away.So I'm very still.The feeder does attract hummingbirds and does not seem to attract bugs.  I picked this one because it's cute, and looks nice on the window.  It holds enough to keep my little birds happy for a few days and then it's time to change it anyway. They have shown no interest in the little perch part of it and so flutter in front of it.  It's very easy to clean, just wash it out and roll a paper towel down it.  The brass or copper is discoloring but I haven't really tried to clean it and don't mind.  It has never fallen off.  I'm quite happy with this purchase and may get a couple more to see if I can recreate the scene from the movie The Birds, only with hummingbirds.  Seeing dozens of hummingbirds flapping at my window would be a real treat and I think I should put that on my bucket list.

Breast cancer patients will nod their heads in recognition as they read through this book.  If you know anybody in your life who is going through this awful disease, this book is sure to brighten their day.  Nothing can make breast cancer a pleasant experience but Kate captures the emotions and problems with droll humor.  Would be great in any gift basket for the cancer patient.

When my physical therapist told me to get a pulley system for home use to help me recover from a post-mastectomy Frozen Shoulder, I browsed online for the cheapest one.  As soon as I saw the Duro-Med set though, I became completely captivated by the 1970s photo on the box. Why would they use a clearly outdated photo like that?  Is that somebody's mom?  Sister?
