Did they dig it out of the family photo album and put it on the pulley box?  Has the company been in business for 40 years and they never changed their packaging?  And, check out her arms - they are Michelle Obama arms. Toned, fit, in direct contrast to the dated dress and hairstyle.Of course I had to buy it, who wouldn't?  It arrived a couple of days later. It was very easy to install and I put it over the bathroom door and began my home-based physical therapy.  I guess I don't know what to say except that it works as designed.  It was easy for a one-armed woman to use and that's what it needs to be, and hopefully, someday I'll have the use of two arms again thanks to this device.  I'll never mimic that hairstyle though.

Well, it didn't take long. Less than six months after I bought the iPad, it's obsolete, with the iPad 2 about to hit the stores.  I can't afford another $500.00 for just a smaller form factor, cameras and GPS (especially since I have an iPhone) so I'm keeping it until Gen 3 comes out. To keep people from seeing that I'm stuck in the dark ages - I'm vain that way -  I decided to find a folio-type cover.I purchased the Acase Premium for $10.00, not expecting much.  But, it's very, very nice for the pricepoint.  It is quite secure, with tight elastic for the left side of the device and a slide-in pocket for the right.  It closes over the screen and latches tightly, but you can also fold it to the back and latch it so you can use the screen.  I don't know if it's really leather or not, but it feels like leather.  It doesn't have any kind of chemical smell or anything like that.  The inside seems to be suede.  It definitely provides excellent protection for the tablet, and now it's easy to slip into my purse, which I never did when it was just in a skin.  I find I'm taking it a lot more places thanks to this case.I haven't had it very long so I can't speak to how long it will last but for the price, you can't beat it.  It's a great way to both hide, and protect, your outdated iPad.  With this case, it might last until Gen10.

So, this is what life comes down to when you are 50 years old:  reviewing dryer vent cleaners while sitting at your kitchen table waiting for American Idol.  This is not what I envisioned when I was 12, I can tell you that much.  You kids who think it won't happen to you?It will.  Sorry to burst your bubble.That said, the product works great.  Our dryer pretty much stopped working and we were thinking we needed a new one, which was seriously going to eat into my plastic surgery budget.  One last shot before a trip to the appliance store was this Gardus LintEater.  My husband, who is not the handy one of the family, had to do the work as I have a torn labrum.  (Which sounds dirtier than it is - that's part of your shoulder.)  He, the clumsiest man in the world, had absolutely no problem using this.  I warned him to read the directions first, and he actually listened and followed.  He hooked it up to the drill, and away he went.  He got a bunch of musty, wet lint that had probably been up inside the wall since 1977  - probably consisting of bell bottom material and macramé.Now our dryer actually dries clothes again, and I can continue to save for my facelift. Thank you Gardus.

I love clothes.  But, I live in an older house and I have to share a closet with my husband.  We have done the best we can with a closet system but it's still not enough for a fashionista like me, and I was about to make him put his clothes in the backyard shed.  Hey, it's California, it doesn't get that cold.  I have more than 25 pairs of work/dress pants, and only a 1 1/2 foot space to put them in.  I've been going crazy jamming stuff into that tiny space - putting two or three pants on the same hanger.  Everything wrinkles and I can't see what's in there.I bought five of these skirt/pant hangers and am amazed at how much room I saved.  I have 20 pants hanging up and there is room for a couple more of these.  I think I can get everything hung up now, without having to worry about wrinkles or not finding anything.  I really love them.I would love to add more for my blouses and skirts but the area I have for those is shorter, and I think I could only get two things on. I don't want to spend 10 bucks and only use half the hanger.  It would be nice if these came in different tiers for different spaces.If you are looking to save space in your closet and keep your husband from having to get dressed in the back yard - this is definitely the product for you.Tip:  You can alternate putting pants on one side, and then the other, by twisting the clip.  This makes them even out in the closet, and then you can easily grab them.  Another thing I did was hang some by the bottom and some by the waistband. Another way of maximizing space.  It's helpful to put them together by color and style so you can grab what you want when you need it.

I've been unfortunate enough to need several surgeries the past year, thank you cancer. (I'm fine, thanks for asking.)  The hardest part of any surgery is getting to sleep afterwards.  When your body is cut up and muscles not functioning, getting in and out of bed can be painful, difficult or plain impossible. Afer using bed pillows to try and prop myself into the positions I need to be, I finally bought this pillow.  It's perfect.  It's soft enough to cradle your hurting body, but firm enough to put you in a position where you can get up and out of bed. The bend in it is very gentle, not the strong curve as in the picture.  But, the small curve does seem to help keep you in position.  I also love that it can be used after you recover for sitting on the couch reading or watching TV.  It won't gather dust under the bed.  Just turn it around and you have nice support.  The only reason I gave it four stars instead of five is the flimsy cover that comes with it.  It's not a pillow where you can easily find a case to go on it and that scratchy, cheap cover isn't soft enough.  One other thing - I'm a very small, only 100 pounds.  This fits me perfectly so I wonder if it would be as comfortable if you are a bigger person.  My arms can stay inside it but maybe that isn't necessary?  I leave it for you to decde.

I miss Maui.  I miss the surf, the sand, the rainbows, the sun, and the smell of plumeria wafting on the breeze.  The only way I can recreate the magic of the Islands is through scent, and so I have become addicted to plumeria soap.  It's not easy to find in my area and I was pleased to find this version on Amazon.  This soup is creamy and gentle and best of all, it smells like the air in beautiful Hawaii.  It's a small luxury - a tiny piece of Maui in your bathtub.

I'm cursed.  I'm a night person in a day person world.  When I was younger, I could work swing shift and keep my natural hours, but after I had kids, that was no longer possible.  Not only that, but I chose a job working in a school, and I have to be bright and cheerful and ready to work at the ungodly hour of 7:00 a.m. when all reasonable people are just getting to bed.One of the hardest parts about being a night person is the actual getting up in the morning. Alarm clocks are jarring, heart-attack inducing inventions. I am an expert at hitting the snooze button, to the point that I still need my husband to actually wake me up.  When I got my iPhone, that became my alarm but still, it has a snooze function and I would still sleep an extra hour if left to my own devices.For a couple of years I've been looking at this alarm clock.  Will it magically turn me into a day person?  Will it even wake me up?  Will it be a big waste of money?  I finally broke down and bought one, and I'm very glad I did.This is a very pleasant waking experience.  The gradual light does make it feel like dawn is breaking.  I don't always wake to the light alone, but I do sometimes.  It's nice to snuggle back while the light gets brighter and brighter.  I chose the birds to wake me up and they do, in a gentle manner.  The snooze button is easy to hit, with the clever design that sticks right out.  But the best part of that is it only turns off the sounds, not the light.  So, when formerly I would hit the snooze button and go fully back into my dark, cozy dream-world, now the light stays on and I don't go back into such a deep sleep.  The next time my birds start to sing it's a lot easier to get up.  I rarely have to hit snooze more than 3 times, a far cry from 10 or 15.I found set-up a breeze and the instructions simple to follow.  It also works very well as a side lamp for reading and it's nice that you can dim it so as to not bother your partner.I've had this light for several months now and my mornings, while still difficult, are a lot easier on me.  Hearing an alarm is not something I dread anymore.  No, I'm not a morning person and I guess I never will be.  But, mornings are a lot less painful with this method of awakening.  It is a pricey alarm but worth every penny.

Honestly, I have not found any one of these blocks that work on my deer. I live more then 12 miles from the nearest oak tree. My deer crave acorns worst then a meth addict craves meth. I collect acorns from other places to out them out every once in a while as a treat and y deer go nuts over them. I can pour a 50lb of acorns out and the deer will stay all night until they eat every last one. I put this block out in the same place at the beginning of the season and I can't tell if anything has licked on it after all this time. I have a game camera that monitors this area and it captures around 700 pictures a week and it has never caught a picture of a deer licking this block.

Honestly, I have not found any one of these blocks that work on my deer. I live more then 12 miles from the nearest oak tree. My deer crave acorns worst then a meth addict craves meth. I collect acorns from other places to out them out every once in a while as a treat and y deer go nuts over them. Worked great on the 19,000 BTU DSI furnace on my 2005 Kodiak 19FL Travel trailer.  Easy to install.

So far this device has not been very good.  The transmitter is very weak.  I have not been able to find a position or channel in my truck where it is not fuzzy.  I have the TeckNet MT-095 FM transmitter as well and it has functioned much better for then this one.  Also the pin jack is too short on this one.  It will not work on any phone that has any kind of case or skin.  It will not work on my NEC Terrain either.  It will fit on my Galaxy Skyrocket without any kind of case but it is a flush tight fit with no room to spare.I recommend spending a few dollars more for the TeckNet MT-095.

Pretty good. .223 bullet hits are easy to see at 100 and even at 200 yards through my 3X9x40mm Weaver scope. Even at 300 yards I could see hits, but just barley with my weaver 3X9X40mm scope,  but I had no problem seeing hits through my 3X12X40mm  Bushnell Sportsview scope.The multiple bulls eyes are great because you can use the same target multiple times. I even reuse my targets by coloring over the yellow with a black magic marker.

This light is pretty good, but I really wish the beam would focus down tighter. At 100 yard the beam is around 50 feet wide. This light is just about the same thing as the Mini Cree zoomable led flashlight, only a little brighter and a lot bigger.I have uploaded three pictures to compare. In the first picture you will see three lights. The round light on the left is Stanley LEDLIS 10W Lithium Ion LED Rechargeable Spotlight. The middle light is the SecurityIng® High Power, and the one on the right is the mini cree. The lights are aimed at a field at about 100 yards. As you can see the Stanely 10w spotlight is illuminating all the way to the back of the field which is about 200 yards. In the second picture, I aimed the Stanely 10W spotlight a tree that is 220 yards away. You can make the tree out. In the third picture, I aimed the SecurityIng® High Power at the same spot and you cannot see the tree.This light would be great if it would zoom in narrower, but it is still a pretty good light.  My biggest complaint is the five mode function.  Each time you turn it off, it goes to the next mode when you turn it back on.  I have many other 3 and 5 mode led lights.  Most of them reset to brightest each time you turn them on and then you can half press the button to change the mode.  Others remember the the mode the light was in when it was turned off and and that is the mode they are in when you turn them back on.  On this light though, the mode changes each time you turn it on and that can be a little inconvenient if you are using it for some purposes like hunting. I think I will try to go in an bypass the circuitry to see if I can make it a single mode light that comes on at max power each time.Here are product links to the two other lights used in the test.http://www.amazon.com/Stanley-LEDLIS-Lithium-Rechargeable-Spotlight/dp/B00AHJZBCG/ref=sr_1_1?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1417704958&sr=1-1&keywords=stanley+10whttp://www.amazon.com/Flashlight-Torch-Adjustable-Focus-Light/dp/B006E0QAFY/ref=sr_1_1?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1417704990&sr=1-1&keywords=mini+cree

This would be a five star deal if the laser was stable.  I bought this to use on my new Savage Axis 2 XP .223 rifle for varmint hunting.  When I got it out and first installed it, I was very please.  I have my gun sighted in at 200 yards and it was easy to adjust the laser to match the cross hairs.  I thought all was well until I got my gun out to go hunt tonight and looked through the scope and turned the laser on. It was about two feet off.  Had I not checked it before using it, I would have missed everything I tried to shoot at.  I got the Allen wrench to readjust it and did so, but while adjusting it, I noticed that any pressure I applied to the front part of the laser caused the laser to move radically. After zeroing it back in, I reached up and ever so lightly touched the front edge of the laser body and it knocked the laser off about a foot. I did the same to the opposite side and it moved back.  The laser is securely mounted and does not move.  It is the front part of the laser housing that moves.The bottom line is this laser is not stable at all and cannot be trusted. The slightest bump or touch will knock it way off. For a laser that is designed to be a targeting device this instability is inexcusable.  I am a top Amazon.com reviewer with hundreds of product reviews.  Listen to what I am saying.

This is a really good book if you want to learn about the heresies of the Faith Movement and learn about all the blasphemous, stupid and absurd things that men like Kenneth Copland and Benny Hinn have said over the years.  The reason I gave it only three stars is because of a couple things.  While I agree with everything of what Mr. Hanegraaff said about the faith movement and it's ties to the cult and occult, I found the book painfully redundant.  Just about everything about the faith movement is covered quite thoroughly in the first few chapters.  The rest is just an exercise in redundancy for the most part.The one thing that really concerns me is the very last section of this book titled, "The Three Universal Creeds".  In this section Mr. Hanegraaff quotes, "The Apostles' Creed", "The Nicene Creed" and "The Creed of Athanasius".  There are several reasons that I find Mr. Hanegraaff committed a great error in ending his book with these creeds.1. When you are making an intellectual argument against something you claim is false, you must closely examine yourself to make sure that while you are pointing a finger at someone else, you are not pointing three fingers at yourself.  While Mr. Hanegraaaff, makes some good arguments against the teachers of the faith movement, if he himself is guilty of the same kind of ideology, everything he said is called into question.  By quoting these three Catholic Creeds as his closing statement, Mr. Hanegraaaff solidly aligns himself with the Catholic church, which is guilty of almost every single one of the anti-Christ, anti-God heresies that Mr. Hanegraaaff condemns the faith movement teachers of making.  The Catholic church's whole foundation is based on the concept that there are men mere men who are "God's mouth piece on earth" (i.e. the pope).  The Catholic church historically is the worst distorter of the clear teaching of Holy scriptures and has taught many outrageous heresies over the centuries, and continues to do so today. It would take a book much larger then "Christianity in Crisis" to even scratch the surface of the spiritual crimes and scriptural heresies committed by the Catholic church over the last fifteen hundred years, but in the end you would find that the Catholic Church is the largest cultic organization on earth.  By quoting these Catholic Creeds Mr. Hanegraaaff is essentially using the statements of one cultic religious group to discredit the statements of another cultic religious group, and in doing so, he commits intellectual suicide and discredits himself as an unbiased judge.2. When making an intellectual argument, your closing statements are the most important part of your argument.  It is in your closing statements that you want to present your most solid evidence for your case.  While the Catholic creeds that Mr. Hanegraaaff quotes in his closing statements, do contain some truths derived from the Holy Scriptures, they are not in fact "The Inspired Word of God".  These creeds are not found anywhere in the Bible.  In using them as his closing statement, Mr. Hanegraaaff is exalting these creeds as the definitive authority on the subject of God and Truth.  Essentially, Mr. Hanegraaaff, is saying, "These are the most authoritative things that I believe and why you should believe what I am saying."  In doing so, Mr. Hanegraaaff, exalts these creeds even above the very scriptures themselves. Why?  Because, I am sure that, Mr. Hanegraaaff, knows hundreds, if not thousands, of passages from God's Holy Word, that he could have used as his closing statements, but he chose to use these creeds, because he considers them to be of more authority and the decisive word on the subject. In doing so, he also commits the same crime that he accuses the faith teachers of.  The faith teachers exalt themselves as the anointed and then claim that they receive "Special Revelation" that they then use as the authority on the subject of truth instead of the clear teachings of God's Word.  The Catholic church is guilty a thousand times over of committing this same exact crime, and by using their creeds in his final statements, Mr. Hanegraaaff has committed the same crime he accuses the faith teachers of.3. In a few places throughout the book, Mr. Hanegraaaff, refers to historically accepted Christian truths or traditions as an authoritative counter argument to what the faith teachers are teaching.  While this is not as much of a case of intellectual suicide (when it comes to his case against the faith teachers) as aligning himself with the Catholic church, it never the less is a huge hole in his over all case against the faith teachers.  Why?  Because one day in the future, what the faith teachers are teaching today will be considered, "Historic".  And, since what they teach is accepted and followed by million of people claiming to be Christians, including the most major and influential "Christian" figures of this day, these faith movement teachings could also be qualified as "Christian truths and traditions".  Imagine if you will, that at some point in the future another person like, Mr. Hanegraaaff, were to try to discredit a false teaching of that day by using as his source of authority, the accepted Christian Truths and Traditions of this era as taught by the faith movement teachers.  How much authority should that generation grant to that argument.  I propose, NONE.  So when, Mr. Hanegraaaff, uses as a point of authority what was historically accepted as Christian truths or traditions, he is relying, once again on man's opinion for the bases of his argument, and not the clear teachings of the Word of God.  This opens him and his whole case up for attack.Now I want to make it clear here, that there is much to be learned from this book as a whole, and I am not trying to discourage anyone from reading it.  Mr. Hanegraaaff, does present some very good, Bible based, solid arguments against the teaching of the faith movement.  His section on, "Apologetics: The Defense of the Faith", is very good and I highly recommend that that section should be learned by heart by every person who calls themselves a Christian.  I believe that, Mr. Hanegraaaff, was very sincere in his writing of this book, and that he desperately wants to free people from the deceptive teachings of the faith movement teachers and I applaud him for this effort.  My concern is that, Mr. Hanegraaaff, is blind to the hypocrisy of his own beliefs, especially when it comes to aligning himself with the Catholic church, which is guilty a thousand times over of the same heresies as the faith teachers he so vehemently attacks in this book.  I know this book was written a long time ago and my hope is that, since then, he has disaligned himself from the Catholic church, and now relies solely on the clear teaching of the Word of God for the bases of his arguments.
Worked perfectly for my Kenmore NG dryer.  The instructions were thorough and made it easy to complete the job.

I bought 3 of these to upgrade some old systems.  I put one in a Fujitsu laptop and the other two in two custom built Desktops. On the laptop I am running Windows Vista Business. On one desktop I am running Ubuntu Linux 14.04 and on the other I running Windows 7 Home premium. On all three systems there has been significant performance gains vs my old disk drives.  Start up time on my Win 7 desktop has been reduced from 2 Minutes to 32  seconds.  Applications open and run incredibly fast.  My overall system performance is smoother and faster on all systems.Now, I am seeing a lot of 1 star reviews here lately and all of them are centered on Firmware version 5.0.6, which supposedly has reduced the read and write performance of the drive from 450 Mbs to 170Mbps.  I have checked the drives I bought and they are all Firmware version 5.0.6.So what does this mean.  Well, I am not going to argue about the read write speeds and whether they have been reduced by the firmware update.  I am just telling what the real world results have been with my three systems.  The truth is, these people that are complaining are talking about maximum capabilities and very few people will ever push their computer hardware to their maximum capacity.  Another truth is that a computer is only as fast as it's slowest component.  So even if you had a hard drive that could read and write at 1TBps but your motherboard bus speed was a maximum of 200 Mbps, the fastest speed you would get out of the drive is 200Mbps.  The overwhelming majority of computers that consumers are using have cheaper motherboards with slower bus speeds.  There are motherboards with super fast speeds that cost more by themselves then what most people pay for their complete computer system, including monitor, keyboard and mouse.My point is this.  This drive is one of the lowest cost drives on the market. Other drive of the same size cost two to three times as much.  If you have the money to spend and want to pay more, go right ahead, but depending on your other system components, you may not see any better performance over this drive.  All I know is that this drive with firmware 5.0.6 drastically improved the performance of all three systems I put it in and I would not hesitate to buy it again if I needed to.

UPDATE: 10/06/2014Well after writing my original review, I bought one of these for myself and after using this phone for several months, I stand by everything I said in my original review, however, there are a couple things I would like to add.  I have actually stopped using the Terrain myself and switch back to my old S2 Skyrocket.  I really like the phone itself and it bothers me that I had to switch back.  The main reason I had to switch back has nothing to do with the phone itself, but has to do with the people who design the android apps.  I am a heavy business user that depends on several business related apps every day to do business.  Several of my business related apps do not function properly on the Terrain because they are designed exclusively for larger screened smartphone and/or are incompatible with candy bar style smartphones.  In a world where there still exist millions of candybar style smart phone like Blackberrys, I find it almost inconceivable and totally inexcusable that serious business oriented app designers would design an app that would only work on smartphone with huge touchscreens.  But alas, that is the irresponsible tech world we live in.  Because of this, I found myself having to carry my old S2 Skyrocket around with me so I could use it to run the apps I needed that were incompatible with the Terrain and it just made no sense, so I was forced to switch back, even though I liked the terrain much better.The second thing is that I require quite a few apps for many purposes (i.e. camscanner, acar, aquamail, etc, etc).  Even though this phone has the same amount of ram as my old S2 Skyrocket, I ran out of ram app space before I got all my apps installed that I need, and this is after disabling all other non essential apps like facebook and all the at&t crapware. I never ran into this bottle nrck no matter how many apps I installed on my s2 skyrocket (that has the same amount of ram), so I am not sure who is at fault here. Is it a phone design problem, an Android problem or something else.Regardless, I still like the phone and will continue to use it on days when I require a rugged waterproof phone.  It take pretty good pictures and videos and the battery life is much better then my Skyrocket.  The battery charges very fast too.  If they were charging 200 or 300 hundred for this phone I would reduce ny rating down to a 4 start, but at $85, it is well worth 5 stars.Original Review:Bought this for my son who destroyed his Galaxy S3 in less then three months. He has only had it a few days, but he already loves it. I think I will buy one for me for when my Samsung Galaxy bites the dust.Don't let the price fool you. This is a great phone with good specs. In fact, you will be hard pressed to find a ruggedized smartphone with these kinds of specs at any price. It has a dual core 1.5 Ghz processor, 8GB of internal memory (expandable to 32GB with MicroSD), 2G, 3G, 4G and LTE capability, Corning Gorilla Glass 2, Wi-Fi 802.11 b/g/n, Bluetooth 4.0, GPS radio, Accelerometer, proximity and compass sensors, and even a FM radio antenna for crying out loud. It has military grade water, dust and shock resistance. It has rear and front facing cameras. And the list goes on.Honestly, this phone should be priced in the $400 to $500 dollar range. The reason it is not, is only because the NEC company drop it's phone lines and does not offer support for them anymore. So what does this mean? Well, all that it means is that NEC will not be releasing any updates for the operating system on the phone. The phone comes with Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) which a very good version of android and should be good for as long as you will own the phone. Besides this, Android is an open source operating system and there are many people in the android community writing custom android operating systems (roms) for phones. For example, I am currently running android Kitkat on my old Samsung Galaxy S2 Skyrocket, but neither Samsung nor AT&T have released this upgrade for this old model phone. The android community made this ROM for my model of phone and it works great, actually it is much better then the ROMs from the manufacturers because it's not full of bloatware (useless programs manufactures and phone service providers stick in the operating system that you can't get rid of and that hog system resources).The bottom line is this. This phone is priced at $85 bucks and that is highway robbery for a phone with these specs. The one thing you need to know is that this phone is a WORK phone and is not intended to be used as a toy.There are some reviews that complain about how small the screen is. REALLY!! It's like these people cannot read or something! They order a candy bar style phone with a real keyboard and they expect to get a full size 5" screen like what comes on an S5 or something. ARE YOU KIDDING ME! How can they complain about the size of the screen when they knew that it was a small screen when they ordered the dang phone. That's like buying a red car and then complaining that the car is red. Are they being serious?I have not found any reviews that have any serious complaints about the actual functionality of this phone, and that is all that matters. Yes, there are always going to be some glitches with the android ROM or app incompatibility. But these kinds of glitches and complaints are present even in the newest of phones on the market. It is just part of a fast moving, ever evolving, technology market that never stays in one place long enough to work all the kinks out.PROS:1. Unbelievable price!2. Incredible specs for a ruggedized smartphone.3. Military grade water, dust and shock proofing.CONS:1. Manufacturer has discontinued support.Bottom Line:If you need a great rugged, waterproof, dust proof and shock proof, smartphone with LTE connectivity, your search is over. Don't worry about the lack of manufacturer support because, if this thing works out of the box, you should never need any support. At a price that is one fifth of any other ruggedized smartphone with these specs, you can afford to buy several, just in case you drive over your first one with a bulldozer and manage to break it.

I have to say that I really like it.  I have had way less problems with it then I did with two Samsung Galaxy phones I had previously.  The battery life is better then I ever had with my S2 and my Skyrocket. I have been able to use the phone for everything I used my Galaxy's for; scan receipts with Camscanner, track vehicle expenses with Acar app, use as a navigation device with Google maps, track vehicle engine data Torque via a bluetooth OBD2 scanner, do emailing on my 6 email accounts with Aquamail and much much more.  I do miss the larger screen on my Skyrocket, but I do not miss all the headaches with sluggish performance, freezes and glitchy hardware I had with both my Galaxy's.  My NEC Terrain seems like a solid well built device that runs smoothly and will last a long time.

Every American Christian should read this book and take what it says to heart.  Unlike a lot of modern theological books that are written by people sitting in air conditioned offices that have never paid a price for their belief in Jesus, this book was written by a man that eventually and voluntarily gave up his life for the cause of Christ.  As a person, who myself has faced persecution and arrest in anti-christ countries as a missionary, I can attest to the validity of the core message of this book.The idea that God loves you too much to let you suffer, is about the most blasphemous and false doctrine to ever permeate the Christian church. It is especially rampant in the United States of America where preachers preach the false doctrine of self gratification, self indulgent Christianity where God is reduced to genie in a bottle that you can rub with the write words (faith formulas) and get anything you want.  Where salvation and lavish prosperity is taught as a birthright because you were lucky enough to be born in the the country of America, and because of this God loves you more then any other race in the world and would never consider letting you suffer even the slightest bit.The Cost of Discipleship will open your eyes to the truth about what is necessary to truly follow the "real" God of the Bible.  An omniscient, omnipotent creator who deserves to be worshiped and served.  A God who deserves to be followed by His creation that loves Him above all else and trust Him and respects His decrees more then their own opinions, culture or traditions.  A God who requires His followers to honor Him as King in their lives and to be patriotic to His kingdom more then their own countries.

This is a good fan and cooler.  I bought two of these and used them on AMD CPUs (it can be used for an Intel CPU as well). The reason I cannot give it five stars is because it is a lot more difficult to put together then any other Fan/Heatsink I have ever used.  The instructions are not clear on how you are supposed to do it and once you figure it out, you find out that one of the screws that is needed to attach one of the feet is almost impossible to get in because is sits directly under the fan and there is no way to get a screwdriver on it without taking the fan and fan housing off.  I was able to get the screw in without taking the fan off with a pair of needle nosed pliers, but it was very difficult and took a lot of patience.The other reason I cannot give this five stars is because on both of my motherboards it blocked one of my ram ports making it unusable. This thing is huge and requires a lot of room.Aside from the above problems, I have no doubt that it will keep my cpu cool.  It is well built and very low priced for what you get.PROS:1. Low cost.2. Well built.3. Works for both AMD and INTEL based systems.CONS:1. Poor instructions difficult to assemble (for AMD system).2. Interferes with Ram ports on AMD Motherboards.

These are great little cheap surveillance cameras.  I bought two of them to install in my parents house to monitor it remotely while they are on a two month long vacation to Canada.  There have been a lot of break-ins in their neighborhood.  I chose this model because it has alarm inputs that allow me to wire door sensors to the camera that will take pictures of anyone opening the front or back doors of the house and send me alerts via email when the doors are opened.  This method is way more reliable then using motion detection, which results in false alarms and failed detection.  So far they have worked flawlessly since I installed them.I use the IP Cam Remote app on my android phone to remotely access the cameras and control them.  For the price that I paid ($43) these things are 5 star.  They function well and come with their own DDNS (dedicated internet address you can use for remote access).  The video quality is about the only area that could be complained about, but this no different then any other budget security cam.  I have paid as much as twice as much for other cameras that video quality that is just as bad.  Honestly video quality in security cameras is a rarity.  Just think of all the video you have seen on the news from store video cams of robberies.  Have you ever seen one that was clear and easy to identify the perp?  See what I mean?  And those are commercial grade cameras!  There are cameras you can buy that will give you better video quality, but they are not cheap.  The video quality of this camera is good enough for most security proposes and for the price, they cannot be beat.  NOTE: The lens can be manually focused to improve video clarity by rotating the black ring around the lens.One thing that I have to mention hear is that, to my surprise, this camera came with the special connector that goes to the alarm input panel.  I have bought other cameras with alarm inputs that did not include the connector and had to buy them extra.  Let me tell you, those little buggers are hard to find.  The last time I had to order them from England because that was the only place I could find some for sale.PROS:1. Low Price2. Has Alarm Inputs and comes with the special plug connector.3. Includes dedicated DDNS for remote access (so you don't have to set this up through another provider).4. Focusable lens (manual)CONS:1. Low but average video quality for cameras in this price range.Bottom Line:For a $43 remotely accessible security camera with night vision and alarm inputs, it is really hard to find anything to complain about.  For anyone needing cheap home security and remote monitoring these things are the way to go.
Bought this for my son and he loves it.  I have another solar powered model similar to this one and it has never let me down.

I monitor my grandparents (elderly, home bound) and parents house (travel and are away from home a lot).  I am using these in combination with security cameras to monitor traffic that go in and out of doors.  My cameras are set to take pictures each time a door is opened and these things have worked flawlessly.  Of course you need a security camera that has alarm inputs (not many have them) for this to work.  Using these door sensors is way more reliable then using the motion detection feature of the security camera. With these, there is never a false alarms or missed events like I use to get when I was using motion detection.  The cameras take the pictures and email them to me and I get them on my smartphone in just a few seconds no matter where I am.  If I get a picture of an unauthorized person going in their houses I can access the camera remotely and monitor their activities and if they are up to no good, I can alert the police and provide them photos if they don't get their in time.This summer I was stuck in downtown traffic in Houston Texas, when I got a Front Door alarm email from my Grandparents house in Lubbock Texas 500 miles away.  The picture was of a man I did not recognize, so I remotely access the camera to see what was going on.  The young man was standing in the front door way talking a miles an hour to my grandfather who has dementia.  I immediately called their house and got my grandmother and asked her who the man was and what he wanted.  She said he was a salesman trying to sale them a home security system.  She then walked over to him and said to the man, "We don't need anything you are selling".  She then told them man to look up at the camera and said, "My grandson is watching you right now and is on the phone asking who you are and he has pictures of you."  I watched the whole thing and it was so funny.  The poor security alarm salesman just hung his head and walked away.  LOL!

This is my second order of these.  I have ordered 4 packs (400 DVDs) each time for DVD duplication of my Dad's video book of his life on the foreign mission field.  These are the best price I can find on full face printable DVD-Rs anywhere and I have had not problems with them so far.

I guess if I were to talk about just the housing base, I would have to give this maybe a three star.  The housing base is okay, but very unstable.  Even with everything tightened up it is still floppy and will shake in the wind.  But the housing is not the worst thing about this unit, that prize goes to the lens cover.The lens cover on this makes it completely worthless.  It distorts the image and invert the colors.  Everyone knows that security cams don't have the best image to begin with, and this thing makes them 3 times worse.  During the day time the colors are inverted and the image kind of looks like looking at an old color negative film slide, a slightly out of focus one at that.  If that were all it did, I would say okay, it might still be usable, but that is not all. Keep reading.This lens cover destroys any night vision use of the camera.  At night when the Infrared lights on the camera turn on to give you night vision, the IR light reflects off the lens cover and turns everything white.  It is IMPOSSIBLE to see anything at night.  It is like looking at a bright flashlight that is being shined into the camera lens.The bottom line is that lens cover on this thing is made out of the wrong material.  I have other outdoor cameras with similar looking lens covers and they don't have these problems.  The colors on my other outdoor cameras look natural and they do not reflect IR light.  The manufacturer of this unit needs to do some research on what type of lens material to make their lens covers out of.  They need to find a material that does not invert the colors and that allows IR light to pass through it without filtering it or reflecting it.PROS:Low CostAllows most indoor cameras to be used outdoorsCONS:Unstable constructionLens cover distorts images and inverts colors.Not usable at night because lens cover reflects IR light into the camera lens.Final thought.  This is a great idea that needs some more development, at least by this manufacturer.  As it is, this unit is not ready for sale to the public.

Update: Warning! Dangerous! Burn risk!Well, my first unit died.  Actually it almost burned up while on my ear.  I had just finished a call and left it on my ear when all the sudden I felt pain in my ear and ripped the thing off.  It was extremely hot and even though I switched the power button to off, it continued to heat up to the point of melting and eventually died when the battery ran out.  I had all kinds of problems with my first unit from day one, and I have a friend that also says he has all the same problems.  After it died, I called into Plantronics and they were very helpful.  They were very concerned that it almost burned me and had me send my unit to a special technician to have the unit dissembled and investigated to see what caused it to heat up.  They were very eager to replace the unit. I honestly did not want another legend and requested another model.  They offered me the new Edge, but since it does not have an ear loop like the Voyager models, I did not want it.  So I had to take another Legend.  Well, my new Legend has all the same problems as my first one and more.  I absolutely hate it.  I really can't understand why so many people give this model high reviews, nobody that I know that has used one likes it.UPDATE:I am beginning to hate this thing.  4 out 5 of people complain about the the sound quality of my voice when holding a conversation.  In most cases I have to switch to the handset to continue talking with them.  I thought it might be a bad mic in my unit, but I talked with a friend that has the same model and he said he has the same problem.UPDATE:In my original review, I had not had this unit long enough to comment on it's features.  Again I want to state here that I am a long time Voyager user that has used 4 different models of the Voyager Pro line.  My last voyager before this one was the Voyager Pro HD.Now that I have had this unit for a month, I can better comment on it's features and compare them to the Voyager Pro HD that it replaced (my wife washed it). There are several things that I will have to say that are improved in the Legend over the Pro HD.  The ear sensors that automatically switch from the phone to the ear piece are much better on the Legend then on the Pro HD. The sensors on the Pro HD only worked every now and then, but the sensors on the Legend have worked every time I have tried it.Another feature that I have found to be better is voice command and recognition.  I absolutely could never use my Pro HD for any kind of voice command or voice to text (v2T) function in anything less then a perfectly quite environment. Using it while driving was impossible. But I am able to use my Legend while driving and in a room where other people are talking, and I would have to say that it is surprisingly accurate in noisy situations, but of course it is not perfect.  Battery life has been exceptional for me as well. All of my Voyagers have had great battery life but I feel I am getting even more out of this Legend.The one thing that is not better and is actually worst in the Legend vs the Pro HD is the bluetooth connection strength. The distance that I can walk away from my phone before the reception starts to degrade is about half the distance of what it was with my Pro HD.  About 10 feet is all the range I can get out of this Legend, where as I could get 20 to 30 feet away from Pro HD before the reception started to degrade.This unit does have a little better noise cancellation then the Pro HD, but noise cancellation in of itself creates other problems.  Noise cancellation is the process of filtering out the ambient sound from the audio stream that is going into the mics.  Plantronics accomplishes this through dual mics, one to hear what's coming out of your mouth and one to monitor the ambient sounds in the room.  The built in software tries to filter out the ambient sound that it is receiving from the second mic, but in doing so it also filters out any audio tones from your voice that are in the same range as the audio tones in the ambient sound.  The result of this filtering is that the outputted audio (what the person on the other end of the line hears) is muffled and lower in volume.  This is one of the reasons that there are several reviews about sound quality issues with this unit.  But this problem is not unique to the Legend, it effects all bluetooth units with noise cancellation technology across the board, with maybe the exception of Jawbone devices, which does not use speakers, but instead uses vibration sensing technology to convert the vibrations it feels in your jaw into sound.The two main drawback of this device is the proprietary charging cable and the volume control which does not work with my Galaxy Skyrocket (read my original review for details).PROS (over the Voyager Pro HD)1. Better ear sensors2. Improved voice command and V2T function.3. Improved Voice Cancellation.4. Improved Battery life.CONS1. Shorter bluetooth reception range.2. Rare Proprietary charging cable that is difficult to find and expensive to replace.3. Volume control that will not work unless in an active call.ORIGINAL REVIEW:This is my 4th Plantronics Voyager headset in 6 years.  I really like the Voyager line and have been relatively pleased with their quality and durability.  I am hard on my headsets and these things stand up to my abuse.  I normally only have to replace them when I lose them, which coincidentally, is why I bought this new Legend.I have only been using this new Legend for a day so I can't really comment on it's features yet, but so far it has been about on par with my last Voyager headset, the HD Pro.  I am only writing this review now, because there is one thing right out of the box that is a glaring defect of this unit over the other models I have owned.  This unit does not use the standard micro USB charging standard that my last three Voyager units did.  Honestly, this came as a huge surprise to me because I saw this mentioned no where in the description when I bought it.  I would have certainly never bought this Legend had I known that it came with a unique custom charging cable.  I really have a hard time believing the stupidity of Plantronics in deciding to go with a custom proprietary charging cable when the rest of the electronics industry, even the old hold out Apple, are all going with the micro usb standard for charging small electronics. Just when you think the environmentally unfriendly idiocy of old was gone, when every electronic gadget had it's own proprietary charger and you had to carry an extra bag along with you on trips just to house all your chargers; Plantronics starts playing that old game again. Who cares if it creates more toxic landfill waste and customers have to carry a bag full of different cables, when a single cable would do. Right?Again I want to make it extremely clear that this headset has a custom "PROPRIETARY" charging cable.  You will not find this cable in most stores.  It is very unique, and if you lose the cable or need and extra, you will have to order it online.  You have been warned.The only other thing that I have found so far about the Legend that I consider a con is that the volume control on the headset does not work in conjunction with my Samsung Galaxy Skyrocket.  The headset controls will not increase the volume of the headset and the phone volume controls have no effect on the headset either.  The only way I have found to get the headset volume controls to work is to wake the phone up and try to adjust the volume, and while the volume bar is active on the phone, then and only then can I adjust the volume by using the headset controls.I will probably return this Legend and buy another HD Pro.  If I don't, I may update this review later on.

Okay, this is the 10th on of these that I have ordered.  I have to keep ordering because everyone I meet (family mostly) goes crazy about it and I end up giving it to them (they are so dang cheap).  I buy extras to keep on hand just to give away.  I do not know how they can make these thing this cheap.  I am going upload a video review and a photo where I compare this headlight to a 2000 lumen Stanley FatMax LED spotlight.  You will be surprised to see just how bright this little headlight is.

These boxes are good for the price.  They are not great.  The cardboard is kind of soft compared to some other boxes I have bought from places like U-Line.  Honestly, I think Walmart gets their boxes from the same supplier.  I compared the boxes they sell at walmart to these and they were identical.  The price of the ones at walmart are about the same as these before shipping cost are included.  Once you add in the shipping cost, these boxes end up more expensive then buying them at walmart.

These boxes are good for the price.  They are not great.  The cardboard is kind of soft compared to some other boxes I have bought from places like U-Line.  Honestly, I think Walmart gets their boxes from the same supplier.  I compared the boxes they sell at walmart to these and they were identical.  The price of the ones at walmart are about the same as these before shipping cost are included.  Once you add in the shipping cost, these boxes end up more expensive then buying them at walmart.

The bottom line here is that this is the best deal on large cell bubble wrap anywhere.  I have looked and looked for a better deal and you just can't find a lower price on large cell bubble wrap then this.  The problem is that you never know what quality of bubble wrap you are going to get when you order here.  I have ordered from here three times and each time I got a different quality of bubble wrap, it also came in a different format each time.  Some came in a huge roll and others came in cardboard box.  The first batch I ordered was decent quality.  The second batch I ordered was really bad; the bubbles were not fully inflated and 25% of the bubbles were flat.  The third batch I ordered was the best (it came in the cardboard box).  The bubbles in the third batch were so full they were hard, like a balloon that is on the verge of bursting.If I ever need large cell bubble wrap I will order here and pray I get the good stuff.

I really like this reader much better the I do the "Juiced System's Multi-functional 4 in 1 Adapter" I had before.  I had trouble getting a good connection because of the short micro usb stem on the Juiced card reader.  This card readers has a nice pigtail that makes it much easier to use.  That and it cost one forth of the price of the Juiced adapter that does the same thing.

This review is for the Roku 3500R HDMI Streaming Stick.When I received the device it would not work with none of my TVs when plugged into the HDMI ports.  When I contacted Roku support about they immediately said that they would send me an HDMI extender that would fix the problem.  I asked them why they were so sure a simple extension cord would fix the problem and they said that there was a known defect with the HDMI connection on the 3500R being too short and not making contact with most TVs.  It took a few days for the part to get to me and it did fix the problem, but just barely.  You have to hold your tongue just right for the 3500R to make a connection, even with the extender, and if it gets moved even the slightest, it loses connection.Once I got it to work, I thought my problems were over.  I thought wrong.  The device gets extremely hot and freezes up and has to be unplugged to unfreeze it.  After a long troubleshooting session and Roku support, it was finally revealed that the Roku 3500R is an HD content ONLY device that requires a minimum of a 3.5 Mbps internet connection to work.  Roku recommends at least a 5 Mbps connection for best performance.  Of course this is stated nowhere in the documentation or on the Amazon.com ad page.  The bottom line is that people who have a basic cable or DSL internet connection cannot use the 3500R.  I have a good solid 3 Mbps connection and I cannot use the 3500R with my connection according Roku tech support.  Roku support emphatically stated that the 3500R will only stream HD content.  I was very surprised to find out about this limitation. Most other internet streaming devices I have used had smart bandwidth sensing technology and would adjust the quality of the video stream according to the speed of the bandwidth connection.  Roku support suggested that the solution to the problem I was having with their device was for me to spend another $30 a month to increase my bandwidth to make it compatible with their device.  I AM NOT KIDDING! I asked them if Roku thought it wise to make an internet streaming device that would only be usable by a small fraction of internet users.  They had no comment.  I asked them why this LIMITATION was not mentioned anywhere in the documentation or in the advertised specs?  Their response was that; "The 3500R is a beta product and they were still working all the bugs out."  These are Roku's words, not mine.THE ROKU 3500R IS A BETA PRODUCT WITH BUGS!  Wow!  Glad to know that Roku has no problem selling a product that is buggy and has known defects and crippling limitation.  Not to mention using all of us as unpaid beta testers.Aside from the hardware defects and software limitations and bugs, the 3500R would be a nice streaming device, but there are some features I immediately found lacking in the interface as well.  Here are the features found lacking.1. No Free Content filter option:The main reason I got the Roku is to watch free content. I have never and never will pay for cable or satellite TV.  I am satisfied with watching commercials to pay for my TV habit.  The problem is that most of the channels that Roku promotes are paid channels or subscription channels that require you to have a cable or satellite subscription.  Now I understand that this may be good for some people, but why not offer an option to list only free content for people like me. I mean, if you are like me and are looking for free content only, you will spend hours wading through Roku's endless menus to find something to watch.  It takes 3 to 4 steps on each channel to find out of there is any free content available, and each time you have to go back to the beginning and start all over again.  This takes several minutes each time you try a new show or channel because the 3500R is very slow to load.  It would be great if Roku would add an option to the menu that would allow you to list only free content.  It would save users hours of time wading through hundreds of paid and subscription only channels and content.2. No Parental Controls or mature content filtering.As a parent that likes to filter what my child watches (especially what they can access when I am not around) I found it to be a huge oversight that Roku does not offer any kind of parental controls or content filtering options.  Just like with trying to find free content, you have to go through multiple steps to see what the ratings of shows are.  If you are a parent, let me warn you right now, the Roku can access almost ANY kind of video on the internet and there are even channels that are dedicated to adult content that your kids can access without any restrictions.  It would be great if Roku would add an option to filter all content by a rating system and/or require a password or pin to watch anything over a certain rating. I find it appalling that in a world where our children are being targeted by perverts, that a responsible company would not make filtering adult content for the protection of our children a priority.3. No Access to Network TV channels like ABC, NBC, and CBS.There are a few shows that I like to watch that are on network TV.  I have an HTPC contacted to my TV as well and I use it to go directly to these channels via a browser and watch these shows.  I was very surprised that the Roku has none of these channels and only offers these shows (which you get see for free in a bowser) as a "Pay per Episode" option.The Bottom Line!If you have a Nintendo, X-Box 360, Smart TV,  HTPC or any other device that allows internet streaming, you have no need for a Roku of any kind, especially if you do not have some type of cable or satellite TV subscription service.  A Roku device offers no advantage over a standard internet browser and is actually a lot more limited.  You can access everything a Roku can right on your computer, actually you can access a lot more from your computer.  You can access HULU free from your computer, not from Roku (Paid Hulu Plus only).  You can access Network TV shows (CBS, NBC, ABC etc.) from their home site for free on a computer; not from a Roku.  You can install parental controls on you computer, not on a Roku.  You can connect any desktop or laptop and most tablets to your TV to use it as and HTPC and get all the content on the internet you want right on your TV.If you already have a cable or satellite subscription it might be worth it to get a Roku, but aside from that, I can't really see any advantage to the Roku.  Actually, all I see is disadvantages, and that is not even considering the hardware and software defects and limitations of the 3500R.
I fell asleep after 5 minutes.  Pretty scenery can only keep you awake so long.  The narration is about as boring and as dry ask Ben Stien's eye drop commercial.

Volume 1 is the only one of this series that holds true to the definition of Acoustic.  I fell in love with volume 1 so I bought volumes 2,3 & 4.  Volume 1 sounded very professional with excellent singing.  It is one of those worship CDs that calms you and makes you want to quietly sing along. Unfortunately, 2, 3, & 4 did not follow the same style.  The quality of the recording does not sound professional and the singing sounds like a regular church group.  Honestly, they sound like they were made by a hometown group in their garage; not a professional group in a recording studio.  I have listened to volume 1 all the way through a hundred times, but I can't get through 2, 3, & 4.  The style and singing of volumes 2, 3, & 4 irritates me like fingers dragging on a chalkboard.  It's not just me either.  My wife and kids, who love volume 1, start screaming at me to turn it off when I try to play volumes 2, 3, & 4 on our home stereo or in the car.  I am sure there are probably those that would love the style of 2, 3, & 4.  I really wish the same that volumes 2, 3, & 4 were made with the same style as volume 1.  It is too bad that they were not.

Unlike most obscene modern TV series that promote sexual immorality and human depravity to unprecedented levels, Dr Quinn is decent show about decent people with decent morals.  There is a whorehouse represented in the show, but the women are depicted as victims of circumstance that detest the life they live, rather then the modern trend of praising sexual promiscuity and demeaning anyone who seeks to live a decent moral life as stupid and crazy.The acting is superb and the stories will touch your heart. Like most series, season one is always the best.  If the writers kept this pattern through the rest of the series, it would be great.  Hopefully, they did not follow the patter of many other TV series that start out with a great decent cast and story line and then, once people are hooked, they slowly start adding and pushing political moral agendas that are counter to American traditional values. I have not seen the later seasons, so I cannot say if this show does follow this pattern.  I thoroughly enjoyed season one though and recommend it.

Chocolate and caramel are two of my favorite things, and I have a lot of experience with candy that combine them together. My gold standard here, for milk chocolate, remains the Godiva Milk Chocolate Caramel Bar, which is magnitude better than their bite-sized Milk Chocolate Caramels and similarly a magnitude better than these. However, those of us who have to watch our waistlines can't chow down on large chocolate bars without paying the price, and sometimes a little bit is better than a lot.In those cases, these are a good option. Comparable to the competitive Godiva minis, it doesn't stint on the caramel - which is soft and sweet and adequately coated in chocolate. Whether that's a good thing depends likely on whether you like Hershey's milk chocolate. I typically do, in mixtures, although not always in stand-alone. (I'm more of a dark chocolate fan; if I'm in the mood for pure milk chocolate but not for breaking the bank, I usually go for Dove.)There is one danger inherent in ordering soft-filled candies in bags online. A small portion of the candy in the bag I received came crushed. I have yet to find a candy at a moderate price-point that avoids this issue. It's a built-in risk of the packaging. Sometimes you find the same issue buying them in stores, when they are damaged in transit.When it comes to any grocery product that is widely available, price-checking is a good idea.

Having had to buy medical gloves to care for a diabetic pet, I soon discovered that they were useful to me in other contexts as well - especially cooking. I do not like handling meat with my bare hands for fear of cross-contamination. I wear medical gloves when making meatloaf or hamburgers or when cutting chicken or other poultry - really for anything that requires much contact. This is my first go at Ammex, and I have found these gloves a good and reasonable alternative to the brand I usually buy  (SafeTouch latex gloves by Dynarex - it doesn't matter to me if my gloves have latex or not). They are currently cheaper. This lot has been supple and comfortable and has withstood activity. I am not a large woman, but the large gloves are a comfortable fit for me. My hands and feet are woefully stubby. If you have very large hands, the large may be too small.

I have been using these shower gels for a couple of weeks now and have different feelings about each. They all lather richly and seem to clean about equally (with caveat for the gourmet, which has abrasives in it).My favorite is the "Perfume" gel. The one I have is rose-scented, and while the scent is quite strong it doesn't seem to trigger my scent-sensitivity. I am inclined to migraines and cannot wear perfume because of that. I find this leaves a noticeable but not overpowering scent of rose behind that dissipates gradually over a few hours.Following on that, the gourmet "mango" has a very pleasant but far more subtle scent. As mentioned above, it has an abrasive agent in it to help exfoliate. Some shower gels overdo this to the point that using them becomes unpleasant. I haven't experienced that with this one, but as with any abrasive gel you want to handle with care. If your skin is sensitive, you may suffer for it.Finally, the "shine" gel was a bit of a disappointment. I was counting on some lingering shimmer from it, in line with the brief ad copy, but so far as I can tell it rinses off cleanly. Ordinarily, this is a good thing in a soap, but it does kind of scoff at the whole notion of "sparkling" after you use it.Currently, the set has a decent price for the volume of product. The packaging is normal for shower gels, which means "slippery when soapy/wet" - not a feature I appreciate, but I don't feel like docking them for being like everybody else.Preference plays such a major part in scents that it's hard to say that what I like will also please you, but these products have certainly pleased me.

According to my son, who has been using this exclusively for several weeks now, this is a massive step up in electric razor quality, although at a premium price - gets closer, more comfortably than any of the mid-priced electric shavers he's tried before. It charges quickly and performs quietly and well, even on wet skin. The self-cleaner is a bit complicated, however, and the base is bulky - it takes more counter real estate than he can easily spare. He's found these worth it. In the past, his main gripe with electric razors has been their inefficiency, as a result of which he tends to abandon them quickly for manuals. This one is a winner.

This system may be a little complex for beginners/non-professionals, like me. While set-up is pretty easy, but the system is not optimized for the casual. Instructions are minimal. The audio output is in CAF format, which has to be converted to use pretty much anywhere, it seems. However, while I feel like I've just scratched the surface on it in three weeks of use, I've managed to get it functional and to produce some pretty interesting o output. Sound quality is good, and I like the Studio One software. The effects and virtual instruments library is pretty extensive, and it can add a lot of variety to your tracks. If you're wanting to master this, it's likely to take some time (unless you're already deeply familiar with this kind of thing), but it's got features that are usable out the box, and those who are patient may find plenty to do at the beginner level as they learn their way around.

This has worked like a charm for me. Charge it up, load it up, and then you can access content either regularly (like any flash drive) or wirelessly. It's a huge benefit when you have wifi devices with limited storage space. I have been able to smoothly stream movies to my iPad and iPhone.Note that it's critical that you download the right app. SanDisk has more than one, and they offer you a visual identification guide that you must follow. Also note that you may have to go into "settings" to get your device picked up even if you have the right app.

There are some people who are specialists in shampoos who can talk about the "handfeel" and the lathering abilities and the kinds of things you'd read about in a hair design magazine. I'm not one of them, and my 18-year-old son, who is using this product, is even less.What I can say is this - he's been using this product for several weeks now with good success. It cleans his hair well and leaves it soft and manageable. It does have a distinctive perfume, as all Axe products do. Hard to characterize it, exactly, but it's a bit piney - kind of outdoorsy and fresh. The smell lingers. Have care what other scented products you mix it with.Also be aware that one of the key ingredients here is Dimethiconol. This silicone-based product can make your hair look fantastic - it coats it for shine and to smooth out frizzle. It also builds up. You should occasionally (every two weeks for instance) use a clarifying shampoo (wash rinse wash rinse - as Dimethiconol is not simple to dissolve) to strip off the build-up, or your hair may eventually become lank and limp. The Dimethiconol build-up can prevent the hair shaft from absorbing moisture and the clarifying shampoo is drying, so this is probably not a good shampoo for you if your hair is prone to dryness.

This is fast, as promised - delicious? More like tasty, courtesy of the tons of seasonings (especially sodium) in the mix. It's a good, quick, unhealthy food option, with 37% of the average daily allotment of sodium in one relatively modest 230 calorie serving. The rice is mushy, the consistency overall like a thick stew. If you're looking for a quality meal, you're looking in the wrong place. This is more like fast food for those days when you don't have time or maybe budget for fast food.

I want to be upfront here that my problem with this book is the read. Enrique's story is an important one to add context to the life of an illegal immigrant to the United States and to her family, to the impact that it creates for her son, for the steps that he is willing to take to avoid a life of crippling poverty, apparently without hope. Whether you are for relaxing standards or for tightening them or even for just keeping them the same, it's still a topic that deserves thoughtful consideration and understanding from every aspect.But this book - oh, my word, this book. I found it repetitive and dull; a horrible slog to get through. It's a well-researched story, and I don't doubt that the newspaper series the book is based on deserved the Pulitzers it received. But the constant regurgitation of not only facts, but words and phrases went a fair way to killing momentum. The focus not only on key details that help set the emotional heart of the participants but also on trivial, exhaustive details killed the rest.Kudos to Nazario for the hard-work of putting this profile together, but I did not even remotely enjoy the read.

Kelly Carlin's memoir is exactly that - Kelly Carlin's memoir. It is not a biography of George Carlin, although George plays into his daughter's life, obviously, and in a major way. A "daddy's girl," Kelly is frank about the impact that her much-loved father's genius and his substances (as well as those of her mother) impacted her. Those interested in reading about other people's lives may find much of value here about the experience of growing up in such an environment, about trying to figure out your own role and be successful in your own light in the shadow of such fame. Those looking for the insightful and sometimes biting social commentary of George himself would do better to look elsewhere.Kelly's strengths here are her candor and completeness. The latter also presented occasional challenges to me, as there were times when the reading was a bit slow. On the whole, however, an enjoyable and informative experience.

Fairly classy looking clippers (am I the only one who sees a Tuxedo front?) are sharp as promised and work pretty well, cutting in one go and catching (most) nail clippings in the rubberized surround. They are on the small side. Currently the Amazon description does not specify that these are for fingernails, but the product packaging itself does. It is a little difficult for me, at least, to empty out the nail clipping - pulling it away from the backing is tricky.

For a ready-made sauce, this  Zesty Orange is a winner for my family - a tad bit on the sweet side and a bit mild, it works well with egg rolls and crispy fried chicken nuggets. While it doesn't match the flavor depth of an at-home sauce with fresh ingredients, it's easily as a good as any other ready-made sauce I've ever tried and for one of us (my husband) his favorite.

This lotion has a creamy feel and a smooth application, although my son (the primary user) says it is a bit thick. He doesn't like the feeling of lotions coating his skin but is acne-prone and needs a moisturizer to top his acne medication. Importantly, in the week he's been using it, it hasn't broken him out. He discovered early on that it's important to apply it thin; sunscreens have a tendency to sting the eyes when you sweat, and this one is no exception. Applying it thin seems to eliminate that problem. Worthy of note, it's not a very strong sunscreen nor is it a sports sunscreen. If you're planning on spending a lot of time out doors, you'll want to use a specific product for that purpose.

Survive the Night has a strong start, with a solid setup of some interesting characters. Fresh from rehab, Casey is a bit of a good girl gone bad on the cusp of deciding what role she'll take next. A popular high school athlete, after an accident sidelines her from the team she takes to drugs and a new crowd of friends whose partying could get her killed. On this night, quite quickly.The basic premise is an intriguing one, but ultimately fell short for me. The idea of being trapped in dark sewers with a killer is a pretty horrific one, but as the plot advanced I kind of checked out - or more formally "lost my suspension of disbelief." Maybe some compelling explanations of what was going on could have saved it for me, but there's nothing like that - so it wound up feeling random.That said, the writing is overall solid with a nice flow and consistently constructed characters. While the plot lost me, the writing made it possible for me to finish anyway (mainly because I was curious to see just how unreliable our narrator was). I wouldn't write off the author (and might even read her earlier book, with the hopes that it will be better grounded),  but this book was a solid "meh"If not for the overall deftness of writing, this would be a 2 at best for me. Solid prose bumps it up.

For people already familiar with the classic SIMON, this game will hold few surprises, which for me is not a bad thing, as nostalgia is what interested me in this product. The original SIMON was fun. Relatively melodic, playable in both competitive and solo modes, it was pretty addictive, with a high replay value.This version essentially offers one game - what the classic called "Simon Says." In this game, Simon presents players with an increasingly complex sequence of sounds (including the visual cue of lighting the colored wedge corresponding to the noise), and players must reproduce them. You can play this game in solo mode or in "pass" mode, where each player has a unique sequence to remember.Missing from the original are the "player adds" mode (in which Simon makes a sound, you reproduce and add a sound, Simon reproduces and adds a sound, and so on) and the "choose your color" mode (in which 2, 3 or 4 players play the game simultaneously, each operating a single color - 2 colors for 2 players; for 3 players a color is eliminated - with players being eliminated gradually until the last man standing). The Micro series is also missing the difficulty level selector - a slider that allowed you to adjust the number of sequences Simon would offer to declare you having "won" the game. I do not remember the original Simon tracking your score numerically, as this one does - maybe that compensates for the fact that most of us will end this game with the "razz" sound of failure.What the smaller version lacks in diversity it makes up in portability. The volume on this is not so loud that I can't tolerate it in the car (your mileage may vary, as they say), and it's easy enough to slip into a backpack for play anywhere. (Lacking an "off" switch, note, it may be noisy in doing this. This is not a good game to bring for a school game day, unless your teacher has a Phillips head screwdriver to put back a removed battery.) A larger child can hold this in one hand to play if he or she chooses, depressing the wedges with the fingers of the other hand. It can also be placed on a surface, although its small size means it's rather easily knocked off. (A catastrophe that doesn't seem to hurt the game, but may impact the frustration level of the player.)Note that there is another miniature version of the game - included in the set I liked above and individually at Hasbro 14397018500 Simon Memory Game Carabiner Edition - which offers a carabiner presumably specifically to attach it to backpacks and the like. I have not tried or even seen in person that version, so I'm not sure how it relates to this in size. But according to reviews I've found, it also lacks an "off" switch.

What this is: a decent budget curtain that will give you a little bit of light diffusion and perhaps some privacy screening. (Budget is an important word here.)What it's not: a high-end elegant lace curtain.These curtains are not expensive; if you're looking for cheap curtains that imply you spent a lot of money, these are not the curtains you want. If your curtains can be unabashedly inexpensive, they serve. They are heavy polyester thread and will not float in the breeze like finer lace.The lace has a nice design for me, at least - I'm not a huge fan of florally, old-fashioned lace.

This book was a page turner for me; highly poetic in places but not overly purple, it presented an extremely sympathetic protagonist who has a serious disconnect from his own story. It's an interesting place to be, as readers. We can understand the bits that Todd cannot, so what the other characters in the story say and do makes more sense to us than it does to him. We also have a rich view of Todd's own interior monologues, so we know what he cannot vocalize to them. It carried me along like some kind of mute witness, wishing that I could actually do something to straighten things out.Todd is not only disconnected from the events in his life, but from the people. Those around him largely see a flat, affectless aging man, a man whose condition perplexes them or causes them to view him as less than human. We see a person longing for connection, simultaneously reaching back into his past for memories of the mother who loved him best and into the present for a woman who might love him now. None of which he can truly convey.So much rich texture in what is really a small story. I found it heartbreaking and heartwarming - often at the same time.

This is a very sturdy "tablet light" for preschoolers that really delivers. Brightly colored, fun, and offering easy access to tons of educational apps, it's a pretty good way to let a child feel sophisticated (if you have iPad envy in your house, for instance) while still limiting her to age appropriate activities (and limiting the potential to do damage). The video camera and voice recorder are fun; the ability to personalize, fantastic. The apps are diverse and engrossing.That said, it does have some potential challenges. We encountered our first on setup, as two computers declined to recognize the LeapFrog. This proved to be a Firewall issue; once permission was given in our settings for the device, it functioned without issue.More troubling, it eats batteries like air. If this sees a lot of use, you're better off with rechargeables. I'm considering investing in the recharger pack, which is evidently compatible - users both here and there have said as much.

While time is the only true test of a hose's durability, this one impresses out the box. Sturdy and heavy, it's a solid performer that has so far lived up to its "kink resistant" commitment. It's got a good touch to it, to boot, with an exterior with a tiny bit of flex. I'm not capable of measuring its full strength, both because I live in the city and because I have absolutely no mechanism for reviewing the pounds per square inch it delivers.UPDATE: While I received this in exchange for an honest review, it impressed me enough that I have subsequently purchased two more. I'm a fan.

The only problem with this product - which is quite good and has a gratifyingly long shelf-life of 25 years - is that it's all packaged together and must be used quickly after opening. This can of tasty goodness has 6 servings of dried, cinnamon-dusted apples in it - if, for you, a serving is 35 pieces. (A pretty generous serving for what is essentially a pretty healthy snack.) Once the can is opened it either must be consumed immediately or refrigerated/frozen and consumed within a week.Honestly, if you're not buying these for camping or prepping or something else that requires long-term storage, you can probably find a cheaper source of dried apples. It's the shelf life that makes these worth the money.
