As good as they are, they'd be so much better if they came in individually packaged servings so that opening the can didn't immediately start a clock ticking on the entire contents.

I picked these up because I've purchased others in the line and was looking for some grey socks. The great advantage they offer is a smooth toe-seam. But while the ones I had purchased previously have held up well, these socks simply don't seem well constructed. They shed lint like crazy. Even after multiple wearings, my feet come out coated in black. These socks aren't subjected to heavy wear, but even so they quickly show their wear. I'm disappointed - though comfortable, they've just not been a good investment.

My 17-year-old son is the videographer of the family. I asked him to test this product and report back to me, and this is what he has to say.Having used Corel a few generations ago, this is not all new, but it's got some great new features.  The interface has always been pretty intuitive, and this is unchanged, but the list mode of your media gives you tons of information on your videos, making it much easier to identify what you want. And when you are using a video in a project, there is a green check on it--this helps avoid using the same clip twice, which is a nice feature.There are several new features that are a true plus for the software.One that is particularly appealing is the ability to record narration and system audio at the same time. If you want to do a screen capture of yourself doing something (a new feature anyway since his last version) and explain what you are doing as you are doing it, you can. This is an especially good feature for those who want to review videogames or films or riff them.The new freeze frame effect lets you not only grab a moment of a video, but grab a sequence of specific duration and easily pull it out to play with, putting it in different positions as needs serve. The audio ducking tool is a good one for people who do voice-over narration over these sequences, because it automatically lowers the volume of the main track when you narrate and returns it after the narration clip is ended.Text overlay on films has been given a lot more customization, including blending and transparency. The ability to move captioning within your project easily is cool.Masking and green-screen have both been enhanced, with better blending capabilities and easier-to-use green-screening even in lower light scenarios.The program also supports more video formats than it formerly did and, with the optional purchase of a plug-in, will allow you to create BluRays.His dream program, I know, is Adobe After Effects, but with its monthly subscription business model there's no way that's on his budget. With recent updates and ease of use, Corel has pulled solidly ahead among more affordable options.

I'm getting to be quite a connoisseur of these. This the third variety Mountain House meal I've tried - the other two were breakfast options - and this is by far my favorite. The reconstituted eggs were doable, but this is something I would actually eat at home in a time pinch. The eggs were emergency-or-camping-only. My husband was not as big a fan of the flavor, which he found bland (better with hot sauce), but to me it was about on par with a decent frozen dinner. Not home-made or restaurant quality, but pretty good. The rice was a little al dente, the beef was a little tough. But good.This is good news to me, because I bought a metric ton of this stuff before I ever tried it. When I got the opportunity to sample a few flavors, I figured it would be a good idea to see what I was in for. I'm not a full-on prepper, but I try to set aside some supplies for an emergency, and I had been told that Mountain House's offerings were good. I'm so glad that I was told right. These blow MREs out the water.I am a bit bugged by two things. First, I don't like that this is "2.5 servings." I've said before that I think foods should be sold in quantities of whole persons. But a larger issue for me is that serving size. A healthy adult man needs between 2,000 and 3,000 calories a day. A healthy woman needs 1,800 to 2,000 calories per day. For 2,000 calories a day (light for a man, heavier for a woman), that's about 667 calories a meal, if you do the "breakfast, lunch and dinner" division. A serving of this isn't even a third of that, at 180 calories. I'd be packing one of these per person, but only if I had something to add to it.Plan your meals accordingly.

Skin problems don't go away with age, unfortunately, but essential skin oils do. Standard pore strips had never had ill effects on me before - like most people, I was simply in awe at the stuff collected on the little strip and relieved to be cleared of what seemed like filth. But the stuff you see clinging to the strips is generally not dirt or blackheads, but sebaceous filaments - a combination of skin cells and sebum collected in a channel intended to help get sebum to the surface of the skin. Sebum, of course, isn't filth - it's a necessary skin protectant. It helps keep bad stuff out (dirt, bacteria) and good stuff in (moisture). Without it, you get dry, flaky and perhaps even cracking skin. You can get rashes and, yes, even acne. What's more, all the empty channels left behind when you remove the filaments don't go away. They're permanent. And they will refill within a matter of weeks, because they're supposed to be there and doing exactly what they do.I'd always regarded that tight-skinned feeling following use of a pore strip with cleanliness, good hygiene, but this time it feels more like a burn--and four days after use, my skin remains quite unhappy with me. I think I'll leave my sebacous filaments where they are. At my age, dry skin is more an issue than oily.

Okay, so this story is pretty far-fetched, even within the internal logic of the tale, but I didn't care. When I started reading it, I expected it to be kind of ridiculous. It was recommended to me, and I picked it up with great skepticism. But it turned out to be incredibly sweet. Ehd and Elizabeth are not just separated by the ordinary cultural gap. Ehd is a man of his time, not just pre-literate but barely verbal or even able to grasp the concept of language. Elizabeth is light years beyond him intellectually, but they need to bring both their skills together to survive in his hostile prehistoric landscape. In the doing, they build a love story that is really surprisingly touching. I teared up more than once and at one point openly wept. Kudos, Shay Savage.I love it (5 stars) is a little too strong for me. Sometimes, Ehd's perspective and preoccupations do get tedious - his obsession with reproduction comes to mind - even though it feels plausibly authentic enough to put that aside. And without spoilers, I actually felt like the epilogue broke my mood. Too, though the concept was intriguingly different, it took me a bit to really get caught up.If I could, I would happily give it 4.5.

I play a lot of card games with my extended family - Uno, Wizard, Phase 10 are among the branded games, with a good half a dozen games played with a regular deck of cards - and we're always looking for new games to add to the family roster. I was delighted when the opportunity for this one came along.This game is very much in the vein of others we play. Your goal is to get rid of your cards - not to be the last one holding them. Along the way, you have the opportunity to play "karma" cards to either make your opponent eat cards or to prevent your having to do so. The game can change in a minute, with someone who seems very close to winning suddenly finding themselves in dire straits.At this writing, there's a nice video demonstrating gameplay at http://www.sugarcayne.com/2014/03/how-to-play-karma-set-enterprises/

I own a metric ton of this stuff, but had never tried it, so when I got the opportunity to pick up a couple of single pouch breakfast offerings for review, I figured it would be a good idea to see what I'm in for. I'm not a full-on prepper, but I try to set aside some supplies for an emergency, and I had been told that Mountain House's offerings were good.They are. I have now tried two - this one and the Precooked Scrambled Eggs with Bacon.The stuff does not really look good in the package. Freeze-dried eggs look like styrofoam, but adding a cup of boiling water, stirring, and letting it sit turns it into something surprisingly tasty and filling. This is the second variety I've tried, and like the former I found it a bit dry. I wasn't sure before if I had overstrained it (you're left with a bit of soup from the rehydration process), so I didn't strain it as aggressively this time, but it didn't really help. The moisture loss is internal, if you can make sense of that - compared to moist, gleaming scrambled eggs, this...isn't.As with the other variety, the flavor of this is good. Seasoning is heavy (lot of sodium in these), but that's what makes them palatable. I prefer the other flavor, but that's not because of any innate difference in quality. My husband liked this one better.Mountain House's Pro Packs offer a gratifying meal for a small outlay of effort. They will serve well in an emergency or if you are away from quality fresh ingredients - much better than many of the emergency foods I've stashed (and choked down) in the past. My buckets of emergency backup food seem at this point like a good investment, and I wouldn't hesitate to take these camping for an almost-like-home meal.I do have the same issue with this that I did with the last one. Packing 1.5 servings of anything in a bag is ridiculous. Food should be packaged in increments of whole persons.

This is an adorable concept with some nice features, but it does have some issues about which potential buyers should be aware.The cover is charming and fun, it offers some padding, and the seams are well reinforced. It's sturdy and should survive some abuse. The velcro tabs for the straps are also sturdy, as are the ears - which is a good thing, as those ears are tempting carry points. The straps are not too long, which is both an advantage and a disadvantage. The advantage is that they're less likely to get hung up on things when not in use holding the iPad in position. The downside is that they're kind of less useful in holding the iPad in position. In my car, the seat-to-back-of-seat ratio is not optimal for hanging this device as pictured, not and still have a child of two reach the pad.My major concern with the unit is the stand at the rear. I've included a picture of this - it's quite flimsy. My stand arrived with a curve that predisposes it to close, and the only thing keeping it open is a bendable nylon strap (same consistency as the hanging strap) that is also predisposed to close. It doesn't take much to make this stand fold in upon itself, and unfortunately two-year-olds aren't known for their gentle touch. This item doesn't remain standing for long.The rear of the cover has some fit issues, as per picture two. It is held closed by a velcro flap where the velcro is small and centralized in the middle. Right out the box, it is already beginning to curl (picture 2), and it will be very easy for small fingers to find purchase to pull it open. It'll also be appealing for them to do so, as the most eye-catching thing on the back is the logo - which is right in the middle of the closure.Speaking of the logo, the one sewn onto the side (picture 3) has slightly sharp edges, especially at the corners. I wish it were a little more soft, given the age of the intended audience.It's a really nice concept with some nice design features but a few flaws that I hope they will improve in future iterations.

I own a metric ton of this stuff, but have never tried it, so when I got the opportunity to pick up a single pouch for review, I figured it would be a good idea to see what I'm in for. I'm not a full-on prepper, but I try to set aside some supplies for an emergency, and I had been told that Mountain House's offerings were good.No lie. At least, this one is.The contents of the pouch are none-too-appetizing on first review - the eggs look like styrofoam - but adding a cup of boiling water, stirring, and letting it sit turns it into something surprisingly tasty and filling. I found the product a little dry. Maybe I over-strained the water out afterwards, I don't know. But the flavor was good. It's not a dead ringer for real eggs. Just for comparison purpose, I had my three-person household sample it alongside some fresh-made scrambled eggs. It's not hard to tell the difference between them, but it's still a really gratifying meal for a small outlay of effort. And a lot easier to store and port than real eggs. My buckets of emergency backup food seem at this point like a good investment, and I wouldn't hesitate to take these camping for an almost-like-home meal.One curiosity: 1.5 servings per bag? Why? Shenanigans like these always annoy me. Food should be packaged in increments of whole persons.

I do not read Showalter religiously but have picked up enough of her books over the years to be pretty familiar with her style and her evolving trends. For a while there, people were concerned that she had toned down the sex to the point that she was losing a big part of what constituted her stories. Well, friends, I don't know if this is the first book where the trend reverses, but the sex is here.I realize this is a bit like saying that you read Playboy for the articles - highly suspect - but I don't really care whether my romances have explicit sex in them or not. I generally skim or skip when the action gets too hot and heavy. (If I want erotica, I know where to find it.) I read Showalter because she manages somehow to go really super dark in her plots - hyper-violence! epic battles of good vs. evil! superbeings clashing over world-shattering stakes! - while still being really whimsical. Sometimes maybe a little on the verge of too much, maybe. The women in this book sounded to me like a Cosmo quorum. But it's still playful and breezy and good-spirited and leavens the darkness nicely. Fantasy-horror-rom-com.Sometimes I have a problem with Showalter's world building. She's been at it so long and has built such an amazing canon that I'm constantly stumbling over plots and people I don't remember or just don't know, and I've run into a book or two where I felt sidelined by subplots or set-up for a future book. That wasn't an issue at all in Burning Dawn. There were references to the broader mythos and, yes, some groundwork, but it never distracted from the main story or left me confused.Anyhoodle, if you pant over alpha men and flippant women with a heart of gold, if your stomach doesn't churn when people are disemboweled or beheaded in fiction (or if you can push past it), if you can handle a story that is simultaneously grim and bouncy, AND if you do not shy at some pretty explicit shenanigans between (and above and nowhere near) the sheets, this could be the book for you.Fun times. I recommend.

This is a solid, heavy fire pit that offers some nice protection against sparks with an open mesh top and sides. Removable sides on two ends make tending the fire easy, and the vinyl cover helps protect it from exposure between uses. It's heavy enough to make moving it around a bit difficult, when the recommended sand is in the base, but to me the stability of the unit makes that a worthwhile sacrifice. Assembly was not without a bit of pain (when is it over?) but it was all over in about 30 minutes. We've used this multiple times already and in fact found it an unexpected help during a recent power outage. Fire-cooked hotdogs: they're not just for summer.

I think stories about people who grow up in extraordinary circumstances will always be fascinating to me, as I have always been intrigued by what is innate to the human condition and what is imposed--by cultural and familial expectations. Fictionalized accounts like this one aren't science, of course--just somebody else's exploration into the same question--but they are still thought-provoking and engaging. Feral-child Mari is now a wife and mother. The way her differences affect not only her but also her family makes an intriguing study.On the story level, this is a tale of growth and self-discovery, mostly for Mari but also for her two children and her not-always-sympathetic husband. (Man, I could have slapped him so many times.) There's a mystery at the heart of it that kept me flipping pages as past and present meet. I enjoyed and will look more into the author's works.

I am not a doctor, pharmacist, chemist or herbalist. I'm a woman of a certain age who takes vitamins and supplements and who is prone to waking up in the middle of the night with her clothes as wet as if she'd just coached the winning team at the Super Bowl. (Please don't ever douse me with Gatorade. I have enough experience with pulling away clinging clothing at this stage to know I don't much care for it.) I keep spare nightgowns by my bed. I've been taking this stuff for a few weeks now, and I think it has helped. It hasn't proven a miracle drug for me - still with the middle of the night clothing changes - but I think they are happening less frequently and perhaps less severely.A bit of research shows me that the top ingredient, Nakai, has shown some effectiveness as an antiandrogen - which means that to at least some extent it blocks androgens from impacting your body. Medically proven antiandrogens are given to women for things like acne, amenorrhea (that who cessation of menstruation thing), excessive hair growth, and loss of hair caused by androgen. It seems to be the source of most of the claims here. Next on the list, cynanchum wilfordii, is a little harder to find, but it's used to treat anemia and, according to the documents the makers of this supplement submitted to the FDA in 2006, may also enhance libido. (They say it's used that way in Korea.)  The third ingredient on the list, phlomis umbrosa, is touted in that same document for general tissue repair.People who take supplements should always be mindful that "natural" and "over the counter" do not necessarily equal safe. Foxglove (aka digitalis) is a natural ingredient, but it can cause seizures, heart arrhythmias and even death. St. John's Wort, freely available and commonly used to self-treat depression, can cause birth control pills to fail and organ transplant rejection. I had a friend years ago who took an herb she had been told would help her morning sickness only to discover that it was the main ingredient in an abortifacient used in China. If you have a medical condition and especially if you are taking other medications, talk to your doctor or pharmacist to make sure this is safe.

I'm a bit a smoothie fanatic, so my blender sees a lot of use. This one, while pricey, is quite powerful and has been very effective at blending even hard frozen ingredients. It's loud--I've never met a blender that will quietly crush ice, but this one seems louder than most--but that's not an issue for me. I like that it feels very stable. The glass top is heavy; the plastic base seems lightweight in comparison but is much larger in proportion to the pitcher than usual. I've had no issues with rocking or walking in use.That said, I can't honestly say that this blender is enough of an advancement over my previous (a KitchenAid in this family) to justify the huge jump in price. Is this one better than that? Yes, I believe it honestly is - although there's also a possibility that my old KitchenAid is suffering from some age and seems worse than it started. I've been using it for a couple of weeks now, and it's a workhorse. But is it worth more than three times as much as KitchenAid? I'm not that specialized, myself. If you use a blender constantly, or have enough disposable income, then it might be a good expense for you.

This entertaining fantasy novel has a seriously dark side. On the one hand, there's a truly gruesome villain who is horrifyingly brutal in the way he treats women. On the other, there's a gorgeous romantic lead who is horrifyingly brutal in the way he treats women. This latter element has been pretty divisive. I guess it comes down to this: can you buy that an 18-year-old female jinni might have complicated and confusing feelings for the incredibly hot and evidently charming master who has basically tortured her for years? I can. And personally I never got the feeling that Demetrios was trying to excuse the bad behavior or downplay the severity of what Malek did. Nor did she ever portray Nalia's confused feelings as healthy.The book was not a perfect fit for me, but it was an enjoyable read. I haven't read much (maybe any) jinni fantasy, and Demetrios's take seemed rich, with a fully realized culture behind it. The romance elements of the novel were not as deeply engaging to me as this and the threat of the aforementioned truly gruesome villain. I'm way more interested in this fractured society than I am in Nalia's love life.This is the first book in a trilogy, so there's plenty that's left unresolved, but I'm happy to say that I (at least) got a good sense of closure. I can't stand hanging series that offer no payoff for the book in my hand - generally, by the time the next comes out, I've either forgotten the original or just no longer care.I may not have loved it, but I liked it - it kept me reading.

First, I think this book has been miscategorized: "humor and entertainment" did not describe the experience I had, and I'm glad of it. I understand that the marketing strategy here is likely meant to capitalize on the popularity of the 2014 film The Interview, but I think that doing so fails to give credit to what Fischer has actually produced: a taut, terse book about two people whose lives are savaged by a corrupt empire.I learned a ton about Korea (both north and south). While predominantly about the massive personal impact Kim Jong-Il and his regime had on the lives to two kidnapped South Korean filmmakers, the book contextualizes their story well, politically, economically and philosophically. And it does this painlessly, without feeling remotely like the history lesson it is. There's nothing funny about what happened to Choi Eun-Hee and Shin Sang-Ok - it's horrific. The book doesn't lapse into melodrama, though, but communicates details straightforwardly, with a highly readable brisk pace. It's a gripping, engrossing tale.Those who have any confusion on the issue should be aware that this is not an academic work; there's no apparatus here, and Fischer clearly has his own perspective on events, which he seems to feel comfortable interjecting throughout the tale. I didn't find this intrusive, as I'm not looking for an academic work on the subject. If you are, you should look elsewhere.

This safe offers a substantial sense of security. A hefty 135+ lbs. when empty, it's not going to be easily carried away from your home in an invasion, and the earsplitting alarm (that thing is LOUD) that it emits when moved is going to discourage thieves from even wanting to try. (You'll want to make sure you don't enter the code incorrectly too many times, or you risk that same very effective discouragement.) In terms of entry, you can use the keypad alone or add an extra layer of security by using the keypad and the key, requiring that both be provided to open it.The safe is solidly constructed, I haven't tested flameproofing or waterproofing, but I trust ETL verification. ETL Verified Marks are bestowed by the Intertek Corporation. This performance testing service is paid for by manufacturers, so the ABSENCE of a mark doesn't mean a feature doesn't work, but Intertek's reputation relies on their trustworthiness in giving the marks. They have over 1,000 labs across the world, and if they say that the safes they were given to test in this line offer 1-hour fire protection for digital media up to 1-hour at 1700 F / 927 C in the event of a fire, I believe them.On the subject of digital media, please note that the safe's instructions say "DO NOT store any film based technology or media in this safe." This is due to the risk of moisture accumulation within the safe, even if you retain (as you are supposed to) the desiccant they provide and replace it or recharge it (as you are supposed to) every six months. Negatives, floppy disks - not here. Likewise, you are advised not to store watches, stamps or photos in the safe and, if you do anyway, to first put them in an airtight container. Pearls are another no-go, but not because of humidity. Evidently, they will simply melt if your safe is engulfed in fire. Other things not to store: firearms and medication (I imagine the humidity again) and combustibles (not sure why - but I'd rather not store combustibles in my safe anyway).Please note that this comes with a warranty that you need to register. In the event of a fire, your SentrySafe will not be reusable. They offer an after-fire replacement program.

This book offers a complete introduction to DJing, covering aspects from building a set-up to using your set-up to creating a demo to standing out in a performance setting. In keeping with the "For DUMMIES" brand, it offers to do so in a way that makes sense for complete neophytes - no background knowledge needed.Completely to my surprise, I am a beginner DJ. Always a vocal fan of DJs, I was pleasantly shocked to receive at Christmas a Numark iDJ Pro Professional DJ Controller for iPad, which comes with some amazing features but, alas, doesn't come with skill. Nor, at least in the case of mine, a manual. People, this thing is pretty much a musical instrument. Loving piano doesn't make you a pianist. You can plunk. You can pick out tunes. But you're not Van Cliburn, and if you aspire to be Van Cliburn, your noodling is just going to disappoint.Maybe somewhere you can sign up for DJ lessons, but so far as I know you can't do it around here. This book's promise to "DJ like a pro-without skipping a beat" was too much to resist.What I found was a very comprehensive guide that doesn't quite bring me to "like a pro" levels, in part because it is so comprehensive and in part because nothing can (more on that in a minute). For the truly aspiring professional DJ starting from nothing, this thing could be gold. 395 pages long (sans index), it very thoroughly explains what your options are in DJing and how to become the DJ of your dreams. This starts with about 185 pages (15-200) of discussion of equipment: what you can buy; which you should buy (according to your resources and the type of DJ you want to be); how you should set it up. All of this is written in a conversational, easy-to-digest style that makes what could be pretty dry reading pleasant. (Since I'm reviewing the book, I read all of this even though my DJ Toolbox was put together for me, and I did find some scattered tips that were interesting and useful even in my situation.)Actually mixing and modifying music is the focus of section 3 - 84 pages are devoted to mixing, beatmatching, and scratching. This section is incredibly dense, but still readable. There's a lot of information packed in here. Coming from the newbie perspective (with educated ears and clueless hands), I felt it offered some solid tips for grasping beatmatching basics and striving for the next level. It talks not only about the hows, but the whys of effective mixing and scratching.Part 4 begins with more attention to performance and technique. Within the context of "Getting Noticed and Playing Live," it offers some next-step tips for those who have mastered the basics in Part 3, specifically beatmatching and mixing. It goes into the art of using your playlist to build energy and mood in your audience, to please your patrons (both in constructing your demo and in live performance). Intermingled with all of this are some of the nuts and bolts of professional djing - how to market yourself, what to look for in an agency, what to look for in a gig.The book is a very well-rounded look at DJing as a profession, and as such is not so much focused on DJing as an art as would have served _me_, but there's plenty enough of that included to take me at least a little closer to Van Cliburnism. I imagine we all know that no book will take me there completely: I need technique (which this offers in spades), but I also need talent and time to develop it. You don't learn to be "like a pro" from reading, but from playing - with aptitude. On the whole, though, this is an impressive blend of business and art, and I imagine that it could have a lot to offer the person who aspires to be the next Armin van Buuren or Wundrkut or even the guy people want to play their weddings.If you're a true beginner, though, and want to get the best from this, buy the book BEFORE you buy the gear. If you've already got the gear, well, it still has a lot to offer.

I've been using this product for a couple of weeks now, and while I can say that it delivers what it promises - hair is thicker while using it - it also kind of kills style. They recommend applying it to roots and midshaft for layered hair, but in spite of following these directions to the best of my ability, I wind up with an all-over pouf that is difficult to style.My hair is just a touch past shoulder length at the moment. It is fine and has always been very straight. I have only within the past few years learned that a great stylist can create the illusion of volume with the clever use of layering, so these days my hair tricks people into thinking I have some texture. I thought I'd give this a try to see if it could better that effect.As near as I can tell by evaluating the ingredients (see the bottom of this post, as these are not at this writing listed on Amazon), this product relies on several hair-coating agents meant to give the appearance of volume. PVP, Polyvinylpyrrolidone, is the ingredient that gives many hairsprays their holding effect. VP/VA Copolymer inhibits hair from absorbing moisture and is found in mascaras and other volumizing hair products. The potentially drying, coarsening effects of these are countered by softening and anti-static agents, like cetyl alcohol (one of the good ones) and Polyquaternium 37.While the countering agents here do a pretty good job - my hair feels generally soft, if not as silky as it usually does - it still feels to me like trying to brush through hair that has been sprayed. I'm not styling so much as taming, and the end-result does not appeal.Longterm build-up has not been a huge issue, but I've not been using this long. Products that coat your hair will usually eventually weigh it down - contravening the lift its meant to provide and making it look a bit greasy. To avoid long-term build-up, I'd recommend a weekly wash with a clarifying shampoo. (I use Redken Cleansing Cream, and it works for me - but I don't know if it's the best or most economical.)For me, this is not a product I will continue to use. If my hair were long with fewer layers, I'd probably love it, but what it's doing now mostly is fighting against a great cut. In terms of what to expect from it, we're not talking about an 80s hair band's worth of lift, but definitely more volume, especially along the length.Ingredients are:WATER, ISODECYL NEOPENTANOATE, PVP, POLYQUATERNIUM-37, VP/VA COPOLYMER, CETYL ALCOHOL, POLYIMIDE-1, BENZYL ALCOHOL, HYDROXYPROPYL METHYLCELLULOSE, FRAGRANCE, SILICONE QUATERNIUM-18, TRIDECETH-6, MALIC ACID, TRIDECETH-12, GLYCINE, STEARTRIMONIUM CHLORIDE, GLYCERIN, HYDROLYZED VEGETABLE PROTEIN PG-PROPYL SILANETRIOL, ALCOHOL DENAT., AMP-ISOSTEAROYL HYDROLYZED WHEAT PROTEIN, HYDROLYZED KERATIN, METHYLCHLOROISOTHIAZOLINONE, METHYLISOTHIAZOLINONE, GREEN 3.

I am a George Foreman fan. Lacking space and needed equipment for outdoor grilling, I've relied on indoor grills for nearly 20 years. To me, the most important features of these grills are removable platters (for easy cleaning), proper tilt (for easy cleaning) and adjustable temperature (for easy cooking) - this unit has them all. It's a good size for cooking for my family of three as well. I've tried hamburgers, chicken breasts and pork chops with good success. The angle is, as with past George Foreman's, great for grease runoff. I have had other brands in the past where the grease actually ran out the back because it wasn't steep enough for the grease to flow forward. The lid fits down better over the content better than previous George Foreman's, courtesy of the hinge lid. I have not yet tried the waffle plate - would be nice to have some recipes and directions included for that.

I'm a big fan of Clarks Women's boots. I wear a size 6, but have wide feet, so I generally get by with an increase to 6.5 - I have successfully done this with multiple pair of Clarks ordered from Amazon in the past. Unfortunately, these boots were not on the same size scale as my previous orders - they were tight across the forefoot to the point that I had to return them. I was sorry to have to do it - the leather is soft, and the shoes look good in person. Typical of Clarks, they felt like they had quality soles with good support.

What you get here is exactly what it claims to be - an item that will both sound an alarm and make it harder for a door to open. It has a great non-skid pad on the base that works on hard surfaces and holds up pretty effectively on carpet, too. Unlike with a traditional doorstop, you would not wedge the door closed with this, not if you want it to operate as an alarm as well. I tested to see if the alarm would still function if the metal plate was _partially_ depressed before it was turned on, and it did not. Make sure that only the white plastic goes under the door, and it should work fine to alert you and at least temporarily delay entry to give you time to react.The on-off slider is low profile, which is helpful for traveling, as you really don't want this going off in your suitcase, but I really wish that the battery compartment was not held closed by a screw. I don't usually travel with a Phillip's head screwdriver. If you do, or you're willing to trust that this won't accidentally go off in transit, that might not be a concern for you.

This book reminded me a bit of The Great Gatsby.  Captures the spirit of a generation? Absolutely. Sure, not everybody in America is appearing on (or aspiring to appear on) reality t.v., but not everybody in Fitzgerald's time was hanging out in speakeasies, either.  What we have here is a warped mirror, one in which our characteristics are exaggerated but not fabricated. It is a legitimate slice of American culture: the drive to be something, to be a star, to elevate beyond the lot to which we were born to and receive the accolades that we need to feel special. Whether that's the pyrite shine of a toddler's tiara or a direct line to your personal Lord and Savior, the goal is the same: to have a place in the universe that matters. In a way, like Gatsby, the book is about the hollowness of the "American dream", our race to reach a meaningless pinnacle - upon achieving which, we race to the next. It is about the shallowness of reaching for fame and fortune above happiness, about the damage we do to those around us and to the relationships that really matter. Before we ever meet him, Ray has been pushed to a pinnacle beyond his capacities (much like daughter Bailey, groomed to attain a goal to reflect glory on his parent), and we can see the destruction that it left behind on him. A failed doctor who might have been an excellent nurse, he is self-destructing one pill-pack at a time.Further analysis requires spoilers, and I don't believe in spoilers. I'll just say that there's a lot of meaning packed in what looks deceptively like a lightweight book. Like Gatsby, this book could inspire essays and classroom debates. Unlike Gatsby, the students reading it will probably be having fun (no offense, Fitzgerald).What's really amazing about this book, to me, is that while it makes its point with mockery (and a lot of humor), it manages to do it with heart as well. It's easy to make fun of people. It's a lot harder to make fun of people without losing sight of their humanity. I not only laughed at these characters, but cared about them (some more than others). By and large, they were stupid, shallow, petty, sometimes even mean people, but they were stupid, shallow, petty and sometimes even mean people that Butler made understandable, sympathetic. As a result, I was flipping pages not only to find out what absurd situation the author would drop on his characters next, but to root for them to come out okay.Quite an accomplishment that.I can't go so far as to say it's the great American novel, but it's certainly a really good one. A painless read, you can get a lot out of it if you want to. Or you can just have some fun.

Like the condition itself, it seems, this memoir offers glimmers of light. I wanted to know more about the medical base of this disorder than Lyndsey offers, but I can hardly fault her for that - she wants it far more than I do. Suffering a rare, crippling disorder that cannot be explained must be incredibly frustrating. But as Lyndsey lives figuratively and literally in the dark, she manages to find some truths that might not otherwise be visible, lost in the distraction of the mundane. Her book is as much about developing an incredible self-reliance as it is dealing with near total dependance on others.While Lyndsey's book is often lyrical, I don't want to make it sound like she lives in or describes some mystical other dimension, where the loss of light has brought some kind of new age enlightenment. The challenges she has to overcome are profound and not always pretty, from stale air and bad smells to fearing the loss of a support network you need, literally, to survive. This is not a book of platitudes nor the musings of some kind of patient, medieval saint. It feels real.I found the book generally quite interesting, although a little emotionally detached at a few points, in part because of the narrative structure. Lyndsey's situation is vividly painted, in snippets, interspersed with musings on larger issues or reflections on work games or memories of life at different times. It's a good opportunity to learn something about what life is like in extremely different circumstances, to try to imagine how we would live in them, and to admire a woman who seems to be handling them amazingly well.

I find these kinds of things invaluable when I travel - when you don't have time for a full shower, but need a mid-point refreshment. This is the first time I've used these, and I was impressed. Inside of the package displayed currently on Amazon is a smaller, slightly more discreet pack in metallic pink with a resealable white triangle closure (kind of jarring, from a design standpoint) that can easily fit into a purse or three-ounce plastic bag. This contains 10 pre-moistened towelettes. These have a slightly fruity scent with a faint alcohol undertone. I can't wear perfume because of scent sensitivity, and these did not bother me, although what does bother people will be highly individualized. The towelettes are slightly textured, which adds some gentle exfoliation.In terms of using this on your face, you can - and I tried - but it's not something you'll want to do regularly. Denatured alcohol is the second ingredient on the list. The rapid evaporation is quite likely one of the reasons this is cooling and also can tame odor issues. But, unlike fatty alcohols, it can also be drying. If you must use it on your face, I'd follow up with a moisturizer.

This one is a page-turner. I was quickly and deeply engrossed in Sam's mysteries, as he tries to work out why his friend killed himself but also resolve some more urgent and immediate questions, such as who is using his dead friend's online account...and why. Sam is a deeply sympathetic character surrounded by a strong supporting cast, and the music added an interesting layer of complexity to the story. I was about halfway through the book before I decided to listen to the songs called out in the chapter headers and found them a nice "multimedia" touch. However, they're not essential - if you don't like the music, you can ignore that aspect pretty much completely without any real loss. I was unfamiliar with half the songs before I started listening, and it didn't interfere with my enjoyment of the story.The story wraps up nicely for the most part. I like closure, so this was mostly a good thing for me, but I have to confess that I felt one of the major plot points was shuffled off without proper attention.  No spoilers from me! And I don't want to overplay it. It didn't spoil the book for me - I still really enjoyed it. It just kept the story from being the 5 star event it otherwise likely would have been for me.

After years of barely bothering with makeup, I reached a point where I decided that I needed to look professional or something. I visited one of those premium makeup displays you find in department stores and got all the instructions I needed to achieve that, more or less, along with about $400 worth of makeup. To be fair to the makeup clerk, they evidently did a good job on more than just selling - I get compliments on my natural look. (Yes, really.) But I have been a slave to that routine and makeup line ever since.The Neutrogena eye shadow plus primer replaces three of the products I was using - a $20 brow lifting pencil, a $20 eyeshadow, and a (bet you can guess) $20 shadow eyeliner. It offers less quantities than the items I was using, but it's also currently less than the price of a single unit, and the compactness is a plus for me, as I travel. In writing the review, I've discovered that the line I uses offers a similar four-in-one product (so that saleswoman was even better at upselling than I knew), but even that is $35.00. The quality of the makeup seems pretty comparable to the line I've been using, and it works in the same way - swipe the brow, swipe the lids, crease and edge. Bam. The makeup goes on smoothly, blends well, and stays put.The one thing I find unacceptable about this product may come down to a matter of personal preference - I loathe the application sponge. I have been accustomed to using brushes and after several goes with the included sponge ditched it in favor of those. Aging skin (to be candid) gets thin and sensitive, and the sponge applicator feels a bit like sandpaper. The brushes seem to allow more precise control, anyway.On the whole, an effective makeup and, for me, a comparable bargain. It's also a reminder that maybe I ought to branch outside of the advice at the Benefit bar, now that I've mastered a basic routine.

This lightweight vacuum cleaner wins big points for versatility. It's got the usual attachments, but a big plus in the microfiber swipe - so much better than vacuuming alone for hardwoods. The low profile head of the main vacuum is a nice feature, as it fits neatly under the edge of a lot of my furniture, allowing me better reach on lighter clean days when I don't want to move furniture (and on those units like my bed which will probably stay put until I move or die). It's narrow enough to fit in the gap between one of my toilets and the cabinet next to it. Not having to bend as often to clean that space is a major plus! Alas, it's not quite narrow enough to do the same in the other bathroom. It's the first vacuum I've ever used that can go from carpet to hard flooring without fiddling with settings. The detachable base makes this a dream for stairs.It is a budget priced vacuum, though, and in a few areas it shows. First, this unit is noisy. Vacuums are, of course, but this one as from the get-go had a squeal like a fleeing boar (I imagine), particularly unpleasant in small spaces. Second, I miss the retractable cord. Third, while an excellent lightweight vacuum, it really doesn't have the suction of my older, full-size cleaner. I cleaned a 2,000 square foot house - top to bottom - with this unit and only filled the canister halfway. My larger vacuum seems to suck dirt from the center of the earth, and it accordingly must be emptied more often.As a final note, I have some trouble getting one of the attachments in and out of its storage point on the unit. I had to get my husband to put it on the first few times, as it was simply too tight for me to do it, and it's still hard enough that I find myself avoiding using the tool.On balance, I think this is an excellent vacuum for those who want versatility and portability, but those seeking heavy-duty cleaning may prefer to use it supplementally.

Unfamiliar with Martin's blog, I picked this up because I like memoirs and I love people who undertake challenges like this - "Over the course of 195 weeks, food writer and blogger Sasha Martin set out to cook--and eat--a meal from every country in the world." I was looking forward to reading about this journey in detail - something akin to A.J. Jacobs, perhaps the excellent The Year of Living Biblically: One Man's Humble Quest to Follow the Bible as Literally as Possible, I guess - and was a little taken aback to find the memoir more traditional in layout, the cooking challenge just a small part of it, later in the text. I guess the blog readers got the full details on the project. This is a  more intimate look at a life, chronological, starting before the author was even born.While I didn't exactly get what I was expecting, what I got was quite good. Martin's story is a poignant one, with a lot of challenges, ranging from extreme poverty to the repeated loss of loved ones. Cooking becomes a metaphor for connection and more, an actual vehicle for it, as childhood meals with family (or foster family) lead to her creating family and community of her own. Heart-tugging and heart-warming, Martin's story makes no apologies for the failings of her loved ones, but simply relates what she lives through and how she manages to start afresh.Aside from my surprise with the content, I really enjoyed the book and the recipes I've tried. (Yes, there are recipes: doable and delicious.)I do have a quibble with the title (though not the type to ding the rating): "Life From Scratch." Martin deserves all due credit for building something strong out of what she inherited, but everything in this book emphasizes that her life is not that. It's more akin to friendship bread. The recipes themselves are the starter, a web of traditions from her heritage and beyond. Her book becomes a way of passing that on. With a host of insights and recipes, Martin offers fodder for our building something ourselves.Strong and readable prose, clear direction, good recipes, and a likable, candid author make this a memoir to recommend.

This coffeemaker has some sweet features. I love that the unit can brew large or small without loss of quality. As the only person in my house who drinks coffee, I don't need a massive coffeemaker on a daily basis, but I have regular company that swells my demand considerably. This unit serves both needs. It will also easily adjust the strength of the coffee. I'm particularly fond of the bold setting.The so-called "sneak a cup" feature works as advertised - on testing, I was able to remove the carafe for an early serving without creating a mess on the counter.The stainless steel carafe here is obviously going to be more sturdy than a glass coffee carafe. Good thing it's thick, as the heat of the coffee relies on it. Without a heating plate, it needs the insulation.  It's got a nice wide opening, which makes it easy to clean.I do wish that it was possible to view the coffee level in the pot. I have an electric water pitcher with a steel case, but it has a thin sliver of glass that allows you to see the contents. I realize that there might be a trade-off in temperature, but not knowing how much coffee is left in the pot is kind of disappointing.It would also be nice if it would make some noise to let you know when it's finished, particularly as the brewing cycle can run quite long (especially on stronger settings).

I'm surprised how much heat this little guy can push out. It easily sits below a desk, but this is really meant to be left out in the open for all in a room to experience. Really, this is overkill for heating up your feet at work.It has a digital display that lets you choose a range of temperatures, so it doesn't overheat a room. This isn't just an on/off switch, so it can tend to turn on and off to regulate the temperature of a room.And it does that masterfully. I've set this up in our master bedroom and my mancave, and in both instances I notice a difference immediately. Seriously, the second it is turned on it is blowing out hot air.Keep in mind that this does blow the hot air, it isn't like some other ones that radiate heat. The blower isn't loud, but it is present if you are sensitive to that. Very ambient noise, like the fan of a computer power supply.Finally, I appreciate the safety features. If it gets knocked over, it turns off. Actually, it tends to get a little upset if I try to move it without turning it off.Overall, I'm very impressed and happy with this heater.

I like it, and will probably use it on occasion if it the mood hits, but I don't love it.First, I want to address the price. I hate the practice that some watching companies have of stating an MSRP of 5-10 times what they intent to sell it for. I'll admit, that is a huge turnoff for me on this watch. I'm probably alone on this...There are some aspects of this watch that I do like. The blue face is very unique and eye-catching, especially since it changes with every small adjustment in the light. The face itself is rather large, but that seems to be what people prefer these days.I also like the band. First, leather is generally more comfortable to wear, but I've never seen a leather band with a clasp. It took me a minute to get the concept around it, but it looks like a leather band but you don't unstrap the band when you want to take it off, you open the clasp and slide it off like a metal band. Really weird to me at first, but it grew on me. After securing the clasp and then running the leather band through the two loops, this is nearly impossible to have it fall off or get stolen. Plus, I like the look and the feel of the leather.There are a few things about this watch that I'm not a big fan of. First, it is really, really thick.Again, that's probably the style these days. It has a turn button the side for adjusting the time and day, but that also has another decoration around it to... I don't know. Look pretty? I guess? It doesn't do anything else and it is just not that attractive to me. The metal part of the watch that connects to the watch band is really sharp. I feel like I could slice cheese or open mailing boxes with it or something. It pulled on my hair when I first put it on, but that doesn't seem to happen as much anymore. The date window is really tiny, so you better have some good eyesight. What surprises me is that the hour and minute hands have a white area near the ends, which I thought might have been made of some sort of glow-in-the-dark material like I've seen on a ton of other watches I've owned. Nope. Just decoration. So at night, there is no way of telling the time on this watch without turning on the lights. So, beware of that! Totally useless at night.So, yeah, I like it, but I hoped for a bit more since the official price is eighty or so bucks.

Creepy. Lots of interesting characters. A pretty unpredictable storyline with writers who weren't afraid to off any character. All in all, I loved it! Also, they threw in a few crossovers from season 2, which I really enjoyed. It made long-time fans like me excited. I can't wait to dive into season 5!

Very well priced and works great. I notice a HUGE speed difference when I use this over using my WiFi connection. I'm not sure how to measure effectiveness, but my Internet connection is now my bottleneck whenever I'm at locations with very high speed Internet. It's really small and portable. What isn't there to love about this cable? You couldn't ask for more for a mere $18!

This is awesome!! It's like a geek detector as my fellow geeks will give me thumbs up and cheers whenever I wear this. It fits great. The biggest surprise of this hat is that it totally heats me up. I'm amazed and how a hat can do that. It feel sturdy and can't wait to wear this on the slopes so I can identify those who belong in my tribe. :)

Setup didn't take too long. I set up a cloud account, downloaded an app, and then synced via bluetooth. All in all, less than ten minutes without any hurrying. I've been digging this so far because I like to take notes by hand now and then, and this gives me a way to get it imported with the rest of my notes. I'm not an artist, so I haven't tried drawing anything, but so far boxes and circles tend to end up in the right (-ish) locations on the paper.I do love the quality of the cover, it looks and feels very nice and sturdy, like I can expect to get years of use out of it without too many problems. My biggest fear is losing the pen and having to purchase a handful of them at regular intervals, as I do tend to lose my pens more than I'd care to admit.

I was hoping to get something that was a little bit classy looking, but I wasn't really blown away by this watch when it came in. Don't get me wrong, it's okay, but not amazing. It felt heavy on my wrist, the bezel doesn't rotate, and the buttons on the side seem to be larger than they really need to be. I'm certainly glad I didn't fork out seven hundred bucks for this!! Pricing it closer to $100 is closer to its real value, as I do think I can get more years out of this watch than most things cheaper than this.But it does keep good time and the lens is very clear. Oh, and the box it came in was downright amazing! I've... never complimented a watch for that before.This might be a vain test, but when I wear my Citizen (which cost me closer to the $700), I get compliments on a regular basis. This hasn't turned anybody's heads, yet. So, again, pricing it closer to the $100 it shows as its discounted price would be a lot more accurate portrayal of its value.

Did an excellent job of vacuuming. It has a ton of airflow for what looks like a small little engine. I love that there is  a place for the accessories and the retractable cord so I'm not tripping all over it. I had one a lot like it, made by Samsung, that didn't last long and this will be a suitable replacement. It also did an excellent job of cleaning out my car. The price isn't horrible, at $350, but it does feel like it is going to withstand the test of time a lot longer than vacuums that cost less than this. I think it is a good bank for the buck!

Standard black and white or color options print quick and clean. I've been very happy with those. However, I have not been overly pleased with the printout of photo prints. the colors tend to run and I've tried it on a couple of different options, but I just find that I'll do better taking those down to CostCo and have them print it instead.

It took about a minute to install (with a power screwdriver) and works great and keeping cables off the ground the making under my desk look nice. I highly recommend it to anybody looking to tidy thing up under their desks. I like how you can use the little wire things on the side to loop my cables around to keep extra slack from  hanging down.

Used this for a handful of podcast interviews and the guests came out sounding very good. I've got some microphones I bought from Amazon for about $60 that I use all the time, and these didn't seem perceptively better. Keep in mind, I don't know if I have that sensitive of hearing, but withstanding the price, these did sound very nice. It also comes with a good case for carrying this around in.

These are great! I love how Dockers feel and I feel like I'll be able to wear them for a long time before they give out. I do like the button and zipper, since these are often neglected when quality is considered, but these seem extremely well built. Overall, I'm very happy with these Khakis.

It's very basic, but it is very powerful considering the price. I do like the price, appreciate the bubble level on the top of the drill, and found the grip to be fairly comfortable. There isn't a torque setting, just FYI. That might be the biggest thing I'm missing.Keep an extension cord nearby, the current cord is not too long and won't let you reach most projects.I'll mention the power again, I do like how strong this works. Better than any wireless/battery operated drills I've used.

I love the modular aspect of this and now the inside of my computer looks so much more clean since I don't have a ton of unused black cables spidering all over the inside of my desktop. It looks so clean and organized now, it is hard to imagine it was me who actually put this together.I run a higher-end video card and this powers it without any problems, even after downgrading from an 800 watt power supply.

I love it, since my last computer was soooo loud! I replaced it with this, and it is now like it isn't even there. If I didn't see my desktop screen in front of me, I would think it was turned off. It is also roomy inside, so moving my old motherboard and components over took about fifteen minutes. Also, it is built well, not flimsy like those types of cases that tend to cut me up if I rub against it wrong.I love it and recommend it without hesitation.

I'll be honest, I'm not noticing a huge increase in energy or anything. Then again, I haven't been taking it consistently to get a real indication on if I would or not. I was a bit surprised when I opened it and realized these weren't shaped to be swallowed, but chewed. I feared the texture and taste would be one of those chalky, reject-citrus flavored type of pills, but the taste isn't that bad. It isn't so good I'd start popping these like candy, but I didn't find myself running for some sort of liquid to push these down with afterward.

It's a great fit. I like that the sleeve has a little bit of padding between the zipper and the Surface, protecting it from wear marks by rubbing against the zipper. Most sleeves like this overlook that. I've never owned a laptop sleeve before, but I love the extra protection I feel this gives the Surface when I stick it in the sleeve before tossing it into my backpack.

I think this is my sixth Otterbox I've tried out on my S6. The SYMMETRY version was my favorite, but I'm not sure if this overtakes that title or comes really close. I like the feel of the leather and I love the little slit to carry one card, which is what beats out the SYMMETRY. The screen is obviously a little more protected. However, I do have to deal with the flap when the phone is in use, which can sometimes work and sometimes get in the way. Oh, I also like how it tilts forward when you fold the flap under itself. It isn't much of a tilt, but the slight tilt is still better than just laying down flat when I want to watch something. I love the easy access to the power slot too, no need to remove any plastic covers or anything to get that to work. Thank goodness, it was one problem I had with some of the beefier cases. Otherwise, the thickness is about the same as I got with SYMMETRY... just a little more, and it provides some really good protection.You know what, I change my mind, I think this is now my favorite. There are so many more pros than cons on this. Don't get me wrong, all the OtterBoxes have been amazing, but I find myself using this case exclusively with no strong desire to go back to the SYMMETRY.The only thing that would make this more excellent is if the S6 would turn on when I open the flap, but I suspect that is more a limitation with the S6 than the case.If you like to fully protect your phone with one case, but don't want to go with one of the larger OtterBoxes that turns your phone into a (well-protected) brick, then I highly recommend looking at this one.

Setup on this took about ten minutes. Instructions weren't straight forward so I just looked at the box and things came together with intuition and, when I ran out of parts, I knew it was set up.I think my favorite aspect of this grill is that it heats up fast. I mean like REALLY REALLY fast. I'll turn it on, grab some frozen meat out of the freezer, and throw it on and it will hit the grill already sizzling.Cleanup is a bit of a mixed bag. The non-stick surface cleans up easily, but there is no easy way to really get in there and clean it. I just poured water on it while using paper towels to basically push the water and gunk toward the grease catch. Took about four cups to do the entire thing, I just made sure to empty the grease catch frequently so it didn't spill over onto my shoes. I do wish the griddle was removable, but it is what it is..Otherwise, I foresee many years of happy usage with this.

I had several people play with this since we are evaluating the keyboards we have where I work. I wasn't so much suggesting this one because of the niche market this aims at, but wanted them to feel the mechanical keyboard side of it with the quieter keys. Across the board, everybody said two things: "Ooooooh, pretty lights! The keyboard feels nicer than the crap Dell sends as default, but the other mechanical keyboards feel better, though this is quieter."To expand, yes, the lights are pretty. I wouldn't allow them in a work environment because, by default, the keys light up for a second after getting pressed and that has "guess my password" written all over it. I know they can be overridden, but this seems like one extra hole I'd have to patch up from an IT perspective. But, the lights are pretty awesome! After hooking this up at home, I do love how it looks walking into the room to use my computer.This does have a somewhat mechanical feel to it, which I like. They aren't the red or black buttons, which most people (including myself) prefer, but these are much more quiet. Significantly. Those who tried it did say that the louder ones would not be good in a cubicle environment because the neighbor would always hear them typing. So they actually preferred this keyboard (or something like it) in those situations.I'm surprised how quiet it actually is, while still being pretty responsive to the touch. Not my favorite to type on, but it is still a positive experience.Some other things: I like how you can customize the light show. I also like the media bar in the function keys, though it does take a bit of getting used to finding the function key just right to the (huge) space bar.At two hundred bucks, I'm a little surprised that this keyboard doesn't have USB 3.0 built into the back, but only USB 2.0. I'd expect nothing but the best when spending that much money.Which brings me to the build of the keyboard as a whole... it feels kind of light and flimsy. I wonder how it will hold up in the long run with heavy usage. Probably fine, but most mechanical keybaords are built like tanks and the plastic-like feel of this one kind of worries me. I'd be very nervous if I were in the habit of transporting it on a regular basis, but I just hooked it up to my home computer and it should be staying there until something better comes along.All in all, I like it, but I don't think I $200-like it. I was given this for free in exchange for an honest review. Honestly, I'd be upset if I had actually spent the $200. If (when) the price comes down, I'll recommend it more.

This is a great little audio receiver for my DSLR video camera for small video projects. I did a project about a year ago and something like this would have been extremely helpful, especially when working with XLR mics and multiple mic sources. Great for sending it raw to the camera or recording and editing/re-mixing the multi-wave audio file later. Easy to set up, decently easy to use. Some things weren't completely intuitive, but with work we figured it all out.An emphasis on smaller projects. I'd want more if I were trying to shoot more professional video. Then again, I wouldn't be using a DSLR Canon to shoot it with in that case.

I'm amazed how this bad guy will punch through so much paper especially with the staple portion being in the middle of the stapler. I'd think it would get more leverage at the end of it, myself. It is very effective, though you don't want to use it on just a couple sheets of paper because the longer staples will curl back in on itself and poke through the top. Just use a standard staple for less than 20 sheets of paper. This is for larger staple jobs, like 30-50--though I thought it did just fine with 20-30 as well.Also, you don't have to be the Incredible Hulk to staple with this. It really does take less effort, like most modern staplers. If you've got an older stapler that you're struggling with, this is a great replacement at a reasonable price.Oh, I thought the purple thing at the bottom for clearing jams was pretty creative. Finally, a stapler that isn't too proud to say, "I'm going to mess up now and then, but now i've made it easier to get me back and working." I've only use it for a week and it hasn't jammed yet. Maybe with more usage and age?I only have one complaint: the staples coming out the middle of the stapler. I wish it came out on the far end of the arm like, you know, every stapler out there. It comes in handy when stapling boxes, which is an additional useful function of heavy duty staplers.

It's okay. It takes a little bit for that CPAP to settle in there just right. I do like the firmness of the pillow, but the notches didn't do much for me, even when I did position it right. I like the idea, but I think it is not for everybody. Still, it's a great pillow for general use anyway. I do wish it was a little bit larger.

This is an awesome compliment to the body wash I've been using for years. Also, it's great to take to the gym when I don't want to carry around two things to wash myself with. I'm surprised it's taken Old Spice this long to come out with something like this (or for me to notice that they'd come out with something like this).

Pros:- I was surprised how loud this little thing could get.- This isn't something that is phenomenal, or something you'd use to entertain a room full of people, but it worked out well for playing some music or a movie louder than my cell phone or Kindle Fire could dish out by themselves. Also, I could position the speakers to face me, unlike the cell/Fire, which point away from me. This is a great substitute.- I haven't used it to charge any of my devices (good idea, but I haven't got that desperate yet).- I only have one, so I didn't test its stereo capabilities, but I thought that was an interesting idea.- Setup was easy.- I like that you can also go with an auxiliary cable instead of only bluetooth.- Pretty light weight and portable- Pictures indicated that it was a bit weatherproof. That's good!Neutral-I never tested the call function on this, I don't think I'd ever use it anyway.Cons- It starts to create some distortion when you turn it up all the way. That said, you can get this pretty loud before that becomes a problem. For its size and price, I'm actually happy with how well this did before it started to distort.

Got this in and my wife loved it. She thought it looked really well (she's a fan of silver) with her wardrobes. It's been a couple of weeks, and it has (so far) kept perfect timing. The Japanese quartz movement keeps excellent time at a much smaller price than a certain other country. She has tiny little bird arms, and I don't have a watch kit, so she had to go to a watch dealer and get it sized to her arm. So if you've got tiny wrists, this should still size well for you. The clasp is different than anything I've seen before. It clasps twice, instead of once. To me, it strikes me as a second point of potential failure, but it really holds on there when she is wearing it. It does take a little bit of force for the clasps to snap into place.Overall, it's a great time keeper and much cheaper than several other watches she's considered.

It took me a little bit to figure out how to turn on. It certainly does NOT want to chop up any fingers, so I felt totally safe working on this. Otherwise, it chops things up like it is nothing. My wife my salsa a few times with it and loves it. Nothing else in our kitchen chops it up like this does, and it beats the manual method (which is time consuming and put the cutter in danger of losing a digit or something).

I was surprised by how light this was when it arrived, I expected something twice as heavy.. at least. Then I got concerned that the first kid who ran into the net would destroy it. Actually, this is pretty sturdy and perfect for kids (maybe 10 and under) to get interested in playing tennis. The balls are larger and have more wind resistance than regular tennis ball, which is good in the sense that it is nearly impossible to bean somebody with it.Setup took me about ten minutes or so and I entertained my nieces and nephews for about an hour before they thought my dog looked more interesting. One problem I did have (and didn't really consider) is that I live on a hill and there was no fair yet convenient place to locate this. So, make sure you've got some flat land for it before proceeding. It's portable, I took it to the park and they were happy with it there.This can also double as a pickleball net. For kids.

Took about twenty minutes to set up, and seems like it is going to be very stable and last forever. I noticed it said that is was rustproof, and I noticed a lot more rust than I'd care to admit to when I took down my old (ten years old) one. Just be careful, wherever you put it, it's there to stay. There is no adjusting. But the extra space is nice.
Interesting message. I liked their analogy of the football field. I wish they had a "where do you go from here" type of ending, but the shopping examples were a plus as well.

Maybe I should have been forewarned by the fact that the perfect Gwyneth Paltrow is in this film, but masochist that I am, I watched it anyway (the other actors weren't as irritating).  I'm one of those people who thinks that 12-Step programs have done much more harm than good, and this movie sure didn't change my mind. Tim Robbins, for example, plays a sex addict in "recovery" for many years and a genuine 12-Step cultist. He speaks in aphorisms and believes in every myth that AA preaches--e.g., that if you're not in a 12-Step program and going to meetings, you're "white knuckling".  And the actors who play "recovering" addicts repeatedly refer to sex addiction as a "disease" rather than taking responsibility for their own actions.A comedy this isn't.  This is an extended ad for AA and a film for 12-Step True Believers.  I am not one of those. The reality is that Alcoholics Anonymous and all its siblings have an extremely low success rate (5-10%). But "Thanks for Sharing" makes it look like one big touchy feely group grope with an icky sticky happy ending.

I've watched about 40 minutes of this film so far and I can guess where it's going.  It is pro-Christian God and full of offensive stereotypes (the ever-so-polite Duck Dynasty couple who spends the week nuking mallards and Sundays piously attending church; the smug, cynical, atheistic philosophy professor who mentally abuses his Christian girlfriend; the sweet, humble Christian student who earnestly wants to prove the existence of God; a disaffected Muslim girl with a big bad father, who secretly wants to be a Christian and whose preacher of choice is the well-known homophobe Franklin Graham;  and--most offensive for me as an animal rights activist--the brash and apparently God-less and friend-less animal advocate who challenges that nice Duck Dynasty couple and ends up with cancer).  It goes on like that. The non-Christians are all nasty and screwed up, while the Christians are without exception the nicest people in the world.When I was in my 20s working a lot of temp jobs, I got to know a co-worker who identified herself as a born-again Christian.  So I asked her what happened to people who weren't Christians after death, and she replied without hesitation that they went to Hell.  I never forgot that.  And it pretty much cured me of any illusions I had about Christianity being a tolerant, loving, peaceful religion, because basically her beliefs condemned not only atheists and agnostics to the eternal fires, but also anyone who follows other religions (Muslim, Hindu, Buddhist, Jew, Jain, etc.).I recently lost my life partner, who, when I once asked him if he was an atheist, looked at me like he was puzzled and said he wasn't even interested in the question of whether or not God exists.  It was kind of like asking someone who doesn't care about sports what baseball team they're fans of.  It's a meaningless question.  And when he learned that he was dying, he didn't change his tune at all.  He made a comment not long before he passed away that he knew that after he died there was nothingness and he would cease to exist, and that was OK with him.  He was someone who did a great deal of good in the world, lived his life to the fullest, and many people loved and admired him.  You don't need to believe in "God" to be a good person.  Not at all.I was raised, somewhat reluctantly, as a Catholic by a mother who also never took much of an interest in the existence or non-existence of God.  In fact, when she was in an assisted living facility dying of cancer, she specifically asked me to keep the visiting clergyman away from her because she thought he was creepy.  I'm a bit different. After I left Catholicism behind in my early 20s, I still retained a curiosity about spiritual matters which has lasted many years, with a special fascination for eastern religions.  I would call myself a long-time agnostic, and it's for that reason that I'm watching this film.I hope it doesn't turn out to be the stereotypical Christian propaganda rant, but it looks like it's definitely going in that direction.  Clearly nobody has ever proven, nor are they likely to ever prove, whether God exists. But it doesn't follow that you should swallow a lot of religious gobbledygook on the off chance that you may be rewarded someday by a judgmental God who may deign to admit you to Heaven.  I believe that people should be good for the sake of being good, not for the promise of getting something in return, because that makes the whole process seem totally self-serving.I finally got through this film and I have to warn you it's a huge Christian propaganda piece.  I don't want to give away the plot, but I will say that creationism rears its silly head, the student tasked with proving God isn't dead only manages to show that scientists haven't proven his nonexistence (maybe that's because scientists don't concern themselves with theology?), it's unashamedly anti-Islam, there are highly improbable last-minute conversions, the Duck Dynasty killer makes another heroic appearance, and it's just generally absurd. Ick sticky skin crawly.  And I'm not even an atheist.I will say the acting is very professional, with a number of attractive young actors, so I gave it two stars.  But it's so biased against anything that isn't Christian that it's downright depressing. I didn't read the credits--I started fast forwarding toward the end--but I imagine Franklin Graham had a hand in it.  No gay characters whatsoever.  Watch it to know what to beware of, but take it with a boulder of salt.This is an honest review written by a real customer.

People with Asperger's no longer have to feel embarrassed about themselves. The 21st century is replete with them. It's downright trendy to be an Aspie. Bill Gates and the Silicon Valley geeks have done very well despite their conspicuous presence on the autism spectrum. And Temple Grandin is another example of someone with high-functioning autism who was raised as normally as possible and told that she could do anything she wanted, just like everyone else, and has been successful. That's the good news.The bad news is the fact that she chose to work as a Cattle Mafia enabler. I can't help but think of World War II, when Jews, gypsies, gays, and disabled people arrived by cattle car at European concentration camps, only to be greeted by lovely classical music and a courteous speech about how they were going to be allowed to shower and clean up after their long journey. They were deliberately calmed down so as not to be intractable and cause trouble for the Nazi guards, and then herded off to the poison showers. This is essentially what Grandin does. She tricks cows into thinking that they're in no danger with her specially designed walkways, when in fact they're being marched off to an ugly slaughter.While her ability to transcend her Asperger's, create a prosperous career, and write books is admirable, I cannot respect her choice of industries to work in. She presents herself as an animal lover and advocate who can communicate with nonhuman animals, and this film certainly reflects that. Yet she is not a vegetarian/vegan (claims that she tried it once and it made her feel sick) and is now trying to expand her operations to corporate farms, to fool millions more animals into imagining that humans have their best interests at heart.As an Aspie myself, I can empathize with the problems Grandin has with noise, touch, interpreting social cues, anxiety, etc., and Claire Dane does a masterful job of portraying Grandin's physical and psychological issues.Some people would argue that at least Grandin is doing something positive for the unfortunate genetic freaks created by the agriculture industry for human consumption. But as an ethical vegan, I say that so much more could be done, like encouraging consumers to stop eating and wearing animal products while educating them on the healthy way to do that and how a plant-based life can literally save our planet. People have got to stop swallowing the corporate Kool-Aid about the mythical superiority of animal protein. They shouldn't be obsessing on their steaks because there's an awful lot at stake here.This is an honest review written by a real customer.

I have years of experience with Cushex (I gave it to a now departed dog off and on for symptoms of Cushing's), and although I can't prove it scientifically, I believe it extended her life and made her more comfortable.  She was diagnosed at the age of 7 with Cushing's after a dex test, and died at 13.  I rejected the conventional drug treatment, which was basically giving her DDT every day (as my vet recently called it).  There is now a new, supposedly safer, drug treatment available, but my current Cushing's dog is quite old (13), and I've decided to use the kinder, gentler Cushex again for her symptoms.  So, five stars for this product.

When I ordered this adapter near the end of 2011, there was a different description on the web page that gave me the impression that it would work on my particular model Lenovo laptop.  I waited ages for it to arrive (it was sent by slow boat from China, apparently), and when it did, the plug into the computer didn't fit.  For the price I paid, I didn't think it was worth returning, so my husband tried to solder the plug into fitting better, but that didn't work either.  Sometimes you get what you pay for. My bad.

I've used Tradewinds Tapeworm tabs a number of times in the past for getting rid of tapeworms in my dogs.
