The system itself is mediocre.  Four gigs of ram just isn't that much, more is 500gb of space, and they're still making Celeron processors??  If you need a backup computer, if you need a computer for your grandparents, if you're a poor student who needs to write papers and go online for the most part, or if you're only going to use the most basic of applications then you can readily invest in this system.  Otherwise, there are so many other options out there that I would readily recommend (Lenovo being a favorite of mine at the moment).

I usually use Vaja leather cases with my iPhones (and I've used about half-a-dozen since getting my first iPhone years ago).  Vaja cases last, the leather is great and it takes a beating while offering a good amount of protection (depending on your needs and which case you decide to go with).  This 'ullu' 'Premium leather snap-on case' seems to be a miss for me.  The outside is leather but the interior is plastic.  The corners are not fully covered either on top or on the bottom (the Vaja case I'm using now is practically a copy of this one but with better protection, including fully covering all four corners).  This ullu case doesn't feel very 'premium' if I'm honest.  It's light, as is the Vaja, but for a few more dollars you can get a fully customized Vaja rather than this half-leather case.

Sound quality is good, not great.  The bass is somewhat 'deep' but there are some distortions here and there as well.  It does get loud if/when you need it and it's definitely a great value for its size and sound quality. It is very easy to use.  I got it out of the box and it was connected to my iPhone within a minute and playing music right away.  However, when I tried to connect this speaker to my computer via bluetooth I had absolutely no luck.  Not sure where the problem is as I've been able to use other bluetooth devices with my computer, but it is the main reason for a four rather than five star review.If you're making a call, the speaker works very well.  I kept it at a 3 foot distance and never struggled to either talk or listen to the other person.  The speaker uses rechargeable batteries and for whatever reason has two on/off buttons, one is located by the charging area and the other by the speaker volume/bluetooth connection controls.  Overall, a nice quality speaker for the price, just a shame I couldn't get it to work with my computer.

I'm surprised at the price this item is going for.  I've regularly had a need for a heavy hand stapler such as this around the house, especially one that can use a variety of different sized staples.  The price point is excellent for what you're getting.  Staples are easy to load, there is some strength required in using this stapler so be careful when putting it to use.  I haven't experienced any deformed staples thus far and this has just been a great tool to use on a variety of odd jobs.

The pen is good enough quality for the price but the "5th technology" is utter tripe.  If you're not using this pen daily the ink will simply run dry within a matter of weeks.  For my needs it has consistently underperformed for the price point Parker charges.  Not recommended.  I'd have more respect for Parker if like printer ink companies they charged a nickle for the product and a dime for the refill, at least you know what you're getting into.  Here your wallet is sedated by the price of the pen and readily taken advantage of at every opportunity for the ink refills.

This is a pricey item but it looks great and performs very, very well.  Build quality looks excellent, the grinder is easy to put together and you get three grinding plates so you can switch them out depending on your needs.  Thus far I've tried grinding some chicken and red meat for patties.  Both came out great without any issues and it took just a few minutes (grinding about 2-3lbs worth each time).  The motor is powerful enough to give you no issues if you're using this on a regular basis (weekly - can't imagine there's a reason to use this daily).  Bottom line is I'm really impressed with what this machine can do and I'm glad to have another reason to cook more at home.

I found these to be good but not great.  I prefer Lancaster Soft Creme Candy to Werther's Original Soft Caramels.  The texture of Werther's is good but they seem less filling and not as memorable. First time I Tried Lancaster's caramels I was hooked.  These I'm more impartial to.

These Jolly Rancher Hard Candies contain both corn syrup and sugar but there is no listing of how much is in each candy.  I like them.  Blue Raspberry is a great flavor and these would be perfect to give out on Halloween, to have around the house in general during the holiday season or to snack on during trips.  They taste great and last a good while, but I am also of the opinion that if you're going to make sweet candies, just use sugar.

It's a nice body wash but nothing special at all.  The scent is good but doesn't linger or really make an impression.  I've enjoyed Dove products more than this one, not to speak of the more pricey varieties out there.  And while I like the new Irish Spring Bar Soaps that have added shea butter, in this body wash it doesn't seem to make much of a difference.

If you like to snack between meals (or at times instead of meals), Hershey's kisses are a nice treat.  I have yet to incorporate them into any of the baking I do and truthfully I don't think I will.  These are nice but they're not great in terms of quality.  You're getting a lot of chocolate with this huge pack but it isn't amazing chocolate.  For me, Lindt is still among the best you can find if we're talking about quality.  I'd rather spend a little more and have amazing chocolate than spend less and have a huge bag of mediocre quality milk chocolate.

Great trimmer.  I've used gas-powered tools in the past (snow-blower) and have consistently tried to avoid them as they presented more hassle than they were worth, although they did perform quite well.  I was happy to put this trimmer to use in my yard area (not very huge though).  The trimmer comes already put together in a rather large box, battery included.  I charged the battery for a few hours and went to test it out.  It performed very well.  I recommend glasses and some ear plugs, otherwise this was a great tool to use.  It isn't very heavy, the balance is great, but definitely give yourself some room as you get used to it walking around.  I only needed the battery to work for about 40 minutes and I saw no sluggishness in this time period.  I don't know how well it would perform working hours on end, but for someone with a smaller rather than larger yard/property, this is a great investment.  You've got a battery that you can recharge, a two-speed setting, and a warranty if anything goes wrong.

David Stahel's latest work, 'The Battle for Moscow', is somewhat removed from his previous volumes on this topic.  This is his fourth book and it becomes evident that what was clearly visible on a majority of pages in his first three texts is missing from much of this latest effort.  That is, there is a significant lack of tactical and operational descriptions of battles.  At least one amazon reviewer has already commented on how disappointed they were to discover this.  Yet, in this supposed 'weakness' lies the strength of Stahel's argument(s).  The Wehrmacht on June 22, 1941 was a vaunted fighting force that managed to defeat and conquer most of Europe.  The ensuing invasion of the Soviet Union showcased, on the surface, the Wehrmacht's military prowess operationally and on a tactical level as numerous encirclements and victories were achieved.  Stahel outlines them all quite well (mainly in regards to Army Groups Center and South) in his previous volumes.  That is, the Red Army lost hundreds of thousands in the encirclements at Minsk, Smolensk, Kiev, and finally at Viazma/Briansk.  Yet, the narrative that concentrates on the victorious outcomes of those encirclements misses the forest for the trees.Thus, 'The Battle for Moscow' is a somewhat different creature than Stahel's previous works because it highlights again and again the slow progress of the German Army in the latter half of Operation Typhoon throughout November and early December of 1941.  There are no major battles, encirclements, or defeats of the Red Army because German forces were incapable of launching significant operations to achieve such feats, and when a major city was taken, Rostov by Army Group South, it eventually had to be evacuated due to Red Army pressure and German inability to hold it.  Stahel thus forces the reader to assume the physical and psychological state of the German Army through the numerous diaries, letters, memoirs, and battle reports that he quotes from.  The exhaustion of German troops was palpable on very page as they became bogged down in the mud of early November while hoping for a sudden freeze to create conditions for an eventual lunge toward Moscow.  And when that freeze did come it brought with it new obstacles that while facilitating one last push toward the Soviet capital also meant a whole new level of exhaustion, misery, disease and madness for countless soldiers.Additionally, on more than one occasion Stahel draws the reader's attention to the genocidal nature of the war that Hitler unleashed against the Soviet Union and the complicity of the Wehrmacht in the numerous stages of the Holocaust and the deaths of millions of Soviet prisoners of war.  One simply cannot discuss Operation Barbarossa or Typhoon without highlighting the numerous difficulties the Germans faced in the rear from Soviet partisans and how they treated the civilian population as the cold set in and they needed both clothing and dwellings to keep warm, which often meant stealing from the local population and displacing it to fend for themselves while appropriating their living quarters.Finally, much of Stahel's concentration rests on the German commanders and their actions throughout November.  Unlike many self-serving post-war memoirs, archival documentation from this period shows that generals like Bock, Guderian, Kluge, etc., had a choice in how they handled their troops and assignments.  None were forced to go on the offensive, the majority of those decisions they took for themselves based on a variety of factors until their forces were simply beyond the means of, in some cases, even picking up their weapons.  No German general was dismissed at this point (dismissals would come after the Soviet counter-offensive commenced) and yet being on the frontline, knowing the situation their soldiers were facing, they continued to ignore the exhaustion of their troops, the limits of their mobility (lack of trucks, tanks, planes, etc.) and forced their depleted formations onto the offensive again and again.  What was the end goal?  Moscow was never supposed to be captured, but encirclement was no longer an option as the targets were far too distant for what the Wehrmacht could hope to accomplish in November or December.  Thus, Stahel emphasizes the disconnect that existed between the goals of German commanders and the reality of what their forces could accomplish, with the final result being a situation that soon found exhausted and depleted German troops retreating in the face of a well-developed and planned Soviet counter-offensive.

This is the second conditioner I've tried from Pantene and it's very similar to the other in this line.  The scent is nice and not overpowering (at least for me), you'll need a little more rather than less depending on how much hair you have (I have short hair and with this conditioner I use more than with some others) and the end result is good, but I wouldn't say great or anything special.  Considering the price these usually go for, it's a good enough purchase.

I'm not new to war literature but I am somewhat distant from literature that deals with the Vietnam war.  I've read some texts on it and am always interested in new accounts that deal with interesting missions and individuals.  In some ways I think this book could have been a lot more than it was.  When you get right down to it, you have something that reads more like a journalistic account than a 'biography'.  This is a short read at under 300 pages and a quick one, which reflects well on the author's writing style and abilities.  But there are many 'actors' to keep track of and often they're introduced rather quickly and without much depth with the end result that there's little connection between the reader and the subject(s).  Nonetheless, the main subject of the book, Roy Benavidez, is definitely the stuff of 'legends'.The author begins with a description of Roy's background and family, which helped him become the man he was when the Vietnam war was in progress.  There is a small history dealing with Studies and Observations Group (SOG), which was in charge of numerous intelligence missions in and around Vietnam (and I'd have loved to hear more about them) and then the fateful mission that had Benavidez running 75 years from a helicopter to give much needed support to his friends is recounted from numerous points of view and eye witness accounts.  The final chapters deal with the numerous issues involved in attempting to get Benavidez awarded the Medal of Honor and the bureaucratic red tape that almost made that 'mission impossible.'  Overall, this is an entertaining read with some amazing details that will make you stop and reread sentences and paragraphs on more than one occasion as you check if what you'd just read was actually written.  Stories like these might make many think of the familiar motto "An Army of One" but in truth that statement belies the fact that while one man can make a huge difference, men like Benavidez display such heroic qualities in response to the society and environment that reared them.  There is no 'army of one', but there are some men who encompass all that our armed forces should strive to emulate and those back home should recognize and celebrate.

I was contacted and asked if I'd be interested in reviewing this Digital scale and I agreed.At the moment I have an Omron Full Body scale that I'm using so I was able to check the accuracy of one against the other.  In general this Smart Weigh scale is very nicely designed.  It doesn't take up much room and is very simple to use.  Just insert the batteries that come with it and step on it.  It will turn on, record your weight, and that's pretty much all there is to it.  Comparing this Smart Weigh scale to the Omron there was a consistent 1lb difference in the weight both scales recorded.  The Omron was showing my weight 1lb heavier than the Smart Weigh.  Unfortunately I do not have a third scale to figure out which of these is lying to me.  A 1lb difference isn't horrible though and it's very helpful to see and track your progress with the different color set up so you know when you've gone up or down in weight.  This is especially helpful for those who don't weigh themselves daily and aren't keeping a log.

I'm not a fan of the consistency of this conditioner.  With some conditioners a little goes a long way, not so much with this one, but you don't need handfuls of it either.  The scent is fine as is the conditioner in general, it will leave your hair feeling soft and clean.  I like it for the most part and the price point is great.

You have a choice of four different types of baking cups. This review is for the “sophisticated staybrite” cups. My baking cups came in packs of six pastel and six packs of a navy blue print. You get twelve boxes and each box has liners for 36 cupcakes. You’re not going to run out for a long time.I hate greasing muffin pans and I can never be totally sure all cupcakes will detach unscathed so these liners are the answer. The thing I like best is they can stand alone without a muffin pan so you can get all the cupcakes on one cookie sheet for those dreaded “cupcakes for all” school parties and no muffin tins to wash..Since the liners are foil you can also use them for things like mimi-meatloafs . They are pretty enough to serve as nut-cups or individual candy cups.

After reading some of the other reviews I really wasn’t expecting much of this apron. Actually I was surprised.  It is fairly good quality material for the price.  The top and skirt part are a crisp percale and the waistband is cotton twill.  I didn’t like the big floppy, unnecessary bow so I removed it, opened it up and used the fabric to make a six inch wide pocket.  There is enough fabric in the bow to make two pockets if you’d like.  The waist ties are about three feet long so, depending on your waist size, you can pull the ties around and tie the bow in front..I give the apron a good spray of fabric sizing before ironing. It would look very cute over a black outfit. No, it’s not going to offer much protection for serious cooking but it makes you look so Martha Stewart-ish. I think it would also be fun for a young “kitchen helper”.

Refrigerator shelf liners? It sounded like a good idea at first. No more scrubbing up milk dribbles, just replace with a clean liner. In reality they didn’t work that great.  They cut down on the light quite a bit and scooting the milk cartons out caused them to slide or bunch.  I think the whole point of glass shelves is so you can see what’s in the bins without opening them. Maybe the liners aren’t really meant to be used on the big shelves?So, I cut them to fit the bins and the shelves in the doors and they look very nice.  I like that they are reversible with a very pretty design on both sides and that they are washable.Note: this review is for the fridge liners.

If you’re buying these for looks and not daily use they are a very pretty pattern and the tango red matches the DII shelf liners and other products however I don’t think they will be very useful. Even after several washing's they aren’t very absorbent and I just can’t envision myself ironing dishtowels.The towels are a large 18 X 28 and I’m considering cutting them in half, hemming the end and making napkins from them.  I don’t mind ironing napkins. Dish towels, no.

Fortunately for the Oster marketing department I’m the one writing this review and not my animals.The fountain is lightweight, easy to fill and clean. I think it’s very attractive (well for a cat fountain).  The sound is very soothing once you get over the compulsion to check for leaky faucets.So, the animal test: “Baby” AKA scare-dy cat took one look at it and slowly backed away.  The Himalayan looked at it like “You’ve GOT to be kidding!” and walked away with her tail in the air.  My very smart Aussie has touched the electric fence a couple of times and avoids anything that buzzes or sounds the least bit electrical.  So five stars from me, one from the animals. I win.I’m going to give them another week or so and see if they decide it’s harmless and I’ll leave their other dish out for a while.

These cloths are about the quality you’d find in any dollar store but at half the price.  They absorb well and wash up well like any microfiber towel.If you shop around on Amazon you can find much thicker, larger cloths at a much more economical price.  I will probably pack these in camping gear because they’re thin and lightweight and should dry fast.

This printer is a very sleek, compact, nice looking little printer. It was simple to set up. Go to 123.hp.com/setup for simple instructions. You can use it without a computer but if you want to use a computer be sure to set this one as default before sending your print job. One of my favorite features is the self-deploying output tray. I’m embarrassed to tell you how many times I’ve forgotten to pull out the tray and I’ve had to crawl around on the floor looking for the pages. Also you can set it in “quiet mode” if you need it to be quiet. You will have to set up your printer separately on each device you want to use it with. It does great photos although it only has one tray so you will have to set-up for photo paper. Two- sided printing works very well.Re: the instant ink. It will save you about 50% on ink. If you sign up in the first 7 days after activating the printer you get three months free trial.  Be sure to go to hpinstantink.com to cancel if you don’t want to continue or your card will be charged. You can choose a monthly plan based on your pages printed, not ink used. Your printer orders ink when it’s low. Original HP ink delivered to your door and you can change or cancel anytime. There is a page in the back of the manual that gives you the rate info.

That sounds like some kind of oxymoron joke but when I looked around I was surprised at how many other plastic electrical items I have.  It is true, when you lower the toasting lever, it doesn't have that satisfying thuwnk-twang you get with a metal toaster but it works great.  It has the toasting rods like a high end toaster/convection oven I have, not the coiled wire which just seems to toast the surface of your bread.My toaster has a very nice finish and I like the red, retro look. I haven’t tried the defrost mode but it works great for everything from bagels to fat slices of sourdough bread. It is so easy to clean with the removable crumb tray and glass door.Be sure to remove all packing material and heat the toaster on “4” before using.  There is a one year warranty but you can double that if you go online to register the toaster. They have some interesting recipes on their web-site, mydash.com.

I’m always curious when someone says “It smells like something my grandmother would wear.” Is that a bad thing? Is the grandmother 50 years old and “poison” and “obsession” were the popular perfumes of her youth? Or maybe she’s 80 years old and still wears the Chanel # 5 she wore when she was thirty? My own grandmother always seemed to have a baby on her lap and she smelled of Johnson’s baby powder and graham crackers so I guess everyone has a different idea of what grandmothers smell like.I guess the point I’m trying to make is that the sense of smell is a totally subjective thing and, besides, perfumes will smell entirely different on different people when it combines with their particular body chemistry.The "Love is on" eau de toilette  comes in a very pretty, melting- heart bottle which is in a transparent red plastic box. I think it would make a very nice gift and you might love the fragrance.As for the scent… I was disappointed to say the least. I like a light, floral scent and I couldn’t detect a floral tone at all. It sort of reminds me of a combination man’s shaving lotion and burned toast after I wear it for a while. Maybe it’s just me?

This is a very attractive, plush, absorbent bath mat. The yellow is a cheery color.I haven’t had a problem with the rug being slippery but I suppose that would depend on the type of floor you have. I like that there is no rubberized backing to crack and peel.I had no problem washing the mat in a front loading machine, partially drying in the dryer then finishing drying over a rod.  You might want to wash the dark colors separately, though.

If you’re just looking for an inexpensive wrap to cover up while you’re applying make-up or doing your hair after a shower this wrap serves the purpose.  The Velcro holds firmly and there is enough stretch in the elastic to be comfortable.The ombre color is pretty and there is a hanging loop. I didn’t find it very absorbent.The ends are sloppily sewn and puckered and hang in a very unattractive manner.

We had frost this morning so it was the perfect day to test these gloves out, putting out a hay roll for the cows.A good portion of the gloves is very soft, flexible grain pigskin with a strip of twill fabric on the back. The cuff is a snug knit fabric with a leather pull-on strip. The palm of the glove is made with only a thin seam across two middle fingers so no irritating seams. Even the thumb has the seam running up the outer sides so the pad part is smooth. The interior has a warm cozy lining.These gloves would be great for anyone who has to work outside this winter.

I suppose you’re paying extra for the fancy 6 1/2 inch dia. Tin. (About the size of a saucer) The candy looks like generic M & Ms.  Quite a few of mine had broken shells and they weren’t glossy like the ones pictured on the product page.There is really nothing wrong with the taste just nothing special for the current price of $18-47.

Sheesh! Who comes up with this stuff? It’s just dog food.  Holistic?*In spite of all the ridiculous rhetoric this dog food has good ingredients, no soy corn or wheat. No mysterious “by-products”. The kibble is small for the little guy and you can add a little warm water or broth to make it even better. It would be nice if they would add a re-sealable top to the fancy bag.The larger bag is more economical .Money back guarantee.* characterized by the treatment of the whole person, taking into account mental and social factors, rather than just the physical symptoms of a disease.

"A micelle (/maɪˈsɛl/) or micella (/maɪˈsɛlə/) (plural micelles or micellae, respectively) is an aggregate of surfactant molecules dispersed in a liquid colloid."Well, alrighty then. This is the first toner/cleaner combination I've used and it seems to work very well . It leaves my skin feeling very clean although just a tad sticky for a while. It has a very subtle fragrance which smells floral to me.The product is Soap-free. Alcohol-free. Colorant-free. pH-balanced. Allergy-tested. Non-comedogenic. Suitable for sensitive skin. Safe for contact lens wearers. Tested under dermatological and ophthalmological control .Vichy is a L'Oreal brand, made in France. Don't ask me why the writing on the bottle  looks like Russian.The ingredients are: AQUA/WATER • HEXYLENE GLYCOL • GLYCERIN • POLOXAMER 184 • DISODIUM COCOAMPHODIACETATE • DISODIUM EDTA • PANTHENOL • POLYAMINOPROPYL BIGUANIDE • PARFUM / FRAGRANCE

Oh, lordy, who writes the ad copy for these dog foods?This seems to be a good quality dog food with no wheat, corn or soy. My dog wasn’t crazy about it but she prefers cat food so what does she know? She had no digestive problems with it. The small bag is more expensive per pound but this is the right size to see how your dog likes it before committing to a bigger bag.It would be nice if the glitzy bag was reseal-able.

My picky Himalayan, Bitchy-little-woman-in-a-cheap-fur-coat, likes all the Nutro products but I think this is her favorite. The pate style is too thick and sticks to the bottom of her plate, she licks the gravy off the “shreds’ but this texture is Juussst right. You can hear her sucking it up half way across the room.The Nutro has no fillers, grains, artificial color or preservatives just meat and the vitamins and minerals a cat needs.  You don’t have all the wheat, gluten, titanium dioxide, oat fiber etc. that you will find in other cat food.It is my opinion that cats eat less of the nutrient rich cat food and you also  end up saving in vet bills  so the higher cost is justified in the end for a healthier, happier cat

If you’re looking for an affordable headset this one is about what you would expect for the price.The sound is adequate but I really wouldn’t recommend these for an adult with a normal size head. There isn’t much adjustment in the band. The on-ear cup might be more comfortable for a smaller person.

It’s not totally clear to me why they call this an all-in-one printer.  I have two all-in-one printers (one Epson, one Canon) which include a fax, document feeder and print legal size documents.  Yes, I know FAX machines aren’t used as much nowadays but we still get requests, mostly from European countries, and it’s better to have a fax and not need it than to need one and not have it.All of that being irrelevant I can tell you Canon makes very well made and dependable machines.  Although the measurements are given in the description I was surprised at the weight and size of the printer. It is much larger than some wireless printers I have seen. It was simple to unpack with a minimum of packing material.  I suggest you go to canon.com/ijsetup and click on “installation while viewing video”. The instructions are much simpler than trying to interpret the set-up guide. Just follow instructions on the 2.5 LCD screenOperation is only guaranteed on windows 8.1, 8, 7, vista and XP. My guess is if you have windows 10 you can go to their website to find a work-around if the printer doesn’t work with windows 10.The printer printed flawlessly, from an iphone, using the included sample photo paper. This printer seemed much quieter than most.Be prepared for a sticker-shock heart attack when you have to replace the ink.Sometimes I wonder if it wouldn't be better to just buy a new machine with included ink.You can buy individual cartridges but it always seems cheaper to buy the "bundle" tanks and  I always buy the XL size cartridges because I think they are more economical. 100% US based service and support at 800-OK-CANON.Made in Vietnam.

Since we plan to use this seed for “dormant seeding” I obviously can’t tell you how this particular bag of seed will grow but we planted some last spring which did very well. Of course you will need to prepare the ground properly and water well. Even letting the seedlings dry out for a few hours will kill them. The seed will take 14 to 21 days to germinate.For dormant seeding you plant in Dec, Jan or Feb and the seed germinate in the spring.“One benefit of dormant seeding is the freezing and thawing of the earth creates crevices in the soil and makes an ideal seedbed. Once conditions are just right in the spring, since the grass seed will already be in place, chances of germination are much improved. This may be beneficial for areas that experience frequent watering bans.” You can “overseed” with winter rye if you want.When planning a dormant overseeding soil should be prepared by aerating or power raking prior to the ground freezing. Any soil amendments for adjusting the pH, such as lime or sulphur, should also be applied prior to the cold weather. Starter Food for New Grass is recommended in the spring, when new seedlings emerge.If you can’t plant for some time the seeds will be viable for a long time if stored properly. You will have a reduction in germination of 5 to 7% for each year the seed is kept.

This is a really nice, fun floor puzzle, 3 x2 feet. In our opinion the bigger the better! Because of the bigger pieces it’s easy for the younger ones to get in on the fun. Works for the 3, 4, 7 and 9 year olds. The pieces are sturdy enough to handle a little abuse.The glow-in-the dark works best with a black- light or charge it for a few minutes with a bright flashlight. After all the fun of putting it together you can color the back side.The box has a handle and is handy for storage.

This is the first time  we (well, my dog) have tried the venison flavor of Nutro although we've tried several others. The first ingredient, venison meal, has 300 times the protein of just the meat so that sounds good to me.  Nutro doesn’t add artificial flavors or colors (like Science diets titanium dioxide) so the fewer things to cause allergies and stomach problems the better. Also their minerals are chelated. If you go to their website they have a six page glossary of ingredients and their use and they are up-front about their ingredients and where they come from.Now to the true test…Does the dog like it? Yes! Of course she prefers the canned chunky Nutro but I try to give her some of each.The food may seem a little pricey to some but my Aussie seems to eat less of the protein rich food than the stuff with lots of fillers, like corn, and I'm sure it saves on vet bills. As a matter of fact I took her in for a check-up today and I got several comments on how good she looks.If you would like more info on dog food you can check out dogfoodadvisor.com

This is about the cutest thing ever from her wrinkled knees to the little tuft of felt hair. This is the sort of toy your child will hold on to for years so it’s a good thing it’s machine washable.We also have the baby Stella doll which is similar but this one is about half the price and just as cute. The removable clothes are a little better made and the pacifier is fastened on with a ribbon. The magnet isn't as obvious on the mouth of the Adora doll.The doll is made of plush material and has embroidered features including the little heart shaped belly button.  A very huggable, even chewable, first baby doll.

If you’re not expecting a “chef Quality” knife then this knife is OK for the price.The blade is heavy enough although the handle feels a little wimpy. They say the sharpener built in to the sheath sharpens the knife every time you put it away and I don’t have a reason to think otherwise.I like the idea of having a sheath for the blade since I store my knives in a drawer. It works fine once you discover the right angle to insert the knife into the sheath and you get over the fear of it slipping and cutting your wrist.

I’m not sure if this is meant for old people or just old hair that has been growing for a while nevertheless I decided to give it a try.The product is a thin-ish lotion with no obnoxious fragrance.  You spread a few pumps on your hands and spread it on your damp hair from about mid-length down, not on the scalpI decided to use it on just one side to be sure the end result wasn’t from my shampoo or conditioner.  I was amazed! I really didn’t expect much from such a cheap product (why do we always expect expensive=better? Human nature I guess. ) After a day in atrocious humidity my hair still has more body and is” bouncy” on one side.You can also use it on dry hair so I put a little on the other side and put a curler in it. It dried quickly and now I match all around.In my opinion this is a good product for such an economical price.

I've never used any brand of vacuum bag but the foodsaver brand but I usually use the roll bags because I can cut them to fit whatever I’m freezing.However these pre-made bags are great.  My favorite use is for dividing larger value packs of stuff and freezing half.  I also like to use them to seal things like dog food in gallon portions to keep it fresh when I open a big bag. I don't like polishing silver so I can store 12 place settings in a gallon bag to keep it from tarnishing between uses.  Also some serving pieces. Of course they're great for storing large cuts of meat but you'll be surprised how many other uses you will find for them.

Sorry, the nine-year-old made me do it.This is just a basic, economical, passive welding helmet.  Since occasional MIG or TIG welding is the only kind done around here this is perfectly adequate.The narrow shell design is a good idea. The knob adjustments on the side work well. The helmet is ULTRA lightweight…6 ounces.The headgear can be adjusted by moving the pegs in the holes on top of the head or twisting the knob on the back of the head. The angle from the face can also be adjusted.  We're considering getting a magnifying lens which comes in several diopters and cost under $10. How great would that be to weld without sweaty glasses? (Check out Cyberweld)

I’ve never owned a trapper keeper so I don’t have anything to compare this one to.The outside plastic looks fairly strong but the inside pockets look sort of flimsy. The ring assembly is just ordinary round ring, not that easy to open.The snap closure is totally worthless. It doesn't really hold at all.The graphics are kind of cool if you're in to star wars but I’m really not impressed enough to pay the present price of $18.05. If you are, I guess 3 stars (OK) is a fair rating..

Hasbro has about 60 brands of toys and, in my opinion, playschool is the best.This little dressy kid girl is as cute as the dressy kid boy.  Besides being a cuddly little friend she is educational and great for teaching little-uns zipping, tying, buttoning skills.  The hair is a soft tactile plush and the features are embroidered.The clothes are well sewn, with back-stitching, and are  non-removable (a good thing).  It’s really fun to hide little surprises in the pockets for the kid to find.The doll is washable and comes with a ring to hang her on a back-pack, stroller etc because she is going to go everywhere with you.Just a fun, well-made doll without all the “gimme, gimme” street-walker accessories.

This is a cute little plush puppy.  Be sure to open up the Velcro pocket on the back and set the toggle switch to “on” instead of “demo”. The toy can be washed if you remove the electronic box first. It is well-made and looks like it will last a long time.Usually if a toy says “Fisher-Price” I’m all in but I’m a little disappointed in this one.  I actually tried it out myself before giving it a baby test.  If the puppy is close enough to feel the vibrations the music is much too loud and there is no way to turn it down or off unless you turn it to demo.  I think it would keep a baby awake. You are supposed to be able to turn the vibrations off by pressing the tummy for a few seconds. It didn't work for me even after turning off and back on to reset.

I don’t know that there is a lot I can add to this binder’s description that isn’t on the product page. Mine seems well-sewn but the ring assembly, which can be removed, seems a little flimsy and cheaply made.  For something this expensive you would expect better quality rings, maybe “D” rings.You’re supposed to be able to bend the back over and fasten it with the Velcro strap so the file will stand upright on your desk.  It seems very stiff but maybe it will loosen with use.The file pockets only go half way down which seems a little odd. The ID tabs for the files are in the pencil pocket under the front flap. When you have the binder fully stuffed, with file pocket and paper, it will only expand to a max of two inches and still zip.

This is another great Nutro dog food but with limited ingredients if you dog has a sensitive stomach.Chicken, Chicken Meal, Brewers Rice, Rice Bran, Whole Brown Rice, Whole Grain Oatmeal, Chicken Fat Split Peas, Natural Flavor, Dried Plain Beet Pulp, Sunflower Oil, Soybean Oil Pea Protein plus all the minerals and vitamins to keep your dog healthy.No outsourcing.  Go to nutro.com/goodness to learn where their ingredients come from.According to my test dummy the taste is great too.

I've been doing a lot of research on dog food lately and I've come to one major conclusion: Dog food is like sausage. You're really better off not knowing what is in it and how it's made.Nutro is the one dog food I've found that has ingredients I can understand and nothing to activate your gag reflex. No "by-products" or "plasmas". They have a six page glossary on their website explaining the ingredients. They have been in business since 1926 and never outsource. Their food is mostly 4 or 5 star ratings on dogfoodadvisor.com.My Aussie absolutely LOVES the Nutro food especially the chunky ones. This one has Chicken Broth, Chicken, Chicken Liver, Turkey, Beef Liver, Potato Starch, Wheat Gluten, Ground Rice, Egg Product, Whole Rice, Salt, Sunflower Oil and all necessary minerals and vitamins.

This is another great Nutro dog food but with cellulose, extra fiber and fewer calories to keep your dog healthy but not over-weight. The high fiber and high protein helps your dog feel full.The number one ingredient is farm-raised chicken. Never outsourced. Easy pour, reseal-able bag.Besides all that, Pup loves it.

What kind of dog is Teddy? All I can tell you for sure is "short". His tiny little feet barely touch the ground but I suspect he is really a Doberman trapped in that tiny little bug-eyed body.This kibble is just the right size for small dogs.  Perfectly balanced like all Nutro food. No artificial flavors, colors or preservatives. Chicken is the #1 ingredient.Easy open and reseal bag for freshness.Visible difference guarantee.

I wouldn't want her to know I said this but there is a certain little Shih Tzu who looks like a little barrel with buggy eyes and a tongue hanging out. It's really not her fault. She is so picky and we tend to give her what she wants and it's not always the best for her.Like all Nutro items I've reviewed this is another quality dogfood.  These are the first ingredients: Chicken, Chicken Meal, Whole Brown Rice, Brewers Rice, Rice Bran, Pea Protein, and Whole Grain Oatmeal. The eighth ingredient is powdered cellulose.  This isn't in most of their recipes but helps in the weight loss food.  I checked to find out what this was and this is their answer:"Powdered cellulose is a natural source of fiber that supports healthy digestion. Cellulose is a part of the NUTRO FIBERBLEND(tm) Formula which includes the ingredients Dried Plain Beet Pulp, Flax Seed and Cellulose. Cellulose is included in the formula because it provides a great source of insoluble fiber for digestive health. The digestive tract works best with an optimal balance of soluble and insoluble fiber levels, and FIBERBLEND(tm) is used to achieve this balance. Pets need insoluble fiber to aid in waste elimination and promote gastrointestinal health.  Cellulose is used in many pet foods and human foods. It is the most common natural compound found on earth, as it provides structure to cell walls of all plants, including fruits and vegetables.  The Nutro Company uses cellulose made from virgin paper. The supplier of our cellulose follows the Food Chemical Codex (FCC), which is a compendium of internationally recognized standards for the purity and identity of food ingredients. "When I contacted another well-known manufacturer about the source of THEIR cellulose this was their answer: "Once it is purified it is impossible to determine its original source.". Nutro is transparent about all their ingredients and they have a 6 page glossary of descriptive terms used....All of which is beside the point, I guess.But the true test; will she eat it?  Yes, if it has a little warm water or broth sprinkled over it to soften it a little or maybe a teaspoon or two of baby-food pumpkin or applesauce mixed in.  This is pretty good for a chubb-O who usually has to be bribed with bacon.I think The fact they don't use artificial color, flavors or preservatives might also  help her allergies.

Back in the day a lunch box had a handle and held your lunch and a thermos. If that's what you're expecting you will be surprised. This is a little box, 6.8 x 5.4 x2.2.It is a cute little box, with see-through glasses design on top, and it coordinates with the skip-hop thermos.The box is sort of curved on the sides so the inner container won't crush you other food.  It is dishwasher safe.  BPA-free, PVC-free, Phthalate-free.One of the latches snapped off the first time I opened it. I managed to replace it but I don't have a lot of confidence this "lunch kit" will last that long.

These potholders are fairly well made but there is absolutely no insulation. Most potholders have a lining of insul-fab or something and as far as I can tell there is nothing here but a couple of layers of cotton fabric.Total failure as pot-holders if you're using them to protect your hands. No heat-resistance at all.

Of course your results with this conditioner will depend on your type of hair. I have fine curly hair and it left my hair very soft and shiny. Because of the palm oils I think it would work even better on dry, frizzy hair.The directions on the product page say you can use it on dry hair but I think that is a miss-print and probably refers to the nourishing oil (third step.) The directions on the actual bottle just say "...press in to damp hair, leave three minutes and rinse." As seems the trend lately all cosmetics want you to use their "system" and this is step #2 along with their shampoo and oil infinite finishing oil.  I used it with my regular shampoo and I doubt you would be able to tell the difference.The only negative to the conditioner is the fragrance. It is very strong and reminds me of an expensive men's cologne. Fortunately it doesn't linger on your hair. If you're sensitive to fragrance this probably wouldn't be a good choice for you.

Be prepared to dedicate some time and space for this toy (it is 4.5 ft. long) but once you get it together it's worth it. This is certainly not something you're going to want to take apart and put away every day! The instructions are in black and white so you'll probably do just as well working from the photo on the box.  Also have 5 AAA batteries on hand. The car has three batteries but for demo only so they  won't last long.The description says for 1 to 5 year old but I think one year old might  be pushing it a little unless you have a VERY precocious one year old.Only one car and remote are included but you can buy more for around $16. This is a really fun and well-made toy.

No idea why anyone would actually pay for a game that has Google AND Flurry Analaytcs, IAP, pop up advertising, and who knows what else!In the few minutes that I messed around with Civiballs, my firewall stopped so many connections that I don't even want to think about keeping this thing on my system.I can't give an honest review on the game itself, other than mention that it is a spyware infested bug fest that constantly tries to make outside contact, and crashed on my rooted phone.I did not want to try it on an unrooted device (nor can I suggest for others to do the same), since I don't have the necessary software to stop the app from phoning home. I guess I could have always tweaked my router, but didn't really feel like giving Civiballs another chance.The best part is that it can also read the phone status and identity of your phone, meaning HeroCraft and their partners will have your personal devices DID (unique number used to tag each device), your phone number, AND the number of anyone that is connected to your device via call.The other winning permissions are Full Network Access, and the ability to view network connections (including devices connected to said network).I am simply disgusted by this app, and I won't even mention the In app purchasing or random ads that pop up during gameplay... Whoops.As I said, this "App" has been removed from my device, and the shady developer should be ashamed for not disclosing all the junkware that they included within.

It all started for me a little over 15 years ago with an old White's 5900. My grandmother lost a ring somewhere in her massive, poorly maintained yard, and it was up to me (and a second hand 5900) to find it.Long story short, I did just that - and found out that I rather enjoyed hunting in the process.Over the years, I went through many more metal detectors before settling on the Time Ranger some time in 2010. My previously favorite MD was the Garrett Ace 250 (which my wife currently uses - used actually).Hunting is a great hobby, and will pay for itself within a few years (or much sooner if you are lucky).I spent a little over $400 on my Time Ranger, and it paid for itself on the third day - when I dug up a very nice ring (while hunting a popular beach).I went back there countless times over the years, and while I didn't get any more major finds, I do quite often get silver and gold rings, as well as massive amounts of coin. This alone should tell you how great the TR is, since that beach is hunted by dozens of other enthusiasts.A few years ago I got my wife into the hobby and she has been using my old Ace 250. For a while we would go out a few times a week, but that came to an end when hunting made a comeback. These past few years everyone seems to be walking around with a metal detector, looking for lost treasures.While we no longer have time to hunt every week, we make it a point to go out at least once a month, and try our luck. I sometimes follow behind her (if the area looks promising), and since the TR has a greater depth range than the A250, often find things she missed.My deepest find was a coin that was almost 14 inches BELOW ground. Her Ace 250 swept right over it (literally), but the TR had no issue finding it. It was so deep that I almost gave up on it after digging out about 12 inches, but my pinpointer confirmed something, and I kept going.Now I know it's not fair to compare the Ace 250 ($200 dollar detector), vs the Time Ranger (400 dollar detector), but since the TR can now be bought for under $170, it falls in the same price range as the Ace!Both are great detectors, but the TR comes with more bells, whistles, and options. My cousin actually bought the 350 model a few years back and I often find good stuff he missed, while he has no such luck if I lead (although I do try to leave him plenty of junk).I also sometimes compete in sponsored hunts, where I usually end up in the top 10. I never actually took first place, that is usually "reserved" for people with thousand dollar machines and a lot more experience than me (but I did come in fourth twice so far, and fifth quite a few times as well - beating out some very expensive MD's).But enough ranting, let me tell you why you should buy this metal detector.First of all, the price is outstanding. Dollar for dollar, you can't beat this machine unless you move up to the Garrett AT Pro. I will be the first to admit, that machine is technically better - but the price difference is huge. If you have $600 to spend on the AT Pro, by all means go with that. Eventually I will upgrade to the ATP as well, but only when it falls into the $400 (or below) range.Second - as long as you know how to ground balance your unit, this thing will detect pretty much anything you want it to.Third - it is waterproof. Just don't submerse it too far and get water on the circuits/display enclosure. Having said that, their support is nice enough to repair your system fairly cheap and extremely fast if you do get it wet.Fourth - You can actually exclude certain items and metals from being found with a simple press of a button! Careful when using this feature though, since I found a LOT of jewelry that read out as pull tabs.Fifth - If you have the patience to learn this wonderful detector - it will last you a life time and get you a lot of great finds.I actually just bought another one for my wife, and sold her Ace 250 on Craigslist.To sum it up, this is a great detector at a great price. I hunted rocky mountains, sandy beaches, and everything in between. Never had an issue with the detection rate or quality. Salt water can get a little tricky, but adjusting the sensitivity quickly fixed the problem. So go ahead and buy confidently. For under $170, you will NOT buy a better metal detector at the moment.

I work out quite often, and since I am (sadly) no longer in my 30's, I sometimes become very sore after increasing weight. My usual solution is a soak (with salts of course) and Tiger Balm - LOTS of Tiger Balm.I have used and reviewed plenty of these things, and have to say that this vi-tae product is the best pain relief salt I have ever used. The pleasant wintergreen, rosemary, and cedarwood smells overpower pretty much everything else in this mix, resulting in an aroma that is somewhat similar to Tiger Balm. The mix also contains hints of thyme, eucalyptus, and some other pleasant pine-like scent that I can't quite put my finger on.Even more surprising is how effective it is at easing my soreness after a work out. A 35 minute soak left me completely relaxed, and while some discomfort remained, it wasn't too bad. I even decided to skip the Tiger Balm, and that is the biggest praise I can give this product. In fact, it was so effective that I decided to try it again, thinking the first result a fluke. So I increased my squat weight by another 10 pounds and did an additional set - which of course resulted in soreness the very next day. Sure enough, another soak took care of it once again!Having said that, I do have an issue with this mix as well. The 16 ounce container has (at most) enough salt for just five soaks, and sells for $31.50. That is a bit excessive, and puts them on the same level as spa salts (even more expensive than some spa salts actually).If vi-tae lowers the price, and sets up a subscribe and save option with Amazon, I would gladly recommend this product to everyone, as it is I can only recommend it to those that actually need proper pain relief, or don't mind the high price for a quality product.

Let me start off by saying that this game is not for everyone, it mostly caters to those of us that grew up on Roguelike's.Like most games from the genre that inspire it, there are no instructions. You are simply dropped into a level and are left to figure everything out on your own. However without skills, leveling (leveling up), looting, or money - this game is much less cruel than most other Roguelike's. Having said that, what it lacks in character attachment and certain other areas - it more than makes up in plain deviousness (and enemy placement). Instead of having unlimited moves as we do in most Roguelike's, Ending only gives you a set amount - making the whole thing require a lot more thought, although not until the later levels... The most hardcore can also argue that this set of limited moves imposes the same barrier on you as food does in most Roguelike games, and I agree - to a point.I won't ruin it for those of us that enjoy the challenge of figuring things out, but I will give a hint to some of the people that say the enemies in this game have no rhyme or reason. Quite contrary.Simply look at the way the enemy is positioned, and know that every time you move - so does it (all of them to be exact). Ending uses a turn based movement system (like a lot of other Roguelike's), and it has to be exploited to win.Another hint - take a very close look at the enemies that face you. Specifically which of their ends are "fat". That "fat" end can destroy you if the enemy attacks before you do.Final hint - You CAN destroy white (not grey) blocks, and sometimes it is beneficial to destroy something (even an enemy) to force everything else to move, other times it is actually detrimental.That's all the hints I will give, since I don't want to be utterly flamed by the people that thrive on games like these. If you have any questions, post them in the comments section and I will answer.With the hints out of the way, lets get back to the real review. Ending has a wide variety of enemies, even if they are all represented by a combination of lines, x's, and squares (those of us that played Akalabeth, think of the world map). There are even enemies that can't be destroyed and whose only purpose is to literally get in your way, move you, and prevent you from escaping the level by reaching the end (presented as a block with a staircase leading down).Ending has three game modes (although only two are drastically different), a puzzle mode where you have to proceed level by level, a survival mode where you are brutally hunted by enemies as you try to escape (this is the mode that will mostly interest the Roguelike fans), and a mode where you can pretty much pick your levels.5/3/2014 Edit: I am WRONG here. The third mode is actually a level editor. Please take a look at T. Crowe's excellent review for more info.The game's minimalistic approach encompass everything about it - from the music (there is none), to the graphics (think old Atari or early computer games). There is even only a single permission in place (which should be removed, since it serves no purpose in a game such as this).Having said all this, I will once again state the most important part of this review - THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. It caters to a niche of gamers, and does so extremely well.My suggestion to the developer, is to add a tutorial mode that will explain a few things about the game, and one that is entirely optional so as to not impact those of us that enjoy figuring things out on our own. My other suggestion is to please remove the single permission you have in place. What purpose does it serve?Other than that, this is a VERY solid game, and well worth the price of admission - and VERY recommended as today's free app of the day.As a side note, Mr. Aaron Steed - I would really LOVE to see you take on a full Roguelike game on the Android. It is very obvious that you love the genre, and have enemy, trap, and level design in place. Why not add gear, loot, and leveling to the equation?

Now I may not be the best person to review this game, since I am a LEGO fan, a Star Wars nut, and a gamer that enjoys top down 2D shooters. So this game hits me on multiple levels, and when I got to fly the Millennium Falcon, I went full on nerd mode.The game is a very simple top down shooter, with some interesting levels, pleasant graphics, and excellent sound effects. You can chose to pilot for either the Empire or the Rebellion, and this will impact the vehicles you have access to, as well as the enemies you face. Sadly the levels stay mostly the same. The destructible environments are also a nice little feature, but nothing game changing.There are 18 levels spread through two campaigns (Clone Wars and Galactic Civil War) and 4 planets (Geonosis, Endor, Yavin, and Hoth). Combined with the simple but effective upgrade system, you will really be playing this for a while. By destroying your enemies and collecting their scraps, you can upgrade your ship with everything from extra HP to super-weapons.So why did I score this a 4 out of 5? Well while there are no in app purchases at the moment, the permissions in the game ARE already there to allow for such nonsense.I see absolutely no reason to have the following permissions in a single player game:Open network socketsAccess information about Wi-Fi networksAccess information about networksFinally, even though the game IS pretty large, I ended up beating it in just a few hours. Having a lot more levels, upgrades, and Microfighters would go a long way to making this game stellar.To sum it up, yes the game is easily worth the $.99 cent entry fee, and even though you can beat it in just a few hours - it offers a lot of bang for your buck. Add in the lack of IAP and you got a winner. Hopefully the game gets updated with more levels and Microfigthers, as well as stays IAP free.5/9/2014 Update: While the game ran just fine on my two test phones (Nexus 4 with a custom ROM, and a stock Nexus 5), it does have performance issues (including crashes) on some hardware. The issue, most likely, revolves around the obscene amount of RAM the game uses. There seems to be a memory leak within the app itself, as this number seems to increase the longer you play.

I love sprinkling this into the whirlpool and taking a nice, long soak with my wife, while smooth jazz plays in the background.The pleasant smell of Hinoki and Ginger permeate the air, mixing perfectly with the warm Florida breeze, and all our troubles simply soak away...That is until my daughter runs by, "accidentally" tips over the speaker and our glasses of wine, causing the whole experience to come to a very abrupt end.Jokes aside, this stuff is amazing. It smells great and helps to relieve minor aches and pains. However $27 bucks for just 66 ounces is expensive, since to get any kind of soothing effect I had to use about a fourth of a container per soak.After looking around locally, I now get 5 pounds of Hinoki and 5 pounds of Ginger/Chamomile bath salts. That whole order costs me LESS than a three pack of this stuff, and lasts a lot longer. Now the quality is not as good as what this product offers, but the price is much less for over twice the salt.If they ever lower the price to be more reasonable, I will gladly boost this up to a 5 star review.

When we lived in Florida, this was pretty much a necessity. With this swimsuit on, you don't really have to worry too much about getting your child to stand still for 10+ minutes while you apply sunscreen.My daughter could spend hours in the pool, and I would lounge on the chair next to it (in the shade, with some "refreshments"). I had her come out ever 30-40 minutes to re-apply sunscreen to her arms and face, and back in she went.Money well spent.As an added bonus, the suit allowed my daughter to wade into the deep end (with my supervision of course), and swim around there, which she loved. I asked her many times if the floating foam got in her way, and she always said no.

I had a pretty bad fall and ended up hurting my back. The doctor prescribed me some muscle relaxants and painkillers, but they didn't really agree with my system and made me pretty dizzy... Meaning I couldn't even drive.They also took 20+ minutes to kick in, and stopped working every few hours.Having used the regular Tiger Balm before for minor aches, I decided to give this Ultra Strength rub a try.My wife would massage this stuff directly into my back and within minutes the pain would become nothing but a dull ache.There really are no side effects with this ointment, unless you count the strong menthol smell that will follow you for hours.Most importantly is that unlike painkillers, two applications of Tiger Balm would last me the day. Yes, the pain was never completely gone, but the improvement was huge - AND it didn't have any impact on my driving.

Having used this product for a little over a week I lost about a pound. So while I can not comment on the health benefits, of which many are claimed - it did help me shed some weight. This is most likely due to the fructooligosaccharides contained within.I changed absolutely nothing about my diet other than adding this to my yogurt (instead of honey), and my tea (instead of honey and evaporated cane juice).I didn't really feel better or more energized, but my wife claimed to have more energy (which she used to nag me with, I kid, I kid), and she lost about a pound as well.Not bad for a week of use. We will continue to use this syrup and will most likely buy it again when we run out.My wife actually bought Yacon syrup before from Whole Foods (or the local vitamin shop), and it tasted terrible - like dirt. So we didn't really use it. At least this brand tastes like a mix of honey and molasses, with a hint of nut. Huge plus, but it's still a bit too earthy for me. My wife was OK with the taste, but she is also OK with drinking Kombucha daily - which is also quite healthy if home brewed, but tastes weird to me.As with all supplements, this should be taken in moderation - no more than 4 teaspoons per day. Otherwise some stomach issues may occur (mostly gas).If you want to check out an actual study on the benefits of Yacon for weight loss, please check for the link in the comments section. Amazon still stupidly does not allow you to link to sites in the main portion of your review.Finally, I have to comment on the price. $21.97 per 8 ounce bottle is a bit steep. I checked my local vitamin store and an 11 ounce bottle cost $17.99. Having said that, I do believe it is the same brand that my wife purchased previously, and as I said - that stuff tasted like dirt.

Let me start off this review by saying that I LOVE, LOOOOVE TES games. I loved them ever since I first played Daggerfall (before all the patches that made it playable), and played Arena shortly after I finally finished Daggerfall. I have been following TES very closely from that time on. Heck, I even liked Redguard, and everyone I know tells me that game is terrible.So I was extremely excited and ordered the Imperial Edition from GMG as soon as I found a 20% off code (I had to buy two copies, so I did not want to shell out that much for an MMO with a monthly subscription fee).I have been playing this game for a while now (remember Imperial Edition gets a nice head start option), so I think I can finally give a decent and most importantly spoiler free review of this game.Early access actually started off pretty well. The character creation is great, and both my wife and I were able to create the avatars we wanted. We also quickly jumped into a friends guild - and that is where our first surprise came... EVERYONE in TESO can SEE your ACTUAL account name. In fact adding a "friend" to your list, gives you their actual account name.My account names are always weird and have nothing to do with my real name, but my wife usually uses a combination of her first, and last name. Meaning everyone and their grandmothers knew they were playing with a female. This lead to a lot of people (even those from our guild), that would start asking her where she lives, her age, and if she was hot, etc.In fact a lot of "friends" that we met in TESO had their names and year of birth as their account name, since they were not warned that this name will be so freely and publicly available. Heck, some people even had their state in there! I kid you not, one of the players I met had FirstNameLastNameStateDOB as his user name. What an epic fail in this day and age to not CLEARLY warn users about something like this.After we got out of the "newbie" areas, the game started to really lack polish. A LOT of quests were broken, requiring you to re-log and hope you get in the instance where the quest is working. The best part is that while you re-log, you can actually experience a character rollback. I completed a quest, only to re-log and find out that I never completed it. These random rollbacks had a very major impact on the game for us. We all lost money, experience, time, and most importantly LOOT and materials...Moreover, a friend that was playing with us re-logged only to be greeted by characters that were not his. He called it a night after that. The issue was fixed the next day. That's right... There was some database linking error and the poor guy literally (temporarily) lost access to HIS characters. Not a big deal, since it was only the second (or third) day of playing, but this is unacceptable.The game was taken offline for a good 10 hours (or more), and everything appeared to be fixed, however after playing for a few more hours we ran into broken quests once more, and more harassment for my wife due to her very obvious account name (that we petitioned to have changed with no response so far).While I first loved crafting in this game, it involves quite a large chunk of time AND inventory management, making it lose its charm rather quickly.Want to research and improve something? Well that will take 6, 12, 24 hours real time. You do not have to be on for this, but that is QUITE a time commitment. My biggest problem with this was when I started research on an item and logged into an alt. Came back a few hours later only to find that my crafter got rolled back and never started the research... So I started the research again and went to sleep, ONLY to log on the next day and find out that he was ONCE AGAIN rolled back to before he started the research. That was quite infuriating.Now lets move on to the inventory system... Which is downright terrible as it gives you only 60 bank slots total... That are shared across ALL your characters... 60 SHARED bank slots is a joke, since one crafter can easily fill those! Everyone in our guild is simply rolling alts as an alternative bank, and I personally have 4 characters with full inventories as my bank mules... I have people in our guild that have to use spreadsheets to keep track of who has what materials, and that is a pretty big design fail.Either give each character 60 bank slots, with 10 shared slots on top of that - or increase the shared number of slots to 120+.Speaking of crafting, most nodes in the game are guarded by NPC's, and since they are not instanced to your character - it means that other players WILL run up to the node while you are taking care of the mob and steal it, quickly running away as you finish the mob.This gets even worse in dungeons. The best loot I have seen so far is either crafted or comes from a dungeon chest (not the dungeon boss). This means that you (or your group) can be fighting said boss, and some idiot can go loot your chest... So you get NOTHING. To make things even better, if you kick said ninja looter they stay in the dungeon with you and are free to continue ninja looting... What is this? I don't even....The game is not all bad however. It does have some epic parts! You can become a vampire or werewolf, heck you can even get impregnated by a wasp and give birth to a waspling that will follow you around (and protect you), thinking you are its parent.My most "OMG" experience so far has been riding through a forest and having my horse make a nervous neigh, only to find that it was scared of a wolf that was fairly close by. That is pretty epic and really made the world feel alive.The quests and instancing also get an honorable mention. Although it is still a very theme park like game, I really enjoyed some of the voice acting and quests. The heavy instancing also makes it possible to feel like you made a real difference on the world.Moments like that aren't too common, but they add a lot of extra to the world, making it truly feel lived in.Finally lets move on the Pièce de résistance, and the reason why I am giving this game such a low score (I would actually give it one star had it not been for some awesome moments).As of right now, there are two HUGE issues in the game. Widespread duping (and it will get a lot worse when people find out how easy it is), and the client is being trusted with a LOT of things. I will not be saying exactly what, but a simple HEX EDITING program is ENOUGH to allow one to speed hack, teleport, have unlimited rolling AND dodging... Meaning PvP in this game is about to become utter garbage. The PvE is affected as well, but PvP is completely shot.Apparently ZeniMax did not learn from the folks at Cryptic after they had plenty of issues due to keeping so much clientside. Google "mmogfails" and read up on their disaster. Unless TESO acts fast, I can see the same thing happening here. Also check the comments section for more info. I can't post links in this review.I think I will give this game some time to mature, maybe a year or two, and play The Secret World and Guild Wars 2 in the meantime. Both are buy to play games, and do certain things better than TESO. The story in TSW is the best I have seen in any MMO to date, and GW2 does most other things better than TESO. As a bonus, neither game allow you to cheat and gain a huge advantage over legit players.Sorry Bethesda, it really pains to give you guys a two star review - but certain problems with the game (mostly due to poor design choices) really hinder its enjoyment for the Mitchell family. WHY... WHYYYY trust the client in this day and age?As a side note, I want to comment on how terrible ZeniMax support is (and not just because they haven't responded to my wife's account name change request after multiple days).My acquaintance (a 62+ year old retiree that I sometimes do computer work for) was BANNED from the game due to a "TOS violation". After multiple (failed) attempts at contacting support, he finally got a reply and was un-banned after an "investigation" took place...He is now literally done with the game. You lost a very big fan there, and it was all due to sloppy work. Not nice ZM/Bethesda... Not nice at all.I hope that you enjoyed my unbiased, spoiler free review of TESO. Now I would like to make a request of you, the Amazon gaming community. If you downvote my review, can you please post your reason for doing so in the comments section? I have posted nothing but our honest opinion and experience of/with the game, and would like to know why I will be getting downvoted (and I know those are coming)... Unless you work for ZeniMax damage control that is, or never bothered to read my review and are downvoting simply because of the way I scored the game. Than feel free to ignore my request.Anyway thanks for taking the time to read my rather large piece, and see you all around!4/11/2014 UPDATE: Please check the comment section. There have been some interesting developments after I published this review.4/18/2014 UPDATE: WOW, I didn't even notice that I started getting helpful votes. I really wonder how that happened. I was sure that this review would be forever buried and tagged as unhelpful.4/18/2014 UPDATE 2: Oh I see. The dupe finally got out and people started looking a bit deeper. Honestly I am surprised it took this long, since anyone messing around in the guild bank had a pretty high chance of figuring out how to do this. We discovered it by accident and made a forum post about it... Only to have it deleted. Shortly after that it was all over guild chat and people were duping Grand Soul Gems and more. I honestly thought the dupe would get out that same day, but apparently I was wrong.4/19/2014 UPDATE: Seems like ZeniMax introduced another bug into the game. This one will allow you to get unlimited mail (chests) from your hirelings. I simply don't know how to react to the way they are running things.4/19/2014 UPDATE 2: Earlier today I received an e-mail from a reader that asked to remain anonymous. This e-mail contains instructions on yet another dupe, and this one (like the original) will allow you to dupe everything. I just tested it out and can confirm it works. The author informed me that this exploit has existed since launch. I think I am going to call it quits with ESO. I don't want to reward incompetence with money, and most importantly my time. Consider this my final update to this review. I will be doing the only thing ZeniMax understands and speak with my wallet. Honestly, it seems to me as if ZeniMax is simply using the PC crowd as beta testers for their console release of the game. It is my firm belief that TESO will be buy or free to play within a year of its launch. My guess, sometime in early 2015, probably a bit before April.I would also like to make a request. For the last few days people have been sending me quite a lot of ESO bug reports and issues. I want you all to know that I have no impact on them getting fixed. Please don't e-mail me regarding this game.Edit: 5/18/2014 UPDATE: Although we no longer play The Elder Scrolls Online, I want to point out that ZeniMax DID in fact charge us both right out of the gate for an EXTRA month (on TOP of our "free" month of gametime). We were charged an extra $15 when we entered in our CD-Keys. This is unacceptable! After a few e-mails with ZM, the money was refunded back to my credit card, but that is yet another example of ZM's incompetence.Thank you for your time,- Sam

A DVD... It all started with a DVD... This DVD... Did I mention this kit comes with a DVD?After my wife bought it for me at a garage sale, I took great joy in my new (used), red, one pound ball, and super sexy (although scratched) DVD disk.Upon smoothly inserting it into the DVD player using my (soon to be acquired) epic Tai Chi skills, I cracked my back and had to call it a day.When I came to, I not only knew Tai Chi, but also Kung Fu. Next thing I know, I am honing my skills in a temple and just as I am getting good, I find out that it will soon be turned into a strip mall unless we come up with one million dollars.It's about this time that I also meet some guy (pretty convenient, eh?) that tells me I can make some nice money with my mad Tai Fu skills and we get swept away into the world of unlawful street fighting.Long story short, I woke up and put this little kit in storage. Because it really doesn't teach you anything. I mean with the instructor facing you, all the moves have to be reversed. Not too hard, but annoying. The instructor looks like he knows his stuff, but goes way too fast toward the end, and I didn't see any full forms here. Just a bunch of stuff thrown together.Contrary to my dreams, I am no Tai Chi expert, but he could have at least thrown a few short forms into the DVD, because as it is - this is simply a bunch of exercises, and nothing else.Your best bet is to either take a few classes, or get a better DVD. Try YouTube and search for "Peking form". There are much better, free videos out there, that also go into a lot more detail.

I snagged this at my local Best Buy for $450 AND got to use another deal they had to get an additional controller for 15% off.My total came out to be a few bucks more than what Amazon wanted for just this bundle. To make things sweeter, I also got an additional 1 month free of Xbox Live Gold membership, since they were giving out these cards with a physical purchase of Titanfall. I spoke to a blue shirt and he told me I can take one if I get the bundle too. Thanks Best Buy!Best Buy also has a deal on "accessories", where you get them for 15% off if you buy a game, well this comes with a game and rings up the accessory for an extra 15% off.So I bought the Titanfall Bundle + the cool Limited Edition Titanfall Wireless Controller + an extra month of XBL for a few bucks more than Amazon wanted for the base bundle. Seems brick and mortar stores are finally able to compete with Amazon!It may be worth calling your local Best Buy to see what kind of a deal you can get, since Amazon still has not bothered to price match the Walmart or Best Buy deal.Now on to the bundle - It does not come with a physical copy of the game, nor does it come with the special limited edition Titanfall painted controller. No idea why, but it comes with the standard black controller, and a code to download the game onto your Xbone.While I am still downloading Titanfall, I can already say that the new Kinect is simply awesome. I love controlling everything by simply giving it voice commands.I will update this review later with more info on the game itself, but if YouTube videos are anything to go by, I will not be disappointed...UPDATE:Amazon now has a code - "XIAMAZON", that when entered brings down the price of this bundle by $50.Way to go Amazon! I hope my review is what got you guys to do this. Probably not, but I can hope, can't I?So now Amazon is once again the top dog. Having said that, I am still happy with my Best Buy purchase because I got the additional controller I wanted, and an extra XBL card on top of that.Edit: According to the manager at my Best Buy, to qualify for the extra XBL card, I had to buy the Limited Edition controller, and the Titanfall game. Not just the game. That is why the LE controller is also 15% off when bought with Titanfall (or the bundle), and the normal controller is not. So just FYI for those interested.As a side note, the LE controller looks and feels exactly like the original Xbone controller, but the TF paint job gives it an extra OOMPH (IMHO).UPDATE 2 (4/6/2014):TARGET now has this bundle + 12 months of Xbox Live all for $449.99. Even cheaper if you have the Red Card. Refer to the link I provide in the comments section for more info (Amazon won't allow me to link to Target in the main review).Just had multiple friends order this epic deal.Comes out to just over $460 foor most people after using Red Card (free shipping too).I am uploading a screen shot of their web page for a reference point as well. Hopefully Amazon will price match.

I was going to write an actual review for this title, but I can't be bothered - it is obvious Magisoft didn't when they created this 2D running "game".There is really not much to say. You can jump to avoid hazards or attack to kill monsters. Both of these actions are done through tapping the left or right part of your screen.That's all there is to this uninspired, boring, and buggy app.The graphics are quite nice, but the sound and gameplay are pretty bland. In fact, this so called "game" seems to be mix of fantasy and crap - I call it fantacrap.In the two hours that I "played" this, if it can even be called that - the game crashed three times.
