No errors, no nothing - it just stopped responding. The controlls also leave much to be desired since there is noticeable input lag, and sometimes the touch is not registered at all.How this simple app (that looks like it was homework for a "My first Android App" class) is priced at $10, I don't even know. I think they meant $1.00, but misplaced the decimal point.This is one of the worst "runner" type games on the Adnroid, and I really have no idea why it requires the Full Network Access permission, nor why it uses bandwidth while played - being that there is literally nothing that requires this.To sum up, feel free to download it as the FAotD, but do not spend a single cent on it - the game is NOT worth it.

I got a free "sample" at GNC with a purchase of some protein.I work out quite a bit and have to simply laugh at this scam.This product will NOT do anything that it claims. At most it could possibly increase your libido, however it will NOT boost your testosterone (by much anyway). This can NOT be done through a "mineral blend". Don't fall for their lies and purchase it.Please be sure to check the comments section of this review for actual research that shows their active ingredient does not work.If you want to boost your testosterone, you need Testosterone Injections, which also have plenty of side effects.Want to boost your testosterone (by a bit) the natural way? Do this:1. Make sure you get enough Zinc.2. Get a lot of Vitamin D.3. Get rid of all processed sugar in your diet.4. Get more good fats.5. Consume more whey protein.6. Add Squats, Deadlifts, and Military Press's to your workout routine.7. Do NOT buy crap that has not been tested and has wild claims.Stay away from products such as this that are designed to prey on the gullible and uninformed.Side note: Want to build more muscle? Consider Whey and Creatine. Also add full body exercises to your routine. Take a closer look at point #6. It will show you what I mean.Update: Wow, look at that. I am getting downvoted and new 5 star reviews are popping up claiming this product works, but oddly the reviewers only have ONE review under their belt. Come on MuscleTech marketing, you guys can do better, can't you? Jeez, this is pathetic.

Before I start this review, I will say that I purchased two of these instead of PS3 controllers. Both were defective and refused to update their firmware via the app (Nyko PlayPad Firmware Updater). The second app (Nyko Playground BETA) had issues detecting Amazon versions of their supported apps (or told me there was an issue pairing the controllers). The Google Play versions of said games worked, but a few supported titles purchased from Amazon did not!Now lets get into the review.I bought two of these to use with FPse and some games. I mostly wanted to replay my legally owned Final Fantasy games in all their PSX glory - boy was I in for a disappointment. On the first controller, one of the sticks kept getting stuck in random positions, causing my characters to keep running around. On the other, the side buttons (BOTH OF THEM) would get stuck and get me into an infinite menu loop.Really Nyko? What the heck are you doing with these controllers? Do you not care about your own reputation anymore?Moreover doing a Google search reveals this to be a COMMON problem!Let's move onto some more issues. FPse would not detect the dual sticks as separate entities until I updated the firmware, which was impossible as the app fails to do so (for both controllers, on the Nexus 4, 5 AND a Samsung Blaze).I tried playing some Sonic games, and while the ones I purchased from the Play Store worked, the one I got from Amazon DID NOT.All in all, these controllers are downright horrible. They have issues with buttons sticking after being pressed, and the Android apps that are meant to enhance them do not work!Maybe if I got a fully working one, I would write a different review - BUT out of the two I bought, BOTH HAD multiple issues. This is simply ridiculous in this day and age.Please take a look at my pictures for more info (either in the comments section or via Amazon's customer images).At the moment, I bought some PS3 controllers from Target (they were cheaper than these buggy jokes), and am using those instead - they work like a CHARM with my PSX (and all Android) games.So my advice is to stay away, FAR away from these so called "Pro" pads.Even at $19.99 the Nyko Playpad Pro is not worth it.If you root your phone, you can use the regular PS3 controller, which is of much better build quality, and is currently on clearance for $15 at my local Target.

EDIT: Updated and re-written on 4/1/2014 after some more compatibility and performance issues have been resolved.Ron Gilbert is a great designer and after hearing that he will be releasing a new adventure game, I went a little nuts. I mean after such great titles as Maniac Mansion, Day of the Tentacle, and the Monkey Island games (not even going to mention his non adventure games), I had VERY high expectations. I actually bought this game on Steam and for Android as soon as they became available.First of all let me get all this crash talk out of the way. They have obviously been making progress from when the game launched, but there are still issues.It runs flawlessly on my Nexus 5 and my wife's Nexus 4. I went through the game thrice on my Nexus 5 (with one crash), and my wife ran through it once on her Nexus 4 (with no issues). HOWEVER it does crash (is unplayable) on my friends Galaxy S3, and LG G2. No idea what the cause of this strange behavior is. After he rooted his S3, and installed a custom ROM (Cyanogenmod) - it worked fine. He does not want to root the G2, so I have no idea if it would work on that (while rooted).If the game is crashing for you, maybe try updating your version of Android (OS), or if you are at all tech savvy, root your phone and install a custom ROM (WARNING this will void your warranty and may brick/break your phone).Finally when you download the game from here, open it and let it run for a while - as it needs to download some more files and update. It may look like it's not responding, but it's actually downloading some data.With that out of the way, lets get on to the game.I will TRY to make this as spoiler free as possible, and I ask that you keep it spoiler free in the comments section as well.The Cave has a vast and varied cast of characters (7 to be exact), each having their own unique ability that will come in super handy when trying to solve puzzles. You form a party of three of these and head into *ominous voice* THEEE CAAAAAAVVEEE.While inside you solve various puzzles and interact with the denizens that thrive within. Using your character's unique abilities you get access to areas that others can't reach, so in order to get the full story you will need to beat the game 3 times. Don't worry, puzzles can be solved in different ways and every character has unique areas, which cuts down on the tedium.The game is also fairly short, clocking in at about 2-3 hours per playthrough, but much shorter your last time through. All in all I finished the whole thing in about 8 hours.Both the graphics and sound are excellent, with crisp visuals and some memorable tunes (and sound effects) throughout.Special mention goes to voice acting, with some very familiar voices that gamers will surely recognize.Another mention goes to the touch controls (that take a while getting used to, but are quite good after the initial hassle). This game proves that adventure games benefit greatly from the touch screen. Really, being able to play the game with such ease is pretty amazing. I thought I would miss the mouse, but I do not.See something? Simply touch it! That's all there is to the controls! Great job Double Fine!My only complaint (other than crashing on some systems) is that the areas you explore seem underpopulated, and the lack of tough puzzles (and puzzles in general) is a downer. I expected a bit more from Ron.My minor gripe is that once again there are unnecessary permissions (for a single player game) in the form of:Open network sockets, Access information about Wi-Fi networks, and Access information about networks. But that is most likely for the following reason: Allows verification of Google app Entitlements.Still, no IAP or extremely dangerous permissions (and classic gameplay) prevent me from giving it anything but an almost perfect score.Simply put this is (currently) one of the best adventure games on the Android platform, and well worth the $4.99 asking price.If it did not crash so much on different Android hardware, I would make it a 5 star game - that said, my friend managed to get a REFUND from Amazon after proving that it kept constantly crashing on his G2 and Galaxy S3, AND he got to keep the game to boot.

This thing is simply great, but is geared more for the outdoorsman than a regular person.Why you would want to use this over a regular charger I will never know, but unless you want to bring a giant battery/generator with you on your fishing/hiking/biking/camping trips, this will do the job - and do it well (although a bit slow).I have used it multiple times while on my combination fishing/camping trip, and it does not disappoint.I put the solar charger on the top of the tent in the morning, with the battery out of direct sunlight - and leave for 5-6 hours. When I come back with my drained phone or GPS, this will charge it up over the next few hours.The charge is slow, yes I said hours - but this entire package (battery and solar panel) is so light that adding it to your gear is incredibly simple. No heavy batteries for me thank you, and at its current sale price - it's a steal.I actually ordered another one today so that I can have two of them going at once for a longer charge.Now a bit of a warning. This package weirdly does not come with any sort of carry case, which is an annoyance. The solar panel also does not do well when not in direct sunlight. I took it biking once through a wooded area and after a 4 hour trek it was enough to charge my phone to a whopping 27% (from 9%). However when we reached our destination, I quickly placed it on a sunny table and the problem resolved itself.However for the current price ($22) this is the BEST SOLAR CHARGER available on Amazon, and I tried them all (well, OK - I tried some of them). I paid $87 for it the first time around, and even at that price this thing is great for those of us that like to enjoy the outdoors!Side note:You can really use the solar panel to charge any battery with the proper USB connection, or even use it to charge your item directly (although then you can run the risk of overheating).Also for those that want this kit just to charge their home devices while at home - stay away. It is not worth it (well maybe it is at its current price). Without direct sunlight, the solar panel is kind of a dud.

Words can't even describe how disappointed I am in this "game". Having played the original Google Play version a while back, I was happy to see a "Full" version as Amazon's FAOTD (since the free version had a lot of forced IAP)... Too bad this IS the same exact version, but for some reason it actually costs money to download on Amazon.Why Anger B.C. TD Full is pure garbage:- The game is available for free on the Google Play Store.- FORCED IAP in a "PAID" game.- You are limited to one hero, if you want the other two they cost real money.- Certain towers can ONLY be bought for real money.- Consumables that are required to finish a level must also be bough for real money.- Extra levels cost money. Only the firs FIVE levels are included in the "full" game. The rest have to be bought for real money.- Overly difficult to force IAP. Anyone see a pattern here?But wait, that was just about the ridiculous amount of IAP. There's more:- Anger B.C. has terribad Engrish spelling and grammar. Quotes like "Different kind of soldier and turret, they have different way to go up" are fairly common.- The gameplay is very grindy and monotonous. This is true of a lot of tower defense games, but Anger B.C. doesn't even try to do anything to switch it up like most TD games.- HORRIBLE rate begging. Unless you agree to rate the game, a screen asking you to do so will pop up EVERY time you launch the game.- Stability issues on the Galaxy S III and the Blaze. Stock firmware caused crashes on both systems after prolonged gameplay.- Poor tutorial with no explanation of anything.- Annoying pan/zoom feature.- I could go on an on, but it's just easier for me to list the things I liked, which is actually nothing...How garbage like this made it into the Amazon Android marketplace is a mystery.This app is a complete waste of Amazons great Free App of the Day, and has absolutely nothing going for it. Don't even bother downloading this junker.Update: Anger B.C. TD Full is now priced at $0.00 and no longer at $.99 cents. Even free the app is simply too limited. There are a lot of better freemium TD games out there.

I was really excited for this game, especially after watching a few of the videos that I will post in the comment section (Amazon doesn't allow linking to other sites in their reviews). I went so far as to pre-order the game on Steam and now wish I could get a refund.The ONLY good thing about this game is that the whole thing can be beaten in under 5 hours (less if not for the bugs). According to Steam, I played this game for 7 hours so far and have had 4 crashes, as well as encountering literally countless bugs, the best of which was doors NOT OPENING, or getting STUCK in the environment - forcing me to reload multiple times... Yeah. No idea how this made it past quality assurance... Way to go Gearbox, way to go.But honestly, the bugs aren't even the worst part. What makes this game so terribly boring is that it feels like an on rails light gun game, with terrible and uninteresting level design (there are some exceptions to this). Why an Aliens game has such limiting environments is beyond my understanding. Invisible walls and missing textures also serve to bring down the little immersion that some of the better designed areas bring to the table.The enemy AI is absolute garbage and allows you to easily blast one Xeno after another as they calmly walk in front of your shotgun (or get glitched in the environment and just stand there). Getting hit in ACM by an alien is virtually impossible.Eventually you also get to fight some humans, but nothing changes. You can still Rambo your way through everything using your trusty shotgun with what feels like unlimited ammunition and pinpoint precision.Next up is the AI of your squad mates, and wow... It is not uncommon to see someone glitched in the environment or running around in circles during a firefight. You simply can't make stuff like this up!All in all this game has the absolutely worst AI I have seen in recent releases, which is even more disappointing seeing as how Gearbox promised us "incredibly advanced AI".Gameplay doesn't fare any better. At one point you are forced into a stealth level and a few Work Loader sequences. That's it. And they are all as bad as the rest of the game. There is NOTHING new or even marginally exciting in Aliens: Colonial Marines. In fact, it makes the disaster that was Duke Nukem Forever seem like a masterpiece. I also don't understand what happened to ACM's graphics and animations. A few of the older demo videos of "actual gameplay" that Gearbox was showing off look much better than the retail game does on my (almost) top of the line gaming machine. Even on the highest settings this game looks like Doom 3, which looked good when it came out years ago - but has not aged too well in the graphic department. For some reason ACM also animates much worse than D3 - the animations seem stiff and forced.Even if I could forgive all of the above, the story is terrible (even more so considering that this is supposed to be the sequel to the films), complete with COUNTLESS plot holes, and "WTH" moments. Without giving anything away, dead characters are brought back to life with no explanation, and areas that have been nuked are now back in perfectly serviceable conditions (once again with no explanation).I suggest that you stay away unless you can get the game for around $10, since in its current state that is all ACM is honestly worth.I am currently working with Steam to try and get my money back due to all the false advertising Gearbox did before the game released (links in the comments section). Hopefully they will honor my request like they did with The War Z.

The premise is simple. This is yet another get object X to point Y in the least amount of time possible game. This time it involves a tractor, a rock (gold) and a truck.Honestly it seems like somebody's rushed Java assignment than an actual game. Using your tractor (yes, the game spells tractor as traktor, go figure) you need to move a tiny stone into the back of a truck. There are usually objects in the way that also need to be moved. That's it. That's the WHOLE game!The tractor controls are overly sensitive and it moves as well as animates poorly. You can literally drive on air...After the first twelve missions I was utterly bored. Honestly it is just repeating the same thing over and over, with very little variation. To make matters worse, there is no actual digging involved - you just clear rubble away from your chunk of gold and move that gold rock to the truck. If that sounds interesting, by all means go ahead and try it out.The only good thing I can say about Traktor Digger is its lack of dangerous permissions. Other than that, it's a stinker and should be passed on. Too bad, since the concept is good, and if the developers actually tried - it could have been interesting. As it is, I don't recommend that you buy this game. Go ahead and download it as today's free app of the day, but prepare to be bored...

Disclaimer: I received this book from the author for reviewing purposes, however if you check my other reviews it should be clear that I am always brutally honest and often (overly) opinionated.With hat out of the way, lets move on.I really enjoyed Rhyme Time, especially the hand drawn art style that is used throughout this book. Something about the overly exaggerated facial features (especially the eyes and nose) made the characters stand out a bit more than they would have otherwise.I also thought the few jokes that were thrown in were above average and made me smirk on more than one occasion, however my amusement was cut short before it even really started due the book's length. There are only a few dozen drawings and sometimes they are reused.The story itself is fairly bland, but that can be forgiven since everything is written with rhyming in mind (more often than not). Without giving too much away, this book sets the stage for three shopkeepers taking on the mob. When I say sets the stage, this is literally all it does. It brings our three heroes together and leaves ALL conflict unresolved. I was expecting at least a few questions to be answered, but got nothing.If Rhyme Time cost only $.99, I would happily give it a four star rating and recommend a purchase - as it is the length really drags the whole package down. While I still think it's worth the current $1.99 asking price, I really wish it was quite a bit longer (or cheaper).I think Rory Scherer is on to something here, it just needs a bit more polish (and a few dozen more pages).

I don't understand why there is so much hate for this game. My almost five old daughter absolutely loves it on her little Atom powered netbook.The graphics (and sound) are cute, and the gameplay is easy enough to grasp. Honestly for adults there is probably nothing here, but children will be enthralled by this overly simplistic strategy title. There are things to build, items to gather, and monsters to fight. Anything that gets a thumbs up from my daughter, also gets a thumbs up from me.Now while I don't think it's worth the full $6.99 asking price, it's certainly a good enough deal for free (or even $.99 cents).I don't know how long the SQRLUVIO will work, so hopefully you manage to snag King's Legacy as a free download. Otherwise hold off until it gets to the $.99 price point.Side note: There are a few reviews that say you can't proceed past level three, that is false as my girl is already on the fourth level. Really, if a five year old can figure it out - an adult gamer should as well.

WOWZA, thank you Amazon and Square Enix for offering us this truly great value. Each one of these games is well worth the $9.99 asking price, but combined this pack is an EPIC value.The best part is that while this pack is out of stock, you can use the attached code (SQRLUVIO) to get any game priced at $2 or less completely free!I snagged my daughter a copy of King's Legacy [Download] and she loves it! There are a few other "free" games out there, but that one was cute (and easy) enough for her to get instantly addicted.Every one, yes EVERY one of these games can also be activated on Steam, and you get separate keys to trade away the games that you already own. Have fun and good luck trying to snag this pack!

Glad to see that Amazon actually screens our reviews and the last game "Big Brain Quiz GOLD" was replaced by something that is actually, well, good.Barnyard Mahjong HD is a pretty solid mahjong solitaire (tile matching) game with a lot of bells and whistles. While it's obviously designed for a much younger audience (the sounds and music are all kid friendly, but not annoying), I had quite a bit of fun with it.I still dislike that there are network permissions, but all things considered - the one permission that is involved here isn't too bad (unless combined with other permissions), and I have not encountered major internet traffic from it (just a few KB - that's normal). MUCH better than the previous FAOTD.The Good:- Good graphics for a mahjong game. Everything is bright and cheery. Very kid friendly.- Fun music and sound effects. Once again, everything is a bit over the top but that is to be expected from a family friendly game.- The puzzles actually change (tile wise) if you restart a level! This is very important as it contributes to the already high replay value of mahjong solitaire.- A save feature is implemented, so you can resume where you left off.- LOTS of levels. There are over 160 of them, and since the tiles change locations each playthrough - well, this will last you a while.- Is still mahjong solitaire, so it is easy to like if you enjoy these types of games.- You can zoom in and out. I honestly wish every mahjong game had this feature.The Bad:- Permissions. The Open network sockets permission is still something to think about as it allows this app free range internet access, and is simply not needed in a single player game.- Social Media integration. - Gah, enough said. I really don't like Facebook or Twitter in my games.- You can buy more games from the developer by following a link on the main screen.- A lot of questionable positive reviews from people with only one or two other reviews under their belt.The Ugly:- I found nothing truly ugly in this game.Scores:Game - 4/5Permissions - 3/5Combined - 4/5. I had fun with this game and so did my daughter.Conclusion:If you are into mahjong solitaire games, you should just instantly download Barnyard Mahjong HD as today's FAOTD. Even priced at $.99, it is still a good deal!

Big Brain Quiz GOLD is actually an above average quiz game, the point of which is to play through five rounds while picking one of three categories. There seem to be plenty of topics, and the UI is very appealing, however all of that is utterly destroyed by the incredibly malicious permissions, constant data access, and an incredibly high price.Kindle users should also be aware that this app does use Amazon's GameCircle.The Good:- Lots of questions and categories - this really is a must for trivia games, and Big Brain does not disappoint.- Nice, clean UI - You can even pick the style you want!- Good sound effects - although there is no music, the effects don't annoy or get in the way (as they do with a lot of quiz games). There is nothing overly wonky here to distract you from answering questions.The Bad:- The ability to purchase more games from the main menu (this is becoming a staple in Android apps).- Annoying fact tidbits that can't be disabled - every time you answer a question, you get a little tidbit of information  accompanying it, even if you answered correctly. All it does is add another button you have to press between every question.- Overpriced at $5.99.The Ugly:- NASTY Permissions (explained below):-- Read only access to phone state - This permission gives an application access to the IMEI, IMSI, and your phone number (as well as incoming and outgoing calls). So think of it as a massive tracking cookie that keeps tabs on everything you do, and that you had no choice in installing.Many software developers use this permission to track purchases and piracy. However the potential for disaster is huge here. A lot of companies will pay good money to get the information above, and once that falls into their hands...-- com.android.vending.BILLING - For easy billing, etc. Usually included for IAP.--- Open network sockets - This permission gives an application free range Internet access.-- Access information about networks - This permissions "informs" the device on what kind of networks you are running.-- Access the list of accounts in the Accounts Service. - Allows access to a list of ALL accounts in the Accounts Service.I have NO idea why all these permissions are required in a single player game, this is simply ridiculous, but that's not even the best part. It gets better you say? Why yes it does:- Constant stream of data while you play. The longer you play, the higher this goes. I wonder why... Check out the uploaded image and see for yourself.Scores:App is a 3/5.Permissions are a flat out 0/5.Combined score: 1/5.Conclusion:If not for the nasty permissions and constant stream of data that this app is guilty of, I would have given it a solid three stars. If you play on a rooted device with proper protection this really won't bother you much and you should download it as today's FAOTD.I do not suggest you purchase it for the full asking price, nor do I suggest that you use it on an unprotected device.

Wacky Sound Effects is a simple soundboard that for some reason requires a lot of nasty permissions. The UI is pretty sloppy, and so is the sound quality. Homer Simpson's "Who Hoo" (and many others) actually have staticy crinkling noises in the background.There is nothing here that you can't find online (for free and with better quality to boot) and charging for such a limited soundboard is obscene.The Good:- I found nothing good about this app.The Bad:- The UI is terrible, presented as a scrolling list of sound effects by letter.- Low quality sound recordings. The effects seem to (mostly) be pulled from the internet. This alone renders this soundboard worthless.- Trying to charge for what is available for free elsewhere. There are countless better (and free) soundboards for you to play with.- Fake five star reviews.- Lots of unnecessary permissions (explained below).The Ugly:- Permissions explained:  - Read only access to phone state - This permission gives an application access to the IMEI, IMSI, and your phone number (as well as incoming and outgoing calls). So think of it as a massive tracking cookie that keeps tabs on everything you do, and that you had no choice in installing.Many software developers use this permission to track purchases and piracy. However the potential for disaster is huge here. A lot of companies will pay good money to get the information above, and once that falls into their hands...  - System tools - Modify global system settings - This permission allows Wacky Sound Effects to mess around with anything and everything that you can if you were to go rampart in your "Settings" menu. Some scary stuff there.Scores:App is a 1/5.Permissions are a 1/5.Combined score: 1/5.If you really want a soundboard, then Wacky Sound Effects is worth it as today's free download. I would stay away as there are many other better quality (and free) soundboards out there.

My time with Dante: The Inferno was both pleasant and frustrating. This is the only game that I have played so far that made me both like and hate it.I liked the graphics and sound, but HATED the controls. I liked the fact that there are no permissions, but hated the CONSTANT rate begging. I really liked the level design, but hated the lame attempt at the story (and the fact that you can't just turn it off).With that little rant out of the way, lets move on to the review:The Good:- Pleasing, yet simple graphics. Just take a look at some of the screenshots, the game looks great.- Addicting top down puzzler game play, with some BRUTALLY difficult levels.- Good music/sound and effects.- NO PERMISSIONS (at the time of this review).- Great level design (although a bit repetitive in places).- Achievements.The Bad:- Constant rate begging. Every few levels a pop up will ask you to rate this app. There is no "no" option, just "Yes" or "Later".- Lame story with no way to turn it off. You can chose to skip the text on a PER LEVEL basis. Sure would be nice to have an option to disable this drivel.The Ugly:- Terrible, jerky controls that almost ruin the game. Yes, they really are that bad. It actually seems like the game is lagging and I found out that it is much easier to quickly tap them than count on the darn things working properly as you glide across them.Score:Game: 3/5 (if the controls are fixed and the rate begging removed, I will bump it up to a 5).Permissions: 5/5Combined: 3/5 (I am going to dock an extra star for the terribad controls, I even made up a new word to describe just how terribly bad they are).Conclusion:I liked Dante: The Inferno more often than not, and although there are a lot of infuriating issues here (most of which can be fixed by smoothing out the controls), I enjoyed his trip through hell.I highly recommend this game as today's FAOTD, however I honestly don't suggest that you spend any money on it until the controls are improved. There were countless times when I failed JUST because they did not respond properly.It is beyond infuriating, and the checkpoint system that is in place is no substitute for properly working controls.

I liked Alphabet Car, in fact if it wasn't for the issues that I will mention below, I would have given this app a four star rating. As it is, I am honestly worried about letting my daughter play around with it.The object of this game is to drive down the road and pick up letters to spell the required words. There are multiple difficulty levels, each increasing the word length by one letter (starting with the Beginner and Preschool 3 letter word category).The tilt and touch controls are spot on and music/sound are all of appropriate cuteness. The graphics (although repetitive) are also fairly nice looking. Every three levels you clear, you get to unlock a new car and ARE TOLD to rate this game... EVERY THREE LEVELS. It just doesn't stop (images uploaded with review).Then there are the incredibly nasty permissions, including "read only access to phone state", which combined with the included network permission makes this app incredibly dangerous. I also don't know why this game causes so much IP traffic (image uploaded with review).The Good:- Bright, flashy, and kid friendly graphics. You can customize your bus with different color combinations and the environments look good (if not a bit repetitive).- Great sound effects, voice, and music. Everything sounds exactly like a learning game should. I also like how the words are pronounced.- Large word selection (but there are still plenty of repeats through the levels on the same difficulty).- Easy to learn controls. You can mess around with speed by moving the clutch up/down, and the tile controls are very responsive.The Bad:- Repetitive game play. Literally the only input you have (other than increasing/decreasing speed) is moving the android device from side to side while the same "road" backgrounds loop and repeat on your screen. A little more variety would have gone a LOOONG way here.- Multiple other links that allow web access built into the app.- Got stuck on the "animoca" loading blue screen and had to be restarted.- Rate begging. Every three levels you clear, Alphabet Car asks you to rate it on Amazon. This is incredibly annoying (image uploaded).- There are links to buy the sequel right there on the front page. Shameful to have it in a kid's game!The Ugly:- Read only access to phone state - This permission gives an application access to the IMEI, IMSI, and your phone number (as well as incoming and outgoing calls). So think of it as a massive tracking cookie that keeps tabs on everything you do, and that you had no choice in installing.Many software developers use this permissionsto track purchases and piracy. However the potential for disaster is huge here. A lot of companies will pay good money to get the information above, and once that falls into their hands...- Open network sockets - This permission gives an application free range Internet access.I still can't understand why this and the above permissions are included in a SINGLE PLAYER game.- Access information about networks - This permissions "informs" the device on what kind of networks you are running.- There is internet traffic to and from the Android device while the game is played (image uploaded with review)!- No Eula is provided. What is done with the data that is obviously collected?Scores:Game is a 4/5.Permissions are a 1/5.Combined score: 2.5/5, since Amazon doesn't allow .5 star ratings, I am making a call here and rating the app 2/5. If you are not worried about your data, or play on a rooted device - feel free to use my "Game" score as a final score.Alphabet Car is worth it as a free download - as long as you have a rooted device with ad/tracking block software installed, or plan on using it in Airplane mode. I am personally removing this app from my phone and leaving it on my daughters rooted + firewalled tablet.I would NOT pay for this game until the "device state" permission is removed.

If you check out some of my other reviews it will be easy to see that I am not a fan of Lenovo. Out of all the companies I have dealt with, they are probably the worst - as their underhanded business practices (using poor re-branded GPU's, subpar parts, etc), and poor customer service combine to create a perfect storm of mediocrity.The sad thing is, I used to be a huge Lenovo supporter (thanks to their excellent ThinkPad line), but just got let down a few too many times with all their other products.Contrary to my warnings against doing so, a friend recently purchased this Y480 model. After playing with it for just a few hours, he was at my doorstep and asking for help. We ended up returning this product and I will go on to explain why in this review.My biggest issue with this heap is that the so called GT640M LE in this laptop is a re-branded (and under-clocked) GT 550M (image uploaded with review). Its actual performance is WORSE than that of a 550M in my wife's much older Acer (with a slightly weaker CPU to boot). Almost 4% worse according to 3D Mark.However the best part of this wonderful GPU is that it overheats and throws up tons of artifacts on newer games such as Guild Wars 2, Planetside 2, The Secret World, and even Tera Online! These artifacts persist for a few minutes before going away while the fan kicks into overdrive and your system sounds like a jet engine.Sound popping is once again back in this model, just like with previous IdeaPads. Every so often while gaming it makes a snap crackle and pop sound. Very distracting, and I am sad to see that this is still a problem (I had it happen with a previous IdeaPad purchased years ago).Contacting Lenovo support, we were told that the Y480 has no known sound static problems, and the GT640M LE is actually the 384 shader version. I offered to provide the tech with a screenshot stating the opposite and was told that screenshots could be faked... Yeah, amazing support. The tech suggested that we send in the laptop for repair and told us that not only would we have to pay for shipping, but if they found nothing wrong - we would be charged a service fee.Below is my standard Good, Bad and Ugly review.The Good:- The third gen I5 in this laptop is fairly powerful.- Keyboard has a nice feel to it.- Good wireless card.The Bad:- Sound device issues. The random static like pops are enough to drive you insane while gaming.- Terrible 1366 x 768 resolution. Not that the GPU can handle even that on lower settings (in modern games).- Slow 5400RPM Hard Drive, that for some reason is also very loud.- Less than 1 hour of gaming time, and about 3 hours of YouTube browsing.- Horrible touchpad that had issues properly detecting clicks.The Ugly:- Old GT 550M re-labeled and sold as a 640M LE. This is done by NVIDIA but Lenovo is one of the very few laptop manufacturers that use the (MUCH CHEAPER) 96 shader version. The real 640M LE is supposed to have 384 shaders (and I have mine running at 850 MHZ without a problem - in another laptop that is).- Comes loaded with a loads of trash. Anything that includes McAfee Internet Security should be destroyed.Conclusion:If you want to deal with terrible customer service and sub-par hardware, by all means purchase this overpriced hunk of junk. I would stay away, far away. For just a hundred dollars more you can get a nice Sony, Acer Timeline or Toshiba laptop or ultrabook.

I don't understand the point of DREAM-e: Exploratory Dream Analysis and Interpretation. It's some sort of incredibly lame dream journal that allows you to chat with the "AI", and by chat I mean answer boring questions that repeat themselves over and over. It doesn't save you time, and it's certainly not interesting reading long winded replies.Trying to interpret a simple dream of my dead army buddy sitting with me by a lake took forever, and didn't even give me a decent result. Googling it yielded a much more satisfying answer, and it was accomplished in MINUTES. I also didn't have to answer the same question OVER AND OVER AND OVER (or pick the color my dead friend reminds me of).As it stands, I like nothing about this app. If it at least saved you time, I would understand its purpose - but it doesn't.I also can't fathom why this text simulator requires the open network sockets permission. This single permission allows DREAM-e complete internet access.The Good:- You can skip through a lot of questions by leaving your answer blank. The AI will just keep going and spouting off its drivel.The Bad:- Fake reviews. This is quickly becoming an Amazon staple. Too bad they are incredibly easy to spot.- Overly repetitive and tedious. Answering the same question 10 times and then deciding what color it should be is utterly pointless. What does it have to do with interpreting dreams? What about those people that dream in black and white?- Priced at $1.99? What makes this app worth more than 2X the price of other apps? In this reviewers opinion - NOTHING.- Doesn't even keep track of your "analyzed" dreams if you exit halfway through the long process. This means that you will have to start over.- I could list countless other things that I don't like about this app, but considering that I find nothing here that I actually enjoyed, it would be easier (and better for my sanity) to stop now.The Ugly:- Open network sockets in a text simulator? What for?- Privacy policy that states all our data is stored locally? Well why the network permission?- At the end of the app you can request "expert" interpretation of your dream (that's right, you can actually send all your private, personal data over to the creators of DREAM-e for "expert" interpretation).Scores:APP: 1/5Permissions: 2/5 (this thing does not need internet access).Final score: 1/5.Conclusion: DREAM-e: Exploratory Dream Analysis and Interpretation is a terrible app and a complete waste of Amazon's FAOTD. I will go as far as saying that this is the worst app I have ever tried out, and certainly one of the most pointless. I see nothing that this thing does that Google can't do better and faster.I have already removed DREAM-e from my device and suggest that you stay away from it as today's freeby. Obviously you should also not buy it at the ridiculously high (for Android software) $1.99 price point.

Critter Escape is an excellent game, the object of which is to reach the level's exit while trying to complete your other objectives - such as rescuing critters, beating up guards, or not being seen (among others). There are plenty of power ups (ghost, speed, mutation, etc) to help you escape the 100+ included levels.What I like most about this app is how it encourages you to think outside the box, and in no time my daughter was trapping guards in environmental hazards that were designed to slow down the player. I really enjoyed doing this as well and it was nice to see my little girl being able to pick up and play this without any issues.Since Critter Escape doesn't feature any nasty permissions, I really don't understand why there is Privacy Policy so prominently displayed on Amazon's web page. I monitored this apps traffic on two devices for about 30 minutes and saw nothing (obviously, because the permissions aren't there), so I don't really see the need for that policy unless they plan on adding network permissions into the game at a later point.At the time of this review, there is no IAP, no nasty permissions, and no bloatware installed with the app.The Good:- Excellent graphics. Critter Escape really takes advantage of your devices hardware.- Good sound and effects. Nothing much to be said about this, the music is good and the effects are downright awesome.- Phenomenal animations. Almost everything is animated well, down to your critter looking down and sighing when you chose to redo a previously completed level. Little touches like this add a lot to the game. My only complaint is that I wish the game took your outfit into account when you are done with the level.- Lots of ways to customize your critter. You can get many outfits (15) to play around with. I prefer the Mr. Peanut look.- Good level and environment designs. Just when I was getting bored of something, it was switched out in favor of something different.The Bad:- Controls. You have two options, but really can only use one if you play on a smaller screen. I found them to be somewhat frustrating and didn't like restarting a level because my directions weren't followed. When you start dealing with environmental hazards, the controls are simply not precise enough for bigger fingers.- Pathfinding. Aaah, the other issue that caused me some minor grief. It is ridiculous to draw out an almost perfect path only to have your creature (and his escorts) die because they got stuck on a corner RIGHT by the level exit.The Ugly:- Nothing really, Critter Escape doesn't have anything that I could classify as ugly.The Score:Game: 4/5Permissions: 5/5Combined: 5/5. Since Amazon doesn't let us give .5 ratings, I am bumping it up to a perfect score because I thoroughly enjoyed my time with the game.Conclusion:Kiz Studios should be commended for designing such a great game, and praised for not using any unnecessary permissions or bloatware. Good job guys, I am really looking forward to more apps from you.I can't recommend this game enough as today's FAOTD, and even at the $.99 price point. Critter Escape is fun, and addicting (if not a bit repetitive), and if it wasn't for the sometimes buggy controls and pathfinding, it would be one of the better games on the Android OS.

Kids Word World - My First Words: Animal (Ad-Free) is an incredibly shoddy product. It tries to (blatantly and unsuccessfully) rip off "My First Words" (down to the STYLE!), and fails in every aspect.Not only does this game feature words that are far too complicated for children, it also has words that are simply misspelled. If that wasn't frustrating enough, the controls are also terrible and spelling out some of the words becomes an incredible hassle.The Good:- Nice, pretty pictures.- Lack of dangerous permissions.The Bad:- EVERYTHING else. Literally, there are only two things I liked about this application.- Misspelled words. I mean seriously, who writes sentences such as: "There is no gray letters in right order, but when you drop a letter in the right place, it will be stick here otherwise it will not."Also, what the hell is a "chimpance"? What a mess...- Terrible controls. Getting the letters to properly line up (especially on the bigger words) is a major pain. Hell, even grabbing them can be frustrating because it doesn't always register your touch!- Hung three times on two different devices in just minutes of play.- Skewed up difficulty. How is "Flowerpecker Bird" an easy word, that is grouped with other words like "Ox", and "Fox", and "Dog".- No undo button, and sometimes the incorrect letters "stick", forcing you to back out (of the game) or move on to the next word...- I could list dozens of other problems, but I really don't want to bother - it is OBVIOUS the developer didn't and just wanted to make a quick buck.The Ugly:- There is nothing too terrible in this game, most of it just falls in the "Bad" category.Score:Game: 1/5Permissions 5/5Combined score: I REFUSE to use lack of dangerous permissions to bring up the score of such a terrible app. I am making a judgement call here and giving it 1 star. Honestly, I am still being too generous.Conclusion: Unless you want your child to learn how to spell words... INCORRECTLY, you will stay away from this junker of a product.

I know I will be getting a lot of downvotes and hate for this, but I don't write reviews to be popular. I do it to help people; and having developed a few apps myself, I think I know a little bit about the Android OS.For those of us with a rooted device, spotting apps that try to suck up our bandwidth is easy, not so much for the rest of Android users.I suggest that people without a rooted device download a little tool called 3G Watchdog (I actually encourage you buy the Pro version). It is a fairly good network monitoring tool (as good as you can get without a rooted device). Establish a baseline and then open Pick a Piggy. Now let it run for a bit while playing. All that "up" and "down" data that you are seeing is the game communicating with a server, and combined with the ridiculous permission the game requires - well, play at your own risk.I gave this app to my daughter on a rooted tablet and have no issues with it. The game IS fun and since my firewall is blocking all traffic, nothing can be done with my data.With that out of the way, lets move on to the actual review.Pick a Piggy is a pretty good puzzler that has you fling Pong the Pig across a hundred levels while collecting stars. Eventually you encounter electric gates that must be disabled, blocks to break through, and other hazards designed to slow you down. To balance this out there a few power ups and abilities that help Pong along.The game's presentation is marvelous, with great hand drawn graphics, a fun soundtrack, and excellent effects. Even though the app is obviously targeting children, I found it quite fun. If it was not for the ridiculous permissions, rate begging, and a stream of data while I played this game, I would have rated it much higher.The Good:- Addicting gameplay. While the objective may be simple, there are a lot of things that make each level fun.- Awesome graphics. The hand drawn backgrounds and animation really make this game stand out above the competition.- Great music and effects. Peppy and upbeat all around.- A lot of levels. A LOT of them, you will be playing this game for a while.- Good physics. Not overly wonky and bouncy (like in some other games).- Almost perfect control. I had no issue at all making "difficult" shots. Sometimes it did release before I wanted to, but that happens in even the best games.- You are only ranked on the stars you collect, so you are free to take your time and experience Pong's many "death" animations.The Bad:- No multiplayer of any kind. The permissions make this seem like a multiplayer game, but it's not.- It asked me to rate it while I was playing. Oh well, at least it didn't ask me to buy more games from the developer.The Ugly:- Read only access to phone state - This permission gives an application access to the IMEI, IMSI, and your phone number (as well as incoming and outgoing calls). So think of it as a massive tracking cookie that keeps tabs on everything you do, and that you had no choice in installing.Many software developers use this permissionsto track purchases and piracy. However the potential for disaster is huge here. A lot of companies will pay good money to get the information above, and once that falls into their hands...- Open network sockets - This permission gives an application free range Internet access.I still can't understand why this and the above permissions are included in a SINGLE PLAYER game.- Access information about networks - This permissions "informs" the device on what kind of networks you are running.- There is internet traffic to and from the Android device while the game is played!- No Eula is provided. What is done with the data that is obviously collected?Scores:Game is a 4/5.Permissions are a 1/5.Combined score: 2.5/5, since Amazon doesn't allow .5 star ratings, and I did enjoy the game - I am making a call here and rating the game 3/5. If you are not worried about your data, or play on a rooted device - feel free to use my "Game" score as a final score.Pick a Piggy is worth it as a free download - as long as you have a rooted device with ad/tracking block software installed, or plan on using it in Airplane mode. I am personally removing this app from my phone and leaving it on my daughters rooted + firewalled tablet.I would personally not pay for this game until the "device state" permission is removed.Hopefully you guys manage to find my review under what no doubt will be a lot of negative votes and hateful remarks with "professionals" telling me that I know nothing about permissions and am just paranoid. I simply suggest you do your own research on the "phone state" permission.

I actually had fun playing Quiet, Please!, even though it is obviously targeting a much younger audience. At heart, it is a very basic adventure game that has you complete tasks all around the house to quite things down so that you can relax.The puzzles all (thankfully) make sense and there are plenty of things to explore and interact with... But after about 20-25 minutes (just when I really started getting into the game), it was all over, and I took my time. If I had to guess, an experienced adventure gamer could beat this thing in less than 15 minutes. My co-worker's five year old son finished this adventure in a little over half an hour.A lot of people will hate the "8 bit" graphics that this game is presented in (not HD 8 bit, the REAL old school stuff), but I loved it. Quiet, Please! actually reminded me of the old DOS games I played many years ago.The Good:- No permissions! YEEEEAH- Addicting adventure gameplay.- LOTS of things to interact with. If you can see it, you can probably do something to it.- Great 8 bit graphics. I love anything that uses old school stuff.- Excellent sound. While there is no music, the cute jibber-jabber speech fits this game almost perfectly.- Encourages children to think as the puzzles are actually logical (as far as adventure games go).The Bad:- Lots of fake positive reviews.- No save option (not really too bad since the game is so short, but could be problematic down the line).- A link to rating this game in the pause menu.- A link to the Author's web page with links to the Android Market and the Play Store.- This is the SHORTEST adventure game I have ever played. Knowing all the puzzles, I could rush through it in mere MINUTES.- No replay value.The Ugly:Absolutely nothing.Scores:The Game: 4/5 (if it was longer, I would rate it a 5/5)Permissions: 4/5 (if the link to the Play Store and Amazon are removed, it will be a 5/5).Combined: 4/5Conclusion:Quiet, Please! is a great little adventure game that will provide you with a few minutes of entertainment. It is certainly worth the free download as today's FAOTD, but I don't think it's worth it at the $.99 price point. This is the shortest game that I have played in years. Combined with the fact that there is no replay value and I just don't see it as a good purchase.My suggestion to Nostatic Software is to add a few more zones to the game. A school seems like an obvious choice, and so does the playground. If that were to happen, and the playtime would increase to at least an hour (hopefully more), I would gladly recommend that people buy this little gem (even at a slightly higher price point).

This is a really basic "ride to the end of the level while avoiding obstacles game". You can also pull off some tricks (that don't matter) by tilting your Android device while speeding down the track... By speeding, I mean slowly crawling. The bike moves at a snail's pace and there is literally no rush of speed in this game, just random obstacles and bumpy tracks thrown at you.Honestly playing this game was a chore, and I didn't enjoy it at all. I tried it on four devices and spent about two hours trying to find something good about it... Sadly I failed.The Good:- There are a lot of levels (too bad they are all tedious, short, and poorly designed).- You can customize your bike (wheels and color).The Bad:- Network permissions in a single player game.Open network sockets - Allows this app free range internet access.Access information about networks - Does exactly what it sounds like.- Poor graphics and animations. I don't know why it's labeled as HD, it is clearly not. The cartoony graphics are very bad all around. Even the tricks you can perform aren't at all exciting.- Only thing you are graded on is time. If you try to bust some tricks, it will actually take away from your time (score).- Bad physics and collision engine. You can literally fall and then get up again to keep riding if done fast enough. Or you can get stuck and even backing up won't do you any good - meaning you will have to restart the level.- No sense of speed. Not only does your bike move slowly, but the course design is terrible and littered with obstacles just to slow you down even more.- Terrible sound and effects. This game is best played on mute. The rag-doll biker just won't shut up when falling.- Has a lot of other games from the developer that you can purchase through the aptly named "More Games" button.- Inaccurate controls. Tilting doesn't always work as well as it should... Going backwards can also sometimes be problematic.- Lots of fake reviews. I don't know anyone in their right mind that would give this game anything more than three stars.- Crashed twice in the two hours that I played. Once on my S III, and once on my Transformer.I could list about a dozen other things that I disliked about this game, but don't want to waste my time doing so.The Ugly:- No "Option" menu. They put in the "More Games" menu, but nothing for options. So you can't even turn off the lame sound or re-calibrate the controls. But hey, I guess selling junk games is more important than making good ones.Score:The Game: 1/5Permissions: 2/5 (Single player games DO NOT need network permissions).Combined: 1.5/5. Since Amazon does not let you give anything half a star, I am making a call here and lowering the score to 1/5 because the game is terrible in every way.Conclusion:Moto Mania HD - Dirt Bike Challenge is not even worth the free download as today's FAOTD, and certainly not worth the $.99 purchase price. I already deleted and forgot about this game from the two devices I tested it on. The racing/trick genre is incredibly over-saturated on the Android OS, and I have no idea how Pig Out Productions plans to compete with this lackluster entry.

Namco has countless times tried to re-invent Pac-Man and put it back into mainstream gaming, failing horribly.Hexage Ltd has succeeded where (many) others couldn't. Don't let the games clever description fool you, this is simply an HD remake of Pac-Man, with more features and a somewhat decent escape story.The object of EVAC HD is to eat all the dots (colors) you can, while navigating through the maze and avoiding ghosts (other blocks) that try to capture (eat) you. If this sounds like a game you played ages ago, that's because it is; but re-skinned and re-imagined for this generation.I absolutely love all the changes they made here. Adding little spaces for you to hide and avoid ghosts (I am not calling them "reds" like the game does) was pure genius, and the power ups add even more strategy to the classic dot gobbling.Side Note:There is a lot of false information floating around about EVAC HD's control scheme.It greatly upsets me when people just randomly spew off made up facts about the product they review based on somebody else's summary. Trust me on this, there is nothing wrong with the controls and you CAN indeed move the joystick to suit your orientation.The Good:- Tight controls. Contrary to some other reviewers, I love the way controls are handled here. I feel they are very good and had no issues whatsoever on two phones and two tablets (INCLUDING the Kindle Fire).- Classic Pac-Man gameplay brings back warm feelings of nostalgia.- Ingenious power ups allow you to do everything from stunning to destroying your captors.- Minor puzzle elements (moving blocks to open doors, blocking off ghosts, etc) add a bit of strategy to the action.- Awesome graphics. I am a sucker for this type of HD-Retro look.- Excellent soundtrack and effects. My only complaint is that no classic Pac-Man tunes made it into the game, but I am guessing the developers simply didn't want to get sued.The Bad:- Social media integration. Really, can we stop it with this crap please? I don't want my device posting that I beat a level and advertise for any game.- Links from within the game allow you to access the Google Play and Amazon store (and purchase things from there).- NETWORK permissions in a SINGLE PLAYER GAME.Open network sockets gives this app free range internet access.Access information about networks allows it to do just that (for both your phone and wireless networks).These things are just not needed in a single player game and are here just for the social media and link aspects of the app.While there is no traffic going to and from the game while it is just being played, hitting some of the other links makes the network monitor light up like a Christmas tree (obviously).- The game is incredibly short. Adding another campaign would go a long way to justifying the higher price point.- Higher price point. The game retails at $1.99 but is NOT YET worth that price in its current state.The Ugly:Thankfully I found nothing too terrible in EVAC HD.Scores:The Game: 5/5Permissions: 2/5 (single player games DO NOT NEED network permissions).Score: 3.5/5, bumping it up to 4/5 because Amazon does not allow .5 ratings, and because I thoroughly enjoyed this game.Conclusion:I am a sucker for HD remakes of classic games, even more so if they are actually good (as is the case here). While I simply can't recommend the game at its $1.99 pricing point, I suggest you grab it as today's free download.If you enjoy classic games, give EVAC HD a try, and if they ever add another campaign (more levels), or drop the price to $.99, or remove the unnecessary network permissions - I would even recommend purchasing it.Good job to the developers for actually improving on a classic. You guys (and gals) did great work here, but some of the things I mentioned are preventing me from giving it a perfect rating. Fix them, and I will bump it up.

Before I start with my actual review, I would just like to thank NOMAD Apps for creating such an amazing game that is not only fun, but doesn't use any unnecessary permissions or third party spy/bloatware.AWEsum! is a really awesome (I had to do it, please forgive me) game, the object of which is to (vertically) line up numbered cubes and make them add up to create the game's current AWEsum!. These blocks fall two at a time and can either be rotated (by tapping the screen), or moved (by dragging them across the screen). They can also be forced into place faster by dragging them down (this also nets you a higher score).Speaking of scoring, you are awarded bonus points for using blocks of a similar color to create the AWEsum!, and there are multiple power ups included to spice up the gameplay. Getting two AWEsum!'s in a row (from the same pair of falling blocks) earns you a "Swap", which can be used to change the numbers on falling blocks, giving you more chances to score.The best part of this app is that there are no permissions, IAP, or bloatware included.The Good:- Simple yet effective graphics and a great UI. Everything you need is right there on the screen, with nothing to distract you from gaming.- Good sound effects, including the announcer.- Creative power ups.Number Bomb that will destroy all the cubes that match the number it falls on (usually resulting in multiple AWEsum!'s if done right).Double Arrow that will destroy all cubes in a row (either vertically or horizontally).Colored Star that will destroy all cubes of a color it lands on.- An EXTENSIVE help option. Everything you could ever want to know about the game is here.- Great option menu that will allow you to adjust your starting block height (turning the game into an instant math puzzle) and level (to increase the speed at which the blocks fall), as well as a myriad of other choices that can impact the game (even the controls).- Well programmed and runs on a wide variety of hardware without a problem or issue.- NO IAP, PERMISSIONS, or SPY/BLOATWARE.- No useless social media integration.The Bad:- Peppy music does get annoying after a while, thankfully it can be disabled in the option menu.- The AWEsum! is only calculated vertically, not across (side by side). I would really like this implemented in the future so that we can line up massive board clearing combos.- Questionable reviews - There are still five star ratings by users with one or two reviews under their belt. Sadly this is now becoming a staple on Amazon. However, in AWEsum!'s defense, I only found a few of them so I won't be marking them as 100% fake.- Aks you to review it in order to unlock a new (and very powerful) power up block.The Ugly:- Absolutely nothing, I couldn't find a single glaring issue with this app.Score:The Game: 5Permissions: 5Combined Score: 5Conclusion:AWEsum! is an amazing game and a superb FAOTD! It is also completely worth its $.99 price point. I can't recommend it enough. If you miss this as a free download, just go ahead any buy it.Apps like this are getting rarer on the Adnroid OS and NOMAD Apps (the developer) should be rewarded and encouraged for releasing such a great game.NOMAD Apps, I can't wait to see your future software.

The object of Tiki Lavalanche (Ad-Free) is to remove most non golden objects from the board while having the golden ones (cubes, balls, triangles, etc) touch solid ground (or each other) and not fall into the boiling lava.The premise is really simple, but there are plenty of things to get in the way (such as bouncing blocks, glass, bombs, etc), and each level has multiple solutions. You are not penalized on time or the amount of moves it takes you to complete each board - you are instead free to actually think things through.Now while the game does have IAP, I am on  Pack 5 (out of 9) so far, and have not used that "feature". The progression system allows you to easily unlock new packs by scoring well on previous levels. If you score poorly (one or two stars), you may need to use the unlock.The Good:- Perfect difficulty level. By not punishing you for moves made or time taken, Tiki Lavalanche lets you play the game at your own pace.- Good progressions system. Unlocking more packs is achieved through scoring well previous levels.- The graphics, while nothing special, really add to the game.- Good sound effects. There are quite a few blocks in the game and each has sounds associated with it.- Great physics engine that actually works well.- 135 levels to get through!The Bad:- IAP - self explanatory. I don't like any of my games to have in app purchases as an option.- Open network sockets permissions allows this app free reign internet acceess.- The Access information about networks permission does exactly what it sounds.Why the above two permisions are needed in a single player game, I don't know. (Well, for IAP and More Games button in the case of Tiki Lavalanche).- Boring, repetitive music (thankfully can be disabled).- Fake five star reviews.The Ugly:- Absolutely nothing. This is where I would make a comment about IAP or some glaring error, or maybe even a nasty permissions, but Tiki Lavalanche has nothing terribly ugly present.Score:The Game: 4/5Permissions: 2/5 (single player games do not NEED any permissions).Total: 3/5Conclusion:Tiki Lavalanche (Ad-Free) really is a good FAOTD, and is even priced well at $.99. I highly recommend it as today's free download, or as a future purchase.As always, having a rooted (and fire-walled) device is a plus when dealing with network permissions, because it is extremely easy to purchase/unlock things from within the game. This is an even bigger issue if your device can access things other than wireless (Edge/3G/etc).

A bit of a warning to those thinking I am giving Tera one star - that is NOT the case. I gave the game three out of five stars (check out my review below).It is simply the score that the terribly lacking DIGITAL Collector's Edition is receiving. In fact, if I could give it zero stars, I would.All this PC Download CE version does (other than cost a lot more) is give you the following in-game items: a level 20 Regal Frostlion Mount, a level 15 Velik's Bloodstone Necklace, and a level 40 Shakan's Bloodstone Necklace.You don't get any digital artwork, maps, storybooks, or in game convenience benefits (such as a store bought level one mount). This so called Collector's Edition doesn't even give you any sort of cosmetic gear/pets or exclusive voices/appearances!What makes this incredibly lacking package a Collector's Edition? En Masse Entertainment, I am asking you directly - why did you label this as such?Coming from other digital CE's this version is quite disappointing.The only difference between this digital CE and the regular version of Tera is the higher price tag and three useless items... If you feel that's worth it, by all means go ahead and purchase it (thus encouraging the developer to continue with these kinds of practices).---------------------- My review of Tera (the base game) is below ----------------------Tera is an action MMORPG, where auto attacking and tab targeting have been removed in favor of a much more fluid (and interesting) combat system. The game plays very much like your standard action game, and defeating enemies requires dodging, blocking, and being mobile. While you must still use a hotbar to trigger abilities, all of them have to be AIMED by you, and can be dodged just as easily by another skilled player (not by monsters, who have terrible, terrible AI). This results in some of the best PvP action I have ever encountered.All is not well however, as the game has quite a few broken quests at this very moment. They recently merged all their servers into just three (the PvP only Mount Tyrannas, the PvE only Tempest Reach, and the Roleplaying server Celestial Hills). This merge created a myriad of problems and broken quests for the team at Enmasse Studios. I tried playing a freshly made toon just for the purpose of this review and found that I could not progress through the prologue because of a quest glitch. Moreover, skipping the prologue and going to the newby area, I was again halted by a quest MOB not spawning - and this once more prevented progression. There were about 20 people trying to finish this story quest (you NEED to complete them), and swearing about the game being a bug filled mess.Logging on with my higher level characters, I was told there were quite a few more bugs in game after the merge (I asked in guild chat), and a lot of them impede progression.The Good:- Tera is incredibly gorgeous on the highest settings, of course you need a beefy computer to run it. My TimelineU M5-481TG-6814 can't handle it on medium or above, while running games like Skyrim on the high settings.- The combat is amazing. I love that auto attack and targeting has been removed. This is by far the best combat in any MMORPG that I have played, and I played a lot of them. The thrill you get from dynamically dodging or blocking (and countering) your opponent's attack adds a lot to the overall feel of things.- Environments and creature design are outstanding. Whoever created the world of Tera should be praised for a job well done. Everything from lush, rolling landscapes, to the mobs and races that inhabit it are all top notch. My only complaint about the races, is that all the females look like slutty supermodels (or borderline illegal for the Elin race).- There are lots of ways to customize your characters (however there are also some limitations - such as not being able to make a purely bald character).- Interesting progression system where you glyph your skills to modify them (there are usually quite a few choices to pick from), and lots of ways to improve your gear (crystals, enchantments, etc).- Fighting BAM's (big ass monsters) is incredibly fun (and they live up to their name). Killing a BAM is like hunting similar creatures in the excellent Monster Hunter games, but a bit more challenging. For all you MH fans out there, do yourself a favor and roll a Berserker - that way you should be able to solo most BAM's. That is my main, and the only character that I can solo most BAM's with (adding to the MH feel).- Server merges make for incredibly populated servers. There are countless players running and fighting all around you.- The world PvP is pretty good, and actually exists in Tera, as does GvG (Guild VS Guild) and Battlegrounds.- You can play for free, just like in Eve by purchasing a Chronoscrolls for in game money. You can also buy one from Amazon and sell it for in game funds. I haven't payed for Tera ever since this system was introduced a while back.The Bad:- There are generally only three quest types in Tera (of the fetch, escort, and slay variety). All MMORPG vets are familiar with these "staples" of the genre. Eventually PQ's do make an appearance, but by that time it is already too late.With the evolution that The Secret World has brought to the genre, playing Tera (or any other MMORPG for that matter just feels stale).- Plenty of broken quests after the server merge.- Grinding, grinding, and did I mention grinding? The best way to level up is still to repeat grind quests in key areas while queuing for dungeons. There is a huge drop off in the leveling speed at 40, and then again at 50. Getting up to 40 however is pretty simple.- The game does not deserve its M rating. It simply doesn't push the boundaries like Age of Conan: Hyborian Adventures or make you think like The Secret World. Other than the nude patches that are floating around the net, there is nothing too inappropriate in Tera. When a game is rated M, I expect it to handle that rating with more than just skimpy dresses.- Tera's story is absolute generic garbage. Everything from the poorly voiced cutscenes to the terrible text. I tried to read the whole thing my first time through, but eventually succumbed to the ultra fast "accept quest and move on" mode. Star Wars: The Old Republic and The Secret World really handle this a LOT better. This is disappointing since I actually loved the Tera books.The Ugly:- Tera is dying. Unless they switch to F2P post haste, I am afraid that even the three current servers will not fill up. My guild, which consisted of hundreds of members months ago, is now down to 17-20 active ones. The merges helped quite a bit, but I don't know for how long.- The AI of some MOBs in this game is unbelievably laughable and makes the monsters in WoW seem like brain surgeons. You can exploit terrain and class skills to no end when it comes to certain encounters.Conclusion:Honestly it would be a mistake to not try this game out. It comes with 30 days of playtime, and if you do everything right it should be the only money you will need to spend (just purchase Chronoscrolls for in game cash).I liked Tera at first, I really did but as time progresses and I experienced other games, I couldn't help but give the game a three star rating. If you have never played an AMMORPG before, feel free to add an extra star to my review, but with the competition being what it is - I can't recommend this game too much. In fact, if it wasn't for my addiction hunting BAM's and world bosses, I would have probably completely moved on by now.---------------------- My review of Tera (the base game) is above ----------------------

This battery pack is the EXACT replacement fro what came in my Motorola Walkie-Talkie.  Down to every letter and code number on it, this is the exact match.  We got them at a great price and the shipping was very fast.
Name brand quality batteries in a bulk packaging to save you money.  Not much more you can say about it.

As I will eventually need this for my printer, I actually ordered it ahead of time as a "fill in" to make the $35 free shipping.  This collects the ink used to "prime" the print heads on the 3800 and 3880 Epson Professional inkjet printers.  It is basically a plastic tube filled with absorbent material to soak up the ink so it doesn't splash all around.  Seems a bit pricey for what it is, but you can't argue with Epson.  You have to have it.

Been using the same model of calendar book for nearly twenty years and I keep all my old ones.  Every once in a while I need to go back and look up some information.  This format works very well for me.  Each day of the week is a full column from top to bottom about 2 inches wide.  The lines are free-form, without times, so it is flexible in how I can use it.  The weekend days split a column.  It is thin and flexible, so it is easy to carry or stash away.

This is a very nice flag for the price paid.  It is a little bit too light a fabric for serious outdoor use.  Excellent for indoor or occasional outdoor use if the winds are not too high.  The binding tape and grommets are sufficient for the purposes mentioned.  The top and bottom seams are double-stitched adn the end hem has four sewn lines.  The colors are very strong adn all the way through the fabric.  A good vaule for what you pay.

Huge difference between pay me now or pay me later. I've had a number of Epson "consumer" inkjets in both narrow and wide carriage formats. They had the multiple tanks, all very small and about $15 a tank. My photography work finally expanded to where I took the leap to the Professional grade Epson 3880 printer. At $1700, the up front investment was huge, but I can see where I am going to make it all up on ink costs. The ink tanks in the 3880 are huge.What I found with the other printers was that I'd pay a couple of hundred dollars for the printer, then pay through the nose in the rapid depletion of ink. Besides the wider carriage capability of the 3880, the inks last forever, or it seems. I kept track of what I've printed since getting it. I've printed 150 posters at 13x19, 75 large format prints at 17x22, almost 450 at 8x10, and during all that was experimenting with printing on metal, wood, and canvas. I bought this tank because I was finally down to about 25% on it and wanted a replacement ready to go. The rest of the tanks are no lower than 35%.Yeah, the tanks are $50 each, but when you consider how much longer they last than the ones in the consumer world, it really saves money in the long run. Amazon continues to be the best and most cost effective source for my Epson inks.

For most people they will either love this movie or hate it, depending on three things.  The first is the cinematography.  The movie creates grand vista of background and highly detailed and ornate scenes for the action to take place, like at the palace.  If you love movies where every scene could be a painting of its own, you'll love this movie.  The second is how well you know the legend and if you have seen previous versions of the story.  If you are a big fan of feudal Japan and the Samurai, you will not be disappointed.  There are many details, some as simple as how the Samurai sign their names to the pledge, which flesh out what the Samurai Code entailed.  This is not your typical Samurai movie with lengthy and massive sword fighting scenes.  The action is there, but kept to a reasonable and maybe minimal amount to make the point.  The third is whether or not you understand this is a redemption movie.  A lot of people I met who hated the movie went to it thinking it was a battle filled tale of revenge, and they clearly did not understand the ending.  If you see how the characters are paying in this life for their sins as away of redeeming their honor in the next life, you will love this movie.

As a general rule I have stopped reviewing DVD's because I apparently do not know what it is that everyone wants to know and I get lots of "not helpful" comments.  However, I make an exception in this case.  I have started to make it a habit of finding the director's cut or unrated versions of movies.  I had only seen Chronicles of Riddick on cable and did not realize what I was missing.  This widescreen version has maybe 9 or 10 extra minutes of material which makes a BIG difference in the story line and fills some gaps in the story.  There are flash-backs to prophecy which explains more of Riddick's past.  There is an entire section where at the hangar where Riddick has some sort of power surge and wipes out almost all of Necromongers.  This explains how he got left behind instead of killed and it also explains Lord Vaco's respect for Riddick.  These small snippets help flesh out the story better.

The labeling appearance has changed, so don't let that throw you if you are reordering.  This is the high quality balsamic sister to their "must" product.  The must version is excellent and I use that where small amounts are used and the flavor of the vinegar itself is most important.  This bottle is less than half the price as the must.  It works really well in salad dressings or in recipes where it is an "accent" flavor and not the star of the show.  The taste is excellent and at half the price, you can afford to be more generous as to when and where you use this versus the must product.

One thing to correct that I saw in several reviews...this does not have lithium ion batteries.  This uses nickel metal hydride batteries.  They eliminate the "memory" problems of nickel cadmium batteries, but do not have the same power curve of lithium ion where they are at full power until when they die.  Nickel metal hydride batteries last a long time and fully charge, however they do have a more tapered power loss at the end of their charge than lithium ion.
