So I quickly grabbed small handfuls of my hair, and slid the device down my length pretty quickly.  And imagine my shock when my very quick straighten session turned my hair into beautiful silk!  It lasted all day, and that includes with humid weather.  Next time I tried this I tried adding volume to just the top of my head and swerve the device under once I get to the bottom of my hair to swing it in.  That was incredibly easy, and again was done in no time at all!!  As for curling, this is where I had the most trouble in learning how to use the device.  I had to wrap my long pieces around the barrel, and close it, which activates the rotary, and then slide it down while continuing to twist my hand around.  I ended up with really cute curls, and for the shorter layers I couldn't twirl them around the barrel, so I ended up wrapping it the best I could, and twirling it like I would a normal curling iron.  The results were fantastic!!I truly love this device, and it is now my one stop shop!  It works very well on my hair, and I could see if working easily on thick hair also.  It'll probably take a lot longer to curl or style than my hair, but I feel it is worth it!  Definitely a keeper!

What a flipping story!  I love all things fantasy with adventure, a speck of romance, danger, and of course witty dialogue, and great characters, and The Girl at Midnight did not disappoint!Our adventure starts off with a young girl named Echo, who is human in every way possible.  Even if that humanity includes living in a secret room in a library, and having friends who definitely couldn't be classified as the human variety with their feathers and plumage.  But Echo never truly felt like she fit in with her friends or the community as her flawless skin betrays her species even though her guardian, the Ala, is like a mother to her.  And when Ala asks her to go on a dangerous quest to find a mystical creature that could put an end to a war that is centuries in the making with their adversaries, Echo doesn't even hesitate.  But little does Echo realize that this journey will be full of danger, deception, and violence, but also peace, unity, and friendship in ways that she could not even attempt to imagine.There's no way that I want to give away the total synopsis of the book, but I will say the characters were written so well, that by the time I reached the final few pages I was at a loss of wanting to know the ending, and yet not wanting the book to end! Again, the characters were wonderful, and I truly empathized with each one of them, and I love the fact that the book goes from one character to another's point of view seamlessly, and it gives the story that much more of a background, and you end up feeling as if you really know the characters.  The plot was superb, even though I did guess the ending, but it was such an adventure getting to the end that you honestly don't care, and can't wait to see it play out.  I also love that the book does end, with no massive cliffhanger, but does leave it open for the next installment nicely.  This is definitely going on my top shelf as one of the best reads this year!

I'm a huge lover of the AVENT bottles, and have bought these for nieces and nephews, besides my own child, and have always had positive results with them.  These AVENT bottles are truly made up of great quality, and they are the perfect size for either preemies or newborns!  I love that they have measuring marks on each side of the bottle, and it's just the right size so measuring is almost redundant in this cute little bottles.  These do come with tops that have a nice little thumbprint impression on the side, which helps to easily get the top off, and the nipples are great on this!  I have had no issues whatsoever in getting my child to take the bottle, and what I like even more is that this has a slow flow of milk to the baby, which really helps their digestive system and reduces the chance of babies having colic.  I also haven't had any issues of the nipple sinking into the bottle, and these truly are a breeze to clean.  I love these bottles, and will definitely purchase more!

Who doesn't love a good suspense story filled with creepy things such as a huge manor house filled with mystery, a cemetery with numerous unmarked graves, and a legend of untold horror surrounding the home?  It's nearly the perfect setting for a great tale, but unfortunately for me, Haunted was so disjointed with a plot seen a mile away, that I was totally bored with this tale.Phoebe is our heroine here, a young girl whose family moved to her stepdads massive estate, because of some horrible deed she did that she just can't seem to remember.  In tow is her young toddler half-sister, Tabby, whom she loves to bits, but also who seemed to steal the spotlight from her.  An avid swimmer, Phoebe is stoked to find out there is a community pool, and immediately goes for a relaxing swim.  That is until she meets a total cutie in the form of Miles, also an avid swimmer who tells her of a legend that surrounds the mansion she now lives in.  In its horrid tale, the mistress of the estate, Madame Arnaud seemingly found the mixture for eternal youth, and ruled over her estate with a tight fist and abject cruelty.  And now with fresh souls in the house, Madame Arnaud is starting to show herself, and it's all Phoebe can do to try to keep those she loves safe.I really, really wanted to like Haunted, but it just wasn't for me.  I did like the characters, and felt they were hashed out pretty well; however, it was the plot that truly left a bad taste in my mouth.  First of all for the villain, you're totally left trying to figure out is it a ghost, still alive, and if so where has it been hiding all this time?  There were a lot of unanswered questions regarding that amid other things.  I truly did dislike the disjointed areas where Phoebe mysteriously started remembering about past things, or managed to wind up somewhere with no recollection of how she got there.  It was very apparent what was going on, but it drove me nuts when the scene just stopped to go to something else.  And the horrible deeds that the villain does just felt like a rip off of a certain figure in history.  As soon as it came out what the person does I immediately thought about that individual, and it seriously made the book take a nose dive into boo land for me.  Seriously, there was no originality here.  And the ending?  Wow.  Talk about anticlimactic.  I was waiting for the villain to pop up again, but nope.  Apparently the weak way the villain bit the dust was it, and the actual ending leaves off with an ending, but there is supposed to be other books in the series.  For me, Haunted was nothing special, with no true suspense, and I rated it a three star basically for the effort of the author.  I would definitely not recommend this unless you want a headache trying to follow Phoebe's memories/reality or don't mind a book that is unoriginal with no scary suspense or mystery really in it.

I normally don't venture too far in my brands, and have always stuck with one in particular for my tampon needs especially, but I always felt that I wasn't getting the right amount of protection, and decided to give the Playtex sport combo pack a try.And I'm so glad I did!  I am very active, always on my feet, and I love to exercise at least three to four times a week, which includes a lot of cardio so the sport theme to this fit my body type perfectly.  The pack itself includes 18 tampons, with eight of them being super, and ten of them being regular, and fourteen pads with wings.  In using the tampons, I always have to pack a super for just the first and second day, and I do like that these are plastic (seriously, THE only way to go), and that the bottom portion of the plastic is ribbed enabling a good grip.  That might sounds silly, but I have butterfingers as it is, and any extra grip is always welcome.  Again, the applicator is great, and these tampons are unscented, which helps if you are sensitive in that area, which I am.  As for the actual pads, I loved these so much!!  I cannot wear a tampon for long periods of time, so during the day it gets plugged, and during the night I switch to pads, and I am seriously in love with these!  They, like normal pads, adhere with adhesive, and are easy to put on, and I swear they do not budge!  The wings go perfectly around my panties with no issues whatsoever, and I love the thin feeling of this pad!  I didn't actually think it would hold much, but let me say that I ended up using these on a lazy Saturday, just to see, and it held up wonderfully! I ended up doing outside work that day, and it never moved or bunched at all, and I stayed nice and dry.  I do love that you can buy one box, and you're set for the month without having to buy boxes of everything.  It is definitely convenient, and I totally recommend it!

My teeth have never been sensitive until recently when ice cream decided to invade the nerves in my tooth causing definite pain.  So I started checking out various toothpastes that provide help for sensitivity, and I came across this unique pen/toothbrush combo.  For starters the toothbrush itself is quite nice, and perfect for those with sensitivity issues as it is labeled extra soft to help with sensitivity while brushing.  The bristles truly are highly soft, but I still feel like I get very clean teeth and gums as, while the bristles are very, very soft, they still manage to get the nasty of my teeth with relative ease.  It also helps that there are plastic pieces in the bristles that help to remove plaque as well.  The opposite side of the brush also has raised rubberized areas that help clean the inside of cheeks too, which is a nice feature.  There is a large blue rubber grip in the middle of the toothbrush, which feels great on the tip of my thumb, and helps provide good a good grip.  The interesting part of this toothbrush is that the bottom is large, and hollowed out.  This allows for the thin Sensitivity Relief Pen to slip inside, in a unique little hideaway.The pen itself is very slender, with a removable plastic cap on one end.  Once the cap is removed, you can easily twist the bottom cap (which also is used as the "end" cap of the toothbrush making it look seamless once put together), and after just two twist the sensitivity medication is on the tip.  You simply apply to the area that needs it, and that's about it!  Just slip the pen back into the toothbrush and you're done.  Having used this for about four days I can tell a difference already in cold foods.  I had no issue in hot liquids or hot food on my tooth, just cold things like ice cream, and so far this has worked.  I don't feel the sensitivity like I used to, but keep in mind I have also switched my toothpaste to one that is proven good for sensitive teeth.  But combining both these factors has definitely made my tooth feel like normal again, and I'm no longer afraid to eat cold treats.

I'd definitely give this 3 1/2 to 4 stars as it serves the purposes I need it to, which is for holding various reports at work.  I used to have about seven plastic folders scrunched together above my desk to hold all my reports in, but I wanted something that took up less room, looked nice (or business oriented), and still held a fair amount of paper.  And the Fellowes Bankers Box worked perfectly for my needs.I already knew before buying this that it is made up of pure cardboard.  And while some people rate this as heavy duty cardboard, and some say it's lightweight, it's basically the same consistency as a normal box you'd get in the mail from ordering something. Strong enough to hold things, but it is cardboard just the same.  I was very excited when I got this in, and immediately started putting it together, and I swear I can seriously not be the only person who couldn't figure out how to close the back of this.  I got so frustrated I took out some craft duct tape in a nice blue color and attacked the back until I had a nice seal. And this comes from someone who is used to putting together large banker boxes from the same company.  I don't know what went wrong there, but I will say duct tape works nicely, and since my letter sorter is situated with it's back to a wall no one can see it.  As for putting the rest of it together that was a breeze!  Simply fold the inside inserts in half, make sure the side with the majority of white is facing up, push up/down the side areas, and slide it in on the bottom.  Do that with the next two inserts, and your ready to do the same thing (folding in half and folding the up/down tabs in the right direction), to the middle insert.  I did have to work this part in to make it fit, but it still wasn't that difficult.  I folded the sides of the actual box inward on all sides, then attached the plastic bars to the inserts, and that was it!My box is done, and it looks pretty good.  Not fantastic as you can totally tell it's cardboard, but it still looks decent, and, again, serves my purpose.  It does have eight compartments, and it does come with a small thing of labels to write on and stick on the plastic bars.  I choose to print normal size labels, and cut them to fit onto the bar, which just looked more professional to me, especially since my hand writing sucks.As for how much paper this can hold...it holds a pretty good amount!  I managed to put a ream of paper in the bottom area as that totally would have weighed it down, and quite possibly broken it, but I have thick reports in the other's about thirty pages, and that's literally nothing to what it can hold!  So if you are in the market for a sorter or something to help keep you organized, then I do totally recommend it!

We have an XBox One that is stuffed in our entertainment center along with all our other electronics, which includes a dvr, Playstation, Wii, etc., and while we do have vented slots for the devices, it can get pretty warm with them on, especially when two or more devices are running at the same time.  We've actually started putting the XBox on top of the entertainment center, which isn't grand in looks, but it helps with the heating issue.  We finally got the Antec X-1 Cooler for the XBox One, and so far, we are in total love with it!  The design of the cooler is honestly one of my main loves for this device.  The front of an XBox One has a beautiful glossy right side to it, and the Antec cooler not only fits perfectly on top of it, but it literally looks like one device versus two.  It's so seamless in design!  It also spouts a nice temperature digital readout on the very top of the device in blue, which is a nice added feature.  The fan is very quiet also, and we have managed to put the XBox back into our entertainment center, and we have definitely noticed it feels less warm in the inside versus when we didn't have an external fan on it.  The box states that the cooler is supposed to make the heat less by thirty percent, and I honestly feel that is pretty darn accurate.  I'm glad we got this, as it definitely does make the XBox cooler, and it helped us to have it in a place we liked versus sitting out on top of our entertainment center.

I adore a good YA mystery that's over flowing with suspense, and The Third Twin just sounded like a massively great story that incorporates tons of toe curling excitement!  And it was...to a point...The Third Twin begins with a, you guessed it, set of twins who look fully identical unless you know them, Ava and Lexi.  Lexi is our heroine here, a senior in high school whose book smart, and has little time for frivolity as she has her eye on a college that her adopted dad went to.  But even Lexi needs to have a little fun every now and then, and that’s when things start to get interesting, as Ava and Lexi felt they needed an escape every now and then from their lives.  So they invented Alicia.  The “third” twin.  This twin is super cool, beautiful, confident, has an don’t-even attitude, and always dates boys that they probably shouldn’t.  It’s all fun and games to them.  Until Lexi is ready to quit as she’s found a boy that she truly likes…but how to come clean about Alicia, and show him her true nerdy self?  And while Lexi is trying to figure that out, the news headline blares on of a horrific murder.  Of a boy that she just went out with as Alicia.  And if that wasn’t enough, detectives are now pounding on the door wanting to talk to Alicia…a person who shouldn’t…doesn’t exist.  And yet…she’s in the police departments records.  With a maddening twist Lexi must quickly find out who the murderer is as the police are looking at her, and Lexi has a bad feeling that the murders aren’t over yet.I went into The Third Twin truly expecting to be biting my nails to the quick in the thick of the suspense, but truly, it wasn’t really all that suspenseful.  There was a certain creep factor, but not enough to fully suck me in.  I did love the characters, as they were portrayed nicely, but I did have one flaw with Lexi, and that was her sheer stupidity.  You ever watch a scary movie, and yell at the tv telling the characters to NOT go in that door??  That was basically like this.  Lexi did things that weren’t that smart, and if there was a murderer on the loose then stay in groups, and do not, for the love of all that is good, go out in a dark alley by yourself!  Sheesh!!!  The plot was pretty good, but again, you could see things coming at Lexi a mile away while she still stumbled through them. If it wasn’t for a good friend, she’d really be in a lot of trouble.  The villain wasn’t someone I thought of, but the author pretty much screams it to Lexi at one point, but Lexi still walks away blindly not realizing it until pages later.  *ugh*  So again, it was a good story, and I’m glad I did read it; however I went into this with way too much expectation.  I do recommend it though as it was a fun, light read, but just know that the suspense and thrill factor are pretty watered down.

This is the cutest comforter ever featuring Star Wars characters!  From the actual picture online I was ready for darker hues, and I was totally surprised when I opened it to reveal much more colorful embellishments that I originally thought!The comforter itself is made of a pretty thick polyester material that's very soft to the touch, and highly comfortable against the skin.  I did wash it before putting it on the bed, and I had no issues at all from that department.  It still retained it's shape well, and there was no bleeding of colors or anything like that, but I did wash it in cold water, and also air dried it.  The Star Wars comforter does include two pillow shams, and the comforter itself, and per the tag is for either a twin or full size bed. I actually have this on a full size bed, and to my happy surprise it actually covers the mattress perfectly!  I did put on a grey skirting, and in putting that on it truly set a nice tone for the bed, and dressed it up even more.  As for the color, like I said it was much lighter than the picture truly shows.  The blues pop in color, the gold is more bright yellow, and even the blacks that are in the picture seem to have an overall lighter feel to it.  So be aware that it isn't truly all black as the picture shows.  It's got a definite pop of color all over it and the block design of the characters works well in the overall scheme.  Again, this comforter feels great, and truly does feel durable, is washable, and still retains is shape without having lumpy middles.  That might change after so many washings, but for right now it still looks great and vibrant!  A definite for any Star Wars fan!

My niece loves crafts of all kinds, and I knew this would be perfect for her as she loves to show off her craft making skills, and what better way than to be able to wear her crafts?!  She immediately delved into this, and started putting pieces together.  The kit does include the necessary items to make five necklaces, which is basically five chains, five pendants, a hand full of caps for the necklace, which was great as they liked to roll away from us, five claps, a bead, and stickers.  I wish they would've included more beads as my niece gave me a look when she saw it, and immediately went to her craft station and pulled out more decorative beads of the same size.  Making the actual necklaces was literally a snap and a two part process.  The first is choosing a sticker for the pendant and putting the pendant together.  The next step is putting it on the chain and attaching the caps and clasp to it.  My niece is eight years old, and while I did ask her if she needed help with the chain, she is persistent enough that she managed to put it together herself after only a few minutes.We both truly enjoyed this craft as I "helped" her choose between the various sticker designs, but it was over very quickly!  We actually added beads on a few necklaces, which helped make the project longer, but it was still a pretty short craft project.  But I will say that she absolutely loved it, and couldn't wait to show off her necklaces to her family, and even presented a few members with their very own creations.  The necklace craft also was sealed very nicely so parts didn't fly all over the place once it was opened.Again, this was a short craft, but she still loved putting it all together, and the necklaces do look adorable!

We have always tried to keep an extra cell phone "floater" around the house for those emergency issues...like when my husband decided his brand new Iphone's screen was just a little too perfect and accidentally dropped a 90 pound weight on it.  Needless to say, with it being a new phone, the turnaround time to get a new one through insurance was over three weeks.  And that didn't include the days it took just to get the information to the insurance company.So for those purposes I definitely checked out the Blu Android phone, and I have to say, I'm pretty impressed.  The phone itself arrived in a nice little boxed package, and once opened the phone is nice and tidy in its little compartment.  Pulling up the phone, you'll find beneath it earbuds with a small controller on the side of one of the wires, a USB cable, a screen protector, a thin rubberized black case, the wall plug, and a manual.As soon as I unwrapped all the accessories, I immediately put the screen protector on, which has two sides.  Pull off the 1st side just a little bit, and stick this side to the phone, sliding your fingers down the phone to smooth it on.  Then after that's complete, smooth out any bubbles.  This screen protector did not come with a cleaning cloth or a cardboard piece, so I just used the screen protector packaging to get rid of any bubbles. Once that's done, easily pull back the 2nd tab, and your done with that part.The next part of this was inserting my SIM card, which was a breeze.  The back of this phone is so seamless that it took me a second to find where I could pop the back off, which is located on the bottom right.  There is the smallest of depressions in the corner of the case where I had to use my nail to pull up.  The back of the case finally lifted enough where I could easily pull it fully off.  And once off, there are two slots, two for SIM cards, and one for a Micro SD card.  Again, it was easy to slide my SIM card in, and that was it!  The cover snaps back into place with little clicks, and it's back to looking seamless in seconds.  The back cover is also coated in a rubberized material to prevent sliding on smooth surfaces and makes my grip feel very secure.This phone does have a built in battery, so beware of that factor if you're not keen on it.  I don't mind it at all, and I do have to say that even with a built in battery this phone is so very light!!!  It feels like it weighs nothing at all!  The overall design is, again, seamless in appearance, with no apparent buttons anywhere on the front.  The sides and bottom/top of the device has a beautiful silver trim that encompasses the power and volume buttons.  It's so tied into the design that you register the barest "bump" of a button.  These buttons are very easy to press and the cell phone responds perfectly with just the barest touch.This phone is an Android, and many people are upset with the whole lollipop factor, but this phone runs smoothly, and I'm one of those people who like to wait anyway to update to new software so the kinks can get worked out. That being said, this phone runs so quietly without any hiccups at all!  In normal Android fashion this phone has all the basic functions already on the home page for you such as the phone, gallery, the play store, google search, messages, contacts, etc.  It also has tons of widgets for customizing screens, and pressing any apps instantly bring it to life within seconds.  There is literally a very low lag time with this phone, which is great! Again, as we are using this phone as a floater, I didn't download much to it, except for basic stuff and a video streaming app.  The screen is massively clear with great quality as I did watch a few videos on youtube as well as watched a series on my video streaming app.  It worked great, and looked fantastic on the five inch screen! The camera works very well and it also has very cool built in photo shopping effects as well as various selections for exposure, quality, etc.  The front facing camera is only a 2MP, so the quality isn't fantastic, but it still works fine.The rubberized case that comes with the phone is very thin, and won't really offer drop protection. This is just for basic wear and tear that comes from sliding it on a desk, or dropping it into a purse.  I would totally recommend getting a new case especially as I don't like the little rubberized raised areas over the power and volume buttons.  It makes them a little hard to operate for me.As for actually sending and receiving calls, our network provider already has good service, and the phone worked as normal with no dropped calls or static over the line.  I could easily hear people on the other line, and they could hear me as well with no issues.I truly like the Blu cellphone, and while this is supposed to be a floater, I've pretty much confiscated it, and am currently using it as my every day cell phone.  The screen is bright, crystal clear, the calls are perfect, and I love the size, and the weight of this device.  It is seriously easy to carry, and works perfectly.  I definitely recommend this phone if you need a floater or want a new cell phone without forking over a kidney.  It definitely carries itself well, and the quality is perfect for the price!

I purchased this product for my husband as a birthday present, and he never drives anywhere without it!  This little bad boy is so small that it doesn't get in the way of driving or distract from your view, which is great!  The suction cup adheres to both of our vehicles nicely, with no issues whatsoever.  It's also so easy to use!  Either charge it with the included cables, or use the included cigarette charger with it in the vehicle, and that's it!  It's ready to go!  It's also very user friendly with only four little buttons on the bottom of the large screen that do everything from going through the menu to going back or forwards through the menu selection as well as take pictures, etc.  The Garmin Dash Cam also has a wide viewing angle, which really helps as it clearly takes video of all sides of the road.  We've used this dash cam at night, during the day, and during nasty weather, and it still features such a bright screen that manages to get everything clearly.  I love the fact that it also does audio and that you can turn off audio easily with one click of a button.  You can also change the vast amount of settings from everything to the display brightness to how long you want the display on to sounds, etc.  It does display the battery up top, and also the amount of time it's recording. In the mornings I will plug it up in the vehicle, and it pops on without me having to press the power button.  It also records in four minutes increments, and does detect any accidents with a high pitched beep.  It scared the living mess out of me first as we live down a bumpy road, and it did "detect" accidents because of the bumpy ride.  So if you hit a pothole or drive down a bumpy path then it will more than likely detect an accident and save the recording.  It also detects if an accident might be imminent as I had a vehicle pull out in front of me turning in the opposite lane, and it did beep.The recordings that we've had so far are all very clear, and look great, and even the pictures we've taken just to test it out all come back with good quality.I definitely recommend this product if you have a long commute or travel often, and the first day it was installed in my husbands vehicle he actually recorded three almost wrecks from other individuals.  I did buy a 32 GB card to go with this product, and I do recommend it so you have extra room to house videos.  It's definitely been a good product for us!

I was in serious need of a padded bag for my new 13 inch MacBook Pro with Retina display, and didn't want to pay an arm, a leg, and half a kidney for one as all the bags I saw were pretty pricey and overly big. I'm not a student, and don't bring my laptop out much, and when I do there is only minimal stuff I'll bring with it, so, again, I didn't want to spend a lot of money, but yet I still wanted good protection for my device. So when I saw the Uncommon bag I decided to go for it, and I'm quite happy I did.The Uncommon bag is very small (seriously, I had doubts my laptop would fit in there at first), but has loads of zippered pockets all over it, which is something I truly wanted to stash cables, wires, chargers, etc. The inside of the bag features a beautiful bright blue material that has a specified padded area for your laptop to go into, and a black piece of fabric attached to one side of the bag that Velcros to the divider holding your laptop securely in place.  I do have a Speck clear case on my laptop, and it did fit totally fine, but I would watch anything thicker.  I believe you could still put your laptop in a very thin neoprene sleeve, and still be able to stash it in the laptop area of the bag, but watch out for anything thicker as it probably won't fit.  That being said, it again is nicely padded, not thickly so with stiff padding, but enough to make me feel like my laptop is totally protected.  After the divider there is a nice open space for a notebook (in my case the charger), and on the opposite side is pockets for pens and cell phones as well as a pouch area for small items.From there the outside of the bag is full of pure happiness as it's covered in a pretty darn feeling tough material that wipes off easily.  I know this because I went out with my laptop while it was drizzling, and the water was very easy to wipe off, and I had no fear it would get to my laptop through all the padding.One side of the bag features a large full length zippered compartment that's perfect for tons of thin items, or even an Ipad, but I would be very fearful of having such an expensive device in a zippered outside pocket versus inside, but that's just me.  Again it's the full length of the bag and there is plenty of room in it for thin type items.  On front of this pocket is a little slant that houses another open pocket that's pretty long, and is perfect for a small pencil bag, or breath mints, tissues, any small items.  Just keep in mind it is not zippered but an open deep pocket so stuff can fall out if you're not careful.On the other side of the bag is another full length zippered pocket, and I will say even the zippers on this bag were well thought out as the tabs are large and easy to hold.  They're also that same beautiful blue color as the inside of the bag.  The top of the bag is zippered as well, and features two handles for easy carrying.  These handles are regular material that you'd normally see, but they are also infused with extra padded material that, again, feels so strong that I have no fear of loose stitching.  The Uncommon bag does have two small metal tabs on each end, both securely attached to the bag where the long strap can attach to. The strap itself is made up of normal strap material with good stitching, and a padded shoulder area that can be moved to accommodate different heights.  The strap itself is movable for the same reason, and I love the fact that the hooks on each end of the strap feel very sturdy, and they rotate.  So if you grab your bag up quickly there is no need to try to straighten the straps before putting it on as the clasps will rotate easily for easy shifting of the straps.Currently I have my MacBook Pro in there, again, with a Speck case on, as well as the charger, a wireless mouse, and a notebook in the actual bag area.  In the front zippered area I have a cleaning cloth in a pouch for my screen, and a small zippered pencil case.  In the other side I have another small notebook.  What I love is that while small and filled with all those items, there's still room for more stuff.  Albeit, it will have to be thin or small items, but there is still room.  I am a small female, only 5'2, and barley top 100 pounds soaking wet, and this bag looks perfect on me.  My husband who is 6'2 and huge still makes this bag look good, and it doesn't look like a weird little thing next to him, which is great as he carries it a lot for me.  The color is also a very dark navy blue on the front and back with a black top, black handles and strap, as well as a beautiful bright blue inside and accent colors for the zippers and logo.This is seriously the best bag for me, and while small still holds an amazing amount of items!  I love the fact that it didn't cost much, is easy to carry, the strap is very comfortable, and it's a very secure, padded bag, that I feel will last a long time!  Great product!

I swear A Court of Thorns and Roses was like watching a movie that had a mixture of Beauty and the Beast, Hunger Games, and Lord of the Rings rolled into one.  My brain was seriously doing a happy dance.Feyre is a mortal girl, just nineteen years of age, who has only known pain, suffering, hunger, and resentment for the faerie beings who enslaved their kind years ago, and ultimately put a wall between their people and mere mortals by decree of a peace treaty between the two species.  No one had heard or saw a faerie in years, but still people are wary, and never go near the wall.  But Feyre has a family to feed, a father and two older sisters who rely on her expertise at hunting to keep them alive through the harsh winter months.  So Feyre edges deeper into the forest than she's ever been, and it's here that she makes the mistake that will change her life forever.  For a single arrow loosed into a creature that surely couldn't be fae has sealed her fate.  In a frightful encounter a beast, who has come to demand amends for his friend's life, gives her two choices.  One is to die a quick and bloody death from his razor sharp claws...and the second...is to live in the fae world forever, and never step a foot back onto mortal soil.  With literally no other choice Feyre sets on her journey with the beast, and is in for a massive shock when she realizes the fae world isn't the dark and hideous place she imagined.  And the beast is definitely not what she imagined either as he transforms into the most handsome fae man she has ever seen.  But not all is right in this beautiful fae world, and too soon Feyre realizes that some beauty simply hides pure evil.  And if she is to survive this new world she must gather and use all her wits, learn to trust her own instincts, and most importantly...hide her softening heart.I almost felt slightly biased in writing a review for A Court of Thorns and Roses as I totally adored the Throne of Glass series by Sarah J. Maas, and this has along the same theme.  The characters here were portrayed nicely, and I totally fell in love with the side characters such as Rhys and Lucien.  Seriously, I loved all the characters, and, if I'm being totally honest, my favorite characters were the villains.  I adore a good villain especially when it's those you love to hate, and Maas did a good job writing them. The plot was great, and moved along nicely, but I will totally admit to being completely bored in the middle of the book.  Nothing, and I mean nothing happened versus Feyre getting drunk, making goo-goo eyes at Tamlin, and a few side characters were introduced.  I was seriously getting sick of her mooing over him, and talking about the colors that surrounded her (she likes to paint).  Another thing I didn't truly find to my liking was the fact that she was supposed to be tough from years of hunting, but seriously we don't see her doing much till the end.  If I was in fae land with a warrior with creepy creatures that would like to eat me, I definitely would want to know how to use a knife or a sword.  Just saying. Also Throne of Glass was YA, but this book doesn't fit totally into that category.  Take out the sex, and then you definitely would have a YA novel on your hands, so be forewarned if you're looking into this series for a young teen.  Definitely for older teens and adults.  Again, I did love this book, loved the side characters, and the story line flowed pretty well.  I just got a little bored midway through, and wished Feyre would've shown just a little more gumption.  Luckily the book did pick up big time closer to the end, and while it doesn't leave us with a huge cliffhanger, there was something said that makes you wonder what will happen next.  I still liked this book a lot, even with the few shortcomings I found in Feyre, and I seriously can't wait to see what happens for our heroine in the future!

I have an amazing little five year old niece who attacked this play set like it was her new best friend!  In seconds we had the teacher "desk," and student "desk" pulled down, and she was already scribbling away on the wash off boards!  This awesome set is, as many reviewers posted, cardboard.  So don't expect a high dollar play set, but yet, still expect that your kids are going to have a wonderful time playing with it!  The play set does include a small pointer, cool stickers that do not stick to any surfaces but the wash off boards, a neat little timer, a little eraser, dry erase markers, a teacher planner book, shapes, and a few dry erase boards with activities on them.  I did end up buying her extra colorful dry erase markers, and she did like those much better than the ones that came with it. I also printed off a few activity pages for teachers online to give to students, and extra little hall passes, and other teacher related handouts, and I have seriously never seen her so enthralled with a play set before!  Her older cousin came over, and they were both fighting over who got to be the teacher!  This set might be cardboard, and therefore I wouldn't recommend for younger kids who might be rough, but my two nieces had the best time ever with it, and they were still playing with it hours later!  This is definitely a cute play set that does have a handy little handle on the top, and the inside opens easily to place all the items back in for a neat storage solution.  The Melissa and Doug School Time play set was a hit, and I think I am officially the best Aunt ever!

I have always used Biore Cleansing Pore Strips, and love the fact that they help remove blackheads from my nose area, and when I saw the Charcoal Pore Strips that helped excess oil I knew I had to try them!These nose strips are the polar opposite in looks compared to the normal nose strip as the charcoal laced strip is pure black with the material side still having that same texture, just in a darker hue due to the charcoal.  The reverse side of it that goes on your nose is pure black, but has that same smooth, silky feel as before. I would advise to totally make sure your hands are fully dried before touching this product!  I had a little water on my hands from wetting my nose, and when I touched the charcoal strips smooth side I had charcoal smeared all over my fingers.  It's just like a charcoal drawing pencil, but it does wash off easily.  Applying the nose strips are easy, and same as before, wash face, dry face, wet nose, (I always pull a little on the pre-made slits to open them so they can easily stretch to fit nicely across my nose), peel off the strip, and apply to your wet nose.  If you haven't used the product before, then you definitely want to know to push the material around the curvature of your nostril on both sides to get the material to stick, and work properly.  I find that when I don't do this I don't get near as good results as it doesn't fully adhere to the curve of my nostrils just by patting it on alone.  Normally I do let this dry for a full fifteen minutes before pulling it off, but because of the charcoal factor, I ended up pulling it off in eleven minutes just in case I had a reaction to it.  Needless to say, I found this product to work flawlessly!!  When I did the normal strips, it always left my nose with the nasty residue and made it feel weird.  With these charcoal nose strips, my nose felt very smooth and clean with only a little charcoal left on my nose where I applied it and it slid on my skin when I was pushing it around the curvature of my nose.  It was easily wiped off, but seriously these felt great on my nose, and my nose didn't feel stiff at all afterwards as it normally does with the regular pore strips!  As for the oil, I did this before I went to bed, and I have very oily skin, and I did notice that area wasn't as oily as it normally is, and throughout my day my nose did appear drier.  However, that only lasted a little while before it was back to normal.In all I truly like these nose strips better than the original, and will continue to buy these.  I also like the fact that it's so dark that you can easily see the results once the strip is pulled off.  On the normal ones you always had to look close to see if it even halfway worked, while on these charcoal ones you can definitely see the results.  In that end, I almost felt like these worked better, but, again, I know it's only because I could truly "see" the results on the dark material versus the lighter one.  Biore is definitely a product I love, and for me it works perfectly!

Who wouldn't love to be the embodiment of a goddess?  A female who is catered to, lives in luxury in a castle with people holding you on a pedestal, and betrothed to a prince?  Twylla seemingly has it all, a young peasant girl who was found as the vessel of a goddess as a child, and whisked away to the castle to live in relative peace...that is if you count the role she must play as executioner to traitors.  Because being the embodiment of a goddess also comes with the heavy price of drinking a vial of poison, living because of who you are to the gods, and yet having the poison ooze from your skin, and the slightest contact with a living individual would result in their instant death. Hugs are definitely not coming Twylla's way anytime soon.  So she lives a very solitary life, praying, sewing, killing, and having a so called friend in the only guard that continues to watch over her.  But on a fateful day he is taken ill, and a new guard, with a more than friendly smile, takes his place.  Never has her heart beat so fast from one kind smile from her new guard, but imagine her surprise when the prince returns, and has eyes only for her.  Twylla is in a very dire predicament as one false move could prove deadly in the eyes of the demented queen who rules with an iron fist.  With secrets abounding, and twist and turns at every corner, Twylla soon realizes that in order to have the peace she desires her role of executioner must come to an end.The Sin Eater's Daughter was a very unusual tale, and I will admit to totally being sucked into it from the very beginning.  It was nothing that I've personally read before, and the concepts were highly interesting of how life was lived at this court, and their customs, gods, and other beliefs as well as how the royals ruled.  I loved seeing that aspect, and I truly did love the characters in the book.  They were all well written, including the villain.  There were twist and turns that I totally did not see coming, and that just kept the book entertaining!  It is a short novel, but I do think it was perfectly written in length as adding anymore would more than likely just be extra fluff.  Again I loved the plot, but there was one weird part in how a story was set up that just seemed thrown in versus tied together.  I don't know if a sequel will be made, but it did leave it open in that regard, but there is definitely no cliffhanger here.  I will also say that I did get bored in the romance scenes, and skimmed over them, as I found Twylla to be too star struck, but that's just me.  The Sin Eater's Daughter was truly a good, light, short read, and it was very entertaining.  There are some areas where I found Twylla to be way too nave, but she was stuck in a castle with no friends, so I guess the naivety isn't too far off if in that situation.  Again, it was still a good read, and I do recommend it if you don't mind a tiny love triangle, that was basically one sided, a bit of romance, intrigue, and fantasy all mixed together!

This was a fun project that was really relaxing to do.  The kit comes with the canvas printed on it in a light color that the paint can overcome, along with paint brushes for detailing areas, the paint itself, a small picture of what the painting is supposed to look like when finished, and a large piece of folded paper that shows the picture with all the numbers on it for reference.  The canvas was folded in half, and then folded again, and I took the initiative from other reviewers on this brand of product, and ironed it gently before I started, which worked very nicely.  It didn't get all the lines out, but as I finished my painting you honestly can't see it any more.  There are some areas, such as areas in the water, and on the houses that aren't marked at all, and have this very light yellowish/khaki color on it.  In the actual picture online it shows the roofs with a mix of black and brown, and also near the waters edge, the colors are slightly different too.  So definitely know there is color variation in this painting, and won't look exactly like the original you see online.  The khaki color on the sides of the tree are also much darker in color.  There are paint pots in the rows with just dots on them, and I did read that these are for more detailing, and I will go back and paint the roofs and play around to get it a little more detail.  I find the boat on mine isn't that distinguishable as a boat, so I'll go back over it and try to even out some lines.  I also did go out and buy some extra tiny brushes, which definitely helped as the ones that come with it have long and thin strands, while I needed a paint brush with short strands for the tiny detail work.  This truly was a great, fun project, and I'm glad I bought it even though the colors weren't as pictured.

Checking our blood pressure has always been in our routine, especially since both my husbands and my parents have high blood pressure.  And needless to say, we keep check of their blood pressure as well. The only thing I hated was actually having to write down our blood pressure to keep tabs on it.  But with the Omron 7 Series blood pressure monitor, that is now a thing of the past!Upon opening the device, you will find the blood pressure cuff, monitor, batteries for the device, and an instruction manual.  The first thing we did was read quickly through the manual, as they are pretty much all the same in regard to pressing a button to activate the device.  But we did according to the manual, set up the time and date, which was highly easy, and we were ready to go!  All the buttons on this device are definitely friendly as they are pretty large, and easy to press.  There is also a user 1, and a user 2 switch, which really made my day!  Because now we can keep track of his on user 1, and me on user 2.  The switch is easy to push, and easy to read so there is no mistaking which one I have it on.  The cuff itself feels great on my arm, and I am super skinny, but when the air puffs in it works fine, and I also don't feel like my arm is being squeezed off by a cobra.  My husband on the other hand, has very large biceps, and the cuff works perfectly on him too.  It only takes a few seconds for this monitor to get your results, and they are on the display in large clear numbers.  Another of my favorite things about the Omron blood pressure monitor is that you can download the app for it on your cell phone, or other device, and it will save your results!  All you have to do is enter a little information, and if you already took results on the monitor it's totally fine!  Just open the app, it will tell you to turn on your bluetooth, and you'll notice little squares on the display screen of the blood pressure monitor while it's pairing.  As soon as it finds your cell phone, the information syncs to your phone, and that's it!  All information is stored in your phone or other device for easy access!This has been the best blood pressure monitor, and my parents are already asking me for one as it's easy to use, with a clear distinct display, easy buttons to press, and it works great with definite accuracy!  I have another blood pressure monitor, and the results were always the same with perhaps a number or two different.  A definite great buy!

I was very iffy on giving the rating I did simply because it does work as it's designed to; however I felt there were a few flaws.The Rapesco Flat Clinch Top Loading Stapler does the job it was supposed to for starters. It's a decent stapler, with a beautiful design in the dark blue color with grey accents on the bottom, and below the staple cavity.  It's very easy to open the top part for loading staples with no tugging or pulling as seen in other brands.  This is just a clean upward pull, and the top opens easily and smoothly.  Inside the staple cavity you will note that it is pretty small, and doesn't hold that many staples.  As a person who works in an office setting stapling invoices for the better part of the day, that means a lot of reloading, which can get annoying very quickly. When closing the stapler, I found that this is seriously the smoothest closing top half that I've come across.  There is barely a noticeable snick as the top half of the staple cavity clicks into place.  I really like that a lot as it's a smooth transition to close it.The Rapesco stapler's top half can also be pulled up with a much harder pull to allow for stapling on items such as a wall, cork board, etc. As for the bottom of the device, it features a smooth rubber type bottom with ridges to help with sliding on smooth surfaces, and the best feature of all on the bottom is a little window that houses a removable tab.  Once you pop off the tab at the bottom a little white card is available for you to write down your name.  I went ahead and printed my name on a label, and attached it to the white card.  It was easy to pop it back into place, and now no one will steal my stapler!  You may laugh, but I swear I have names on the majority of my office supplies so they don't grow legs and walk away.And lastly, for the actual stapling, it works just as any other stapler, but with staples that instead of curve, produce a nice straight line.  This really does help as I don't get stuck with staples any more.  It is, again, a smooth process of stapling papers with a simple click.  It states that you can do around 20-24 pieces of paper in one stack, and that's truly about right.  I did 22 pages, and while I wasn't bearing all my weight on it by any means, it still took a decent amount of pressure to get the staple through that many pages.  I did try 30 pages, and that was a no go as it only stuck my staple in the first few pages, not all the way through them.  The other issue that I found is that this stapler is larger in height than many normal office staplers, and I find that I have trouble trying to grab it off my desk and get my hand around it at times because of this.  I am a small female, with small hands, and while I can still staple items, it does take a little bit of fumbling for a second or two before I have it firmly grasped.  I also found the staples that came with it, when I tried getting the staple out that it did break in half, so they are pretty weak.  This does take normal staples for a regular stapler, so that's good, but I did have to break a line of staples up into sections as one whole line wouldn't fit in the chamber.  When a staple ended with the last one, and a new "stack" slid into place for stapling, it was an easy transition with no staples getting stuck either.The Rapesco Clinch Stapler is a good, small stapler that does come in handy, and I do love the fact that I can grab a stapled stack of invoices without getting stuck by sharp ends.  While it can't hold as many staples, it still holds enough, is light weight, and has that awesome name plate window!  Perhaps I'll get used to the larger grip on this one, but it definitely does replace my old regular stapler!

I personally believe you already have to like Ms. Black's style of writing before you even attempt to read her novels as they are not only gorgeously put together, but most times, so dark and twisted, you're not sure which end is up, and more often than not, you're left feeling slightly disturbed.  And The Dark Part of the Forest doesn't disappoint in this highly intoxicating, odd read!Instead of a normal fairytale, where fairies exist as beautiful little winged creatures that alight around you in glee, Black's fairies are more the type that will lull you with their beauty...then eat you in one gulp.  Much like her other tales, The Darkest Part of the Forest is both gritty and exciting, with dark undertones that easily suck a person in!Hazel and her brother Ben live in a town like no other, a town that holds mystery, a sense of other, shadows that seemingly shift before your eyes, and it's very own attraction that tourist flock to.  An attraction that held Hazel and Ben's attention from children to the teenagers they are now as they both still gape any time they are around the glass coffin in the woods that houses the most mysterious and magical creature of all.  A fiercely handsome boy asleep for centuries dressed in clothes of old, with the smoothest, milkiest skin, the darkest of hair, and the curviest horns protruding from his head to curl around his pointed ears.  This fairy boy has been the catalyst for many of their adventures as children, and soon, he will be the catalyst for one more as his glass coffin is found broken, with the fairy boy gone.  And while this information is rattling at the least, Hazel is even more shocked to wake up to find her bedroom window open, her feet covered in mud, and a cryptic message written on her wall.  Hazel's intuition tells her something is coming her way, and with the help of her crush, and Ben's best friend she hopes to unravel it, and it must be done quickly as her time is growing short to save those she holds dear.I adored The Darkest Part of the Forest so much that I have currently started reading it again!  The first time I listened to this story over audio, and the narrator did an amazingly awesome job with the voices! This time around, I'm actually reading the book, and it's just as good the second time!  The plot is spectacular, with both good and evil fighting a battle, and with Black, there's always a lot of gray areas in between those morals that make a person think.  I loved all the characters as each one brought a piece of something different to the tale, that made it that much more enchanting!  This book is also told mostly in Hazel's point of view, but it does switch to Ben a time or two.  Again, this book is definitely one of the best books I've read this year, and I hate that this one does end.  I almost wish it had a cliff hanger so I could read more!

Tommy Flanagan has many fine albums to his credit, but this isn't one of them. Most of the blame can be assigned to bassist Ron Carter, whose overbearing, funk-oriented sound is out of synch with Flanagan. Tony Williams' drum work also lacks subtlety, and while he does less damage than Carter, together they end up sinking what should have been a good session.Those who are new to Tommy Flanagan's work as a leader, or want to add to what they have, would find any of the following discs from later in his career far more satisfying: Beyond the Bluebird, Nights at the Vanguard, Jazz Poet, Sunset & Mockingbird - Birthday Concert, Lady Be Good... For Ella, and Sea Changes. Flanagan recorded a terrific solo album in 1977 (Alone Too Long), and his earlier work also includes a couple of gems: Overseas and Moodsville Vol. 9: The Tommy Flanagan Trio.Two and a half stars may seem a little harsh, but two out of the three players are on such a different wavelength here that this is an album I can barely listen to.

Having enjoyed Richard Wyands' "Half and Half" (2000) and "As Long as There's Music" (2001), I ventured into the slightly earlier "Get Out of Town" (1997), which like the later albums also feature Kenny and Peter Washington. This is a top-notch effort all the way. Wyands' choice of material is exceptional, including Thad Jones' "Mean What You Say," Ellington's little-known "Angelica" and the rarely heard "I Don't Want to Cry Anymore" from Victor Schertzinger. Wyands, a musician of versatility and subtlety, projects "Angelica" with just the right bounce, while his ballad work on "Why Did I Choose You" reflects a veteran's wisdom where structure and sensitivity go hand in hand. While his treatment of "I Don't Want to Cry Anymore" is worlds apart from Ellis Larkin's gorgeous statement (Live at Maybeck Hall Volume 22), after a couple of listens I decided I wouldn't trade one for the other. Wyands' brings plenty of new ideas even to the overfamiliar "Jitterbug Waltz," which departs from the theme after the first few bars; and "Yardbird Suite" too benefits from the pianist's lively (but thankfully not overactive) imagination.Kenny and Peter Washington prove to be true partners in the best sense of the word, never overstating anything. Many modern players could learn alot from these guys, who are in complete sympathy with their leader.Five stars.

This set has been around for a long time under the Sony label, thus there are a variety of reviews to sample in that incarnation (Mozart: Piano Sonatas). My own view is that De Larrocha's Mozart, while good, is not on par with her recordings of Spanish music. Her playing offers refinement and clarity, but it often lacks the sparkle that distinguishes her best recordings (Icon: Alicia De Larrocha).,The best Mozart cycle among those I'm familiar with is that of Klara Wurtz, and I would recommend it despite the less than ideal sound (Mozart: Complete Piano Sonatas). Without going into a point by point comparison, I would summarize the differences between the two pianists by saying that Wurtz's Mozart is consistently fresh and inspired where De Larrocha's frequently lapses into routine and, at its worst, sounds polite.Three stars.

Prior to acquiring this set I was familiar with perhaps a third of Haydn's keyboard sonatas, so hearing the thirty-odd works that were new to me was a wonderful discovery. (As an aside, I say "works" because this cycle, presented in sequential order, follows the Hoboken numbering system under which pieces that were originally published as divertimentos and partitas are counted as sonatas.)  I can't say that everything here is on the same creative level - for example, I pretty much passed over the first disc of early pieces - but Haydn's genius was already in full flower as evidenced by the material on the third disc.Walter Olbertz, although not well known, is a very capable pianist with a modern outlook. His playing is solid as a rock, colorful and idiomatic, and is also appropriately energetic, but not turbocharged like Hamelin's whose Haydn sonatas can be vehicles for gratuitous displays of technique. Olbertz is also not overfast like Jendo, and vastly more poetic. As to a couple of specifics: Olbertz's traversals of the 20th and 38th sonatas, familiar territory to me through recordings by Brendel and Horowitz, compare very well with those of his more famous colleagues. While the 22nd sounds flatfooted beside Richter's (Richter in Spoleto), the 34th is more lively than Brendel's. In fact, all of Olbertz's readings measure up exceptionally well beside Brendel's, whose Haydn recordings I admire (Haydn: Piano Sonatas). Olbertz also matches up very well against Schiff, whose Haydn set I liked in the past (Piano Sonatas).This cycle, recorded between 1973 and 1978, offers very good sound.Solidly recommended.

Serkin recorded these concertos in 1953 (C minor) and 1954 (C major), a period when he was still very much in his Toscanini mode, which is to say that speed was almost everything. I don't care for the tempo he adopts from the get go of the C minor concerto, and while the execution is faultless, he's just too fast. While the Largo is very pretty, Serkin shifts back into overdrive in the Rondo, although the pace is a bit more measured. The C minor concerto fares somewhat better, but Serkin still favors brilliance over poetry and the music suffers. Again, the first movement is too brisk, almost bloodless, and the Largo is the high point. The Rondo is reasonably balanced, but Serkin seems to want to break out wherever he can. Ormandy does a good job in both concertos, but the soloist is calling the shots.

A number of the recordings in this collection served as my introduction to Mozart's piano concertos, and while I have long since moved on to other pastures, listening again after a decades-long interval left me amazed at how well many of these performances have held up. Without offering commentary on each concerto, an unnecessary labor given the token amount being asked for this download, let me just say that the overall quality is high, and that there are a few performances that number among my all time favorites. The Brendel/Klien recording of the two piano concerto is a genuine classic, and listeners would be well rewarded to have paid $2.99 for that alone. The Brendel performances are the real stars of the show here though: they project tons of energy and personality and for the most part supersede the pianist's later recordings with Neville Marriner, most of which are bland by comparison. While Walter Klien is a good Mozartian, his approach in the concertos in which he is featured is often a little too gentle. Klien's rendering of the 17th concerto is exceptional though, and compares well with Anda's famous record. On the other hand his reading of the 21st concerto is disappointingly colorless, probably the low point of this set.For the most part, the orchestras offer spirited support and are a welcome relief from the over-refined Mozart productions that have prevailed since the 1970's.Five stars.

My primary interest in buying "The Liszt Legacy" was to hear the Arrau and De Larrocha recordings, and my five star rating applies to them alone. I haven't sampled anything else in the set other than the Egon Petri recordings, about which I've commented on below.The pianists included in "The Liszt Legacy" are presented in alphabetical order; thus the Arrau recordings, which were made for American Decca in 1954, appear first. This is the first cd release of this material - five Beethoven sonatas and the Chopin Op. 49 Fantasy - and while it should be of particular interest to Arrau collectors, it's also a superb introduction the great pianist's art.The program opens with the late "Hammerklavier," and proceeds with opp. 13, 27 no. 2, 57 and 81a. While I would have programmed the sonatas in a different order, the "Hammerklavier" is certainly a stunning opening salvo for anyone delving into this set, especially if they were new to Arrau's work. It's also a perfect example of how the pianist's approach evolved over the years between 1954 and 1963, when Arrau recorded the sonata again for Philips. (Arrau went on to re-record two of the Beethoven sonatas included in this set for EMI, "Appassionata" & "Les Adieux," as well as seven others.) The timings of the movements are almost identical, but the placement of emphasis is not. The Decca recording can sound almost matter of fact in certain places compared to the more intense re-make, and while there's nothing that could be described as ordinary about the earlier reading, by the time of the Philips recording the sixty year-old Arrau was reaching for the stars. The footprints of Arrau's approach are the same, having been established well back in time, so the differences between the Decca and Philips "Hammerklavier" are matters of subtlety rather than substance. Still, if I were to choose, I would opt for Philips over Decca despite the fugue, which is a real tour de force.There is no question that the rest of the sonatas benefit from Arrau's fresher approach circa 1954, versus the weightier 1960's recordings for Philips. "Les Adieux" has just enough of the pathos of the later recording, but it exceeds it in technical brilliance (as does Arrau's 1958 reading for EMI). The "Moonlight" and "Pathetique" sonatas too are a little tighter with a slightly more natural feel than the Philips remakes. The "Appassionata," one of Arrau's specialties, is magnificent here - architecture, drama, sweep, and propulsive forward momentum without a hint of rushing. All of these sonatas have a slightly heavier feel in the Philips edition, perhaps because Arrau had by then more fully deployed his arm/body weight approach to the keyboard. Even though the timings don't differ much, the Decca recordings sound fleeter and more percussive, which was typical of Arrau's style at the time. In any case, these sonatas are brilliant snapshots of middle period Arrau that I would not want to be without.The two discs of Spanish music from Alicia De Larrocha are a pure delight. All of the selections are first rate, with the Spanish pianist demonstrating unrivalled authority even in these early recordings (1954-56). If anything, her 1955 Goyescas is preferable to her Hispavox recording from 1963, sounding more whimsical and inspired.  (By the way, Claudio Arrau, who rarely commented on other pianists, was an early admirer of De Larrocha, calling her "a wonderful, sensitive and extremely musical pianist" and included her Decca recording of "Los requiebros" from Goyescas among his 10 desert island selections in a 1960 BBC program.) De Larrocha's traversal of Granados' "Escenas romanticas" are moody and atmospheric, as too are her renderings of Frederic Mompou's "Impresiones Intimas." This is all great music, and anyone who admires De Larrocha would find the two discs in this collection devoted to her art very rewarding.The Egon Petri disc devoted to Bach was recorded for Westminster in 1956. The only thing I'd heard from this pianist was his Westminster recording of the "Hammerklavier" sonata, which I recall as too cool and academic. I was not surprised then to find Petri's Bach a bit dry and pedantic in places. For example, the Toccata and Fugue in C major sound almost curt compared to Horowitz's expansive Carnegie Hall reading; and ditto the Prelude and Fugue in D major when compared with Gilels' majestic reading, also from Carnegie Hall. The Liszt disc, on the other hand, shows the pianist in brilliantly inspired form, sounding as if he were having fun with the music. In fact, the differences between his Liszt and Bach are so significant that in a blindfold test I would never have identified these recordings as the work of the same pianist.While I plan to eventually sample the Lewenthal and Moiseiwitsch material, the Arrau and De Larrocha recordings are by themselves worth the price of this set.

Amazingly, this is the first cd release of Lazar Berman's fabulous 1975 recording of Rachmaninoff's "Moments Musicaux" (originally coupled with Prokofiev's 8th sonata on a Deutsche Grammophone LP). Berman, who had a rather narrow repertoire, had a perfect grasp of each of the six pieces in this suite. The opening nocturne is beautifully played, with the transitions between the three parts handled masterfully. The scherzo-like second movement is a swirling Russian fantasy in Berman's hands, whereas the more somber third is perfectly paced, never sounding funereal like Horowitz. The fourth movement is a tour de force of pianism, with Berman unleashing controlled waves of energy - watch him playing this in recital on youtube and you'll see how easy he makes this music sound. The fifth movement is pure poetry, and while I've always thought that Rachmaninoff had run out of ideas when he penned the sixth movement, Berman still does the best he can with it.The rest of this disc is taken up with the balance of Berman's solo DG recordings of Rachaminoff, all of which were made in 1980. Of principal interest is his recording of the Corelli Variations, a very fine effort although I prefer Ashkenazy's ethereal 1972 recording for Decca despite the less than optimal sound (Rachmaninov: Music for 2 Pianos - Suites Nos. 1 & 2, Opp.5,17 / Etude-Tableau, Op.33 / Symphonic Dances, Op.45 / Russian Rhapsody / Corelli Variations, Op.42). Berman's renderings of the six preludes included here are quite exceptional. While I could have done without the C sharp minor, a warhorse that the composer himself grew sick and tired of playing, Berman has as much to offer in the rest of this music as Richter and Horowitz. While Berman doesn't work himself up into a frenzy the way Horowitz does in op. 32, no. 12, there's still drama combined with a stateliness to it that's quite appealing. The op. 32 no. 10 prelude which follows is very poetic, and while it can't replace Richter's Carnegie Hall recording (Richter Rediscovered: Carnegie Hall Recital 1960), Berman's conception projects a sort of grandeur that's pure Rachmaninoff. The disc closes with a riveting traversal of op. 23 no. 2, which is every bit as good as Richter's classic 1959 recording for the same label (available on Pianist of the Century ~ Sviatoslav Richter).Very highly recommended.

"Melville Goodwin USA" was not well received by the critics when it was published in 1952, and it turned out to be John Marquand's poorest selling book to date. The reader discovers that there's a plot only after slogging through the first two-thirds of the book, and by that time can't be blamed for caring little about how things turn out. What "Melville Goodwin" needed was an editor who could convince the author that there were at least 100 pages that could have been cut from the manuscript.Still, there are rewards for the persevering reader: Marquand's uncanny ability to convey a scene, whether a tract house in suburban Washington or a general's office in the Pentagon, always places you squarely in the picture. And his self-conflicted characters and many wry observations, which ultimately redeem "Melville Goodwin" from the tedium of excess, are served up with far more finesse than anything Sinclair Lewis ever wrote. Mostly, what you get from "Melville Goodwin" is a good dose of Marquand's cynicism delivered in his typical fashion, with velvet gloves.Three and a half stars.

Before Vivaldi composed the great concerto cycles for which he is best remembered today, he wrote a number of works in the concerto a quattro form. Precursors to the concerto for solo instrument and ensemble, concerti a quattro were written for ensembles in which most or all of the instrumental parts were doubled. Michael Talbot writes in his informative liner notes that these concerti "favored a brilliant, flamboyant style of writing in which the outer parts - first violins and bass instruments - were emphasized at the expense of inner parts. The extraction of one or more solo parts in certain passages was a slightly later development - but one that proved so popular that the so called 'solo' concerto, for violin and another instrument, completely eclipsed the concerto a quattro by about 1710. Indeed, from that time onwards a concerto without a solo instrument has seemed a curiosity requiring special explanation."Vivaldi wrote at least 40 concerti a quattro, nine of which were selected by I Musici for this recording. While Mr. Talbot, a noted scholar who specializes in Baroque music, writes that Vivaldi's concerti a quattro "are among the most individually conceived of his works," listeners who are expecting them to compare well with the better known concertos are bound to be disappointed. These are far simpler conceptions with none of the grand sweep and wonderful melodies found in many of the concerti within La Cetra, L'estro armanico, La stravaganza etc. The net result is that despite being well played, not much of the music is particularly memorable.Three and a half stars.

Alicia de Larrocha's Hispavox recordings, which I came to know in the 1970's through Musical Heritage Society licensed LP's, were my introduction to the Spanish piano repertoire. And what a fabulous journey of discovery it was. Even though I had heard no other pianist in this repertoire other than Arrau's Iberia and Rubinstein's Navarra, Larrocha's recordings were so captivating I hardly bothered looking elsewhere. As it turned out, critics and colleagues who had heard her early on were aware of her extraordinary way with Spanish music. New York Times music critic Harold Schonberg wrote of the Spanish works in her 1955 Town Hall debut that "she had a way of idiomatically shaping a musical phrase that cannot be taught -- a sudden dynamic shift, a note instinctively accented, a touch of the pedal, an application of rubato.... Obviously this music is in the pianist's blood. She invested it with a degree of life and imagination that not many pianists before the public today could begin to duplicate." A few years later Claudio Arrau, who rarely commented publicly on other pianists, called Alicia de Larrocha "a wonderful, sensitive and extremely musical pianist," and included one of her recordings among his desert island recommendations for BBC radio in 1960. Her manager, Herbert Breslin, observed in 1978 that "There are two kinds of repertory Alicia plays. Things she plays extremely well, and things she plays better than anyone else. But what I think makes her a phenomenon is that she doesn't give the impression of being a great personality. She's cool as a cucumber. Onstage, she doesn't even like to look at the audience. So what the public is responding to is something in the music."The Hispavox recordings collected in this Icon set are better at projecting that unique "something" which Breslin spoke about than most of Larrocha's later recordings for Decca and RCA. While many of those are of a very high caliber, the Hispavox recordings are generally fresher and more inspired. To cite just two examples: the 1964 recording of Granados' op. 37 "Dances," which brims with energy and charisma - a spirit that permeates all of the recordings assembled here - and the 1963 Goyescas which stands above the 1982 Decca remake.Even if you have Alicia de Larrocha's Decca or RCA recordings of these works, I wouldn't let that stop you from acquiring this landmark collection. The liner notes are exceptional, and include a personal tribute from the pianist's daughter, Alicia Torra de Larrocha, as well as an anecdotal essay by Gregor Benko. And while the sonics can be variable, ranging from superb to congested and metallic-sounding, I was surprised to find that some of the older recordings actually sound better than those Larrocha made for Decca. A case in point is the 1964 recording of Granados' Danzas Españolas which is vastly superior to the hard and dim Decca recording from 1982. (As an aside, a number of recordings are listed in the notes with 1992 copyright dates, which are not to be mistaken for recording dates. For example, Albeniz' Cantos De España was recorded in 1959, but since it was first issued on an EMI cd in 1992, that's the date reflected in the notes.)Highest recommendation.

This is the fourth installment in a series of Ansermet discs issued by Decca in 1992 that focus on the conductor's recordings of French music; but unlike the earlier volumes, it includes less essential repertoire.The star of the program, and the reason why I acquired this disc, is Ansermet's wonderful recording of Debussy's "La Boite a jouxjoux," which dates from near the end of the composer's career. Francois Hudry's liner notes describe the piece as a "ballet for marionettes set in a toybox.... The touching, if slim, subject matter is a story of a wooden soldier who is wounded and cared for by a doll, who falls in love with him." Hudry adds that "Ansermet was particularly fond of this subtle score, which is full of references to the magical world of toys and childhood." I tend not to think of the program, and instead appreciate the music for the enchanting spell it casts.The rest of the program is almost an afterthought: two movements from La Peri, a ballet score by Paul Dukas from 1912, and The Sorcerer's Apprentice, which benefits from a very colorful but subtle reading.The liner notes are valuable. In addition to some critical observations from Hudry, who writes that Ansermet "moulded [the Suisse Romande orchestra] in his own image, obliging the players, sometimes inflexibly, to tackle his favorite repertoire" and calls his reign "almost despotic," the notes also offer interesting photographs of Ansermet, including one of him at the piano in his study with framed photos of Toscanini, Casadesus and Lipatti among others in view, plus a 1917 sketch of the conductor by Picasso.Five stars for La Boite a jouxjoux.

I Musici's Corelli recordings have had a place in my music library for a good many years, as have Neville Marriner's, but I Musici's are the ones to have. The sound of their strings is just fabulous; and while the period instrument folks may be put off, I think Corelli himself would be elated by I Musici's high octane realizations.It's worthwhile sharing Gramophone's 1973 review of one of the original LP's that this set was drawn from:"There is some splendid string playing here: alert, strong, well balanced, and ready to allow an unusual degree of dynamic contrast to the music. Additionally, the number of strings used allows arguably exactly the right degree of contrast between solo and tutti: clearly to be distinguished, yet neither out of scale with the other. The distinction is helped by a contrast in the keyboard element of the continuo: in general, harpsichord for the solo passages, organ for the tuttis. The harpsichord adds little, as it happens; perhaps its backward placing--nothing new with I Musici--discouraged the player from any specially exacting use of the imagination. The organ (a wooden--literally--imitation by Armagni of a baroque model) is more audible, and contributes an effective support to what is already a pretty strong sound."In total the performances are not only strong but stylish: ornamentation is scattered only thinly, but this could not necessarily be rated a defect in these particular concertos.
