There is a bravely imaginative reading of the Fourth Concerto's finale, where Corelli's notation of even quavers is read as indicating a triplet crotchet and quaver effect in order to tally with the prevailing triplet rhythm. Reliable authorities have hinted for some time that this was Corelli's intention (and that of other Italian composers of the period); certainly putting the theory into practice does allow the music on this occasion a new vigour. Added to the more general virtues--which include good, clear recording--this final stroke leaves no doubt that this must be a strongly recommended issue."The sound is incredibly rich, in fact much better than some of the later digital recordings from this ensemble. The cover art, on the other hand, leaves me completely cold - but that's true of most of Philips' Duos releases.Five stars.

These venerable recordings were staples of the music catalog right through the LP era, and while there are now countless options to choose from that cover the same repertoire I still think of Ansermet's records as the gold standard. His Debussy is uniquely authoritative  - to cite just one example, the composer consulted with Ansermet and agreed to make modifications to his Nocturnes in accordance with the conductor's suggestions - and the recordings he made with the Suisse Romande orchestra, which he founded in 1940, reflect a special insight rarely heard elsewhere.Ansermet's association with Images went back to its premiere performance, which he attended (as did Ravel). His approach is atmospheric, colorful, and structurally solid, and as anyone who has heard his classic Falla recordings will know, his grasp of the Spanish idiom was unparalleled (see Falla: Three-Cornered Hat / Ansermet, Berganza). Despite having always admired Argenta's reference recording (España--Chabrier, Granados / Argenta, London Symphony Orchestra), Ansermet's exceeds it.Ansermet's Nocturnes are quite beautiful, however, here the conductor is up against Stokowski's 1957 recording with the London Symphony Orchestra (Debussy: Nocturnes / Iberia / Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun ~ Stokowski), one of the truly great recordings of the 20th century. Ansermet is a very close second; and while he summons up plenty of mystery, he's not quite as ethereal as Stokowski.Printemps, Debussy's first important symphonic work, is sandwiched between Images and the Nocturnes.  That recording dates from 1957, as does Nocturnes, whereas Images comes from 1961. All three offer the superior sound that Decca's engineers were renowned for producing.An assessment from the writer of the liner notes sums up the conductor's work without hyperbole, stating: "Balance, precision, a beautiful style and a warm interpretation: these are the hallmarks of Ansermet's performances, and the reasons why his art will always be unaffected by fashion and false traditions, and continue to have the power to move the listener."Five stars.

This Vivaldi collection mostly dates from relatively early in I Musici's recording career, with the first four concertos (tracks1-12) coming from 1960, the concerto for two trumpets from 1965, and the other concerto from 1972. In addition to the trumpet concerto, there are concertos for two violins, flutes, mandolins, oboes and cellos, so there's a lot of variety to the music. The playing is trademark I Musici, which is to say, full, vibrant, modern sounding but idiomatic. The recorded sound is mostly fine, with the exception of some background noise that's noticeable during the solos on the flute concerto.This disc is also available on Decca Eloquence, with new copies readily available for a few dollars at the time of this writing (Concerti). The Decca disc also includes a double violin concerto (RV 552), which adds an extra fourteen minutes of music.Five stars.

While this disc headlines Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition" and "Night on Bald Mountain," the jewel here is buried in the last track in the program, Ernest Ansermet's recording of Balakirev's extraordinary tone poem, "Tamara."Tamara was based on a ballad by Lermontov, who was himself inspired by an ancient legend he encountered while exiled to the Caucasus. While programatic in nature Balakirev's music transcends the story line, which is about a beautiful (but evil) princess who lures travelers to her enchanted castle in the Caucasus, then murders her guests after a passionate night and dumps their bodies in the river Trek. Not a happy outcome, but the listener is transported on a magic carpet to the inner and outer landscape of Mother Russia. Tamara is wrapped in an Oriental cloud, and while there's a dark moodiness that runs through it, the atmosphere is much more one of mystery than foreboding. You won't hear the sleigh bells of Rachmaninoff, nor the enchantment of Rimsky-Korsakov's "Christmas Eve," but in the midst of swirling rivers of sound are glimpses of snow covered trees silhouetted in darkness. The entire effect is almost mystical, thanks to Ansermet's masterful treatment.I was captivated from the moment I listened to Ansermet's recording on a London Stereo Treasury Series LP I bought back in the early 1970's, and while I've heard other performances of this great, under-appreciated work they don't capture the soul of the music the way this recording does.Five stars.

Over the last year a number of outstanding Arrau performances that had been sitting in various archives around the world have been appearing on cd. Discs such as Claudio Arrau Live at Tanglewood, Claudio Arrau in Recital 1969-1977, Claudio Arrau at Tanglewood and Claudio Arrau and The Romantics - previously unreleased, which have joined others that have been circulating for some time, show a side of the pianist that's quite different from the carefully sculpted studio recordings he made over the last thirty years of his life. While Arrau's solo recordings for Columbia, Brunswick and EMI, which were made between 1946 and 1962, project a good deal of the energy he brought to the stage, the Philips era which ran from 1962 until Arrau's death in 1991, marked a turning point. Then nearly sixty, Arrau was no doubt weighed down by the awareness that he was setting down permanent documents of great works of art. Indeed, in 1972 he told a "Gramophone" critic that "Live performances are, of course, more spontaneous, and they change from day to day. Out of all these experiences you try in the studio to distill the essence and this gives you a great sense of responsibility. Of course, it worries me not having an audience but I like recording none the less. You have to pull yourself together to present something that may be valid for a long time." There were a number of great records for Philips, including a Beethoven sonata cycle and some remarkable Liszt and Debussy; but there were also many recordings that were far less passionate than the performances of the same works Arrau presented in concert. Clearly he was a far freer, if not occasionally explosive artist in front of an audience, as a number of recently released live recordings now show.The performances in this new ICA release were recorded April 5, 1960 at the Swedish Radio Studios in Stockholm. At fifty-six Arrau was still a virtuoso of the first rank, and while he was already transitioning into the phase of his career where the poet-philosopher was to play more of a dominant role, the emphasis in this all-Beethoven recital was still tilted more toward the virtuoso. Since the interpretive footprints of each sonata were established long before (Arrau had been playing all of the Beethoven sonatas in recital since the early 1930's), there are no new revelations here. But what we do find is a tremendous coalescing of parts into a series of wholes captured at a moment in time when the pianist was in a particularly inspired mood. What we hear in Stockholm is a synthesis of pure poetry, intuitive vision and perfect tension.While Arrau uncovers a mountain of detail, he never gets bogged down in excessive point-making. One example will suffice: listen to the masterful way he launches the trill at the two-minute mark of the final movement of op. 110, making a powerful statement that others minimize or rush through. And there's no hint here of the inevitability or even resignation that accompanies this phrase in the recording Arrau made for Philips in 1965. The final fugue, a series of bass notes rapped out by some hands, is transformed into rolling thunder here. The Appassionata sonata, a long term specialty of Arrau, is nothing short of stunning. While Arrau's Appassionata traversals in the 1970's were remarkable for their depth, drama and technical finish, the Stockholm recital reading is molten rock from beginning to end. (It's perhaps not surprising that Arrau made what many regard as his best recording of this sonata at EMI's Abbey Road studio just a few days later, April 11/12.) The great op. 111 is more energetic than Arrau's Philips recording, which may be too Furtwanglerish for some, but I actually prefer it. Still, no one else I've heard digs into these scores this way; in fact, only one other pianist of the 20th century had the same insight into Beethoven -- Schnabel, who Arrau worshipped.ICA's sonics are not much better than acceptable mono. The volume knob needs to be turned way up to get enough sound mass, and while this brings out some background static it's not at all bothersome.Downloaders who are interested in the liner notes can get them at ICA's website.Five stars.

Michael Talbot, an English musicologist who specializes in the Italian Baroque school,  observed in his liner notes to a previous edition of this disc that "Albinoni is a good example of the composer who, having established an original and influential style at the start of his career, lacks the flexibility to keep pace with developments introduced by other composers and before long becomes an arch-conservative." Talbot goes on to say that Albinoni's later works, op. 7 (1715)  & 9 (1722) "offer no advance on op. 5  (1707), in terms of structure and instrumental idiom, though the dimensions are larger and one or two oboes appear in a solo role in several concertos."Talbot, who has written monographs on Vivaldi and Albinoni, adds that "Perhaps only Op. 5 shows the composer consistently at his best: the technical immaturity of Op. 2 has been overcome, while the facile self-repetition of the later concertos is not yet evident." This appraisal strikes me as bit harsh, for while it`s true that some of Albinoni's Op. 7 concertos sound almost interchangeable with others, the twelve concerti making up Op. 9 number among the most original and best of the composer's output.To quote Talbot one more time, "Although the emotional climate of Albinoni's music is normally cooler than that of Vivaldi's - [English musicologist] Arthur Hutchings has said that his music glows where Vivaldi's flames - there are many moments in Op. 5 where melodious urbanity gives way to passionate outbursts.... Repeated hearing will reveal how varied in mood these concertos are, despite their outward similarity." Indeed, the Op. 5 concertos are filled with inventive, uplifting music, with an abundance of wonderful melodies. The strings of I Musici make the most of these scores, delivering thick waves of plush sound. It is fortunate that Decca Eloquence has reissued this valuable disc for I can't imagine a better recording of this glorious music.Five stars.

While this disc duplicates most of the program on the Ansermet Decca "Legends" disc of 2002 (Debussy: Prelude a L'apres-Midi D'un Faune, La Mer, Jeux, Khamma), which presumably was meant to be a single disc collection of the best of the conductor's Debussy recordings, the fact is that this 1992 release does the job better. The primary difference is that this disc includes Ansermet's 1964 recording of La Mer, which is both musically and sonically superior to the recording included in the "Legends" cd. Interestingly, the 1964 La Mer was originally coupled with the very appealing Clarinette Rapsodie and the rarely heard "Khamma" on a London LP which should have been reissued together as it made for an unusual program. In any case, this collection has two out of three of those gems, plus a lovely Claire de Lune, Petite Suite, Prelude à l'aprés~midi d'un faune and Jeux.These are wonderful recordings that are bona-fide classics of the record catalogue. Five stars.

These recordings, made between 1987 and 1989, originally appeared on the Philips label and were out of circulation for a good while, so it's nice to have Newton Classics restore them to the catalogue. I Musici delivers what I would call well-rounded modern performances. They have a big, kind of sweeping sound and while some of the Handelian edges are rounded off, their approach still works well, though they're not as characterful as Marriner/ASMF whose 1960's recordings of the Op. 6 Concerti remain my favorites (Handel: Concerti Grossi Op.3 & Op.6).Marriner communicates more of the Baroque pomp running through this music, an aspect that's pushed into the background by I Musici; and there are a number of instances where Marriner captures the contour of the music where I Musici just sails right through with interesting details left behind. One doesn't have to travel farther than the second movement of the first concerto to find the differences between the two -- here I Musici is relatively speedy and somewhat glib compared to the grandeur of Marriner. Perhaps because I Musici approaches these scores first and foremost as a production for strings -- in other words they receive the standard I Musici treatment -- their Op. 6 doesn't have quite the same personality that Marriner's does.While it's pure speculation, I would guess that had I Musici recorded this repertoire fifteen years before, the results would have been entirely different. A routineness had set in by the late 1980's and this along with personnel changes in the ensemble can all be heard in the music. Nevertheless, I Musici is preferable to Hogwood's more austere recording with the Handel and Haydn Society of which I used to be fond (Handel: 6 Concerti Grossi, Op. 3; 12 Concerti Grossi, Op. 6), and certainly better than that of the smaller-scaled Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which I also used to like but now find much too lightweight (Handel - Concerti Grossi, Op. 6 / Orpheus Chamber Orchestra).Four stars.

The liner notes to this release inform us that "The oboe, which figure prominently in many of the works recorded here, was a relatively new instrument during Handel's youth. It was developed from the shawm by Lully and other French composers during the last third or so of the seventeenth century and then spread to other countries, notably to England, where it was known for its 'inimitable charming sweetness of sound'...." Well, sometimes it pays to read the notes because that was something I didn't know.Two of the three oboe concertos from Handel included in this set may not be quite on the same level as the best of Vivaldi's or Albinoni's, but still make for very pleasant if not rewarding listening. The B flat concerto is a real gem though, with a third movement that's a masterpiece and a sprightly allegro winding things up. Heinz Holliger plays beautifully and the English Chamber Orchestra with Raymond Leppard at the helm are first class partners.The rest of the program is very fine -- the third of the op. 3 Concerto Grossi sounds substantial and lively and blends perfectly with the assortment of other pieces in this well-put together album.This is a prime example of Baroque music performed to perfection on modern instruments; and it doesn't hurt that the 1971 sound is demonstration class.Four stars.

There's not much difference between Brendel-Marriner (1975) and Brendel-Mackerras (2000) in these concertos, except that in the later incarnations Brendel sounds even more deliberate (he takes about three minutes longer with K595) and Mackerras goes right along with him. Brendel-Mackerras tiptoe through the opening movement of K482, sounding almost as if they were walking on eggshells. The whole undertaking is almost lifeless, especially compared to Casadesus-Szell and Geza Anda, two of my favorite readings of this concerto. While Brendel mines extra details from K595, his probing approach is too one-sided when compared with the mixture of animation and poetry that Geza Anda brings to this score (not to mention that Anda's 30 year-old analog recording sounds better than this ultra-soft digital one).Three stars.

Based on the quality of the sound, these are presumably broadcast tapes - the Chopin concerto from March 9, 1960 and the Schumann from May 31, 1962 - and as is typically the case with Arrau, they show him performing more spontaneously than in his studio recordings. The Chopin is not necessarily a concerto that suits Arrau to a tee (unlike Beethoven's, the Brahms B flat major, and both Liszt concertos), however, this performance is far more settled than a hyperactive concert reading from ten years earlier with Fritz Busch and the NY Philharmonic (Arrau Plays Chopin: The Two Concertos). Arrau's whole approach is better judged here, a case where slowing down produced much more satisfying results. While there's still an occasional hint of awkwardness - he doesn't sound quite as comfortable with this work as Rubinstein did -- this is a performance superior to the exciting Busch/NYP concert, and vastly preferable to Arrau's studio recording with Inbal. The Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Italian conductor Massimo Pradella prove to be strong allies too.Arrau's commercial recordings of the Schumann concerto are representative of all that could be wrong with his studio undertakings with orchestras. His 1957 EMI recording with Galliera and the 1963 effort for Philips with Dohnanyi are both mellow to the point of blandness (Grieg: P Cto in a Min / Schumann: P Cto in a Min and Grieg / Schumann: Piano Concertos) -- but send Arrau out in front of an audience, and the results are entirely different.  A 1951 performance with Victor de Sabata and the NY Philharmonic sizzles (De Sabata conducts Schumann and Brahms), and a 1963 TV performance with the London Philharmonic is solid as a rock (Schumann: Piano Concerto in A minor, Carnaval Op. 9 & Beethoven Piano Sonata No. 32 in C minor / Arrau). You can add to the list this newly issued 1962 performance with Rafael Kubelik and the North German Radio Symphony Orchestra, which brings together the best of the two other live recordings. There's a sense of complete authority in this music, absolute control over the keyboard, massive weight and not a moment where Arrau doesn't sound completely dominating. The reflective moments are beautiful, but never dawdled over, and the bravura passages are unleashed with granite-like strength - a perfect combination of drama and poetry.The sound is straightforward mono with ideal balance between piano and orchestra. There's not a hint of audience noise which leads me to wonder whether these recordings were made in empty halls for radio broadcast.Five stars.

Luigi Boccherini (1743-1805) and Franz Haydn were virtual contemporaries (1732-1809) who respected each other, and  borrowed musically from each other as well - a practice that was common then - but that Haydn was the superior composer was recognized even in their time. Indeed, Boccherini was referred to as "the wife of Haydn" by sharp-tongued contemporaries, and as mean-spirited as that statement may appear to be today, there's still an element of truth to it. That Haydn's symphonies are enduring masterpieces of the repertoire and Boccherini's far more modest symphonic output remains relatively unknown speaks for itself. Boccherini's music is for the most part cheerful and melodic - he had, for example, no Sturm and Drang period such as Haydn's - and while not everything he composed was relentlessly sunny, he didn't explore the tragic to the extent that Haydn did.While Boccherini's op. 12 symphonies are not on the same level as even Haydn's earlier works in this genre, they still offer a variety of moods and occasionally surprising depth. The Fourth symphony, for example, is unusual in form and also quite dramatic; and the Second symphony, which is intelligently programed after the Fourth, is much more dynamic than the music one thinks of as coming from this typically congenial composer. The closing movement is wonderfully bouncy, but the movements preceding this are packed with serious material. This is not just happy music. The Fifth symphony, on the other hand, is routine; and the Sixth, which improves after a bland opening movement, still doesn't approach the inventiveness of the Second and Fourth. The First symphony has some promising moments in the first movement, but Boccherini's reliance on short repeated phrases interrupts the forward momentum and wears thin pretty quickly. But the patient listener is rewarded with a beautiful second movement that seems to come out of nowhere. The same is true of the lovely Andantino of the Third symphony, which follows a rather mundane opening Allegro.This type of creative back and forth is representative of the whole mass of Boccherini's six op. 12 symphonies -- just when you think his music isn't sophisticated or inspiring enough to invest much time in, there's a pleasant surprise that shifts the momentum in the other direction.  Despite this, the satisfying moments are too few and far between to offer more than intermittent listening satisfaction.The playing of the New Philharmonia under the direction of Raymond Leppard is exemplary and the 1972 recorded sound is rich and warm.Three and a half stars.

It's surprising that this delightful collection of six Vivaldi oboe concerti is no longer available from Philips, nor does it appear to have been reissued on any other label.A couple of the concertos included here, RV 452 and RV 446, were only discovered in the 1960's, and while there is a discussion in the notes about their provenance (they "differ slightly, in terms of style, from what is generally regarded as undoubtedly authentic Vivaldi"), they have been accepted as having come from the master's pen. In any case, Heinz Holliger and I Musici perform these small masterpieces to perfection. The allegro of RV 463 exemplifies the glorious sound produced by I Musici - big, lush and swinging - and a modern musical approach that now ironically may be somewhat out of fashion, but which I think is classic.The recordings of RV 452, 454, 545 and 446 date from 1981, and RV 463 and 447 from 1975. While I doubt the older recordings qualify as "Digital Classics" as the cover states, the sound is excellent across the board.Also highly recommended from Heinz Holliger is The Baroque Oboe, an outstanding collection which includes three choice albums: Bach: 3 Oboe Concertos, Telemann: Concerti for Oboe, Strings and Basso Continuo - in E minor, in D minor, in C minor, in F minor, in D Major - Heinz Holliger, Iona Brown and Concerti per Oboe.

The Kontarsky brothers were among the finest duo-pianist teams of their day, performing from the 1950's through 1983, when Aloys suffered a debilitating stroke. They were champions of modern music, premiering works from Stockhausen, Berio, and Zimmerman among others, and made a number of fine records for Deutsche Grammophon over the course of their careers. The present disc, recorded in 1973 and 1977, is representative of their best work and includes Debussy's "En blanc et noir," "L'Enfant prodigue" and "Prelude a l'apres d'un faune" as well as Ravel's "Ma Mere l'Oyle" and "Rapsodie espagnole." The program is rounded out by Stravinsky's Sonata for two pianos. The Debussy and Ravel recordings are of the highest caliber, and were considered reference recordings for many years. The Stravinsky too is superb.The Kontarsky brothers were strong technicians, intuitive partners, and had a great feel for Impressionistic music. The recorded sound is also superb.Five stars.

Claudio Arrau recorded the Diabelli Variations in 1952 during his brief stay with Decca, a period which produced a batch of Chopin, as well as some Beethoven sonatas and the Eroica Variations - invaluable recordings that are scattered aross various discs (Steinway Legends, Liszt Legacy, Ballades / Piano Concerto etc), but should be remastered and collected in one set. In lieu of that, we have this MP3 offering of the Diabelli, the only available source for these recordings that I'm aware of.Unfortunately, the sound is not ideal here: first, the sound on the original Decca LP's was echoey and clattery, a problem which has been carried over to and compounded on the mp3 files which were no doubt transferred from old LP's. While there are no skips or pops, there can be sonic stress when the music gets loud (mostly restricted to the fifth variation) as well as occasional faint clicking and static in the background. Nevertheless, I would still recommend this download as the performance is a gem. Arrau is really on top of this score, delivering lots of muscle and drama along with sensitivity without any of the ultra-rhetorical insertions that started appearing in his recordings in the 1960's. Harris Goldsmith, in his Beethoven bicentennial retrospective for "High Fidelity," observed that "Arrau's [recording] has a perfection of detail and reserved classicism that in no way diminishes the warmth and humanity of the music. Arrau, in his more detached way, achieves a cumulative, continuous entity similar to both Serkin and Schnabel."Someone should assemble all of Arrau's Decca/Brunswick recordings, of which this 1952 Diabelli Variations is a crowning achievement, and do a respectable job of reissuing them. Still, five stars are warranted for one of the great recordings of the Diabelli Variations.

For several decades beginning in the 1950's I Musici was the leading ensemble specializing in Italian Baroque music, and their performances were standard-setting in their time. Their recordings still hold up exceptionally well even though approaches to early music, driven by the period instrument revolution, have changed somewhat since then.Perhaps the simplest way to define the differences between I Musici and more contemporary ensembles is that I Musici's approach, while spirited and completely authentic, is also refined and elegant if not occasionally extravagent, whereas more modern groups often sound scaled down and a little more earthy. Both have their merits, although I find myself far more attracted to I Musici's grandeur and sweep.Unfortunately, I Musici's recordings have fallen out of favor with the surge of the period instrument movement - a puzzling development given the beauty of the Italian ensemble's sound, not to mention the soundness of their approach. They produced wonderful recordings of Corelli, Geminiani, Bach, Albinoni and of course Vivaldi; and while they're occasionally guilty of romantic indulgences that no doubt drive purists crazy, well, so what? The music they made was lush and rich, not thin and scrawny, and the sound of their massed strings makes for a glorious listening experience, which after all, is what it's all about.This Vivaldi set doesn't collect all of I Musici's recordings of that composer, but is instead a straight reissue of the Philips Vivaldi Edition sets Vivaldi Edition Vol. 1: Op. 1 - 6 including L'Estro Armonico & La Stravaganza and Vivaldi Edition Vol. 2. All of the concertos are first rate, with the exception of the flute concertos which seem to drag in places. The original 1961 recording of "The Four Seasons" is also included here - a stately version that's vastly preferable to their sonically thin digital remake of 1981 with Pina Carmirelli. The only material I find of lesser interest are the violin and trio sonatas, and this is so only because they pale in comparison to the enriched majesty of the concertos.Five stars.

The Quartetto Italiano is most famous for their Beethoven quartet cycle, which still occupies an exalted place in the catalogue despite an avalanche of formidable competition over the last 40 years, but their Mozart cycle is also a top choice for those looking to add this music to their libraries.While listeners may not turn all that often to the first disc, which includes Mozart's earliest works in the quartet form, the Italian players still make the most of things turning in performances that are fresh and lively. Mozart seemed to take a quantum leap with the eighth quartet (K168), which is already a fully mature statement, and this is where the Quartetto Italiano shows why they had such a great reputation. They understand the music perfectly, their sound is elegant, but not overly so, and beefy where it needs to be. There's no exaggeration, no unnecessary display nor pyrotechnics anywhere, just idiomatic, balanced playing that's a pleasure to listen to. All of the quartets from K168-K173 are played to perfection.The later quartets are also exceptional, and while the QI's approach may sometimes have a little less oomph and edginess than that of the Alban Berg Quartet, my long-standing favorite in this repertoire (Mozart: String Quartets, Nos. 14 - 23), they are still every bit ABQ's equal.These recordings were made between 1966-1972 and still sound wonderful.Very highly recommended!

Had I spent a little more time on research I would have discovered that the contents of this set, along with the other volumes in this Telemann Overture series from Brilliant Classics, are available as a download for only $5.99 (Telemann: Overtures) -- a real bargain. In any case, this set is a fine introduction to the Overtures. There's not a lot of variety to the music (therefore the 3.5 star rating), but the Collegium Instrumentale Brugense under the direction of founder Patrick Peire plays splendidly. This is an ensemble that uses modern instruments, a practice I enthusiastically endorse, and also, according to the liner notes, "respects a historical approach and characterizes itself by researching the stylistic individuality of each composition." While that statement sounds like a bone being thrown to historically informed performance purists, these recordings have an idiomatic feel to them without the thin sound often produced by period instruments. The sonics are also spectacular.Three and a half stars.

Leon Fleisher, one of Artur Schnabel's best-known pupils, summarized his legendary teacher this way: "Schnabel wasn't a flashy virtuoso. He was simply the greatest musician at the keyboard I've ever heard. His playing had an irresistable elan - what the Germans call Schwung - as if he were grabbing you and twirling you in a dance.... His performances were never about him. They were all about the composer. In an era when the cult of personality was still flourishing, Schnabel was insistent that a performer serve the score. He abhorred any kind of showmanship.... He wanted to penetrate to the heart of a score and understand what the composer really wanted. He was most interested in works that allowed him to keep asking questions, probing, exploring - 'music,' as he used to say, 'that is better than it can be performed.'" (from "My Nine Lives: A Memoir of Many Careers in Music," 2010)While Schnabel's recordings supposedly don't do him justice -- he was a nervous performer in the studio, feeling rushed when confronted with the time limitations imposed by the shellac recording process -- they are the only way we have of hearing this great pianist. Indeed some of his recordings, particularly of Beethoven and Bach, are a little too fast for my ears; but others are marvels. I may prefer Arrau's more contemplative Beethoven, yet Schnabel was a major influence on Arrau who revered him (he selected Schnabel's recording of Schubert's D.959 sonata as one of ten "desert island" recordings for the BBC in 1960 and referred to Schnabel as a pianist "whom I have worshipped deeply all my life"). And while there are modern recordings of Bach that dig deeper into the music, though perhaps are a little less exciting than those included in this set, the unwavering pulse that animated these readings still makes for rewarding listening. The Bach and Mozart concerto recordings, including those made with his son Karl, are wonderful. I also love the Mozart sonata and Schubert recordings, which are perfectly paced.Don't let the age of these recordings deter you, as they are surprisingly listenable. And if cost is an issue, the entire contents of this set are available as a download for the incredible price of $8.99 (World's Finest Pianist). At the equivalent of just over $1 a disc, the download is an indispensable acquisition.Five stars.

Claudio Arrau was no stranger to the Chopin Preludes, having played the cycle since the 1920's and first recorded them for Columbia in 1950. He took the Preludes very seriously, calling them "a survey of Chopin's cosmos," and along with the Etudes were among the best of his Chopin output.If one word could describe Arrau's Preludes, it would be "big," and the attention he lavished on each one brought them to life in a way no other artist has done. His comments about the music provide some insight into his approach: of the first Prelude, for example, he observed that "it puts one in a certain tense emotional situation. It has something to do with sexual energy.... There's something positively orgasmic about it." Others were melancholic (no. 4) or enigmatic (no. 14). Arrau observed that starting with the 17th, "you feel that [Chopin's] fundamental approach to life is tragic. The peaceful, positive preludes become like remembrances of things that make life acceptable." And of the dramatic 24th, "you could say that the plunge at the end is like a drowning. Or that it cuts the thread of life - like the Fates in Greek mythology." These insights informed Arrau's interpretations of the Preludes, three complete cycles of which are documented on disc.While all three of Arrau's Prelude cycles are cut from the same cloth, the earliest, the above-mentioned Columbia cycle from 1950, is the lightest, with the pianist still in his virtuoso phase. No less technically brilliant, but far more weighty (and the best of the bunch) is the 1960 Prague Festival recital presented on this disc. By this time Arrau's playing reflected more of the heft and "grand manner" that were hallmarks of his later years. The quieter preludes are played with intimacy whereas the more dramatic ones project form and architectural structure. Arrau brings tremendous technical authority to the etude-like preludes - for example, his fearless attack on the wildly gyrating sixteenth prelude is quite amazing. And who could bring such weight to the seventeenth, eighteenth, twentieth and hair-raising twenty-second preludes? The finale is a series of artillery shots, with the last three chords a hammering doom. This is incredible Chopin playing.The Symphonic Etudes were recorded in 1976, also in Prague. The Etudes have long been favorites of mine (I acquired Arrau's 1970 Philips recording thirty-some years ago), however, this recital performance elevates the music to another level. Arrau, who could be stiff in the studio, was typically far more venturesome in front of an audience and this is clearly the case here. His playing, while structurally monolithic, is supple, colorful, and highly energetic. If you don't know this music, or this great pianist, I can't imagine a better introduction than this thrilling performance.Although the liner notes do not specify the source tapes, I would guess based on the very good sound quality that both recitals were professionally recorded, perhaps for broadcast.Very highly recommended!

What better way to introduce this wonderful assortment of Erroll Garner tracks than to reproduce the following write-up from his manager, Martha Glaser, who was also the producer of "The Erroll Garner Collection":"This album, the second in the series of previously unissued recordings by Erroll Garner, covers a span of output from 1961-65. The rhythm section of Kelly Martin, on drums, and bassist Eddie Calhoun, appears on all of the tracks."As with 'Easy To Love,' the first album in this collection, the dilemma was one of making choices from the abundant and extraordinary Garner recordings in the vaults, still awaiting their first public exposure. Following the release of 'Easy To Love,' critic Gary Giddins asked me why the recordings weren't issued in the 60's when they were recorded, since they are of such prime quality. A good question. Quite simply, Garner recorded so prolifically that in a standard three hour session, he would play, improvising non-stop (usually one-takes), enough material for several outstanding albums. Sometimes, as Erroll said "the piano got so good" to him that he wouldn't let go, or stop. (I still have vivid memories of the engineers frantically trying to change reels as Erroll rolled on, without pause.) Thus, the recordings stockpiled, and there is much glorious material yet to come."Indeed, this is prime Erroll Garner.Five stars.

I'm not always that keen on "best of" compilations, but this program selected from the two studio sessions The MJQ recorded for Pablo is a qualified exception. It was to The MJQ's credit that after a seven year hiatus during which each of the musicians had gone their own way, they took advantage of their Pablo years to explore new material and didn't just use the opportunity to rehash their greatest hits in up-to-date stereo sound.While the tracks included in this compilation are representative of The MJQ's stay on Pablo, I do question the brevity of the 45 minute program in this era of 80 minute cd's. In that three of the "Best of" tracks (Connie's Blues, Echoes and Watergate Blues) were taken from the 46 minute album Together Again and the others from the 43 minute Topsy: This One's for Basie, there's no excuse for the producers of "The Best of the MJQ" to have left so many tracks behind. If I didn't already have "Best of" in my library, I would opt for the other discs which offer a lot more music for not much more money. In any case, this cd still features typically gorgeous playing from this classic ensemble and is worth acquiring at the right price.

Although Claudio Arrau had impressive credentials as a Liszt player - his only teacher was Martin Krause, who was a student of Liszt - and he performed many of the composer's works early in his career, he neither exploited this association, nor became known as a Liszt specialist. Perhaps this was because Krause warned him not to become a specialist in the music of any one composer, urging him instead to embrace all music. Consequently, the younger Arrau's repertoire was very large; however, as he grew older he concentrated on fewer composers, moving as it were from the universal to the particular applying almost prophetic insight into certain scores, especially those of Beethoven and Liszt.Arrau didn't begin recording his Liszt series for Philips until he was nearing seventy, not necessarily an auspicious age to be taking on such a technically challenging project, yet the energy and imagination he brought to this music was truly remarkable. To be sure, Arrau the poet-philosopher was ultimately in charge, and it is the mythic/heroic and spiritual aspects of Liszt's music that are most evident in his recordings. Even such obvious examples as the Transcendental Etudes reveal themselves under Arrau's hands as music first and technical exercises second, not because they are toned down, which they aren't, but because the pianist drills into and extracts the musical core. Indeed there are technical miracles all over the place even though many listeners won't necessarily be aware of them (just listen to the magnificent Verdi paraphrases), but displays of raw power was not what Liszt's, or for that matter any composer's music, was all about for Arrau.Virtually every recording in this box set is exceptional - from the Sonata, which was hailed as a classic when it was first released in 1970, to the selections from Annees de Pelerinage. Les jeux d'eaux a la Villa d'Este glitters with an incomparable display of shimmering color while making a profound spiritual impact. And what a gorgeous sound Arrau's piano makes here! Arrau's Sonetto del Petrarca 104 is a superbly judged combination of architecture and poetry, and no. 123 a statement of sublime transcendence. Listening to the rhapsodic Benediction de Dieu dans la solitude unfurl reminded me of the many unforgettable Arrau recitals I attended in the 1970's when the Maestro frequently programmed the Sonata, Ballade and Les jeux d'eaux. Playing like this forces you to rethink what Liszt is all about.All of this is truly desert island Liszt; and given that many of these recordings have long been unavailable, I would urge collectors to acquire this set while they can.

Despite the extensive introductory material on the founding of the Beverly Hills, Bel Air and Holmby Hills sub-divisions, it's obvious that the author of "Unreal Estate" is no Kevin Starr, who tells complex history in a comprehensible way. I ended up skipping scores of pages of disjointed narrative piled up with needless detail and felt I hadn't missed a thing. Once (or if) you get past the introductory chapters, which readers will soon realize are nothing but pretentious window dressing, you'll find that the history of the houses Michael Gross chose to write about, and the families who built and lived in them, reads like a mixture of  "National Enquirer" and "Hollywood Babylon" with a dash of "Architectural Digest" thrown in. Gross occasionally strays from the path of rehashing gossip and innuendo -- there is some interesting material included such as the history of the Boldt-Weber house -- but the focus is mostly on the stories of the owners of the homes, virtually all of which are denigrating.Furthermore, by adopting a chronological approach rather than one by subject, the author didn't make "Unreal Properties" easy to follow. The same properties are repeatedly revisited over the course of hundreds of pages by which time the reader has lost track of, not to mention interest in, whose house it was in the first (or second, or third) place. This is exacerbated by the virtual absence of photos, which is a huge flaw; there are only three, one of which, strangely enough, is of Jayne Mansfield with Mickey Hargitay. How can a book on houses have almost no pictures? I felt like I was dropped off in the middle of a forest without a compass. Even one photo of each property discussed would have been helpful.One star.

Here's another stunning bargain from the same firm that offers the Arrau, Schnabel, and Solomon EMI box sets, among others, in download format. In this case, this download includes all of the contents of Icon: Dinu Lipatti [Box Set], a seven disc collection that captures nearly all of the recordings of the great Romanian pianist.While I have long admired Dinu Lipatti, my music library included only three Columbia Odyssey LP's that I bought around 40 years ago: the Chopin waltzes, op. 58 sonata (along with a few other Chopin pieces), and the Grieg and Schumann concertos, all classic recordings that still deserve that over-used designation. I had never explored the rest of Lipatti's output, so the majority of the things collected in the EMI set were new to me. The things that really impressed me were his Bach, Mozart, Bartok and especially the Enescu sonata. There was a crystalline quality to Lipatti's playing that really comes through in his Bach and Mozart, although the Mozart concerto (K467) comes across in a surprisingly muscular way. There is a Liszt E-flat major concerto from a 1947 concert, unfortunately in pretty bad sound, and a Chopin E minor concerto recorded live three years later in only marginally better sound. The Bach concerto, recorded with Eduard van Beinum in 1947, is very impressive, with Lipatti displaying a rock solid command of the keyboard, a tremendous sense of rhythm and driving forward momentum. Lipatti's reading of Ravel's "Alborada del gracioso" just sizzles and his Schubert Impromptus, from his final concert, are anything but lightweight. In fact, based on most of the recordings collected in this anthology, I have to say that the comments chronically repeated by other reviewers about Lipatti's "angelic" playing are somewhat off the mark. I would instead say that he was a real dynamo... with wings.The recorded sound is generally very good considering the age of the source material and I would guess that the producers licensed (or appropriated) transfers directly from EMI. Too bad they didn't design better accompanying artwork, but that's easily fixed.Very highly recommended!

This download includes the entire contents of the eight disc EMI Icon box set Icon: Artur Schnabel - Scholar of the Piano at a fraction of the cost. While Schnabel's recordings supposedly don't do him justice -- he was a nervous performer in the studio, feeling rushed when confronted with the time limitations imposed by the shellac recording process -- they are the only way we have of hearing the great pianist. Indeed some of his recordings, particularly of Beethoven and Bach, are little too fast for my ears; but others are marvels. I may prefer Arrau's more contemplative Beethoven, yet Schnabel was a major influence on Arrau who revered him (he selected Schnabel's recording of Schubert's D.959  sonata as one of ten "desert island" recordings for the BBC in 1960 and referred to Schnabel as a pianist "whom I have worshipped deeply all my life").  And while there are modern recordings of Bach that dig deeper into the music, though perhaps are a little less exciting than those included in this set, the unwavering pulse that animated these readings still makes for rewarding listening. The Bach and Mozart concerto recordings, including those made with his son Karl, are wonderful. I also love the Mozart sonata and Schubert recordings, which are perfectly paced.Leon Fleisher, one of Schnabel's best-known pupils, summarized his legendary teacher this way: "Schnabel wasn't a flashy virtuoso. He was simply the greatest musician at the keyboard I've ever heard. His playing had an irresistable elan - what the Germans call Schwung - as if he were grabbing you and twirling you in a dance.... His performances were never about him. They were all about the composer. In an era when the cult of personality was still flourishing, Schnabel was insistent that a performer serve the score. He abhorred any kind of showmanship.... He wanted to penetrate to the heart of a score and understand what the composer really wanted. He was most interested in works that allowed him to keep asking questions, probing, exploring - 'music,' as he used to say, 'that is better than it can be performed.'" (from "My Nine Lives: A Memoir of Many Careers in Music," 2010)Don't let the age of these recordings deter you, as they are surprisingly listenable. The incredible price, at the equivalent of just over $1 a disc, makes this an indispensable acquisition.Five stars.

Claudio Arrau's ultra-rhapsodic approach to the Brahm's D minor concerto is not for all tastes, however, this 1959 concert traversal with Paul Kletzki and the Orchestre National de France is the best of his recordings that I've heard. The first movement, which Arrau stretches to near breaking point in his studio recordings (Giulini, 1961; Haitink, 1969) is somewhat tauter here. The opening minutes, which are meant to lead to a buildup of tension are not as dramatic as they could be, however, there's greater forward momentum than Arrau projects with Giulini or Haitink. The second movement also starts out a little too deliberately and feels excessively solemn. And of all pianists one would think that it would be Arrau who would extract everything from the magnificent plateau reached later in the movement, but it's actually the youthful Leon Fleisher who delivers a statement that's never been equaled (Brahms: Piano Concertos Nos. 1 & 2 / Handel Variations, Op. 24 / Waltzes, Op. 39). The finale finds Arrau much less restrained, making one wish that his vision had been a little less self-willed. Still, this performance explains why so many admired the epic journey Arrau made of this concerto.The B flat major concerto with Markevitch and the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra taken from a 1956 concert is another matter. Arrau's vision of this work fits Brahms perfectly - massiveness combined with virtuosity. The footprint is essentially the same as his titanic 1963 concert reading with Alexander Gibson (Brahms: Piano Concerto No. 2; Schubert: Three Piano Pieces, D946), and if I prefer the later reading it's because the work ripened further under Arrau's hands during the intervening years. While the Markevitch reading has a slightly greater sense of urgency about it, the reading with Gibson finds Arrau, no less technically oriented, focusing more attention on detail while building a bigger statement. There's an epic grandeur to it that's irreplaceable, making it my first choice for the B flat major concerto.This two disc set is filled out with a 1959 reading of the Beethoven C minor concerto with Carl Schuricht and the Orchestre National de France. Arrau, a great Beethoven player, delivers an energetic but polished performance that's more in line with his 1958 EMI studio recording with Galliera than the plusher Philips recording with Haitink from 1964.The sonics differ on all three recordings, which I suspect are radio air checks. The first couple of minutes of the D Minor Concerto suffer from intermittent clouds of static which is resolved prior to the entry of the piano. The B flat major offers acceptable sound, whereas the Beethoven concerto is very compressed.3.5 stars.

This download contains the entire contents the Claudio Arrau Icon box set, a 12 disc collection of all the recordings Arrau made for EMI  (see my review: ICON: Claudio Arrau: Virtuoso Philosopher of the Piano). This is an unbelievable opportunity for anyone building a music library to acquire a block of outstanding recordings, for practically nothing, by one of the greatest pianists of the 20th century.Urgently recommended!

MY small paper clips kept spilling because they were in a box.  So I put them into a caddy-go-round, and I couldn't get them out.  This was the next try and it worked.  I love the way the little clips are just waiting in the opening for me to take them (a little anthropomorphism never hurt), and the days of the spilled boxes are over.  This works great.  I just wish there was a bigger one for jumbo size clips.  Great little gadget.

This is an excellent non-slip shoulder pad, and I could see it would work beautifully - on a strap that detached from the body of the case or the purse that you want to put it on.  Unfortunately, the purse for which I got it didn't have such a strap, so I couldn't use this.  I had to return it, but I would purchase it in the future for a case or a purse that did have a detachable strap.  Aside from that, I'd have given it 5 stars.

The color is gorgeous and the scarf is just beautiful.  What more can I say?  It's just a beautiful scarf that goes with all the outfits I thought it would match.  It's not a dark brown so it won't go with every brown outfit, but it's going to go with a lot.  I'm going to look at the other colors that this comes in because it's such a beautiful scarf.  You won't be disappointed.

As always, Canon brand ink is fantastic.  I wouldn't use a look-alike for any savings amount because of my experience years ago when look-alikes gummed up my printhead and I had to replace it.  SInce then, it's the authentic thing all the way.  I have no trouble with my printer, and the ink actually lasts much longer than the report you get from your printer that the ink is running low.  DOn't believe it.  Keep an eye on the little thin indicator that comes up on the screen, and don't change your ink cartridge until that thin line is G-O-N-E!  This, like all Canon products, is the greatest.

Great little containers for my jumbo paper clips as well as for binder clips!  Really for anything on your office desk.  They're nice looking and hard to knock over which I really appreciate.  I work with students who have learning disabilities, and some have problems with coordination, knocking things over all the time.  One of them collided with one of these little baskets and it didn't tip over and spill all of the clips.  I was very pleased because it avoided a spill and a waste of time having to clean it up.  (My students work with me at my desk which is actually a very large table.  My actual desk is behind me with a computer on it, but I keep all my office supplies on my table, thus my need for non-spillable containers.)  Great little containers and nice looking as well.

This is an excellent follow-up to the chemistry tutor part 1.  It's clear and I found some good material to carry over to my students who have learning disabilities.  I would have no problem even loaning this to them to help them further their abilities in conversions.  Some of the girls could understand it themselves, but others would have to be guided through it because of their learning disabilities.  For the typical student, this is a terrific piece of software that they should be able to navigate with minimum input from a supervising adult.  It's especially helpful for teachers who want to brush up on their conversion skills.  Well worth the money.

These are just plain beautiful colored pencils and they work so smoothly.  You don't get a lot of waste with all the wood surrounding the colored portions, though it does make it a tiny bit more sensitive to pressure, but not enough to be a deal breaker.  I bought this as a reward for a student who earns points.  (I work in a special education center for high school girls, and often, incentive prizes are great for those with organizational difficulties.  This student is a gifted artist and can't afford art materials, so those are my prizes based on my experience with products I've already used, as this one is.)  It comes in a neat little package, but one which can degrade over time.  I do wish it came in a little tin that was more durable since these are best for carrying around to do "spot" sketching, and the present packaging is just not durable enough for that.  But the pencils are great - and I'm a big fan of woodless art pencils, graphite, charcoal, anything I can find without wood.  It just lasts longer.  A great addition to these pencils wood be a pencil extender that Koh-I-Noor puts out.  It's right here on Amazon and really fits well, extending the life and use of stubby little pencils.

These were exactly what I wanted!  I'd purchased a gorgeous necklace that was partly brass chain, but it was too short for my taste.  I looked and looked for brass extensions but there was only silver and gold.  I hit on the idea of using a bracelet instead of an extension because I wanted to add, at the very least, 6" to the necklace.  I found these great antiqued brass chain bracelets.  They match exactly in color and in the size of the chain, and the one that I put onto the necklace is a perfect length.  Now what will I do with the others?  Well, I love wide bracelets, so why not wear six or seven of them at once with my necklace?  It all worked out perfectly.  These are really nice looking bracelets if your taste goes to just one strand, and the lobster claw works beautifully.  It's great as an extension and as a bracelet on its own.

What a fantastic invention and what a great example of what it's supposed to be like.  I absolutely love it.  This fits all my Prismacolor pencils, charcoals, graphite, colored pencils--just everything!  It's going to save all my little stumpy pencils that I can't use otherwise.  This is a fine tool, built very well and designed ever better.  I'm probably getting more.  You'll love it too.

The scard is far too short and the pattern of the flowers is white, which makes it difficult to wear the scarf if you're wearing lilac and gray colors.  The white just doesn't go.  What I didn't like most of all was that the scarf came with a "free gift" which was a cheap wooden cross.  Did it ever occur to the people who sent this out that not everybody wants to get a cross as a gift?  It was not a welcome free gift.  I am returning the two scarves I got, not because of the crosses, not at all, but because I didn't like the scarves at all.  Of course, if you like too-short scarves with two colors in it, this might be for you.  It isn't for me.

Absolutely gorgeous!  I bought this to match a winter ribbed turtleneck, and it's a perfect match!  The scarf is really quite beautiful and is a cross between jewelry and a scarf.  It needs extra special care - no dry cleaning, no high temperature  for washing.  I'd recommend putting this into a hosiery bag before putting it into the wash on cold.  It's a gorgeous scarf and one which I hope lasts a good long time!  It would make a wonderful gift on a special day for a special person.

Just what I expected.  These are perfectly sized Post-its with just the right amount of stickiness on them.  I need them to label about 30 pictures of illustrations for my publisher and couldn't use paper clips; they would ruin the smoothness of the print.  I also couldn't use the extra sticky notes because they would ruin the surface of the picture.  So these have just the right adhesive amount so that there's no residue on the pictures to distort it when photos are taken of the pictures.  And - they can be re-adhered to the painting which is great.

I waited several days before I wrote this review because I didn't want to seem vindictive or nasty, but...I am soooooo disappointed by this paper.  It is so incredibly thin that when you print a photo on it, it simply flops over like a piece of wet spaghetti, nothing like my other photo paper.  I knew the price was too low and so I guess the saying that goes, "If it's too good to be true, it probably is," happens to be true.  It's not worth returning this paper.  I shall use it for printing out letters that will have a higher quality than regular printer paper, but this is NOT photo printing paper at all.  I should have heeded the one review that I read that said the exact same thing about this paper - that it's just too, too lightweight.  Very disappointing

WOW!!!!  Are these files ever B-I-G!!!!!!  They are much larger than I thought they'd be, but that makes them a lot more effective than I thought they would be as well.  They are graded differently which is terrific.  I had one job wehre I had to file down some brass screws to the level of a clear acrylic covering and I didn't want to end up filing down the acrylic also.  I started out with the coarse file to get the screws down to th closest level possible without touching the acrylic sheet window, then I switched to the finest one, and the project was completed perfectly.  Not a single scratch on the acrylic.  These may be BIG, but they do handle beautifully and are well balanced.  They're going to last a l-o-o-o-ng time.

I have a double use for these dusters.  First, the usual, which is that they help keep my computer clean - laptop and desktop alike.  But also, I'm an artist and I do a lot of pencil work.  That means using erasers, much of the time, gum erasers which are great but leave a lot of debris.  If I were to brush away the debris, the drawing would be smudged, but these are powerful enough to blow away the debris and leave my drawing free of eraser remains.  This is a powerful and thorough spray.  I wouldn't do without it.

I absolutely LOVE these erasers.  At first I couldn't imagine what in the world I'd bought so many of them for, but then it became obvious.  As each one is used, the corners get rounded, and I like to have some sharp cornered erasers around to erase errors very carefully and without destroying what I want to leave in.  I like precision and these erasers give it to me.  I also use them for special effects, such as drawing clouds when I want a very bright area, and the sun's rays as well.  Aside from that, it's a great eraser for general erasing.  It does leave debris behind and that would affect the subsequent drawing so I always keep a bottle of multipurpose air spray duster (the kind that's used to keep computers clean) around.  That way I don't smudge my drawing by brushing away the eraser debris - I just blow the debris away and it leaves the paper clean.  One added benefit is that I've purchased other gum erasers and they have had an absolutely horrible odor.  These have a most pleasant scent to them, reason enough to purchase them.  They're also the best gum erasers I've ever used.

I do a lot of pencil drawings as well as paintings, and I found that this was a good finish for both of them.  It provides good coverage, doesn't soak the paper, and doesn't change the color of anything that I've painted or drawn.  I do like to spray very lightly in four directions, spaced out to give each layer enough time to dry thoroughly.  This does dry fast, so it's not a long wait and it protects very well.  I'm pleased with the product and the results.

I asked, about the small tortillions, "What's there to LOVE?"  Well, they do their job.  These medium tortillions are very good quality and though I do a lot of detailed work for which I use the small tortillions, these tortillions are great for the larger areas.  They're a good quality and you get a good amount of them for the price (a dozen).  They also last as long as you're careful with them.

These are perfect for me b/c I do a lot of work in great detail, and when I blemd, I want not to smudge the details.  These small tortillions do that for me.  When I give art lessons, I always let my young students try out a couple of them (there are so many in this one pack) and they love them.  Good quality, though once in a blue moon, there will be one that isn't as sharp as the others.  But on the whole, I love what they do, so I "love" them.

This was a bit tricky to put together, mainly because of the directions.  It is doing a good job in my closet where I like to keep my shirts of similar colors together, but there's not enough room in the closet.  Enter this hanging clothes rack, and I doubled my space.  Luckily the carpeted floor of my closet stays nice and clean, because the bottoms of the shirts do touch the floor.  The rack is adjustable, but it needed to be adjusted to its greates length due to the not unusual length of my shirts.  It seems as if it's going to last a good amount of time because it's made of metal.  I just am not crazy about the way you have to adjust the position of the rack on its poles.  Aside from that, it's a good product that holds a good many shirts.  BTW, don't use this if your original pole doesn't have a center support.  The extra weight will make the original clothes pole bow in the middle.  Luckily, I have a central support, so this works well.

This is truly a beautiful bracelet, but the problem comes in with the fact that it is very loose and I worry that it will fall off of me when I wear it.  I don't want to return it because it IS so pretty, exactly as pictured, so I am carefully bending the wire that holds the bracelet together in hopes of making it a tighter, more secure fit.  It may not have been expensive, but I'd hate to lost it just b/c the wire that holds it together is so loose.

I've been using this barna of GABA (gamma aminobutyric acid) for quite some time, and find that it helps with a neurological problem that I have, so I can't do without them since there's little medicine I can take for the disorder.  It's a superb quality product, and most of all, it's kosher which I require it to be or I can't use it.  Like all Solgar products, this is excellent and you can trust its high quality.  I shall continue to purchase my GABA from this seller as long as it is available there.

Before using this tape for the purpose for which I purchased it, I tried it on several "regular" materials such as paper, cardboard, metal, etc., and it stood up very well.  Then I applied it to an area of a microfiber shoulder bag to which I'd fastened self-sticking no slip straps that weren't sticking very well.  This double-sided tape sticks modestly well, the straps coming loose every so often, and my having to reapply this tape.  Frankly, I do NOT think it's the fault of the tape, b/c all the things on which I tested the tape are still holding fine.  I think it's b/c of the microfiber product that this tape isn't sticking so well.  I don't know if any fabric would be a candidate for this tape, but as I said, I don't think it's b/c of the tape which adheres very well to other more common rpoducts.  Use it for paper, wood, plaster, etc., but don't waste your money on using it for fabrics.  All-in-all, I think this was a good buy, and I shall be able to use it on many other applications, just not the one for which I purchased it.

I was having a difficult time finding orange earrings that fit my sense of style and were the color I wanted.  First, they are a strong spring-clamp earring which makes them safe to wear so that you don't have to worry about them being lost.  Secondly, they are just the color orange for which I was searching to match a necklace that I'd purchased.  They're beautiful without the pricey name brand expense, and they feel great when wearing them.  I thought I was taking a chance when I bought these b/c I usually do go for the more expensive name brand earrings, but these turned out to be one of the best sets of earrings I've purchased that aren't "name brand".  These would make a terrific gift for anyone special.

I was having a difficult time finding a navy blue scarf that was lightweight and unusual.  Enter this scarf.  It's a true navy color first of all, and the lace is just beautiful, very feminine and delicate looking.  It's gotten many compliments and is so lightweight that I can wear it on the hottest of days without even noticing that it's there.  This would make a beautiful gift for someone special.

The seller was very gracious in accepting the return of this necklace which was a great disappointment to me.  The "orange" blown glass beads were barely orange, and they looked nothing like the picture.  The other beads that formed the rest of the necklace didn't go with whatever color the main "orange" beads were supposed to be; they were gold and had no color in common with the other beads.  Kudos to the seller who took this back without a complaint.  If you're looking for a sort-of-gold, kind-of-mixed-in-orange, this will be nice.  But it doesn't look like its picture at all, not in color or in other ways.

I just started to use Vinylux products about 2 months ago, and I'm so incredibly impressed!  The nail polish really does last for one week solid, but one of the keys to its lasting is to use this top coat when you're finished with the application of the nail polish itself.  It lengthens the staying power of the Vinylux nail polish and it also, somehow, accents and improves the beauty of the polish itself.  I would also recommend purchasing Bondaid to apply before using the Vinylux nail polish for maximum staying power.  This is a top-notch product and I recommend it very highly.  In fact, I've already got several friends switching over to Vinylux and buying this product specifically.  Other top coats just don't do the same thing.  This is the best.

This is a beautiful selection of many different charcoal pencils.  It's different to draw in graphite and in charcoal - they feel differently while drawing and give different effects.  Sometimes I want to use one, and other times I want to use the other.  This set provides an excellent selection of high quality charcoal pencils that are a great starter set for anyone.  I recommend them highly b/c of their quality, the selection, and the different materials included in the kit.  I'm not crazy about the sharpener, but I've got an electric sharpener which does a great job.  This would be a great starter for yourself as well as a wonderful gift for an aspiring artist.

I just COULDN'T figure out how these worked!  I went to a specialty bra site, located the bra strap holders for which I'd looked all over Amazon, and bought them after trying several brands at Amazon.  Not worth returning these at all, so now I have a collection of useless bra strap holders that, like these, are not worth the money paid for them.  Avoid these.  Go to a specialty bra site and get the ones there.  They will cost more and the shipping will also, but they'll be worth it.  These just stink!

I do love this notebook as Wilson Jones D rings are the only binders I'll use.  Unfortunately, I'd ordered a 2" binder and got this instead.  Not to worry b/c I could use this for purposes other than the one for which I'd wanted the 2" binder.  As a D-ring binder, it holds many, many more papers than a plain O ring binder.  It also lets you open and close the rings with the simple, easy flip of the single metal tab that is designed for that job.  It's the best made notebook around, and that's why I wouldn't use any other brand.

I live in the Florida Keys, it's been an extremely hot and dry year and our ground is so dry water runs off without penetrating. We don't bother with watering a lawn, its a combination of grass and weeds whatever is rugged enough to come up on its own. This year it looks extra brown so it was a good time to give this product a run. I applied Everydrop to two small areas on Oct.30 and watered it in best I could. I divided one area with a piece of rebar and the other with white aluminum so I could tell the two areas apart in the pictures. The Everydrop was only applied to the LEFT side of both areas. After 9 days there was no change in appearance to either area so on Nov.8, I applied a second time to the left side of each area and photographed both areas. It rained 5 inches on Nov.16 and several times throughout this trial. On Nov.19 after 21 days total, I took another picture. I still don't see any real difference worth mentioning even though I applied it twice rather than the once a month recommened application. Several times during this trial I took a soil sample to see if one side was wetter deeper down then the other but couldn't see any difference. My conclusion, This product does not seem to do anything, I would not recommend it.Note: the before photos show the container of everdrop in the upper left, the second pictures have no bottle.

I have taken a probiotic of one brand or another for years and have found some do work better than others. This one has a few less straines and 25 million rather than my usual 30. I switched from my other brand to this a couple weeks ago and take it every morning. It is working just as well as my usual brand, regularity is not an issue whatsoever. If you struggle with constipation or even the reverse, try this but take it every day and drink plenty of water, you will be amazed how effortless and timely your morning ritual will be. Yes, I would recommend this brand.

I love this little dish. I have almost every piece to this set but never ordered these small casserole dishes, thinking they would be too small. Seems most of the collection is pretty big in size so I finally tried this small oval. I am so glad I got it! This is perfect for my baked artichoke dip or serving a veg. but I ended up keeping my Kerry Gold butter in it in the fridge. It is hard to find a butter dish for European butter but this worked great! Now I wish I had at least another for all the other things I used it for so I will be ordering another one, love it!

I have cooked every Asian cuisine except for Japanese and was really interested in learning about it. This is a great educational tour on the subject and I quickly realized this was a subject I knew next to nothing about past sushi and sashimi. This is a large book with great photography for every recipe which is so important with a recipe you are not familiar with. it is also carefully written walking you through each recipe step by step. I was surprised how simple yet complex Japanese cooking was. I think the most difficult thing for me was learning the ingredients and keeping things simple. As much as I am enjoying this book, I think it is important to note though, many of the ingredients are not attainable to everyone. For me that was quite frustrating but no fault of the author or book, just my remote geographic location which is nowhere near an asian market. In any case, even if I could not acquire an ingredient, I still became far more educated on what Japanese food is and even though I strongly improvised far beyond the listed ingredients the end result was still quite enjoyable and inspired me in new directions. This is a beautiful book on the subject that I would recommend. If you are lucky enough to go to Japan you should definitely explore this book before you go.

This is a fantastic flash drive, it is small and sturdy. It loads lightning fast and holds a lot. I like the design with a hole so you can put it on a key chain or lanyard. I like the solid body especially over the usb connection, it can't bend and does not require a cover like older types. Really nice flash drive, I would buy more of these and I would recommend them.
These are not for small busted woman, the cups are huge even on small sizes.

I have very dry skin so I have to use oil first than sunscreen daily. I was really looking forward to trying this sunscreen oil so I could moisturize and protect my skin in one step. Unfortunately it was not a product I could use, the smell of this is horrible. I am sensitive to strong fragrances and particularly don't like them on my face. This smells like raid bug spray to me. This is a dry type of oil which did not make my skin feel moisturized. I ended up washing it off and going back to my coconut oil and Oil of Olay sensitive skin sunscreen. I did not care for this product at all.

Boy is this delicious especially the triple berry which has strawberry,blackberry and blueberry, the blackberry being the standout! I found this on sale locally, just 2.50 from the regular price of 3.50 worth every penny. The ingredients are simple, fruit, honey, pectin and citric acid thats it, just like the spreads I make myself. The berry is hands down the best of the four, but I also love the tropical with mango, peach and passion fruit yum! It is thinner than preserves much like home made. We love this on oatmeal, yogurt, brie cheese, goat cheese or cottage cheese. Great on crepes and cheesecake too or just on a big spoon, you won't be able to resist trust me! I will be buying this again soon. Great job Smucker's, I'll be sharing this for gifts over the holidays along with my fresh baked bread!

This is a great eye wash that does not sting or burn even a little bit. Great for washing out eyes when you get an eyelash or anything in your eye and it's already irritated this won't further irritate it. I used it when I had pink eye and found it soothed and relieved the itching. I keep this on hand all the time, the eye cup is included.

I always have this on hand and I prefer the "original" because it does not have lidocaine or any pain killing stuff that can burn your eyes. I have used this around my eyes as well as some of my pets and it does not burn at all. It heals cuts fast. Great for the emergency kit in your home, boat or vehicle.
